PARA.EMPHASIS: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) REGULATIONS

SPEECH.PARA: STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO. 266
18 October 1991
Senator the Hon Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No.266, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 17 October 1991.
The Committee raises several points about the Regulations.

(a)Regulation 13 provides that an eligible voter may request a secret ballot. However, there appears to be no provision which requires such voters to be notified of this right. It may be reasonable to include information about this right in the notice fixing the election date and calling for nominations under r.7 or perhaps in the notice relating to the declaration of nominations under r.11.

(b)There may be a conflict between r.19(1) and r.24(c). Regulation 19(1) requires a voter to mark the ballot-paper to indicate his or her preference by placing the number "1" in the box opposite the voter's choice. Thus, r.19(1) does not provide an option; the voter must use a number "1" for the vote to be valid. It is not possible for the voter validly to put a tick, a cross, an "aye", a "yes", or any other indication of choice. However, r.24(c) provides that "a ballot-paper is informal if (among other things) it is so imperfectly marked that the intention of the person who marked the ballot-paper is not clear". Under this provision an intention could be made quite clear by using a tick, for instance, but it would be invalid under the strict provisions of r.19(1) which require a number "1".

(c)Regulation 27(2)(b) provides that in conducting a recount of votes the returning officer, in the case of a poll not by secret ballot, may make any reasonable decision in respect of the allowance or disallowance of a vote cast in the poll. Regulation 28(1) provides that in certain circumstances the returning officer may declare an election to be void. Some criteria are provided for the exercise of these discretions. Thus, in both cases the decision must be reasonable or on reasonable grounds. Also, r.28(2) limits and guides the discretion in r.28(1). However, r.28(2)(c) itself includes a subjective discretion, requiring the returning officer to decide if it is "just" that an election be declared void. The Committee asks whether there are appropriate external review procedures of the merits of these decisions.
(d)There is a typographical error in r.9(2)(c).

(e)Regulation 29(2) provides only that after the poll the returning officer must notify the candidate who has been elected. There is no provision for notifying the unsuccessful candidates, and apparently not even a requirement that the result should be publicly notified and displayed in the way that the holding of the election and the notification of the nominated candidates are required under rr.7 and 11. If this is the case, it would seem to be an important omission.
(f)Regulation 29(2) refers to paragraph 25(1)(a). There is no such paragraph, but there is a paragraph 25(a). However, the reference should be to r.25 in toto.
(g)Regulation 32(3) appears to lack the word "and" after the word"certificate" in the third line. There is also a typographical error in that line.

(h)Regulation 34 provides that certain notices issued by an investigator must be in the "approved form". These notices cover some very important matters such as taking possession of plant, issuing prohibition notices and issuing improvement notices. These forms, covering matters which could be at least as serious as search warrants, are not set out in the Regulations, but are provided by r.2 to be in a form provided by the Commission. In contrast, under r.30, the possibly less important provisional improvement notice "must be set out in accordance with the Form in Schedule 1". This Form is very full and, in addition to specifying the relevant facts and action required, gives the relevant statutory provisions and their effect. The Committee considers that even search warrants issued by Judges should be in a prescribed form. It would seem suitable to provide for such forms in the Regulations themselves.
It may be appropriate for the Regulations to be amended to meet these concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
11 December 1991
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to my letter of 11 November 1991 concerning the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Regulations, Statutory Rules No.266 of 1991. I am now in a position to respond more fully to the Committee's concerns which were set out in your letter of 18 October 1991.

At the outset I should inform the Committee of the circumstances in which the election provisions of the Regulations will be utilised as it appears to be these provisions which have caused the most concern to the Committee. Under section 25 of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 (the Act) secret ballots for the election of health and safety representatives will only occur where there is no union presence in a workplace. Such a circumstance in workplaces covered by the Act would be rare. The election provisions in the Regulations are, therefore, expected to be used only in respect to isolated workplaces with few employees.

The Committee has commented that, although an eligible voter may request a secret ballot under r.13, there is no requirement in the Regulations for voters to be notified of this entitlement. In this respect I draw the Committee's attention to the requirement in r.7(1)(b) that the notice calling for nominations must include notification of the last date upon which a request for a secret ballot may be made. It was considered that this was sufficient to draw to the attention of voters the entitlement to a secret ballot. If the Committee does not regard this provision as sufficient notice I am prepared to amend r.7 to ensure that the entitlement to request a secret ballot is highlighted.

The Committee also raised the question whether a conflict exists between the provisions of r.19(1) and r.24(c). I do not consider that there is such a conflict. A voter is required to mark the ballot paper with the number 1. Even though the ballot paper may be marked with the number 1 the voter's intention may not be clear, for example if every box on the ballot paper were to be marked with the number 1. It is not intended that the provision contained in 24(c) allow some other method of indicating a preference than that provided in r.19. The provision in r.24 provides only that a vote will be considered informal if the voter's intention is not clear. The ballot paper must be marked with the number 1 in order for a valid vote to be cast. Regulation 24(c) does not, and was not intended to, allow for an additional means of indicating the voter's preference to that provided in r.19.

In answer to the Committee's question concerning the availability of appropriate review mechanisms for decisions of returning officers I can advise that no such mechanism is currently provided. I understand the Committee's concerns in relation to this matter and undertake to have the Regulations amended to provide for a review of a decision of a returning officer by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Given that the relevant provisions will be rarely used and that a review will be unlikely I do not believe that such a provision will unduly burden the AAT.

In relation to the Committee's concern that r.29(2) does not provide for notification of the results of an election for a health and safety representative I draw the Committee's attention to subsection 25(9) of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 which provides for the timely display of a notice in the workplace for the purpose of informing employees of the selection (including by election) of a health and safety representative.

I have noted the Committee's concerns about notices under Regulation 34 being required to be in an `approved form' rather than prescribed in the Regulations. While I do not share the view that the relevant notices are in the same category as search warrants, I accept that the notices are of a serious nature. I will, therefore, amend the Regulations to ensure that the forms are prescribed.
Amendments will also be made to correct the minor drafting errors detected in r.9(2)(c), r.29(2) and r.32(3).
I thank the Committee for drawing these matters to my attention and trust that I have been able to allay the Committee's concerns.
Yours fraternally
Peter Cook
Minister for Industrial Relations

PARA.EMPHASIS: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK ORDER NO.L10/91

SPEECH.PARA: MADE UNDER THE AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION ACT 1977
7 November 1991
The Hon Alan Griffiths MP
Minister for Resources
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Order No.L10/91, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 7 November 1991.

The Order substituted a new Form L which gives information relating to the consignment of live-stock by ship or aircraft. Clause 4.3(b) provides that the original copy of Form L must be posted to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation no later than the first working day after the departure of the particular consignment to which it refers. However, Clause 4.5(c) provides that, if the number of stock changes or the destination of part or all of the consignment changes, the licensee must send an amended Form L to the Corporation by facsimile transmission no later than the first working day after the consignment arrives at the final port of discharge.

The Committee asks why the amendment is required to be sent by facsimile when the original only need be posted. In this context the Explanatory Statement advises that the purpose of Form L is to provide the Corporation with "statistical information which is used for the purpose of market analysis and determining the levies payable by reporters".

The Committee is concerned that the instrument may force each licensee to obtain a facsimile machine to send amendments of a Form, the original of which may be sent by post, with the whole Form being used only for statistical purposes.
The Committee believes that it may be appropriate for the instrument to be amended to provide that changes to Form L may be posted.

It may be that there are particular reasons for the urgency attached to amendments of the Form and we would welcome your advice on this. However, if this is the case the Committee would like to be assured that the instrument is not likely to impose additional costs on primary producers.
Your advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
5 December 1991
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles

I refer to your letter of 7 November 1991 to the Minister for Resources, the Hon Alan Griffiths MP, concerning Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) Order No.L10/91. Matters relating to the administration of the AMLC fall within my responsibilities.

You questioned the need, under Clause 4.5(c), for an amended Form L to be forwarded to the AMLC by facsimile rather than post if the number of stock changes or the destination of part or all of the consignment changes.

As stated in the Explanatory Statement, Form L provides the Corporation with statistical information which is used for the purpose of market analysis. This information forms the basis of market intelligence which is provided to licensed exporters by the Corporation and, given the nature of the trade, needs to be provided quickly if the industry is to take full advantage of the opportunities that open up to it. Past experience has shown that amendments sent by mail will not necessarily reach the Corporation in time for it to perform this function in a completely effective manner.

A further function of Form L is to provide the Corporation with a means of monitoring compliance by exporters with other Orders and Directions issued by the Corporation, in particular to ensure that shipments are not diverted to markets that have restrictions placed on them. For example, earlier this year a shipment of live sheep was diverted to Saudi Arabia in contravention to an Order that had been issued by the Corporation. You will appreciate that such a situation may have significant animal welfare implications should the shipment be rejected and as such it is important that the Corporation be immediately aware of any proposed amendments to the original intentions.

The Corporation is also conscious of the possibility of imposing additional costs on exporters. Before putting the Order into effect the Corporation circulated it to licensed exporters and surveyed the ownership of facsimile machines amongst licensees. The survey found that of 108 licensed exporters, 105 owned a facsimile machine. The remaining three licensees are not active exporters. I should also point out that the requirement to forward amendments to the Corporation by facsimile does not necessarily mean that the licensee must own a machine, given that facsimile facilities are available at Post Offices.
I hope this has satisfied your concerns, and I thank the Committee for its interest in this matter.
Yours sincerely
Simon Crean
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy

PARA.EMPHASIS: TRADE PRACTICES (CONSUMER PRODUCT INFORMATION STANDARDS) (COSMETICS) REGULATIONS

SPEECH.PARA: STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.327
29 November 1991
Senator the Hon Michael Tate
Minister for Justice and
Consumer Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Trade Practices (Consumer Product Information Standards) (Cosmetics) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No.327.

For information, I attach a copy of a representation in respect of the Regulations which the Committee has received from the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia. The Committee considered the representation at its meeting of 28 November 1991. I will write to you again in respect of the Regulations when the Committee has had the opportunity to consider them in more detail. In the meantime, perhaps you could consider the points raised by the representation.

However, at this point such a move will be purely procedural, being intended only to keep the matter before the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
Patricia Giles
Chair
5 December 1991
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 29 November 1991 regarding the Trade Practices (Consumer Product Information Standards) (Cosmetics) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No.327.

Attached to your letter was a copy of a representation from the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia (CTFAA) requesting that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances consider requiring the inclusion in the Regulations of a mandatory nomenclature based on the United States Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association (CTFA) Dictionary.

The issue of specifying the nomenclature of ingredients of cosmetics was considered at length and discussed with a wide range of consumers and suppliers during the development of the Regulations. A nominated dictionary of chemical names, or other nomenclature, has the advantage of being very specific but this may restrict the provision of meaningful information to consumers, which is contrary to the primary purpose of the Regulations.

I have carefully reviewed the CTFAA's representations and remain of the opinion that the CTFA Dictionary should not be included as the mandatory nominated nomenclature in the Regulations, at this stage, for the following major reasons.

-The Regulations do not specify any nomenclature. However, guidelines will be issued which will encourage suppliers to choose the nomenclature which gives consumers the clearest and most meaningful information about ingredients. The first preference for nomenclature, therefore, is that an ingredient should be identified by the name generally recognised by consumers. Ingredients such as fruits, vegetables, herbs and animal or marine products should be identified by their common name.

-The second preference is for the ingredients to be identified by a chemical or other technical name or description using a recognised reference (such as the CTFA Dictionary or the Draft Australian Approved Names for Pharmaceutical Substances) where a common name is not appropriate.

-Use of the CTFA Dictionary is wide-spread in North America and Japan but is not universal. The European Community, in particular, has not finalised its nomenclature. It would be premature for Parliament to make the nomenclature of the CTFA Dictionary mandatory in Australia. Moreover, the Regulations do not prevent members of the CTFAA from using the CTFA Dictionary on a voluntary basis.
-There is some opposition within Australia to the adoption of the CTFA Dictionary because of a preference for the use of the Draft Australian Approved Names for Pharmaceutical Substances; and
-The CTFA Dictionary costs over $600 per copy with possible subsequent costs for amendments. I am mindful of the need to avoid imposing additional costs upon industry and consumers.

I am aware, however, that there is a genuine concern both by some industry members and some consumers that a mandatory nomenclature would be desirable. I have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to monitor the Regulations and if it appears that problems with nomenclature are being experienced within the first 12 months of the Regulations becoming effective, then the matter will be reviewed.
To assist the Committee's deliberations, I have included in the Attachment some additional background information about the nomenclature of ingredients in cosmetic products.
Please let me know if I can be of further assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
Michael Tate
Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs
BACKGROUND INFORMATION ON THE TRADE PRACTICES (CONSUMER PRODUCT INFORMATION STANDARDS) (COSMETICS) REGULATIONS,
STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.327

The proposed regulations were first issued in draft form for public comment in December 1990. The draft regulations contained the following suggested hierarchical structure, in descending order, for the naming of ingredients used in cosmetic products:
-the United States Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association (CTFA) Dictionary;
-US Pharmacopoeia and supplements OR the European Pharmacopoeia and supplements;
-the accepted chemical name in the Chemicals Abstraction Service nomenclature OR in the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry nomenclature;
-if the ingredient is a colour but is not listed in the CTFA Dictionary, the publication Society of Dyers and Colourist Index;
-Draft Australian Approved Names for Pharmaceutical Substances;
-US Approved Names and the US Pharmacopoeia Dictionary of Approved Names with cumulative lists;
-the chemical or other approved technical name or description.

The nomenclature was specified because of earlier representations from the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia (CTFAA) who claimed that the majority of cosmetic companies in Australia were at that time already using the CTFA Dictionary as the main source for nomenclature.
Responses to the public consultation process indicated that the suggested nomenclature posed a number of difficulties.

Although the above order of preference followed the CTFAA's suggestion, some officials of the Australian Society of Cosmetic Chemists preferred the Draft Australian Approved Names for Pharmaceutical Substances as the first choice. There are some differences between the names in the CTFA Dictionary and the names for the same compounds in the Draft Australian Approved Names.

The nomenclature in the European Community is different again to both the CTFA Dictionary and the Draft Australian Approved Names. European exports to the United States must comply, however, with the US requirements and follow the CTFA Dictionary. It is understood that the European Community is currently developing a uniform nomenclature for cosmetic ingredients.
In a letter of 6 November 1991 to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, the CTFAA notes that:
"There are several different nomenclatures operating around the world.
"The CTFA Dictionary nomenclature has been adopted in the USA, Canada and Japan and is now being modified to include European chemical names and thus will be eventually used throughout the EC.
"Since most of the countries which export cosmetics to Australia already use this nomenclature. . . . . .

It will be noted that the CTFAA admits that there are several different nomenclatures; that the CTFA Dictionary has only been adopted by the USA, Canada and Japan; and that only a majority of Australian cosmetic imports are labelled according to the CTFA Dictionary. The CTFAA's confidence that the European Community will adopt the CTFA Dictionary could prove misplaced.

An additional difficulty centres around the proliferation of small Australian suppliers who are not members of the CTFAA and who may use ingredients not listed in the CTFA Dictionary. It has not been ascertained whether all ingredients used in Australia are listed in the CTFA Dictionary, eg eucalypt oils, ti tree oils, and goanna oils.

In the 20-month period from January 1988 to November 1989 the value of cosmetics imported into Australia was $189m. Imports from European Community countries totalled close on 50% of all imports whilst the US accounted for only about 20% of all imports. This also may have implications for nomenclature.

It should be noted that the CTFAA has some interest in promoting the CTFA Dictionary. US members of the CTFA are already using that Dictionary and it would be more convenient for those companies if the US nomenclature was made mandatory in Australia. If the Dictionary was mandatory all suppliers would be forced to adopt it.

Sales of the Dictionary, which costs over $600 plus amendments, are a source of income to the CTFA and possibly the CTFAA. It is not known whether sales of the Dictionary or the application of the Dictionary are limited in any way to members of the CTFA or CTFAA. Such a restriction, if it exists, may have restrictive trade practices implications.
To compound the above difficulties of nomenclature, a number of consumers have said that they want meaningful information and not a long list of complex chemical names.

For these reasons a nomenclature requirement was not included in the Regulations. Guidelines are to be issued with the Regulations stating, inter alia, that the primary purpose is to provide meaningful and clear information to consumers.
The Guidelines as currently proposed state:
"Suppliers are encouraged to choose nomenclature for the ingredient labelling of cosmetics which will provide consumers with the clearest and most meaningful information.

"Thus an ingredient would most usefully be identified by the name generally recognised by consumers. Ingredients such as fruits, vegetables, herbs and animal or marine products may be identified by their common name.

"Where a common name is not suitable, it would be preferable for the ingredient to be identified by a chemical or other technical name or description. The preferred sources in naming ingredients are the United States Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association Dictionary and the Draft Australian Approved Names for Pharmaceutical Substances.

"If the above two preferred sources do not contain the nomenclature of an ingredient, reference may be made to the US or European Pharmacopoeias, Chemical Abstraction Service nomenclature, or the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry nomenclature, the Society of Dyers and Colourists Index, the US Approved Names and the US Pharmacopoeia Dictionary of Approved Names.
"If an ingredient is not listed in the above sources, the ingredient may be identified by a chemical or other technical name or description.
5 December 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This Bill has been drawn up to allow for acts of conscience by public sector employees when they uncover acts of gross fraud and corruption in Government. It seeks to establish a Whistleblowers Protection Agency, headed by a Commissioner, which will have powers to investigate claims of corruption within government or government agencies by Commonwealth employees or by any member of the public. Protection is also extended to consultants engaged by the Government or its agencies.

The Agency established by this Bill will have two major functions: to investigate allegations of wrongdoing within government and its agencies, and to protect those employees or members of the public who make such allegations.

The Agency will have the power to receive and investigate allegations from any member of the public (not just Commonwealth employees) about serious wrongdoing involving federal government employees up to, and including, the Prime Minister. Allegations to be investigated would include violations of law, gross mismanagement, gross waste of public funds, abuse of authority, substantial and specific danger to public liability or safety, or a failure to act lawfully.

The Bill seeks to protect former, current or prospective Federal Government employees who believe they are being harassed or discriminated against because they blew the whistle (or are believed to have blown the whistle). Remedies include re-instatement, ex-gratia payments, and, where appropriate, damages. The remedies will need to be enforced by the Federal Court, and the Agency will have the power to apply to the court for orders or injunctions.

The Whistleblowers Protection Agency will also have the power to recommend disciplinary action or, for severe cases, criminal action against government employees responsible for the harassment or discrimination against whistleblowers. The Bill also seeks to protect whistleblowers from any legal action as a result of the allegations they make to the Agency. This protection would be extended whether or not the allegations were disproved, but not if they were deliberately false or misleading. A person making false and misleading claims would be criminally liable.

A complaint to the Agency will only be made public if it is found to be true. The Agency will also publish details of all complaints in its annual report which will be tabled in Parliament. However, only the full details of substantiated and true claims will be revealed.

The Royal Commission Act 1902, the Ombudsman Act 1976 and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Act 1986 all contain some provision for individuals to make complaints about government breaches of ethical standards. However, none of these pieces of legislation were specifically intended to offer protection to whistleblowers.

This Bill has provisions to guard against claims which are made for personal gain, or which are frivolous or deliberately malicious. These provisions will include criminal liability for any person making a false claim to the Agency. In a recent article in The Australian Law Journal, Mr J.G. Starke pointed out: "the whistleblower must have reasonable grounds for believing that a crime or civil wrong has taken place or will take place; and there must be evidence of good faith on the part of the whistleblower.
This Bill will complement the existing defences for whistleblowers under common law and will provide some protection for them legally.

Our Government and public sector processes have been governed by official secrecy for over a century. Breaches of this secrecy have at times attracted criminal liability and, historically, no defence of public interest has been entertained. In Commonwealth legislation alone there are as many as 150 secrecy provisions which penalise the unauthorised disclosure of information. Possibly the most ubiquitous of these is section 70 of the Crimes Act 1914, which imposes a two year prison sentence for any unauthorised disclosure of information by a current or former Commonwealth employee.

To some degree, the advent of Freedom of Information legislation and certain privacy laws have challenged the notion of official secrecy. But unfortunately, official secrecy is a shield still used by our present political institutions. The very first public service regulations passed in this country in colonial Victoria in 1867 set the pattern for what was to come in all jurisdictions—an official could only disclose information if the disclosure was part of official duty or made with the consent of a Minister. As a result, all jurisdictions with the exception of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia made it a criminal offence for officials to disclose information they were bound to keep secret. Our legal system needs to be altered to protect acts of conscience that are expressed in the exposure of illegal or improper practices.

There have been moves to introduce some form of whistleblowers protection through state based anti-corruption authorities in New South Wales, Queensland, the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia. Legislation is urgently needed at the Federal level because the community demands that government and bureaucracy should not be above the law.

The scandals relating to State Government corruption in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia may have never occurred had individuals been empowered to blow the whistle on corrupt practices. In all cases, some Government employees knew what was going on, but kept quiet. Had they felt protected by law, some of them may have been encouraged to tell the truth, saving taxpayers millions of dollars and preventing political and private sector practices from becoming so debased that the public, to a large degree, lost confidence in the political process.

In Queensland, the Criminal Justice Commission and the Electoral and Administrative Review Commission have just finalised a report recommending state legislation allowing for whistleblowers. The former Corruption Commissioner, Tony Fitzgerald Q.C., drew attention to what he called an "urgent need" for whistleblowers legislation. In his Report released on 3rd July 1989, on public administration and criminal justice in Queensland, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: "It is enormously frustrating and demoralising for conscientious and honest public servants who work in a department or instrumentality in which maladministration or misconduct is present or even tolerated or encouraged. It is extremely difficult for such officers to report their knowledge to those in authority. Even if they do report their knowledge to a senior officer that officer might be in a difficult position.

PARA.TAB: There may be no-one that can be trusted with the information. If either senior officers and/or politicians are involved in misconduct of corruption, the task of exposure becomes impossible for all but the exceptionally courageous or reckless, particularly after indications that such disclosures are not only unwelcome but attract retribution. Strong honest leadership is one step which is essential to a build-up of confidence.

There is an urgent need, however, for legislation which prohibits any person from penalising any other person for making accurate public statements about misconduct, inefficiency or other problems within public instrumentalities.

Fitzgerald went on to argue, "It is necessary to establish a convenient means by which public officers can disclose matters of concern. What is required is an accessible, independent body to which disclosures can be made, confidentially—at least in the first instance—and in any event free from fear of reprisals."

Protection for whistleblowers should be an important element of modern government because this encourages employees to be a part of maintaining honest, effective and accountable government. Employees who blow the whistle on either a private corporation or government, although this legislation deals only with government, are often persecuted and eventually sacked, yet they have usually blown the whistle as an act of conscience with the greater good of society in mind. They are in fact, ethical resisters. By protecting whistleblowers, we enable individuals to make an ethical choice between their responsibility to society generally and their obligations to their employers. To refuse such protection may be to require a person's complicity in activities which they abhor.

SPEECH.PARA: Protection of the Bill is primarily for people who use the Agency mechanism. However, in certain circumstances, a person will be entitled to the Bill's protection, even if they act outside the Bill by going directly to the media or a politician, provided the information they supply is found to be substantially true.

PARA.TAB: A good case study which reveals the essential conflict between official secrecy provisions and the public interest was revealed in the Ponting case, recently resolved in the United Kingdom. Clive Ponting was prosecuted under section 2 of the Official Secrets Act for providing information to a member of parliament. This information cast doubt on the accuracy of statements made to parliament by a Minister about the sinking of the Argentinean ship, the Belgrano. Mr Ponting's defence relied in part on the terms of section 2, which provided that it was not an offence where a person communicates information to "a person to whom it is in the interests of the State his duty to communicate it.

The trial judge directed the jury in accordance with the arguments of the prosecution, namely that the interests of the state referred to Government policies. If this direction had been accepted by the jury, conviction was inevitable, since the policy of the Government was clearly against unauthorised disclosure by civil servants to parliamentarians. Ponting's acquittal by the jury perhaps indicates that on the yardstick of "judgment by peers" the public perceived the interests of the State differently, and most importantly were willing to tolerate individual acts of conscience and courage.

There are double standards operating at present which condone whistleblowing in some circumstances yet, in other circumstances, see whistleblowers vilified and persecuted. For example, reporting a neighbour for defrauding the Social Security Department is regarded as laudable. If I inform the police of some criminal activity that I witnessed, I may even be paid money from public funds in return for demonstrating loyalty to the state. However, other whistleblowers may be variously ridiculed, referred for psychiatric assessment, sacked and possibly prosecuted because of their actions.

One of the reasons for this treatment of whistleblowers is that in the corporate state, governments tend to demand of employees that their first loyalty is to the government itself. Dissent is permitted within the organisation but not against the organisation.

It is a condition which the United States' leading proponent of whistleblowing, Ralph Nader, has called the "new serfdom". Ralph Nader is referring to repression which operates within corporations but the principle applies equally to the agencies of government:

SPEECH.PARA: "The large corporation is lord and manor, and most of its employees have been desensitised such as were medieval peasants who never knew they were serfs. It is true that often the immediate physical deprivations are far fewer, but the price of this fragile shield has been the dulling of the senses and the perceptions of new perils and pressures of a far more embracing consequence."

PARA.TAB: At present, the courts can do little to provide effective protection from harassment and intimidation to an employee who blows the whistle. What eventually breaks whistleblowers down, and deters others from supporting them, is the aversion and subtle abuse which they suffer on a daily basis at work.

That is why I am presenting this Bill today —in an effort to protect future whistleblowers from harassment and intimidation. This legislation will offer extensive protection to the whistleblower, including protection for their physical safety and recompense for any harassment. Our system of liberal democracy should at least offer protection to an ethical resister who blows the whistle in the public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —When my remarks were interrupted by the adjournment last night, I had just concluded referring to the enormous losses which have been suffered in the last few years by the major banks and also by some of the smaller banks. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard several statements from the managing directors of major banks and other information relating to those losses.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: From the Managing Director of Westpac, came:

"Bad debts increased as medium-sized commercial customers and small businesses failed. The level of bankruptcies is now running at uncomfortably high levels. For the year, the group has recorded a net charge for bad debt and doubtful debts of $1.2 billion compared with $578.7 million in 1988-90.
The Annual Report of the Commonwealth Bank last year contains a report from its Chairman, who says of the year's performance:

"While the group's profit performance and targeted capital generation fell short of plan for the year due principally to the impact of increased bad debts—the Bank's performance continues to meet industry standards".

And this year, due once again to a massive rise in the charge against profit for bad and doubtful debt, (a staggering $1.026 billion), group operating profit after tax fell to $272.1 million—a 45.3 per cent fall in profit. In fact, non-performing loans stood at $2.2 billion at June this year, compared with only $504 million 12 months ago.
The chairman's report states:

"Weak domestic economic activity and depressed world market prices for some key Australian exports are expected to limit opportunities during the coming year and intensify competition amongst the banks for quality lending. . .weaknesses in the economy are still affecting borrowers and are expected to continue for some time".

And it wasn't only the larger banks which experienced bad debt problems. The State-owned Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, the largest financial institution in WA, with an asset base of $8.5 million, also reported a net loss of $97 million in the year to March 1990, the first loss in its 45-year history. The charge to general and specific debt provisions was $179 million.

Similarly, the State Bank of NSW reported a 62 per cent drop in pre-tax profit in the 15 months to September last year, to $34.8 million, after charging $207 million to cover provisions for bad and doubtful debts.
The Tasmania Bank last year announced it had lost $6.8 million, after making total bad and doubtful debt provisions of $12.72 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. At the conclusion of my remarks last evening I had also referred to the fact that, apart from the disastrous economic circumstances created by this Government's policies which have contributed to those losses, there was also the problem of inadequate and incorrect risk control being applied by a number of those banks. That has created some of those problems. Those two main factors, rather than deregulation per se, were the source of the problems for the banks and their customers.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, loan policies which lacked risk control and accountability were the norm during the 1980s. Often, massive sums of money were loaned to companies and individuals purely and simply on a piece of paper. There was no inspection of assets or on-site discussion as to any assets the borrower might have had. No comprehensive report existed on how they were ever going to repay the money. Hence, it is evident that there are inherent problems when trading banks and savings banks operate as separate entities. The Victorian Auditor-General's recent report on the State Bank of Victoria highlighted that taxpayers are nearly $1,700m down the drain over the sale of the State Bank of Victoria and the collapse of Tricontinental.

If the Hawke Government is under the mistaken assumption that economic recovery, like Santa Claus, is on the way, it is a cruel and heartless government which is deceiving the Australian people and one which will be ousted at the forthcoming election and dumped on the political scrap heap. Indeed, it seems that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) may be dumped well before the next election.

The Liberal and National parties support this Bill. But, as usual, it is a spoonful of medicine for the banks which has been administered far too late to assist those individuals and companies that have already suffered at the hands of both the banking industry and the indifferent Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bank Integration Bill 1991 is probably the second last piece of financial deregulation legislation to be introduced during the period of the Hawke Government. (Quorum formed). The Bill proposes to facilitate the restructuring of bank groups by granting legal succession to any succeeding entities, and to ensure that any reorganisations are tax neutral for both income and capital gains tax and are exempt from any State tax or duties such as stamp duty.

PARA.TAB: The legislation arises from the 1988 Budget decision to eliminate the distinction between savings and trading banks. The legislation to facilitate this decision was included in the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which was opposed by the Australian Democrats. Of course, the Opposition voted with the Government to pass the Bill.

This Bill before us today merely eliminates the practical problems associated with group restructurings. The Democrats will support this Bill but with the qualification of our second reading amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate condemns the Government for deregulating the banking system because the lack of Reserve Bank control on the money supply has led to the imposition of punitive interest rates which have caused the worst recession in 60 years and the Senate notes that any reductions in interest rates have benefited corporate customers and not retail customers.

Australia's current problems can be traced directly to the policies of deregulation imposed upon Australia by ideologically driven bureaucrats and a like-minded Government and Opposition. As Mr Keating complained when he was looking for a scapegoat for his recession, the banks are running a monetary policy which is inconsistent with the Government's policy. What did he expect when he gave them the power to do so and, indeed, encouraged them to act as they wished?

PARA.TAB: There is also general agreement that the finance binge of the 1980s contributed more to inflation that decade—that is, through asset price inflation—than did the increase in wages. That is a scandal for any government and a disgrace for a Labor government. A fascination and almost religious adherence to the belief that only the private sector can do anything efficiently and that competition is the universal cure to any economic problem have dominated this debate. As I said previously, this philosophy still remains. This is why I stated that this is probably the second last piece of bank deregulation legislation of this Government.The final piece will repeal the requirement that foreign banks operate in Australia as Australian subsidiaries and not as branches.

The recent Martin Committee report, which I will address later, has proposed that the foreign branches be allowed to operate here. The Reserve Bank has already signalled that such an approach will lead to insurmountable supervisory difficulties. In any event, why does everyone seem to accept that the overseas banks are so strong and wonderful and secure? For years we have watched a crisis develop in the American banking system which the Congress has not been able to address. There have also been numerous other bail-outs, such as some recent examples in Norway and Sweden and the disgrace of the BCCI scandal. I think it is right to ask the question: why do we assume that these foreign banks are so impregnable?

The Bill is before the Senate today because of the policy to deregulate the financial system in Australia. That decision, taken exactly eight years ago, must rank as one of the greatest blunders in our history. The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, decided to abandon public control over the money supply and credit growth—the value of the currency —and to eliminate nearly all exchange controls. These decisions reinforce the June 1982 announcement that the Reserve Bank would cease to be involved in the guidance of quantitative bank lending. The impetus for this decision was the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. This Committee was established by the Fraser Government and reported in September 1981. Mr Howard was the Treasurer then and was constrained from implementing the recommendations of this Committee report by the wisdom of the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the hostile disposition of the then Labor Opposition. On coming to government, the Australian Labor Party appointed its own committee, the Martin review group, to review the recommendations of the Campbell Committee. The review group generally endorsed the Campbell Committee's findings.

Then the greatest binge in history occurred. Australia and the rest of the Anglo-Saxon nations went crazy. It was suddenly much more important to shuffle paper than to conduct research, produce inventions or to be involved in productive investments. Greed was good and the very greedy were therefore very good and were idolised by an ignorant and self-indulgent media who led everyone to believe that this time the bubble would not burst.

As we know, the bubble did burst. One day in 1987 all the computers trading on the New York Stock Exchange decided it was time to sell. The Dow Jones Index fell by over 500 points in one day, thus eclipsing the record set on Black Tuesday in 1929 at the beginning of the Great Depression. The resultant loosening of monetary policy was too large and the economy went into an unsustainable boom which was crushed by the criminally high interest rate regime which Mr Keating imposed. The result is almost one million unemployed and the planned destruction of the farm and manufacturing sectors.

During the 1980s the United States went from being the largest creditor nation in the world to the largest debtor nation in the world. In just a few years, the financial dominance of the United States was reversed, bringing it to being the main destination of international savings. Similarly, Australia's foreign gross debt has exploded to be over $168 billion, and the financing of that debt represents a cost to the community of about $12 billion per year. This is the legacy that the Australian community has inherited from financial deregulation.

The Reserve Bank has estimated that the level of non-performing loans is about $29 billion. That means that the supposedly efficient, deregulated banking sector has made about $30 billion worth of mistakes. If we look for a suitable cliche, what cliche do members of the financial community use to justify this scandal? They say they have been on a deregulation learning curve and now, having moved from that, they are entering the mature phase of deregulation. They say, `Everything will be all right; just trust us as usual'.

It is in this context that the Government asked the Martin Committee in the House of Representatives to inquire into the effects of bank deregulation. The Martin Committee has simply endorsed what the Government has done, and indeed it has proposed to further deregulate the provisions applying to foreign banks in Australia. The Committee has accepted that total financial deregulation is the way to go, without considering the relative benefits and costs. That is despite the fact that, at page 2 of the Martin Committee conclusions and recommendations, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Deregulation has not led to a significant reduction in the average domestic interest rate margin. Any reduction has tended to benefit corporate customers rather than retail customers.
At a different time such a conclusion would have moved the members of the Labor Party to seek to address the situation by legislating to attempt to redress this imbalance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you quote the rest of it?
—I am getting on to that. I wonder what John Curtin or Ben Chifley would think of the recommendations in this report. I think they would be appalled.

PARA.TAB: Before examining a few more details of the Martin Committee report, it is important to remember that the commercial banks are merely a part of the financial system. The Government agreed to continue the policy of non-intervention by the Commonwealth into the area of non-bank financial institutions, and this unquestionably led to the collapse of the Pyramid Group in Victoria. We now have the hurried adoption of the second best option—the second best option being the creation of the Australian Financial Institutions Commission—to bring some teeth and a national perspective to the regulation of the non-bank financial institutions. I guess it is better than nothing.

The Government has the power and, I would argue, the responsibility to protect people's savings. Most members of the public do not understand the various risks which each different type of institution bears and—it is perfectly acceptable for us to realise this—they do not understand the financial jargon associated with the 1980s. But they do understand that they want to be able to save with security and that the Government should facilitate such a situation. They do not want to be ripped off by fees and charges. They also know that they have no chance in a legal dispute with a financial institution.

Deregulation did not apply only to banks. The 30/20 rule which applied to superannuation funds was abolished from July 1984. This provided that the tax free status of superannuation funds applied only where at least 30 per cent of the funds' assets were invested in government securities and two-thirds of those had to be invested in Commonwealth securities. The former Treasurer, Mr Kerin, affirmed only two months ago that no restrictions would be imposed upon the investment patterns of superannuation and, as such, the Treasury line continues intact.

So what did the Martin Committee recommend for the future of banking in Australia? It made extensive recommendations, some of which the Democrats agree with. However, the matters which are most relevant to consumers, that is, to the millions of depositors and small borrowers, are dealt with in a pathetic, almost apologetic, way. For example, recommendation 65 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . banks should pay a reasonable rate of interest on all deposit accounts. This should take into account the cost of maintaining accounts.
What about a recommendation to legislate to ensure that banks must pay a reasonable rate of interest on all deposit accounts? This trend continues with recommendation 67, which states:
. . . banks be strongly encouraged to convert all remaining deposit accounts which pay interest on the minimum monthly balance to daily interest.
Again, why should banks and other financial institutions not be forced to pay interest on a daily basis? Are we in such awe of the financial sector? Are we frightened of offending it?

PARA.TAB: The question of penalties for the early repayment of loans is also addressed by the Committee's report. Given our huge foreign debt, it is rather bizarre that a borrower should suffer a penalty for repaying a loan early, and it is to the Committee's credit that it has considered the matter. However, instead of recommending that the law provide that a bank be allowed to recover only the actual costs it incurs because of an early repayment of a debt obligation, the Committee has wimped out, so to speak, and has recommended as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . all banks adopt the practice of recovering actual costs for early repayment of loans rather than imposing a penalty.
Perhaps the most tragic or hilarious recommendation, depending on one's point of view, is No. 74, which states:
. . . banks should ensure that their assessment of risks and other related areas such as ability to repay are thoroughly investigated.

(Quorum formed) For the benefit of those people listening to this debate, I ought to put on the record that these quorums are being called in the middle of my speech because the Opposition is trying to force Labor Party members to come into this chamber, because the Opposition suspects they are meeting in huddles somewhere. Opposition members do not have any commitment to getting on with this legislation. It is the most vexatious way of using quorums.

PARA.TAB: I was saying that recommendation No. 74 of the Martin Committee report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . banks should ensure that their assessment of risk and other related areas such as ability to repay are thoroughly investigated. Credit scoring systems should be amended to incorporate criteria such as income or, where it already exists, to strengthen this requirement. Bank loans officers should be adequately trained in risk assessment techniques.

Call me old fashioned, but I assumed that banks generally did lend with reference to the ability of the borrower to repay the loan. In fact, I thought that such a principle had been operating ever since the Venetians invented banking. I can conclude only one of two things: either the Committee was attempting to brighten up a rather sombre report with some humour or the shareholders in Australian banks should consider getting some new managers. Either way, it is a rather terrifying indictment of deregulated banking.

PARA.TAB: As I said previously, the Committee did produce some good recommendations. For example, the proposal to clarify the confidentiality obligations of the banks is long overdue and a worthwhile exercise. A similar exercise should also be undertaken in respect of the non-bank financial institutions. The complementary proposal that all customers should have access to all personal information concerning them in the records of the bank is another recommendation that the Democrats support. But again this should be specifically guaranteed in legislation, not in some sort of self-regulatory arrangement.

The Committee's recommendation that banks cease the practice of obtaining an unlimited guarantee from a person other than the borrower is another long overdue step. The matter has been raised by the Banking Ombudsman and a number of consumer groups. There have been horrific examples in the media of migrants or poorly educated people not understanding the ramifications of becoming a guarantor and then suffering the consequences of losing their homes. There must be plain English wording for these kinds of arrangements and the liability of a guarantor should be carefully explained to a potential guarantor.

Recommendations Nos 98 and 99 of the report are a welcome change to the self-regulation or market forces approach of much of the rest of the report. I commend the Committee for tackling the question of a standardised calculation of the rate of interest on all loans and deposits. The Committee has recommended that this Parliament legislate to require that all banks and other State regulated institutions adopt a comparison rate of interest when describing loan or deposit rates.

This would mean that the consumer will, for the first time, be able properly to compare the true returns or costs of an investment or a loan. This, more than anything else, will assist in true competition in banking because the consumer who makes the choices will be better informed. Even the most ardent economic rationalist must agree with this proposal, as it will really promote competition in the banking sector and across the whole financial sector if the State regulated institutions are also regulated in a similar manner.

A similar issue exists in relation to life insurance and superannuation investments, which I will pursue in the Senate at a future time. The tragedy of the current system we are talking about today is borne out by recommendation No. 101 of the report. Here the Committee recommended that retail banks and the Department of Social Security jointly investigate the feasibility of developing a basic banking product. The product should be offered by all retail banks, should allow for a set number of free withdrawals each week and should be targeted to the needs of low income Australians.

Who would have believed that, after the longest period of Labor rule in the history of this country, a basic social justice facility such as a fair bank account does not exist, and that the best a Government controlled committee can come up with is that banks and the Government jointly investigate the feasibility of establishing such a facility? Of course such a proposal is feasible. What about a recommendation that the law be changed to ensure that all retail banks provide such an account? Who is really suffering the long term results of the deregulation of the financial system? It is the sort of people who need that account. The Government introduced a punitive deemed earnings regime against pensioners and other social security beneficiaries. There was no cooperative investigation into the feasibility or fairness of that system.

The final recommendation of the Martin Committee is that the terms of reference of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration be broadened to include a responsibility for reviewing the banking industry. This is well short of the royal commission requested by former Senator Paul McLean and other members of the community, but it does show that even the major parties have discovered enough about the abuses which are possible under a deregulated system to warrant a permanent parliamentary watchdog. It remains to be seen whether this watchdog will have the teeth that it should have and, more importantly, whether it will have the personnel to protect the interests of the community instead of being a compliant rubber stamp. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for deregulating the banking system because the lack of Reserve Bank control on the money supply has led to the imposition of punitive interest rates which have caused the worst recession in 60 years and the Senate notes that any reductions in interest rates have benefited corporate customers and not retail customers".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Bank Integration Bill 1991 is to finalise the removal of the distinction between savings banks and trading banks, which commenced with the Banking Legislation Amendment Act 1989. I was going to apologise for addressing most my remarks to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the Martin inquiry, because I understand there will be no opportunity to address this report in this chamber as it was tabled in the other place. However, as Senator Kernot addressed her remarks entirely to that report, I do not think I need to apologise for doing so.
—You only need to apologise if you do it for too long.

—I will not hold up the Senate for too long. I thought that Senator Kernot would have addressed a very important aspect of that report, the foreign currency loans, although it was not deemed to be too important at the beginning. Former Senator Paul McLean took a great deal of time in this place on that aspect. Although he bored us to tears with some of the other things he brought before the Senate—
—Ha, ha!

—Just a minute. I give him credit because in this chamber he exposed the actions of the banks on foreign currency loans—something that no-one else had done before, or has done since in Australia. Foreign currency loans came out of the 1982-84 period, when much cheaper money was available overseas than in Australia and when some Australian banks, short of funds and wanting to satisfy their customers so they would not lose them, started bringing in and retailing foreign currency. They retailed a lot of foreign currency to businesses or people who could not afford to pay the interest charged on Australian money, if it was available. When the Australian dollar collapsed, interest rates on money brought onshore became too high, and a lot of businesses went to the wall. Foreign currency loans had been going on for 50 years—they were nothing new—but they expanded in the early 1980s.

PARA.TAB: The Committee concluded that the primary reason for banks offering foreign currency loans to a much wider part of the community than they had previously was competitive pressure; for example, some banks did not have enough Australian currency and wanted to market foreign currency loans so they could keep their customers. The banks denied this. The Committee also identified that there were perceived tax advantages—that is where the banks came under suspicion at the time, and they have been under suspicion ever since—to banks selling foreign currency loans. It would appear that some banks deliberately structured the product to take advantage of those perceived tax benefits. No doubt, the Australian Taxation Office is looking at that situation.

The Committee's recommendation 59 is that the banks ensure greater disclosure of foreign exchange transactions by advising foreign currency loan customers in advance of all fees and charges associated with foreign currency transactions. There are greater risks involved in foreign currency loans, even if loan customers do not go into hedging, which brings the interest fairly close to the Australian rate.

The banks claimed they did not market, promote or sell foreign currency loans. They endeavoured to portray themselves—and they did it pretty well—as passive victims of borrowers, often advised by brokers determined to obtain foreign currency loans. This may be true in some cases, but it is difficult to sustain in all cases. I have heard from people all over Australia—not only from my State of Western Australia, but from New South Wales and Victoria—that banks did actively market them and brokers did market them, so the banks have to cop their fair share of blame for what happened.

In the case of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the brokers marketed foreign currency loans so well that all the clients of certain brokers from Western Australia were flown, at whose expense I do not know, to the Commonwealth Bank branch at North Sydney to fix up loans. Let no-one say that brokers did not push foreign currency loans and that the banks were not actively marketing. Former Senator McLean used to say that the villain in this fiasco was Westpac. I will come to the Westpac letters later. I believe that in the end when all is disclosed about how the Commonwealth Bank acted—and a lot was disclosed in the Sydney Morning Herald some time ago; some of the bank's ex-officers have made public some of the goings-on—it will make Westpac look like a Sunday school outfit. As I said, the Committee identified that that had happened.

The Committee also identified some of the promotional measures adopted by some banks. There was some advertising of the product. I remember the advertising that took place. Some seminars and other promotions were conducted which involved a discussion of foreign currency loans. There was at least one instance where a member of a bank's staff had targets for selling foreign currency loans. This could have happened at somewhere like the North Sydney branch of the Commonwealth Bank. People from even Western Australia and Queensland were involved.

I said that I would not take too much of the Senate's time but I have a little more to discuss. Recommendation 60 relates to people who are in trouble, irrespective of whether they have been to court or cannot afford to go to court. The Committee recommended that all mediators:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . funded by the banks, but acceptable to both banks and foreign currency borrowers, be appointed to mediate in foreign currency loan cases that remain in dispute. Mediation is not compulsory, banks will pay for their own mediators or for a general mediator based on usage. The determinations of the mediator will not be binding on either party. Banks should endeavour to the extent possible, to advise all foreign currency loan borrowers of the mediatory mechanism. The mediator should operate under the following conditions:
.mediation would be not possible where cases have already proceeded through all stages of appeal so that the court processes are recognised.

That is fair enough to me but, as has been portrayed in the newspapers, there have been problems of discovery. The banks, whether deliberately or not, certainly did not discover all the relevant documents that litigators would have needed to be successful in court. We are now finding that some cases are starting to be successful. Unfortunately, many of those who took the banks on did so far too early. So I have my reservations about accepting that recommendation in toto.

PARA.TAB: There are also those borrowers who have gone through the legal system—Senator Cooney would know about this—and, at the end of a 12-day trial, have lost their case. By the time many of them have reached the appeal stage they have no money after paying all the solicitors, the QCs and the costs awarded against them. They have no money left to risk doing anything further by way of appeal.

The banks offered some of their customers deals—and I know that the Commonwealth Bank did this—under which they were given nine months leeway to sell their assets. Thankfully, I was successful in convincing a bank to extend for three months the time period for repayment of one of its customers from Western Australia so that that person could get finance somewhere else. But to me these customers had to sign the deals because, in effect, they had a gun held at their heads.

Although I welcome recommendation 60, it does nothing for those who, under duress, signed away their right of appeal. The recommendation is not strong enough. It should be extended to cover those who signed a deal under duress not to carry on with an appeal.

Recommendation 60 makes the point that mediation under section 60 would not be possible where out of court settlements have been reached. That is something that we would have to agree with. Of course, I believe that, where there has not been total discovery, that ground should be gone over again. However, mediation can be sought where cases are still pending in court without final decision. Of course, that can happen in commercial litigation at any time. Finally, recommendation 60 concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: .any determination of the mediator will be non-binding on both parties so that both have the appropriate option of pursuing court action.
Of course, that is only commonsense. The other Committee finding I would like to comment on is recommendation No. 61: the Westpac letters. The recommendation states:

. . . the Attorney-General refer the so-called `Westpac letters' to the National Crime Authority for investigation as to whether any criminal wrongdoings arise from the management of foreign exchange contracts by Partnership Pacific Limited.

Of course, this was the driving force behind Senator McLean's argument. That is where he started. Unfortunately, he clouded the issue by looking at a wide range of dissatisfactions with the banks, but it was originally the central point of his argument.

PARA.TAB: I welcome that recommendation because, having read the Westpac letters, I believe Westpac has a lot to answer for. But I do not believe that recommendation should apply just to Westpac. I know that it is its letters which have been exposed, but I think the recommendation also applies to other banks. In fact, former senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia have admitted that there are some problems in that bank also. I throw in the other banks which are in the same position. In this case, many more discoveries should have been made.

That is about all I have to say on this matter. I have not had the chance to read the Democrats' amendment to this motion, but no doubt someone will decide which way we will go in relation to it. Before I sit down, I would like to commend the work of former Senator McLean in his exposure of banking malpractice in the area of foreign currency loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —But deregulation is a factor.

—If I were to get onto the subject of deregulation, I would use up the 30 minutes available to me, but I promised my Whip that I would not speak for more than five minutes. Senator Kernot should not get me onto deregulation, otherwise we will get onto the nationalisation of the banks—an issue which the Democrats would have supported. That, along with the issue of petrol rationing, led to the Labor Government losing office in 1949. However, Senator Kernot is probably not old enough to remember that. I will not get onto that issue, otherwise I will take up my half an hour. As I have said, I commend the work of former Senator McLean in the area of foreign currency loans. I will let others judge where he wandered from that issue in pursuing the rest of his misgivings about the banks.

—I will be very brief in my remarks. Unlike my colleague Senator Panizza, I have had the opportunity to read and consider the amendment which the Australian Democrats have moved to this motion and I can assure the Democrats that we will not be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that there is a major dichotomy in this Parliament between the Democrats and the Liberal and National parties. The Democrats believe in regulation and control. That is simplistic and, ultimately, it does not work. When people are members of parliament, they think they can fix up all of the problems simply by exercising some degree of control in some way or another over an organisation or a body. If honourable senators want to see the ultimate result of that approach, they should go and look at Eastern Europe and see the devastation that has been brought down upon the poor people of Eastern Europe by governments—operating in what they probably genuinely believed was the best interests of the people of their nation—controlling and regulating all of the activities of society. It is no good for people such as the Democrats to say, `We don't want to regulate and control all of the activities, just some'. It has been demonstrated quite clearly time and time again that regulation and control arrangements end up producing devastating results.

This particular banking problem that we have in Australia has been, once again, brought about because of control. When Mr Keating was Treasurer he introduced what was called banking deregulation. The problem was that he did not go far enough. Having allowed 16 foreign banks to come into Australia, he panicked. The left wing of the Labor Party panicked; they were jumping up and down about these foreign banks coming in. People such as the Australian Democrats were also jumping up and down. After 16 of these foreign banks came into Australia he said, `That is it; we won't allow any more'.

Not only did he limit the number to 16, but also he exercised a degree of control over those banks by making sure that they were not allowed to open branches in Australia. They had to be genuinely full banks in Australia so that even a bank as large as Germany's Deutsche Bank, which I think is probably one of the largest banks in the world, is not allowed to operate a branch system; it has to operate here with a capital base as required by Australian banking regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—I do wish Senator Kernot would listen to this, because it is very important. Those managing the Australian banks are not fools; they are business people. They said to themselves, `There are only 16 of these banks here and we are going to make sure that none of them get established properly. We are going to do our best to break those banks, to make sure that their management back at the home base closes up their Australian operations'. So, the Australian banks took on the 16 foreign banks. They undercut their loans. Every time a foreign bank put a proposition to someone, one of the major Australian banks was prepared to lend more on less security to get the business, to make sure that, for example, Chase Manhattan did not establish itself securely in Australia.

PARA.TAB: After a while the Australian banks squeezed the 16 foreign banks to the stage where their management back in their home country said it was not worth while being in Australia. But, of course, the Australian major banks were destroying in many ways their own capital base. Now they have to recover their equity, and they are taking it out of Australian depositors. We will not solve that problem by regulation and control.

Now these banks are deliberately trying to re-establish their equity by reducing their loan arrangements. They are not deliberately doing it to small business people; they are not deliberately taking away money from them. They are simply saying to their branch managers, `Reduce your lending in that particular branch, and do it however you wish'. The branch manager will look around and he might see a business which is up against it. He knows that if he were to take $10,000 or $20,000 of that fellow's overdraft, the business would go to the wall. He will not take it off him, so he looks around and sees a business that is doing all right, that has a few bob or does not have a big overdraft. He reduces the overdraft of that business so that that business becomes squeezed. But that is probably the one business that he ought to be lending more money to, because it is the one that is successful.

So around Australia small businesses are being squeezed because the major trading banks are undertaking a general reduction of debt in order to recover the losses they effected upon themselves by competing with the foreign banks. That is the situation. It is a simplistic explanation but generally that is what is happening in Australia.

Why has this happened in Australia? Because Mr Keating limited the number of foreign trading banks that came in. Had he said that it was unlimited or that banks could open branches in Australia, there would have been genuine competition and the major Australian trading banks would not have tried to take on those 16 foreign banks and tried to squeeze them out of business.

If the Government were to open up banking to genuine competition and allow banks such as the Deutsche Bank of Germany to operate simply on a branch arrangement in Australia, it would find that there would be plenty of money made available at very low, reasonable interest rates to the businesses which ought to be able to borrow money in Australia. The fundamental difference between us and the Australian Democrats and between us and many people in the Australian Labor Party is that they do not understand that there must be genuine competition if this country is to get over the economic problems which it is suffering at present.

Genuine competition in all areas and genuine competition in the banking area would make money available for housing, for small business and big business, and for those who will be successful—those who will create the jobs that are needed in this country. Until such time as this Government—we do not have to worry about the Democrats because they will never be in government—wakes up to this matter, this country will continue to bump along at the bottom of the economic depression that we are suffering at present. This country will not recover from its present problems until such time as this Government allows genuine competition to come into effect or until such time as the Liberal and National parties get into government and are able to effect the policies so very well set out in our Fightback package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for his comments, which were substantially in support of the Bank Integration Bill. Unfortunately I was not here when he made his remarks last night; however, I listened to what he had to say this morning. Senator Lewis spoke about the Australian Democrats' amendment to some extent.

PARA.TAB: The debate has substantially been—not inappropriately in the circumstances—about the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into the Australian banking industry—the Martin Committee. Although, technically, this is not what people should have been discussing, given the significance of the report and the fact that the Senate will not otherwise get a chance to debate it, it is at least of passing relevance to this legislation. I think it was appropriate that the Senate was used as a forum for such debate on this occasion. I do not intend to pursue that indulgence, but I understand why Senator Panizza and Senator Kernot did.

I will very briefly reiterate what the Bill is about and then say something about the Australian Democrats' amendment. This Bill will facilitate the integration of savings banks and trading banks. It is not a major measure in that regard because most of the relevant and required legislative amendments received royal assent in November 1989, implementing a decision announced during the Budget Speech in August 1988. At that time we indicated that further legislation would be necessary, and I think it is appropriate that we are proceeding in this methodical way.

The Senate would be aware that the rationale for amalgamating into group trading banks and savings banks results from a policy decision to treat them in the same way and a prudential preference by the Reserve Bank of Australia for each banking group to have only one licence. Without this legislation, however, the amalgamations would have been unduly complex and costly. Therefore, the Government has decided to pass Commonwealth legislation to facilitate the transfer of assets and liabilities for each of the eight pairs of banks involved, exempting them from most Commonwealth and State taxes and charges and providing for income tax neutrality. All the States and Territories have indicated general agreement with the Bill and will cooperate by passing complementary legislation in the States for the incorporation of the relevant banks.

That briefly outlines for the record the purpose of the Bill. I have reiterated what has been said in the second reading debate and have mentioned what Senator Chapman said in his response on behalf of the Opposition. I now turn my attention briefly to the Opposition's second reading amendment. When I heard the first of Senator Kernot's remarks I was not aware that she was moving a second reading amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats—not the Opposition.
