—I am sorry—the Democrats' second reading amendment. I was referring to Senator Kernot's remarks in support of it, which would have been even more surprising had it been an Opposition second reading amendment. When Senator Kernot started to speak, it sounded like a reiteration of all the urban myths we heard in the 1980s about the banking system, strung together with a series of assumptions and assertions. I then found that a second reading amendment had been distributed and subsequently moved by Senator Kernot. It is a remarkable amendment in that I regard it as absolutely economically incoherent. Some people might think that is not remarkable because it is a Democrats amendment. The amendment makes no sense at all. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . condemns the Government for deregulating the banking system because the lack of Reserve Bank control on the money supply has led to the imposition of punitive interest rates which have caused the worst recession in 60 years . . .

The linkage between those three assertions was not made in Senator Kernot's speech, and they are internally contradictory. If a student put that sentence in a high school economics essay, he would fail; it is just economically incoherent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did she study economics?
—Senator Kernot obviously has not studied it at all. The amendment continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any reductions in interest rates have benefited corporate customers and not retail customers.

Many people in the community would be very surprised to know that their mortgage interest rates have not gone down, because all the indications are that they have, and millions of Australians are benefiting from it.

PARA.TAB: It is true that on the last two occasions there has been a marginal indication of priority by the banks to pass on the interest rate cuts more quickly and in larger measure to corporate customers and not retail customers, to use the phraseology of the amendment. Overall, that has not been the case; in fact, there was some concern in the early stages that there was not a sufficient pass-on of reductions in interest rates to the corporate sector. People were very concerned about that.

In the context of a priority concern about the creation of jobs, there is a lot of merit in saying that one of the priorities in the reduction of interest rates should be that they are passed on to the people for whom interest rates are a significant cost burden. Interest rates make it impossible for them to spend money in other ways, such as employing people. I do not think the statement is right. However, if it is right, I do not apologise for it.

The amendment is an attempt to put a veneer of economic logic on a series of assertions that, if the banks had not been deregulated, we would not have a recession. There is no evidence of that. I understand it is possible to argue a case against deregulation of the banks. Some competent economists have put an internally consistent argument for that. The Government does not share their view, but I accept that it is possible to put forward such a thesis. In nearly 60 years since Lord Keynes wrote his work there has been a lot of discussion. Many people thought that we should have deregulation, and some have thought that we should not. I am not saying it is impossible to put forward an argument for that. I am not aware of anybody who would say that has caused a loss of Reserve Bank control of the money supply, nor would I expect anybody to say that it has therefore led to the imposition of punitive interest rates, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the Government. They are not blaming the banks for that.

—It is not blaming the banks, but somehow or other in a very convoluted way it is linking it back to deregulation. If we look around the world, we see that not every country has taken the same course with regard to banking; nevertheless, many of them are suffering the same situation with regard to recession. There is no correlation between those sorts of factors and the attitudes of the governments in question to issues of deregulation of banks.

PARA.TAB: This is just a nonsense amendment. Whatever else we might disagree about, I am not surprised that the Opposition is not supporting it. I thank all honourable senators for their support of the Bill and for the debate on the Martin Committee report, which was off the subject of the Bill; nevertheless, it was a debate that was needed at some stage in the Senate, and it might as well have been today. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—(11.10 a.m.)—I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)Clause 11, page 6, at the end of the clause, add the following subclause:

TAB.TAB: "(3) In subsection (2):

PARA.TAB: `tax', in relation to the complementary legislation of a particular State, does not include any fee or tax prescribed by the Corporations Regulations of that State.".
(2)Clause 18, page 8, line 33, omit "trading", substitute "business'.

SPEECH.PARA: These are essentially technical amendments. The second is a drafting amendment and I will speak no more about that. The first merely makes more specific the freedom of the States to charge fees and taxes imposed under the corporations law. It merely makes explicit what was always intended. It would obviously be unacceptable if the provision dealing with the States' complementary legislation did not equally preserve that freedom. This amendment merely serves to do that. I will not take up the time of the Senate with a lengthy argument about its merits; it seems quite straightforward.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991 is to amend the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 to implement the recommendations of the report entitled A Question of Balance. Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia by Professor Peter Baume. The Government has accepted the recommendations as a package and this legislation sets about implementing the first of the legislative changes.

PARA.TAB: These changes are long awaited. Since 1977, not including the Baume inquiry, we have had no fewer than 17 inquiries into pharmacy and the supply of pharmaceuticals. There was one in 1977, two in 1979, three in 1980, one in 1981, two in 1985, two in 1986, three in 1987, one in 1988, two in 1989 and now there is the Baume inquiry. Finally, we have an inquiry the recommendations of which have been accepted by the Government, which has promised to implement them quickly.

I must give my former colleague Professor Peter Baume credit for producing a report that has gained the acceptance of not only the Government but also the industry and consumer organisations. I could say that it took a former Liberal member to get changes implemented in our drug evaluation process. He brought to bear on that Committee his experience here in this chamber, his experience as an outstanding physician and now his background experience as an academic.

The Bill before the Senate makes a number of significant changes to the drug evaluation and approval procedures. The amendments include the following: a change to the objects of the Act to include timely availability of therapeutic goods as an objective of drug evaluation; a new scheme to permit greater use of experimental or unapproved drugs; greater reliance to be placed on data supplied to the Therapeutic Goods Administration by increasing the penalties for false or misleading information; provision for time limits within which the evaluation of drugs must be completed; the enabling of sponsors to make safety-related changes to product information without the need for prior approval; and provision for the lapsing of 25 per cent of evaluation fees where deadlines for the completion of evaluations are not met by the Therapeutic Goods Administration.

The financial impact is the possible loss of revenue by the TGA if it fails to meet deadlines for the evaluation of therapeutic goods although, due to an increase of 20 per cent in that fee, the 25 per cent forfeited by the TGA will mean that it is only 5 per cent behind, so there is no great incentive for the TGA to be on time. I hope that the new and improved arrangements will allow deadlines to be met and that the forfeiture of evaluation fees does not become commonplace. As I said, because it is such a small amount, given the increase, I do not think it will act as an incentive to the TGA to speed up its processes.

Before I go into the specifics of the Bill, I want to outline how the therapeutic goods program of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has operated for some time. The administration of this program has been marred by delays, inefficiency and, in general, the inadequacy of access to new and unapproved therapeutic goods. Patients have been denied access to life saving drugs, and the compliance costs incurred by industry have been too high and have acted as a deterrent to seek general marketing approval for therapeutic goods.

The particular concerns of industry about the current approval process include: the time taken to prepare applications in accordance with the strict data and formatting requirements in Australia; duplication of work already undertaken overseas; and a high level of rejection at the screening for acceptance stage, with a need to supply supplementary information not previously sought by other regulatory services.

The introduction of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 brought with it significant hopes of improvement in the drug evaluation process but, given the problems which were encountered with the regulations accompanying the Act, it is not surprising to see many of these concerns continuing. Some of the concerns that remain include: the unsatisfactory and adversarial nature of communication with the TGA; inefficiencies and resourcing problems

SPEECH.PARA: within both the TGA and the drug evaluation branch; a lack of accountability in the evaluation process generally; and a lack of any professional appeals body in the system.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment in this Bill gives effect to a change to the objects clause of the Act. For too long there has been little or no consideration given to the timely availability of therapeutic goods. Australia's drug evaluators may have served it well by avoiding calamities such as thalidomide in the early 1960s, but this has been at the expense of availability. Of course, there is a great difficulty in achieving the balance between avoiding the thalidomide experience and making sure that there is a timely availability of drugs for Australian residents and citizens. Given that the objects of the Act did not include timely availability, it is not surprising that it was not sought. The result has been a safe therapeutic goods environment but, as I said, to the detriment of patient access to drugs.

Data provided by the TGA to the Baume inquiry showed that the target time for a new chemical entity approval from submission to written approval was 350 days. The actual time was 702 days—twice as long. One of the TGA figures provided to the inquiry showed that it took almost seven weeks for a general marketing application just to be accepted by the TGA. Figures provided by the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association show that the time taken from submission to written approval was increasing.

This situation is intolerable for consumers and for the industry. Consumers are disadvantaged because therapeutic goods are available here later than in other countries and are sometimes not available at all because the firms do not consider it worth while to seek approval. For the industry the situation is unacceptable in terms of the forgone revenue and the discouragement of research and development in Australia. A paragraph in Professor Baume's report seems to sum up the situation. Page 54 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The DEB—
the drug evaluation branch within the TGA—
has never committed itself seriously to timeliness and seems not to have in place any mechanisms ever to allow it to achieve expeditious evaluations for most drugs. Earlier reports—
those are the reports which I mentioned before, some 17 of them—

have drawn attention to inefficiencies and resourcing problems, but there seems to have been no adequate corrective action and no hope that the situation described so often will not continue indefinitely. There is a lack of accountability in the evaluation process generally, so that officers have no incentive to place any importance on timeliness as one important aspect of their task. The Royal Australasian College of Physicians wrote of `considerable in-built delays' in the present system and almost all critics have drawn attention to the same failure of the TGA in greater or lesser detail. One of the more notorious delays was the almost 10 year wait by Australians for slow release morphine, available to the British in 1981, in New Zealand soon after, but approved by the Australian ADEC only in December 1990.
Professor Baume goes on to say:

In defence of the TGA, I understand that about half of this time had elapsed before the application was received by the TGA. Nevertheless the TGA took another four years to evaluate the product before it became available on the market.

Many of us in this chamber will know that morphine is associated with pain relief. I wonder what might have been said by the relatives of those patients who were in pain when a bureaucratic organisation took four years to approve a drug which was involved in pain relief.As I indicated, one of the amendments provides for timely availability to be included as an objective of the Therapeutic Goods Administration. However, the existence of an objective in itself will not speed up the drug approval process. Other amendments will help to facilitate this objective.

PARA.TAB: One of the major reforms emanating from the Baume report is the recommendation relating to greater reliance being placed on data supplied to the TGA in support of applications to register goods. This Bill implements this recommendation. Concurrent with this change is an amendment to increase the penalties for providing false or misleading information. The Secretary will make decisions about the suitability of goods for registration, based on claims made by the applicants. This change is intended to reduce the time taken to check the accuracy of statements made in support of applications. The increase in penalties for providing false or misleading statements is justified, given the increased reliance to be placed on claims by applicants.

The Baume report concluded that, on grounds of resources alone, Australia cannot continue to analyse individual patient data routinely during the evaluation process. Although some critics may suggest that Australia will lower its standards of safety and efficacy, the reality is that our standards will remain at least as high as those of comparable nations. Professor Baume, in his report, makes an important point in regard to the usefulness of assessing all individual patient data. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The final point which I wish to make in response to the critics is that I am not convinced that outcomes in Australia have been better than overseas outcomes as a result of the local evaluation of individual patient data. The oft quoted case of benoxaprofen, for example, where Australia was spared the deaths and serious adverse reactions reported overseas, was a result of concerns about the drug's potential to cause photosensitivity reactions, not a result of concerns which were apparent as a result of the examination of individual patient data.

This Bill also provides for time limits within which the evaluation of drugs must be completed. The therapeutic goods included and the time limits are to be prescribed in regulations. As part of the reductions in evaluation times that have been set, the evaluation fees for an application, as I mentioned before, are to be increased by 20 per cent—75 per cent of the fee is payable at the time of application and the other 25 per cent upon completion of the evaluation process within the specified time limit. If the evaluation time is not met, the 75 per cent accounts for full payment. I hope that the TGA does not just accept this reduction in payment and use it as a means of extending the approval process.

PARA.TAB: This Bill also allows for sponsors to make safety related changes to product information without the need for prior approval. This is in situations where the variation would have the effect of reducing the class of persons for whom the goods may be used. This amendment allows for a speedy change of this information.

One of the major changes included in this Bill relates to the introduction of the special access scheme to replace the individual patient usage scheme. The current IPU scheme—I am sure that Senator Collins, having been up to 2 o'clock, would have even more difficulty than I do in saying that, since I actually went to bed last night a bit earlier than he did—would have to be the greatest indictment of the drug approval process in Australia. The number of IPU approvals has increased at a significant rate in recent years. In 1988, there were 7,767 requests; in 1989, 14,297 requests; and in 1990, 19,415 requests. This contrasts with 9,000 approvals under the equivalent Canadian emergency drug release program in 1990. Due to the unacceptable delays in drug approvals, patients have been forced to seek their therapy through the IPU scheme. The individual patient usage scheme has been plagued by problems. Professor Baume has outlined those problems in his report on pages 128 and 129. I seek leave to incorporate those problems, set out in dot points, in Hansard, to save the Senate some time.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: PROBLEMS WITH THE CURRENT ARRANGEMENTS

PARA.TAB: Medical practitioners, hospital pharmacy departments, and individual consumers, including AIDS activists, have all voiced complaints about the operation of the present IPU system. In summary, the main areas of concern are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: .the application of the IPU guidelines is inconsistent;
.the IPU criteria are framed for people at `death's door', and do not address adequately the needs of those with serious but less immediately life-threatening conditions;
.there is no readily available source of information about treatments available under the IPU arrangements;
.individual prescribers have difficulty making an application and pursuing it through the bureaucratic processes;
.a separate approval is required for every patient prescribed a drug under the IPU arrangements;
.TGA telephones are constantly engaged, causing medical staff to spend excessive times in obtaining approvals;
.the response time of up to 2 days for facsimile requests is unreasonable;
.delays of 2-4 weeks between oral approval and receipt of written authorisation cause problems;
.administrative arrangements for seeking approval have been changed by TGA without notice;

.the high number of IPU approvals suggests that the scheme is attempting to compensate for a seriously deficient regulatory and approval system, and that it has become, in some cases, a preferred default marketing scheme; and
.availability of a treatment depends on the cooperation of the sponsor company, and the cost to hospitals or individuals can be high if the sponsor does not agree to subsidise use.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the concerns and inadequacies of the present system, this Bill introduces a new system called the special access scheme. The new scheme has been designed to provide greater access to unapproved and experimental drugs for terminally ill patients or patients with a life threatening illness. One of the major reforms in this process will be the ability of certain medical practitioners to authorise the supply of specific classes of therapeutic goods to certain classes of patients. The former IPU scheme operated by allowing the Secretary to approve the supply of therapeutic goods not on the register or exempt under the Act, given certain administrative criteria. The central authorising role of the Secretary or his delegate was a problem. Approvals took an inordinate amount of time. Freeing up the system to allow for certain medical practitioners to approve the use according to the prescribing criteria will ensure that patient access to these potentially unapproved and possibly life saving drugs will be improved.

PARA.TAB: Arrangements for access to unapproved drugs under the SAS vary according to the health status of the individual. Category A patients include terminally ill patients with life threatening conditions. The guidelines for medical practitioners for use with the SAS outline the criteria and the procedures for the scheme. The Opposition supports the introduction of this scheme and believes that it is of vital importance that terminally ill patients have access to the supply of unapproved drugs without delay.

I refer to the availability of the regulations. The regulations not only provide for a list of exempt goods under the Act, but also provide for time limits to be set for the TGA to process applications. There are a number of other measures in the regulations, including changes to the composition of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. I believe that it assists the Senate, when examining legislation, especially in this case, to have the associated regulations before it. We have been provided with a draft copy, but only after we asked for it. This morning we received an altered version of that draft. One of those alterations is aimed at addressing a concern that members of the Opposition had that in some aspects of the special access it may be possible for large quantities of drugs to be given to a patient rather than the doctor controlling the amount of drug to which that patient can have access.

A cursory examination of those regulations this morning has not totally convinced me that the concerns that the Opposition has have been addressed. I believe that the intention of the Government is to address those concerns. I put the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and the Department on notice that the Opposition will be carefully examining those regulations when it has more time to do so and when the regulations are tabled. If the regulations do not meet our concerns, the Senate has the ability to disallow them. I hope that there will be cooperation between the coalition and the Australian Democrats and the Department to ensure that those concerns are addressed.

There is one final matter I want to raise. In both the April and August Estimates this year I raised a number of matters regarding the import and export of therapeutic goods. In 30 seconds the unemployment figures for the nation for this month will be released in the press gallery. The issue that I want to address concerns unemployment. It concerns a factory that exists in the electorate of Hotham, where my office is situated. It is the electorate of Simon Crean, one of the contenders in the leadership bid that is currently plaguing our nation. In that electorate is a factory that put off 21 people a couple of weeks ago. The parent company had intentions of investing in capital to open another factory to produce therapeutic goods. That parent company is now most probably not going to invest and is looking to go off-shore because of the problems that it has had in dealing with the bureaucracy—the Therapeutic Goods Association and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and his office.

It saddens me to think that an Australian company, which has a potential of employing Australians when our unemployment situation is most probably at its worst ever, along with other companies is going off-shore or putting off staff. When I was a small child my grandmother used to say to me, `Look after the pennies and the pounds will look after themselves'. This applies to business in Australia. If we look after the small businesses, the economy might have a better chance of looking after itself. We see those jobs eroding bit by bit—21 here, 22 there. These are the numbers that add up to create the pain and misery that we are seeing in Australia at the moment.

What happened with this firm? It approached me because it seemed to be getting nowhere with the TGA. When I moved my office into the electorate the firm approached me because it knew I was responsible for taking health legislation and legislation in this portfolio through the chamber. That was some time ago—earlier this year. I cannot remember the exact date it approached me. It was sufficiently long ago for the problems that it outlined to me to have been addressed.

It seems to me that Mr Crean, whose electorate this factory is in, and whose constituents are being put out of work, has lost a bit of interest because he has now become the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I remind him that he still has responsibilities in his electorate. Apparently, he took some interest in this before he became the Minister for Primary Industries. I call on Mr Crean to address this issue and negotiate with the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, to ensure that the problems facing this business are settled.

The firm is not asking for special treatment—it is not asking for money or a handout; it is asking for a fair go. I believe that one of the reasons the significant investment this firm was to make in Australia is at stake is the inflexible and uncompromising attitude of the Therapeutic Goods Administration. I wish to refer to a letter that I received from the firm. It points out that after a meeting that it had with the Minister and Terry Counihan there was a degree of sympathy from them. I give credit to the Minister and his assistant, Mr Counihan, for that. The letter said:

SPEECH.PARA: At this meeting we found the TGA to be intransigent and inflexible; their attitude to our plight was uncaring and they seemed quite unconcerned when told that we may well be forced to relocate offshore.

Many public servants in Canberra—and I know there is some unemployment here—are insulated from the trauma that is going on in Australia. We cannot afford to let one company go off-shore if we can avoid it. If we can do anything to maintain standards in Australia in terms of imports and exports of therapeutic goods while at the same time ensuring that we do not lose companies here, then we will have served Australia well. I do not believe that Australia is being served well at the moment by the actions of this Minister and the TGA.

PARA.TAB: Basically, the problems are as follows. Imported products which have been grandfathered under the Act have not been checked regarding their standard of manufacturing, despite a specific assurance given to the firm in December last year by the Minister that this would occur. It was given an assurance. It tells me in its correspondence that on the basis of that assurance it was going to make this investment. Now that that assurance has not been upheld it looks like not investing in further factories or investing further capital here. Because of this and because of the fact that the Minister has not kept to his assurance, imported products are now cheaper than local products which are being manufactured to a higher standard. What the firm is asking for—an assurance was given by the Minister—is that imported products meet the same standard of good manufacturing practice as do the therapeutic goods manufactured here. That is what we would all expect. Domestic business is declining as sales are being lost to cheaper imported products.

I believe that the Minister should stand by his word and require all sponsors of imported products to provide evidence of good manufacturing compliance. If this evidence is not forthcoming, registration or listing should be cancelled. On the export side, a major concern has been with the wording now being used on certificates of pharmaceutical products, CPPs. These certificates are required for registration and re-registration of products in the various export markets. The new wording on CPP is unacceptable to the overseas regulatory authorities and is affecting the registration of existing export products. For new products, registration will not even be considered, given the new wording.

As a result of the problems, the firm to which I am referring is beginning to lose forward orders for export products. If this continues to happen we will have more people losing their jobs in Mr Crean's electorate or Mr Duffy's electorate of Holt because some of those people come from there. These are two electorates with the highest unemployment rate in Australia—the unemployment capital of Australia—and, because of the intransigent nature of the Department and the Minister, we have this company which is losing business in Australia and losing export potential.

There is also a problem with the process involved in the evaluation of export products. The industry is far from happy with the procedures as they currently stand. It is very difficult for a firm to compete on the export market when it is subject to the rigorous procedures set down. I will read another letter that was sent from somebody in the Therapeutic Goods Administration to DITAC. It implied in a funny sort of way that this company was concerned about the commercial outcome. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Paradoxically—
the company—

. . . is concerned about any restrictions on exported goods. Again its motivation is commercial but the outcome is inconsistent with the intent of TGA—firstly to protect consumers and secondly to protect the reputation of exported Australian made therapeutic goods and the Australian industry.

Twice this letter says `although the company's motivation is commercial', as if that were a sin. Of course its motivation is commercial. It wants to create jobs for Australians, not destroy them. That is what it is motivated by. It is motivated by good standards and it is motivated to ensure that it can create jobs in Australia, something some of our bureaucrats forget. That is my concern.

PARA.TAB: I urge the Minister to give an assurance that these problems will be examined. As yet the problems have not been resolved. The Minister has failed to keep his assurance. The situation seems to be in a stalemate. When somebody rang Mr Crean's office, one of his staff said, `You should make peace with the Minister'. That is what was said. This is about jobs and about the futures of those 21 families who now have somebody unemployed. What does Mr Crean's office say? It says, `You should make peace with the Minister'. Is it not about the Minister making peace with the people he represents as well?

The firm needs to know what is happening with imports so it can decide whether to go ahead with further investment. Surely out of work Australians deserve employment generating projects to be able to go ahead, instead of being stalled by what seems to be—I may stand to be corrected—an uncaring attitude of the Department, the TGA and the Minister. I hope that we will see this issue resolved. There is little time to wait. That investment decision is hanging in the balance. I hope that we will see a response to the concerns and the Minister meeting the assurances he gave to that company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991 introduces certain changes to the drug approval process following the recommendations made by Professor Peter Baume in his report, A Question of Balance—Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia. As perhaps could be expected from someone of Professor Baume's experience and sensitivity, his report was a very careful and considered exploration of the issues involved in drug evaluation and availability in Australia. While it did not entirely please everybody, I think it is fair to say that most individuals and organisations involved in this field felt that he had made a significant and long overdue contribution. He has certainly made enormous progress and it is going to help us now to work through a bureaucratic nightmare that has been in need of major reform for many years.

PARA.TAB: Professor Baume's recommendations were far from being radical, but he did identify one of the major issues in the administration of therapeutic goods; that is, the question of timely availability of drugs. The desirability of balancing that concern against the need to maintain high standards of safety is now going to have to be a major consideration. As many commentators on the Australian situation have observed, our drug regulation system has really been defined by two medical disasters: thalidomide and AIDS. These two catastrophes represent the opposite ends of the regulation spectrum. On the one hand, we want a system that provides adequate protection from dangerous or potentially dangerous new drugs; on the other hand, we want to make sure that we give people who have a terminal or life threatening illness the best possible chance of survival.

The two sides of the argument are not always easy to reconcile and, although people with serious illnesses face these difficulties for many years, this issue of timely availability has become more urgent and more focused as a consequence of the advent of AIDS. The relatively high profile of HIV-AIDS and the problems associated with its treatment have very clearly highlighted the tension between the need for safety and the need for a speedy evaluation process.

Professor Baume's report was not the first time these issues have been canvassed, as has already been noted in this chamber today; indeed, it was the sixth, seventh or eighth time that our drug regulation system has been looked at. However, Professor Baume considered this tension between safety and availability very carefully and he pointed out the need for a balance between these two concerns. He also highlighted the fact that this is not really covered anywhere in the existing legislation—the Therapeutic Goods Act. He saw that omission as having a significant impact on the performance of the TGA and the perception it has of itself. In his report summary he was critical of the TGA's mission statement which refers only to the quality, safety and efficacy of therapeutic goods and fails to mention the crucial aspect of timeliness at all. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The present object of the TGA would be served best if no new drugs were made available ever, for only then could one be completely sure that Australians would suffer no untoward effects of new drugs.
This Bill attempts to rectify the imbalance in the Therapeutic Goods Act, giving our drug evaluators a clear statutory direction that timeliness is now to be one of their principal aims.

PARA.TAB: I understand that Senator Patterson has proposed amendments on this issue. I believe—although I have not as yet seen the final draft of the amendments—that the Opposition will be attempting to insert Professor Baume's specific words. While we could argue that this may be somewhat of a semantic exercise, I believe that this is something that we can support because it seems to be a more comprehensive approach and certainly makes it very clear that timely availability of therapeutic goods is to be one of the major objects of the Act. This may turn out to be important, especially given Professor Baume's public observation—following the release of his report—that the TGA has virtually made up its own policies because it was effectively operating in a policy vacuum.

The Bill also introduces the special access scheme, which is intended to provide greater access to experimental or unapproved drugs by persons with a terminal or life threatening illness. Again, although concerns about this issue have been around for some time, the problems experienced by people with HIV-AIDS in accessing treatment has really brought this issue to the forefront of public attention. Many people find it difficult to see why a person confronted with a terminal illness such as AIDS should not be able to access unapproved drugs—drugs that have been approved overseas and are readily available in, for example, the United States and Europe, but have not been approved here—and many people who are dying are often not only willing to take the additional risks for themselves, but they often feel that the risks that they are taking may eventually be of benefit to others in similar circumstances.

I have frequently been moved by the view expressed by people with a terminal illness that, even if their use of an unapproved or experimental drug proves to be of no personal benefit to them, it may save the lives of those who come after them. There are certainly problems with any approach that totally opens up access to drugs without any accompanying standards at all or regulatory measures, not the least of them being that we do not want to put terminally or seriously ill people in a position where they are susceptible to unethical or fraudulent exploitation. But it should be possible to exercise commonsense and come up with a drug evaluation regime that is sufficiently flexible and practical to assist people with a claim to earlier access, but which also ensures that standards are maintained. Under such a flexible system it then becomes the case that people having access to drugs at an earlier stage in the development or evaluation process must personally accept the greater risks involved. As I said earlier, many terminally ill people are certainly prepared to do that.

The report of the United States national committee to review current procedures for approval of new drugs for cancer and AIDS, which looked at approval procedures in the United States for cancer and AIDS drugs, put this matter very clearly in its opening statement. The committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: Life-threatening illnesses for which inadequate therapies exist deserve urgent attention by society. Cancer and AIDS qualify eminently for this designation. Patients suffering from these diseases cannot afford the luxury of waiting for drug development and regulation to move as slowly as they usually do towards ultimate regulatory approval and marketing. For cancer and AIDS patients time is running out and they are understandably impatient with delays in obtaining the pharmacotherapy which represents their only hope.

When, as has been occurring in this country, we combine delays in marketing approval with a complex and unwieldy individual access program, it is not hard to see why people with a life threatening illness have become increasingly frustrated and annoyed by the hoops that they have to jump through and the hurdles that they have to climb over in order to gain the drugs that they urgently want.

PARA.TAB: Over the years many people with life threatening illnesses have travelled overseas to attempt to access these drugs. They have secretly imported some restrictive products or unapproved drugs into the country, and in this past year we have seen the AIDS Council of New South Wales set up a program to assist people to import anti-HIV drugs via a quite complex overseas network, including a buyers club in America. I believe it is neither fair nor desirable that seriously ill people should have to go to such lengths, should have to go through such trauma and should be put to such expense because the official system is not properly catering for their needs.

I do not want to go into the issue of clinical trials, but I do want to make some points about the individual patient usage scheme that Senator Patterson has already detailed. Professor Baume noted that there were many complaints about the operation of the IPU. I understand Senator Patterson has incorporated the complaints, so I will not go over them again, but I stress that it really is getting out of hand.

In 1988 we had 7,667 requests for IPU approvals; by 1990 it had gone up to 19,415 requests. One of the commonly voiced observations about the IPU arrangements is that this high number of requests is an indication that the IPU scheme is compensating for a serious deficiency in our regulatory system and, in effect, has become a kind of de facto marketing scheme. Recognising the limitations of the IPU system, Professor Baume recommended that a new scheme for special access to unapproved drugs be established, and this Bill before us sets up some of the legislative framework for such a scheme. Among other things, the Bill contains provision for the secretary to authorise specific medical practitioners to directly supply unapproved drugs to patients who are seriously ill with life threatening illnesses. This makes it clear that, subject to the authorisation process, the decision about the use of the unapproved product and its associated risks is the province of the patient and his or her doctor.

This is definitely a step forward but, as much of the finer detail will be in the form of regulations—and I have seen no draft regulations at all—it is quite difficult for me to state with any certainty at this time that there will be a major improvement in the availability of these drugs to terminally ill individuals. I certainly hope that there will be approval and that is the whole issue on which this Bill is based. I do not believe that terminally ill people should have to resort to subterfuge to obtain drugs and I do not believe they should have to drag themselves over unnecessary bureaucratic obstacles at the very time when they are most susceptible and most in need of support.

The Government has dragged its feet for far too long in this area at very high cost to seriously and terminally ill individuals. Although we are still a long way from the perfect system, I hope that the changes introduced as a consequence of the Baume report signify the start of a better deal for these people.

Other changes brought about by this Bill are also welcomed and are directed towards improving the evaluation process. The introduction of target times for the processing of applications is a sensible move, providing an incentive for timely performance that has quite clearly been absent within the TGA for some time. Professor Baume pointed out that the TGA's performance appears to have deteriorated in recent years and that the available evidence confirmed that the TGA was in fact getting further and further away from meeting its targets.

Professor Baume also noted that the drug evaluation branch within the TGA has never committed itself seriously to timeliness and seems not to have in place any mechanisms ever to allow it to achieve expeditious evaluation for most drugs. There is a lack of accountability in the evaluation process generally, so that officers have no incentive to place any importance on timeliness as one important aspect of their task. Professor Baume recommended some very specific time lines and performance indicators in his report, and this Bill provides the framework within which those time lines can be fixed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has had considerable problems with the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991, mainly because the Government has not abided by the normal procedure. The normal practice—and I would like to make this very clear—is for a Bill to be introduced into the House of which the relevant Minister is a member. In order to allow proper debate to take place, the Senate has set down a specific time by which Bills must be introduced into this chamber. The Government sought to get around this requirement by introducing this health Bill into the Senate, not into the House of Representatives. As a result, tremendous problems have been created for the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: This Bill has not been before our shadow Cabinet or our party room. The Government, without any direct consultation with the Opposition on the likely problems which could arise, brought this Bill into the Senate, thereby avoiding the proper procedure that is normally followed. A considerable number of phone calls have been made because of the tremendous problems this has caused for us.

This Bill tries to strike a balance between the approach of making sure that Australia is able to keep its very high standard of assessing the safety of new drugs that enter this country before approving them for use by our citizens and the approach of allowing people with life threatening diseases or terminally ill patients access to overseas drugs which have not yet been approved for use in Australia.

We have known for many years that the drug evaluation process has been very slow. There has been an immense backlog of overseas drugs waiting to be evaluated. People have called for the approval and introduction of drugs that have been approved overseas and which have been acknowledged to be helpful in the treatment of certain diseases. However, because of the backlog, those drugs are not available. This Bill allows for the timely availability of new or improved therapeutic goods. I hope the Bill is successful. I hope that these objectives are able to be carried out and that the problems can be overcome.

Doctors often face a dilemma when they are treating terminally ill patients or patients who have a life threatening disease for whom no more can be done under normal medical procedures. The patient says, `I read about a drug that they are using in America, or Taiwan, or wherever. I think that drug could help me. Can't you get it for me?'. The doctor says, `No, I can't get it for you. I can't bring it in. It is not available'. The patient says, `But I am dying. Perhaps I have a chance with this drug. There is nothing more you can do for me. Please, can't you get it for me?.' Under this legislation, the doctor will be able to bring in that drug for that patient. As I said, this will apply only to people who are terminally ill or who have a life threatening disease. In those circumstances, this Bill allows a drug company or agent to bring a drug into Australia.

The Opposition has faced a dilemma because of the problems we have had with the introduction of this Bill into the Senate. We had a briefing from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I suggested to the Department that we follow this matter through in a practical way. Take the situation where a doctor is permitted to bring into Australia an unlimited quantity of drugs for his patient. The doctor could well say to the patient, `Look, I don't think that drug is going to do you any good. Indeed, the drug could do you harm'. The patient says, `Doctor, I'm dying. Please bring it in for me'. The doctor says, `Fine. I'll bring it in'. He brings in, say, a 12-month supply and says, `This is on your own head, because I don't believe this drug will do you any good. It has not been approved. I have concerns that it has not been tested well enough'. The doctor then has 12 months supply on his hands. I asked the Department what will happen to the drug. Will the doctor be able to give the 12- months supply straight to the patient and say, `You organise it. You house it—I really don't want to have anything to do with this drug'. The Department said that there was nothing to stop that occurring.

The Government has accepted in principle an amendment that the Opposition has put forward. However, rather than amend the legislation, the Government suggested that the amendment be put in the regulations. The Opposition accepted that. The regulations now state that the drug is dispensed on prescription of a medical practitioner who has prescribed the drug in accordance with good medical practice. So the doctor must prescribe the drug in accordance with the recommended quantities over the period of time. That is one of the problems that the Opposition faced.

There are many other problems, and Senator Patterson has spoken about those at length. I do not want to take up too much time of the Senate. I know that my colleague Senator Knowles will also speak in this area and I also know that Senator Kernot wants to add a few words. Senator Patterson spoke of a problem that she has in her State.

The unemployment figures have just been released. Unemployment has gone up from 10.1 per cent to 10.5 per cent. It is appalling that the unemployment figures are really as high as they are. We know the Government has admitted that the figures will go above 11 per cent. I have not had time to assess the seasonally adjusted figures or even the actual figures, but I know they are horrific. I will leave these figures for my colleague Senator Knowles, who will perhaps have a few more minutes to look at them, to decipher. The figures only arrived while I was on my feet. When the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, responds, I wonder whether he would tell us what the Government intends to do about unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am going to talk about therapeutic goods.
—The Minister has said no, he is not. I do not care whether he talks about therapeutic goods. I do not care whether he talks about unemployment. I do not care whether he talks about anything—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. If Senator Walters is going to quote me, let her quote me correctly. I said I was not going to talk about it; I was going to talk about therapeutic goods, which is the subject of the Bill before the chamber.

—That is exactly what I said. I said that he was not going to talk about it, that he was going to talk about therapeutic goods. I do not care whether he talks about therapeutic goods. I do not care whether he talks about any other health issue. I do not care whether he talks about his own portfolio as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The situation is that in every second reading debate those opposite ought to be talking about the unemployment problem we have because that is the major issue Australia is facing. At the moment in Tasmania—the Minister's State—youth unemployment has gone from 9.2 per cent to 11.3 per cent.
—In one year.

—In one year. I cannot believe that the Minister is not concerned enough to pick up something out of this and give us a response on the concern he might have for all these young people. We have 33 per cent unemployment amongst the youth in Tasmania; it is 31 per cent in the rest of Australia. That is really quite appalling. The Bill before us needs amending, as Senator Patterson has already said. I will be supporting the amendments moved by the Opposition and I sincerely hope the Minister will take up my concerns on unemployment.

—Senator Lees has already indicated that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991. I take this opportunity to make a few brief comments regarding the administration so far of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, particularly in relation to a case that has come to my attention in my home State of Queensland. The case concerns a couple who run a small herb farm on the Sunshine Coast. They have spent many years building up a small business which grows and sells herbs often used in natural remedies. Recently, these people have been prosecuted for breaching the Therapeutic Goods Act by allegedly selling herbs which, according to the labels, had therapeutic properties.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to go into whether this is right or wrong under the terms of the Act, but I want to make a few comments about the way the case has been handled. The herb growers made the mistake of relying on their local Federal House of Representatives member to inform them of when the Bill was to passed, but it was not until many months afterwards that they found out it actually had been passed. They then made many attempts by phone, and in writing, to find out how the new Act would affect their business, particularly in light of the new labelling information and the claims that could be legally made by them on their herb labels.

While they were trying to find this out, they were visited in May by a Queensland health inspector who said they had contravened the 1982 Queensland Therapeutic Goods Act over labelling claims of a herb. The herbalists then wrote to the Queensland Health Department to try to find out what was in the Queensland Act as compared with the Federal Act. They submitted their herb labels for inspection to see whether they complied with the Act. Months later, in September, a reply finally arrived in the form of a summons to appear in court. After that, in October, another reply was received which referred them to Canberra if they wanted information on how to correctly label their herbs.

To this date, the matter has still not been resolved and these people are still not clear on what they now can or cannot say on their labels. They believe they have been unfairly treated. They believe they have been singled out because, like many others, they used their democratic right to express an opinion to their parliamentarians against the introduction of this Therapeutic Goods Act. They can see that many other herb growers and sellers who did not object to the Act, and who were known to them before it was introduced, seem to have escaped prosecution despite using the same labels. That is the problem: they are identical labels. Some people have been prosecuted and some have not.

Despite numerous attempts to find out how the Act affected them, and despite every effort to get information so they could comply with the law, they believe they have been thwarted by bureaucratic inefficiency and buck-passing. It seems to me to be rather pointless to pass a Bill and then not to make every effort to inform the people who are most affected, especially when those people themselves take measures to seek out that information.

I am concerned about their claims that the majority of people who spoke out against this Act seem to have had some action taken against them. I assure the Senate that these people are trying to comply with the Act and need some further assistance. I hope that the Therapeutic Goods Commission, which administers this Act, clarifies or improves its efforts in distributing the information that it is supposed to distribute. I hope that, through cooperation, compliance will be encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991. I am delighted to see it before the Parliament because I think much of its contents are well overdue. The report put down by Professor Peter Baume covers so many of the aspects for which people in Australia have been waiting for so long.

PARA.TAB: There has been enormous difficulty in getting approval for use in Australia of many drugs that have been used overseas very successfully over a long period for the treatment of a wide variety of illnesses. This legislation will ensure that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee does not engage in long and drawn out procedures. This is one of the most encouraging results of Professor Baume's report.

There has been a need for the Australian system to accommodate more rapidly drugs that have been used overseas, even drugs that are not necessarily lifesaving but do provide a better quality of life for many patients. I just cite two drugs that are used in areas with which I have been involved for quite some time.

Chelation therapy has been used extensively overseas for the treatment of many circulatory problems. In fact, a number of countries in Europe will not allow people to undergo procedures such as coronary bypass operations without taking a course of chelation therapy. In years gone by, chelation therapy has been regarded as very much an alternative medical procedure. Yet, in overseas countries it has led to a lessening of demand for surgical treatment.

Quite frankly, if I were confronted with the need for bypass surgery, I am sure that I would prefer to have the option of having a drug available to me that had the possibility of delaying, if not totally avoiding, surgical procedure. While chelation therapy has been used very successfully in New Zealand, it is not allowed in Australia. In New Zealand, in fact, the private health insurance companies have actually allowed people to insure for this procedure.

Here in Australia we have had a very different set of circumstances. Although two or three years ago people were readily able to receive various forms of this treatment, they were unable to make a claim on Medicare or private health insurance. All that people are asking is for the drug to be made readily available for them on an ongoing basis even if they had to pay for it themselves. Quite often, a course of treatment might cost a person about $1,200.

People should be allowed to choose. Not only would this procedure be of benefit to the individual concerned but also all taxpayers would benefit if there were less demand for people to go into hospital for surgical procedures. When one considers that this type of treatment can be undertaken in a doctor's surgery for maybe two or three hours over about 12 weeks, that it keeps people off waiting lists and that it keeps people out of hospitals, surely the cost advantage for Australia is far greater than putting a handful of ball-bearings under the feet of everyone who tries to get the drug approved?

I have been able to ascertain from ADEC, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and any other authority, that a number of years ago a drug used in this procedure proved to have some deleterious side effects and that, in about 1945, a death occurred as a consequence of its use. This is quite ironic. It is amazing to think that the overuse, the wrong prescription of a drug, in 1945 is still being cited to me as a reason why this drug has not been approved here for use in the treatment of circulatory problems. Yet, the only way that many people, including children, are treated in Australia for lead poisoning is by chelation therapy. So therein lies the real contradiction: a drug can be approved for therapy for one illness and yet not for the wider illness.

Constituents who have been on the verge of facing major surgery have written to me and talked to me about this matter. Some of these people are facing amputation of limbs because poor circulation has led to gangrene in their extremities. They are now leading full and active lives as a result of receiving chelation therapy.

Another aspect of the stalling by ADEC is that if that treatment had been more readily available for a lot of people it would have also kept them off sickness benefits, it would have kept them off unemployment benefit and it would have allowed them to get back to living full and active lives without being a demand on the community in general. We must look at the availability of those drugs. I certainly hope that this legislation will enable action to be taken in this area.

One of the other things that we have been active in pursuing—and Senator Jones has also been involved in this—is the use of the oestrogen patch which is a very good source of treatment for menopause. One of the worst side effects of menopause is osteoporosis. While the oestrogen patch has been approved in 31 countries, once again ADEC has been dragging the chain here in the approval stakes.

One of the reasons cited for this delay was the marketing details provided by the manufacturer, Ciba-Geigy. It is claimed that the manufacturer's information was only suitable for European countries. Yet once again, one can go across the Tasman and get this product freely in New Zealand. Many people cannot take other forms of medication, other forms of oral oestrogen or subderminal, the gels, the creams or whatever, because of their very bad side effects.

I have known first-hand of people who have had very serious side effects. If the patch had been available to them they would now be leading better lives. They would not have suffered broken bones, broken limbs and stress caused by illness. Once again, if we can ensure that there is ready access to these drugs and eliminate the delays that have existed in this country for so long, we will be able to improve health in this country without having to resort to surgical intervention.

I am pleased to see that agreement has been reached to cover another concern of the coalition by amending the regulations. I refer here to the importation of lifesaving drugs. We were concerned that drugs brought in by a doctor for the treatment of a patient facing a life threatening disease could be distributed widely in the community. There was no control mechanism in place to ensure that they were not, for example, put on to the black market or used for other purposes.

It is consoling to see that, under the regulations, drugs will only be dispensed on the prescription of a medical practitioner who has prescribed the drug in accordance with good medical practice. I think that will allay any fears that the community might have about crank drugs being brought in and about quackery. Let us face it, there are enough controls now on medical practitioners to ensure that they do not get caught up in that, regardless of what the patient requires.

Earlier this year in Western Australia, a lady who was terminally ill with cancer and very near the end of her life was asking for one last shot at living. She wanted access to particular drugs. It was largely through the work of her medical practitioner, her husband, the community and even the media that this lady eventually got the drugs. But, of course, it was all too late. She received the drugs only about two or three weeks before she passed away.

This legislation will allow those people to have some freedom of choice without forcing drugs on people who might consider that they are crank drugs or quackery. I am very pleased that this legislation has now come before us. I think it is well overdue. I am delighted that it is a former colleague of mine Peter Baume, now Professor Peter Baume, who has been the catalyst to this happening and to people in Australia being given a real choice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I appreciate the contributions made by Opposition and Democrat senators to the debate on this important Bill, the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1991. I believe there is general recognition that it is extremely important to the health and well-being of Australians, particularly those who are suffering from painful or debilitating illnesses, that drug evaluation in Australia be carried out in a way which, whilst taking due cautionary and precautionary measures to ensure the safety of therapeutic goods available within Australia, makes such goods available in a timely way to alleviate pain and distress and perhaps help effect a cure and speed up the healing process for those who are stricken with an illness or subjected to some traumatic accident or other acute situation.

PARA.TAB: The Government acknowledges that Professor Peter Baume, a former colleague in this place, in his report on the future of drug evaluation in Australia, has come up with a very well-balanced approach to timeliness and safety. The Government also acknowledges some of the very practical suggestions he has made: for example, as an encouragement to the Therapeutic Goods Administration, to require government funding to be subject to a monetary penalty if certain evaluations are not carried out according to a set timetable. In these ways I believe he has—and the Government accepts—indicated a way in which applications can, and ought to, be processed. Incentives are built in to ensure that that process is undertaken as speedily as possible.

Senators from all parts of the chamber have pointed to the fact that when people are confronting the certainty of death and have a terminal or life threatening illness special provision clearly ought to be made to help them psychologically face that prospect by giving them the assurance that virtually whatever they wish, by way of the administration of a drug of which they have learnt, can be undertaken. I think Senator Lees emphasised that the voluntary subjection of people confronting death to treatment by a particular drug or therapeutic process may not have any great beneficial impact on their own situation but is recognised as being part of the clinical evidence and history which might, together with treatments administered to others, constitute a reference point for the evaluation of that drug and, hence, lead to a better situation in the future for others suffering the same or similar diseases. I think there are very good reasons for the type of process which is being implemented by this amending Bill, and therefore I am not surprised that it has received such support around the chamber.

During the debate, Senator Patterson raised the matter of a company which imports goods, has had those drugs registered under the grandfather clause and now wishes to re-export those goods. The Act says that the exported goods must meet the same standards as locally supplied drugs, and therefore they are required to be evaluated. The company is complaining of delays in that evaluation process. The Act does recognise and require that the same standards should be applied to exported goods as to those available in Australia. It is very important to preserve Australia's reputation as a supplier of therapeutic goods overseas, and it is important as a matter of moral principle that we do not export therapeutic goods which do not meet the minimum required standards within the Australian community.

I am advised that the Therapeutic Goods Authority is making every effort to expedite the evaluation but that other priorities have intervened, such as the approval of new AIDS drugs. As honourable senators will know, DDI was only cleared on about 6 December, following a meeting of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. It is most unfortunate that this matter has been delayed in the way in which Senator Patterson has indicated, but I will undertake to ensure that the further representations she has made during the debate are relayed to both the office of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and that of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Simon Crean), quite apart from the officials in the chamber who have heard Senator Patterson reinforce those representations.

I think Senator Patterson also raised the forfeiture of the 25 per cent evaluation fee if the program is not adhered to in a timely manner and was querying whether that was sufficient as an incentive. I understand that in the Baume report there is a recommendation that from 1 September 1992, if the TGA fails to meet an evaluation deadline, the normal process may be bypassed and an appeal made direct to the AAT. I am advised that the Government intends to accept that recommendation, so there will be further incentive and process built in to ensure that the evaluation timetables are adhered to.

Another matter raised by Senator Patterson in the debate was the supply of benemid, or probenecid, in Australia. I understand that probenecid is a drug used in the treatment of gout—hence Senator Patterson's interest—and also to potentiate the action of certain antibiotics. The drug has been available in Australia for over 30 years and was manufactured in Australia by Merck, Sharp and Dohme. Recently, the company has experienced problems with the manufacturing process of the approved Australian formulation of the drug. This has resulted in the removal by the company of the Australian formulation from the market as its quality and efficacy could no longer be assured. As an interim measure, the Department has approved the importation of several batches of the same formulation of the drug from the United States pending resolution of the problem.

Initially, the parent company in the United States had been unable to fully satisfy demand, and shortages have therefore arisen. However, the company has recently identified additional batches for importation, which should overcome the supply problem. The company in Australia also manufactures a different formulation of the drug for export to New Zealand. This formulation has not been evaluated in Australia and its quality, safety and efficacy cannot be guaranteed. Supply of such an unapproved drug by a company in Australia would constitute an offence under the Therapeutic Goods Act. Under the personal import arrangements, the Act provides that an individual may obtain supplies of this unapproved drug from an overseas source at his or her own risk. In many instances, other drugs available on the Australian market can be used by doctors in place of probenecid. Senator Knowles spoke about the oestrogen patch—or is it estraderm?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the oestrogen patch on the skin. Estraderm is its registered name.

—It is a patch on the skin, hence it is called estraderm. The estraderm patch is now registered. The company is unable to supply an Australia-specific patch but hopes to launch the product in March or April of 1992. Patients are being supplied in the interim by IPU, the individual patient usage program. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of points that Senator Tate referred to in his reply to my speech. I am glad that we were not talking about patches for ostriches but instead ended up talking about oestrogen patches. Senator Tate gave me two replies, one of which concerned Benemid. I do not think that that response satisfies my query, but I will take it back and look at it in more detail and follow up with him if I still have some concern, which I believe I do.

PARA.TAB: The other response concerned a company to which I referred in my speech at the second reading stage. My query did not involve the problem that Senator Tate outlined. There are two problems; one concerns imports and the other exports. With regard to imports, the company is concerned that therapeutic goods are being grandfathered and are not being subjected to good manufacturing practice standards and that, therefore, the company's manufactured products are competing with imports that are of a potentially lower standard because they have not been subjected to as good a manufacturing process as the one it has. So the company is losing to a cheaper import. Further, the requirements for labelling are such that it is affecting forward orders for exports.

The point is that, whatever the problem, it ought to be resolved if it can be. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, if it can be resolved appropriately it should be, without silly comments about making peace with the Minister and so on. I appreciate Senator Tate's assurances—I find that they may be trusted a little more than those of his colleague Mr Staples—that something will be done to address this problem because, if it is not, more jobs will be lost in that company and it will not have that investment. At 11.30 a.m. we found that the unemployment figure had risen from 10.1 per cent to 10.5 per cent. We cannot afford to lose one job in one company in Australia. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, lines 1 to 6, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "3. Section 4 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:

`4. The object of this Act is to provide, so far as the Constitution permits, for the establishment and maintenance of a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety, efficacy and timely availability of therapeutic goods that are:
(a)used in Australia, whether those goods are produced in Australia or elsewhere; or

SPEECH.PARA: (b)exported from Australia.'.".

This first amendment relates to the objects of the Therapeutic Goods Act. As I mentioned at length in the second reading debate, there was a need for balance between timely availability and safety. I gave the example of thalidomide. For too long the emphasis has been on safety alone. This has been at the expense of the availability of new and unapproved drugs. I gave the example of timely availability with slow release morphine and how it took 10 years for Australia to approve that measure. Britain approved it in 1981 and nine years later Australia got around to doing something about it.

PARA.TAB: Professor Baume, in his report into drug evaluation in Australia, recommended an amendment to the Act to include timely availability in the objectives. The problem the Opposition has with regard to clause 3 of the Bill is that it relegates the objective of timely availability behind the objectives of ensuring quality, safety and efficacy. The amendment I have moved on behalf of the Opposition relates to bringing into effect the true intentions of the Baume recommendations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the first amendment. It makes the Bill a little clearer. One wonders why the provision was abbreviated in the first place. However, we will not be supporting the second amendment, but we will discuss that later.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the first amendment put forward by the Opposition adopts the precise words used by our former colleague Professor Peter Baume. The Government can certainly accept this amendment as we believe that it quite properly puts the case for this Act having its objective set out in a clear way for the guidance of the Therapeutic Goods Authority and to establish the Parliament's will in the matter that the objective of the Act is to provide for the establishment and maintenance of a national system of controls relating to the quality, safety, efficacy and timely availability of therapeutic goods. It then goes on to refer to domestic or export purposes.

PARA.TAB: I believe that that is a good and adequate expression of the intention of the Parliament in the passage of this Bill. So I believe that particular objects clause ought to be accepted. I will wait for the second amendment to be put by the Opposition before commenting on it.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 10, page 4, subclause (2), lines 29 to 32, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) The amendment made by subsection (1) does not apply to applications made under section 23 of the Principal Act before the commencement of this Act.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment removes the retrospective element from clause 10 of the Bill. The clause sets out the circumstances under which an application for registration of a therapeutic good lapses. Circumstances may include where some part of the application fee is due or an application contains inaccurate or misleading information. Subclause 10(2) states that subsection (1) applies to applications made before the commencement of this Bill as well as for applications after the commencement. This introduces a retrospective sanction for existing applications. I understand that prior to this amendment a financial penalty applied in circumstances outlined in section 24 of the principal Act.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Senate's attention to the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which met yesterday morning. In the report of that meeting, Committee members drew attention to the retrospective nature of this clause and how it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. I believe that the Australian Democrats have an alternative interpretation of that. I am interested to hear what they have to say. In any case, I move that amendment in the name of the Opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Minister a couple of questions on this amendment. Firstly, it is my understanding—and I stand to be corrected on this point—that this retrospective element does not in any way apply to fines or penalties. Is that correct?
—I am advised that that is correct.

—So basically we are making sure that any application that has inaccurate or misleading information will lapse and, to look at the Bill itself, if information that has been given to the secretary on behalf of the applicant in connection with the application, including information given for the purposes of a requirement, is inaccurate or misleading, the application will lapse. If this is correct, the Australian Democrats believe that it is perfectly right and proper. Indeed, we wonder why it was not in the Bill in the first place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that, on advice from officials who have a responsibility to a Minister in another place, the Government is willing to accept the amendment which, as I am advised, relates to the lapsing of applications which contain information which is inaccurate or misleading in a material particular.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, the officials have considered the comments of the members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the case put by the Opposition. They had a chance to discuss this with Opposition senators yesterday and have concluded that they can accept, on behalf of the Minister and the Department, this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say finally that it is our understanding and my advice that if an application under the old rules was misleading it will now stay in place. So therefore the Australian Democrats wish to strongly state that we will be opposing this amendment. We do not want applications to stay in place if they are misleading.

—We actually gave the Department these amendments in time for it to consider the matter. I do not have all of the legal ammunition behind me to evaluate this but, with the advice of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Department, I am not of a mind to withdraw that amendment and will continue with it. I expect the Department has given it absolute and due consideration and has taken into consideration the concerns of the Democrats. If not, I think it should have done so, given the fact that it had that advice. We are going ahead with that amendment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Aulich)—Minister, am I to understand that you are accepting the amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am accepting the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! We now move to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.
