TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a statement that AIDC had made a profit of $9.6m, which it could keep—which was contained in his statement on employment last month—when the day before he made that statement it was announced that AIDC Ltd, the operating subsidiary of AIDC, had in fact made a loss of $8.8m, prompted me to take a more thorough look at the accounts of both AIDC, the corporation, and AIDC Ltd, the operating company.

PARA.TAB: When I read the Prime Minister's statement and I had seen the announcement of the loss of AIDC Ltd it seemed to me then—and I still believe now—that the Prime Minister had misled the Australian people by making them believe AIDC, which is clearly meant to be a tool of industry policy, had in fact failed. A closer look at the consolidated accounts of AIDC shows that it had an operating loss of $30.6m, with AIDC Ltd itself having an operating loss of $32.9m. Those figures come down to $8.9m and $9.9m respectively when a figure for tax credits—being both for losses and imputed dividends—is set off against those operating losses. That practice is fine so long as at some stage it is anticipated that there will be profits made against which those tax credits can be used.

The most important thing that the Prime Minister said on 14 November concerning AIDC was that he intended to extend the Commonwealth guarantee for loans and other obligations that AIDC enters into, including itself giving guarantees and indemnities, from 1994 to 1998. That, in turn, prompts the question: if that had not been done, would AIDC as a group and AIDC Ltd, in particular, have been viable? If it had been left to the market, would it have failed? In this particular recessionary time, the facility of a government guarantee gives an enormous advantage in terms of borrowings to AIDC, which in turn passes on that benefit to AIDC Ltd for a very small consideration of a service fee.

In terms of accountability, other exceedingly important questions are raised. The first of these relates to how the accounts deal with contingent liabilities and commitments, because no provision is made for contingent liabilities and commitments. These are dealt with in note 25 of the AIDC report, which was tabled in this place the other day. I think it is quite significant that these accounts were signed in September, yet only in December did we finally see them. How convenient it was for the Government that this annual report was tabled a long time after the statement of the Prime Minister on 14 November.

Note 25 includes the financial statements of AIDC's consolidated accounts. A provision is made for contingent liabilities for guarantees and credit risk facilities—there is a statement that these exist—of $433.7m and for commitments for loans and investments committed but undrawn of $318m. These figures started out at $943m and $883m, respectively, but they have become smaller figures because a portion of those risks have been syndicated among the banks.
Going to further notes in the accounts, specifically note 1j, one finds to one's concern, in terms of accountability, that:

SPEECH.PARA: Contingent liabilities arising from guarantees and credit risk facilities provided as part of lending and financial services activities are recorded off balance sheet.

In other words, there is no accountability for those items at all. The only provision that is made for doubtful debts is a provision of $129m in note 10. The $129m provision relates to those things which are on balance sheets. However, again if one has a look at note 9, one will find that shares have not been written down fully to the market value. At every turn, one finds that in terms of accountability a great number of things are left to be desired.

PARA.TAB: The AIDC does not come before Senate Estimates committees. I say here and now that it should. It does not come before Estimates committees presumably on the basis that it does not have funds appropriated for it. Yet if one goes back to the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in 1988 when the principal Act was altered, one will find that the Minister said—to paraphrase what is meant—that AIDC is to remain a tool of industry policy and the preferred option would be for additional capital to be provided to AIDC out of Consolidated Revenue.

The budgetary restriction simply did not allow that to occur. So the Government went through the course of allowing up to 30 per cent of the shares in AIDC Ltd to be sold to the private sector. Of course, about 19 per cent of the share capital has been taken up in that way. But the Minister says that at no time ought this to be taken as an intention to privatise AIDC. So the intention is clearly always to have it a public entity.

Even though no funds are appropriated to the AIDC by way of the Appropriation Bills, nonetheless the fact that Consolidated Revenue is exposed in an unlimited way by way of the Commonwealth's guarantee clearly means that the AIDC should come before the Estimates committees.

In 1989 a provision was made that with regard to borrowings, as distinct from other obligations, the Commonwealth guarantee would operate only in the event that the Chief Executive made a note at the time of the transaction that the guarantee would operate. I do not think one has to be very smart to realise that any person who is in a transaction with the AIDC would insist that the Chief Executive made such a determination. Yet nowhere in the accounts do we see any mention or listing of those transactions where such a determination has been made, and it must be made in writing.

One gets further concerned when one looks at a report that was in the West Australian yesterday concerning Dayton Plaza, a building which has been finished in Perth. It is totally and utterly empty. There is presently a vacancy rate of 18 per cent for office blocks in Perth, with a likely rise to 25 per cent next year. Yet the AIDC has a first mortgage to the tune of $45.8m and the value of the building has been written down from $73.5m to $43m. In its own annual report, the AIDC sets out quite clearly what its charter is, how it is meant to operate and where priorities are meant to go. Buildings in CBDs are not one of them.
Section 6 of the enabling legislation sets out quite clearly what the AIDC is meant to do. Section 6 says basically that the functions of the Corporation are:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to facilitate and encourage, and to facilitate participation by Australian residents and enterprises in, the establishment, development and advancement of Australian industries . . .

It then says that priority in the performance of this function shall be with regard to manufacture, assembly, construction, processing, treatment, transportation or distribution of goods. It further provides for the provision of services in the tourism industry, where indeed they are likely to become subject to competition. Then it refers to industries concerned with technology and research leading to such development.

PARA.TAB: One wonders whether, if one were able to have a look at the investment portfolio of AIDC, how many other Dayton Plazas one might see. And where is the provision in the accounts for the writing down of the value of those investments?

In other words, the important point I want to make is that there is not sufficient scrutiny by the Parliament of a body which is clearly meant to be used as a tool of industry policy by the Government. A decision has been made to extend the guarantee to 1998. Bear in mind that that is the date at which transactions are entered into, not at which they terminate. So, in fact, transactions entered into prior to 1998 can go well into the next century.

One could well say that the contingency liabilities, which are shown as a large sum, will never be subject to scrutiny and that any payments that are made pursuant to those guarantees or indemnities are never going to be disclosed and certainly will never be known by this Parliament. Either AIDC Ltd is meant to be an operating company which can stand alone and which perhaps ought to apply for a banking licence and come under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank and get out of equity investment, or it should continue the course it is on now and stay in equity investment. But it is simply not viable unless it receives the guarantee by the Government, which in turn exposes Consolidated Revenue in a way which is not subject to accountability and in which no quantity or quantum can be made.

The function that government has entered into of corporatising entities and pushing them away from scrutiny by the Parliament is one that really has to be condemned and, indeed, I am saying here and now that when we come to the Supplementary Estimates I will be asking that officers of AIDC come before Estimates committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today on a matter of public interest which relates to the portfolio of the Minister on duty, Senator Cook. It relates to the treatment of ex-Defence Force personnel by the Civil Aviation Authority. I would like to take the Senate through a chronology of events. On 5 August 1991 my office received the first of a number of faxes from Civil Aviation Authority employees who were ex-Defence Force personnel claiming that they were being treated unfairly compared to CAA employees being made redundant and asking me to assist them to seek justice.

PARA.TAB: On 7 August Matt Abraham on ABC Radio 2CN Canberra interviewed Mr Peter Jorm of the CAA's corporate solicitors office, who said that there was a confusion over a superannuation pension and a redundancy payment in the determination which had been made. On 8 August I wrote to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and also to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and asked them why the Government was directing the Civil Aviation Authority in its determination of redundancy arrangements so as to refuse prior service with the defence forces as contributing towards continuous Commonwealth service for redundancy purposes.

On 13 August I wrote to Mr Baldwin, the Chief Executive Officer of the Civil Aviation Authority, and asked him the same question. I told him that I had written to the Ministers and that I was sure he would stand by his employees. On 13 August I wrote to all those CAA ex-Defence Force personnel who had sent faxes and indicated that I had written to the Ministers. On 16 August I received a letter from Mr Baldwin's personal assistant, Kim Brown, who said that my letter had been passed to Mr Tom Grant, the general manager of corporate employees relations, because Mr Baldwin was overseas.

On 20 August a letter of acknowledgment was received from Minister Bilney. On 10 September I received a letter from Mr Tom Grant, the managing director of CAA corporate employee relations, indicating that the redundancy decisions had been made on the redundancy in Australian government employment, or RAGE, guidelines. They said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provided that . . . service with the former employer was not terminated because of voluntary retirement at or above the minimum retirement age applicable to the employee. Receipt of retirement benefits is a conclusive indication of retirement.
He said that this provision had not been written into the CAA award, but that the CAA was bound by government policy.

PARA.TAB: On 19 September I received a letter from Minister Bilney indicating that the matter fell within the portfolio of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, and that he would refer the matter to him. Of course, I had already written to Minister Cook six weeks previously. On 22 October I wrote again to Minister Cook asking him why I had not received a response, or even an acknowledgment, to my letter of early August or to the letter that was referred to him by Minister Bilney. On 22 October I wrote to all the ex-Defence Force CAA members indicating that I had not yet received a response from Minister Cook. On 7 November I received a letter from Minister Cook indicating that a response had been delayed pending consideration by the Industrial Relations Commission of the section 115 certified agreement between CAA and the unions. He said that these negotiations had not been completed. He said that as a matter of priority he would finalise the matter and expected to write to me within the next day.

On 7 November I placed parliamentary questions on notice to the Minister for Industrial Relations asking why the Minister refused to meet with a CAA ex-Defence committee and why he did not believe military service was Commonwealth service. On 12 November Peter Jorm from the Corporate Solicitor's office at CAA faxed a letter acknowledging my questions on notice and advising me that the Minister had been avoiding EXDRAC for 10 weeks. On 19 November Peter Jorm faxed me a copy of his letter to Mr P. Lee of the Department of Industrial Relations which indicated that EXDRAC had agreed to meet with departmental officials on the basis that the Department was prepared to reconsider the basis for the present policy on redundancies for ex-Defence Force personnel.

On 29 November I received the answers to the questions which had been placed on notice. On 29 November Peter Jorm faxed me a letter indicating that both Senator Kernot and I had been provided with incorrect information from the Minister in answer to our questions. He also mentioned that the RSL, the Armed Forces Federation and EXDRAC had met with the Department of Industrial Relations which indicated that there was some prospect that they might alter their policy, but that it would be too late for those ex-Defence Force members who had been made redundant.

On 2 December my office phoned Senator Cook and asked him why he had still not responded to my letters, even though he had said on 7 November that he would do so the next day. On 2 December I wrote to all the EXDRAC members sending them a copy of answers to questions on notice and saying that I would pursue the matter further. On 2 December I asked Peter Jorm to provide comments to the Minister's answers to questions on notice. He sent back a fax with those comments; he was not satisfied.

I allege that Minister Cook has misled the Parliament by saying that EXDRAC was provided with a detailed report. To date, EXDRAC has not been provided with such a detailed report. I see that Minister Cook is now prepared to leave the chamber, although this is a serious matter which concerns the administration by him of his portfolio. I am glad to see that he is now returning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to say that if you want to raise these matters give us some notice. Do it properly, but don't ambush me. I am not going to reply on the spot.

—I am sick of responding to the Minister by polite letters which do not get answered. On 4 December I received a letter from Senator Cook saying that he was not prepared to take the matter further. I notice that Senator Cook is now leaving the chamber. Senator Cook said he was not prepared to take the matter further because of the fact that the people involved received superannuation benefits and thus had no intention of serving on in the Commonwealth employ and that, therefore, it could not be counted as Commonwealth service.

PARA.TAB: On 9 December, EXDRAC members Peter Jorm, who has Master of Education and Bachelor of Laws qualifications, and Keith Engelsman, a CAA test pilot, came to see me about the matter. They raised a number of points, the first of which was that neither of them is personally affected in the representations. Secondly, the break in Commonwealth service which is alleged by Senator Cook has never occurred for most people. They were working in the Public Service before they resigned officially from the Australian Defence Force. In some cases they were working on furlough or leave without pay from the Defence Force and they were still, in fact, officers, warrant officers or sergeants in the Australian Defence Force.

The third point made is that they are not double dipping because they receive superannuation. Their resignation and long service payments are quite different payments. Commonwealth superannuants will get these redundancy payments; Commonwealth superannuants will get their superannuation. The only difference between those who served in the Department of Defence as civilians and those who served in the Department of Defence as uniformed personnel is that when the uniformed personnel leave the Defence Force—as part of our policy of making sure it is a young and fit defence force—they acquire their superannuation entitlements at that stage. Public servants do not get theirs paid until later years.

Nevertheless, they have an entitlement to superannuation at the time they leave the Department of Defence and transfer to the CAA. The only difference between an employee of the Department of Defence and a member of the Defence Force is that one has received his or her superannuation benefit earlier than the other. Both will receive their superannuation benefits in due course. Nevertheless, the two groups of employees are treated entirely differently for redundancy purposes. The prior service of a civilian in the Department of Defence is counted for the continuation of service in the Civil Aviation Authority. The uniformed member does not have any of his service in the Defence Force counted together with his service in the CAA.

I will continue with the points that EXDRAC members made to me on 9 December. They said that Defence personnel, under the Defence Act, need to resign from the Defence Force in order to be covered under the Public Service Act. There is no other way by which they can come under the Public Service Act; they must resign from the requirements on them under the Defence Act. Other Commonwealth members can move around between departments under the same Act, namely the Public Service Act. The problem rests on the legal opinion of what is continuous service. A further point raised was that the Government's RAGE guidelines, to which I referred earlier, are not adequate for this situation or for future situations—and it is a situation which is going to be facing the Commonwealth increasingly in time to come.

The point was also raised that it could affect quite a large proportion of people when redundancies occur in government business enterprises such as Telecom. A number of technical people leave the defence forces to go into entities such as Telecom. If and when redundancies occur in Telecom, they could well be affected in the same way. I suspect that that might be part of Senator Cook's reason for delay on this matter and for his lack of sympathy for those who came out of the Defence Force.

These people were, for instance, pilots, air traffic controllers or engineers. They were poached by the Civil Aviation Authority from the Defence Force at a time when we could ill afford to lose them from the Defence Force. They were attracted to the stability of employment that they would get in the Civil Aviation Authority. They left the defence forces with a letter in their hands offering employment from the Civil Aviation Authority. Some of them—quite a number of them, I understand—actually served out a period of furlough, or leave without pay, in the Civil Aviation Authority while still legally members of the Australian Defence Force.

In former times, women who married had to leave the permanent Public Service on their marriage. I did so a number of years ago. Those women are now able, if they come back into the Public Service, to have their prior service treated as continuous service for superannuation purposes. Yet these people who served in Australia's Defence Force are not given similar treatment.

I brought this matter before the Senate as a matter of public interest because I believe these people are being discriminated against because their pre-CAA employment was with the military rather than the civilian side of the Department of Defence. People go into bodies such as the CAA from both sides of the Defence Department.

If two workers working side by side in the Department of Defence, one uniformed and the other not, move over to the CAA, why should it be only the civilian employee who is able to count his service in the Department of Defence as Commonwealth service for redundancy purposes? As I said earlier, both will receive superannuation: the uniformed worker receives it early, by determination of a government Act; the other receives it after the age of 55. Yet the Department of Industrial Relations wants to say that the person who received the superannuation has retired and did not intend to work on further in the Commonwealth, even though, as can be demonstrated with documentation, this is clearly not the case.

I raise this in the Senate—and I am sorry that Senator Cook has left—because, despite repeated requests, these people have been unable to get a hearing from the Minister for Industrial Relations. He has rejected their requests. I also raise this issue because I understand that a review of the administrative decision was made by the people who actually made the decision. One does not normally regard that as natural justice.

I urge the Minister, although he is not in the chamber now, to take a serious and personal interest in the matter because there has been gross unfairness for the individuals concerned. I have also suggested to EXDRAC that, if it is not satisfied, it should approach the Ombudsman and ask him to investigate on its behalf. At least the Ombudsman, unlike the Opposition, has the right to go into the Department and investigate the files. The matter may end up having to be resolved in the courts, but that would be most unsatisfactory, costly and time-consuming. It would be preferable for all concerned if the matter could be resolved now.

The future retrenchment of workers in other government business enterprises is very much the nigger in the woodpile and the problem behind this issue, but I strongly urge the Government, and especially the Minister, to provide natural justice and, at the very least, a hearing to these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of crucial importance to Australia—the Government's current leadership crisis. I believe that it is appropriate at this time, with the meetings and matters of today and previous days, to have a look at the pretender to the throne, Paul Keating. Mr Keating has been described as the Grim Reaper. He has consistently used catchlines such as `good number' and `on track'. He is also the man who failed to lodge two tax returns, yet in his position as Treasurer he pursued others like a rat up a drainpipe.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the sowings that have been reaped as a result of Mr Keating's stewardship as Treasurer. First, for five quarters in a row the economy has shrunk, and it has shrunk for seven quarters out of the last eight. Our net foreign debt is of the order of $133 billion. When Paul Keating began his stewardship, it was $23 billion. More significantly, our net foreign liabilities are now in the order of $180 billion. That is the debt this country has to service.

There is no doubt that the current situation is the worst since the Great Depression. The impact that it is going to have on the confidence and attitude of people into the next decade and beyond cannot be underestimated. I want to highlight a couple of related points and refer to the destruction of the aspirations of many good Australians. I want to relate the experience that I had with my father following the Great Depression. To the day when we lost him, his decision-making regarding our financial operations was always based on the question, `Can we handle another depression?'. A generation of people made their judgments about what they were going to do bearing in mind whether they could handle a depression. In terms of investing in this country and getting on with the job of promoting growth, people's confidence has been shattered.

Let us look at some of the figures that this Grim Reaper has brought to this country. If we look at the unemployment figure released today, we see that there is an increase to 10.5 per cent—a disastrous figure for Australia, particularly for those people who cannot get a job. In my State of Western Australia the unemployment figure is some 11 per cent.

But let us look at what has happened over the last three years. In 1988-89, 535,000 people were unemployed; in 1989-90, 515,000; and in 1990-91, 713,600. As of this month, the official figures show 900,700 people are unemployed. We are well on track, unfortunately, to coming up with an official figure for the 1991-92 year of an average of one million unemployed people. It is well known, of course, that these figures do not reflect all those people who are unemployed—those unfortunate beings who are the victims of Mr Keating's policies.

Let us look at some of the other results. I have quoted to the Senate the figures in terms of the position which existed. In 1989-90, as I said, some half a million people were looking for jobs, but at that particular time there were 64,300 vacancies. The August 1991-92 figures—the latest available to me—show that, with nearly one million people unemployed, there are only 25,600 vacancies. So in August the number of vacancies was only slightly more than one-third the number in 1989-90, but the number of people unemployed was double that of 1990.

I get back to my point about confidence. People's confidence has been shattered, as is borne out by recent figures showing how investment rates have fallen off. To take this a little further in terms of jobs, in November last year there were actually 7.832 million people in the work force. In November 1991, that figure had shrunk to 7.6501 million. That means that 181,900 fewer people are working now than there were at this time last year.

Let us look at more figures in terms of what Mr Keating has wreaked on the economy of the people of Australia. Look at the great Australian dream, the dream of owning one's own home. This is a dream which, I believe, has been supported by all political parties in this country since Federation. If we look at the figures in terms of dwelling approvals, we find that in 1988-89 the figure was 186,358; in 1989-90 the annual average shrank to 140,016; in 1991 it shrank again to 126,046. That is, in 1991 there were 60,000 fewer approvals than there were just two years ago. Of course, it is a lot worse than that because one has only to drive around Perth, for example, the capital city of my State, to see house after house with `for sale' signs up. The `for sale' signs are continuing to grow in number. I saw one `for lease' sign the other day which read, `Absolutely urgent that we rent this place. We will take anything for it'. That is the impact that the Grim Reaper has had on dwellings and on that great Australian dream.

Let us look at bankruptcies, the other side of the equation. I talked about unemployment, but the other side of the equation concerns the people who are in a position to provide jobs. We find that the increase in bankruptcies has been absolutely enormous. If we look at the 1989-90 figure, we find there was an increase of 15 per cent on average in bankruptcies in Australia. We find in 1991 an increase of 53.1 per cent. We find that so far this year that has grown to in excess of 70 per cent. So we have another statistic about the policies of this man, Mr Keating, who has been touted as the next Prime Minister.

I now want to deal with the impact of interest rates on the Australian economy. Two days ago in this Senate, the former Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh acknowledged that the misuse of monetary policy has done much damage to our economy. One can start almost anywhere, but at the beginning of 1988-89 the banks' prime interest rate was 15 per cent. That gradually grew until in June 1989 it reached 19.75 per cent. In 1989-90 interest rates started off at 20.25 per cent, remained there for seven months and then came down to 18.75 per cent. There have been gradual reductions since that time, but the problem is that the damage has been done. The policies of this man, Mr Keating, have wreaked havoc not only on the businesses in the cities of Australia but also on the farm sector and the miners.

We see from the most recently released figures that the farm sector has shrunk by some 16 per cent. Much of that has been a direct result of the high interest rate policy. Operators have been forced to reduce their operations. We see that around Australia in wheat plantings, wool production, employment patterns and the various activities that lead to a strong economy.

I find it rather interesting but very alarming that Government members cannot find amongst their ranks a replacement leader who has the potential for a better track record than exists at this time. In the current recession, many people were paying prime interest rates of 25, 26 and 27 per cent as the impact of monetary policies filtered through to the banks. Even today, when the indicator rate is down significantly—thank goodness—on what it was, bank overdraft rates are still up around the 15 or 16 per cent mark, at a time when people's incomes have diminished significantly in terms of business output.
I will repeat what I said two days ago about Mr Keating when I was speaking on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: His reliance on monetary policy and his inability to recognise that there must be incentive, reward and profit in one's industrial and taxation systems should condemn him to the depths of the pits forever. His epitaph should read, `Here lies the ex-Treasurer who took Australia's unemployment and bankruptcies to record levels'.
I suggest that probably next week I am going to have to change that from `ex-Treasurer' to `ex-Prime Minister'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate—or the Acting Leader of the Acting Government in the Senate.
—Ask the question.

—Why did the Government allow Mr Keating to deliberately engineer a recession that has put a record 900,000 Australians out of work and created the worst unemployment rate in Australia since the Great Depression? What plans does the Government have to solve this human tragedy?

—Today's unemployment figures are not good. I do not deny or in any way seek to diminish the real pain they represent for working Australians and their families. I do say something about those figures, though.

PARA.TAB: First, there is an extraordinary volatility month to month in the unemployment figures, as we all ought to be well aware of by now. The figures this week show that an additional 36,000 people are unemployed. Those figures should be compared with the figures for the July-August period when 106,000 people were added to the ranks of the unemployed, or those of an earlier month when 83,000 people came off that list. The figures do jump around by quite significant margins and we are seeing just another example of that.

Secondly, it needs to be said that bad as the unemployment rate is, and I frankly acknowledge that it is, at 10.5 per cent it is still within the parameters that were predicted at the time of the Budget and that were fully debated then—the assumptions on which they were based and the policies settings on which they were based. It is our hope and expectation, as was articulated at Budget time, that there will be a pick-up in activity throughout 1991-92, bringing with it reductions in unemployment in the latter part of this financial year and, of course, subsequently throughout 1992-93.

Early signs of that pick-up are now apparent. Non-farm GDP grew by 0.4 per cent in the September quarter, as we have said in this place before, with demand growth, particularly in the export sector, being even stronger. Dwelling unit commencements data released yesterday provide further evidence that the turnaround in the housing sector is well under way. Total commencements rose 6.2 per cent in the September quarter, after rising just 2.6 per cent in the June quarter before that. Again, today's retail trade release shows that turnover rose 2.1 per cent in October, further confirming the now clearly evident sharp improvement in trend growth that began around April-May.

The policies that this Government has set in place, which I have identified throughout the course of this week—as people in debate and discussion throughout the year have before me—have put in place a recovery which will produce sustainable continuing job growth. That is a very different environment to that which we can contemplate as far as the Opposition is concerned.

Before we talk about the position of working people under the present Government, we should look at the attitude to workers' living standards that is so apparent from the Opposition's industrial relations policies. As Senator Cook has said on so many occasions, those policies would bring chaos to our industrial relations system. They would threaten workers' rights to be represented by unions; result in the abandonment of general wage increases, leaving industrially weaker workers exposed to even greater falling living standards; and halt progress in securing adequate superannuation cover.

In health policy the same attitudes prevail—those opposite would abolish bulkbilling for non-card holders, they would cause doctors' fees to rise and they would cause a $2 billion blow-out in Australia's health care bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister was asked what the Government is going to do about one million Australians out of work. He now wants to talk about the Opposition's policies or what he interprets as Opposition policy. That is beyond the question. It is out of order and I ask you to bring him to order.
—I am drawing a contrast, Mr President—
—Order! Are you speaking to the point of order?

—Speaking to the point of order: I am drawing a contrast between the Government's policies, which I am happy to further spell out, and the policies with which we are confronted. That is an entirely legitimate aspect of Question Time. It has ever been thus. I propose to continue with my answer, if you will allow me to do so.
—I believe the answer is in order up to this stage.

—I might just conclude what I was saying about the Opposition's policy. I want to concentrate particularly on the tax policy, which would take us totally backwards, re-entrenching regression and regressivity by introducing, as we all know, a savage, gouging consumption tax on all the necessities of life which would, in supposedly producing compensatory changes, target those with the lowest incomes.

PARA.TAB: I will state again what I have said about our economic strategy, because obviously I have not said it enough times this week. What we are seeking to do in our economic policy is to produce sustainable employment growth. We are not seeking to blow bubbles in the air, producing castles in the air, which will create expectations which may not then be satisfied. We are putting in place a strategy with the following elements: first, the beating of inflation—and we have beaten inflation. We have brought inflation back to 3.3 per cent. We look by contrast at an inflationary environment that the Opposition is going to create, which will result in inflation, on its own figures, of over 12 per cent in the first year of the introduction of its tax. We have pulled interest rates back—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I have drawn your attention to a ruling that you made in 1987 on a number of points. Today, I am going to draw your attention to the ruling you made on 26 November this year. In answer to a point of order I raised with you, you said:

INTERJECT.PARA: It has also been ruled consistently by me . . . that a question that invites a Minister to comment on Opposition policies is out of order, unless the question is linked to the Government's intentions or some other matter of ministerial responsibility.

Clearly, the answer is not linked to the question asked. Mr President, on this occasion I ask you to uphold your own ruling or, if you choose to find it is outside your ruling, to tell us the reasons you distinguish it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I believe that the Minister's answer, particularly the last part of his answer, was about the Government's policies. I will allow it, but I point out to Ministers that any answer that goes for 8 minutes is a long answer.

—The crucial foundations of the Government's policy are: first, beating inflation and producing results which we have already seen are way better than anything that is able to be achieved by the Opposition and are phenomenally better than the kind of inflationary blow-out we are going to see under its tax package. Secondly, to bring interest rates back within manageable dimensions—and we have already done that to the extent of a 9.5 percentage point take-off since the beginning of 1990. Thirdly, to produce a situation where wages growth is held in check by the accord, by productivity agreements of the kind that have been negotiated and put in place and which are utterly at odds with the kind of industrial relations policy of the Opposition that I have just described. Fourthly, we are talking about a fiscal policy which will maintain the structural integrity of the Budget and not produce the kinds of idiot Industry Commission figures that we have seen in the documentation produced so far by the Opposition. Fifthly, we are talking about a reduced current account deficit—

—On a point of order, Mr President: in answer to my previous point of order you told the Minister that his answer was too long. We have interpreted that comment by you in the past as inviting the Minister to sit down. When you tell a Minister that his answer is getting too long, do you mean him to interpret that as an instruction to sit down?

—Mr President, I wish to speak to that point of order. It is impossible for people simultaneously to complain about long answers, to consistently interject and to raise three points of order during the course of that answer, the last of which was by no measure raised pursuant to any standing order but was just part of a consistent tactic to try to disrupt Question Time. I do not think that anybody should be allowed consistently to get away with that.

—Order! In recent times Question Time has degenerated because of a number of issues: firstly, by long answers by Ministers, going far beyond the normal time; secondly, by repeated points of order, the vast majority of which are not points of order at all; and, thirdly, by consistent interjections, which amounts to contempt of the Chair when senators do not stop when I ask them to. I ask everybody to try to make Question Time what it used to be.

—Mr President, I will bring this answer rapidly to a conclusion. The fifth and final general element in our economic strategy is to reduce the current account deficit and, thereby, to stabilise the external debt. They are the five basic pillars of macro-economic policy. The general objectives which underlie the application of each of those instruments and seek to produce each of those results are, first, the objective of keeping demand growth below production growth, thus enabling us to lock in inflation and to lock in the gains which we have achieved in the current account deficit reduction; and, secondly, through a combination of industry policy and micro-economic reform policy, to produce an economic environment which is productive, competitive, efficient and flexible. That is the kind of economic strategy we have. We make no apology for it. We have fully described it. The environment which we confront internationally and in terms of the drought has created transient, temporary, short term difficulties. We are getting our way out of those difficulties.
—I rise on a point of order—
—There is no justification whatsoever for the embalmed lady or anyone else in this place to take exception to what I have said.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Does the Minister believe that he is immune from the Standing Orders and can take no notice of you? Ought we to bring a garbage can and put it in the middle of the floor and pitch the Standing Orders into it? Have we no order at all? Mr President, would you give us some guidelines as to what your rulings mean?

—Mr President, I wish to speak to that point of order. I point out two things: first, that was the fourth point of order during this answer; secondly, we did not, as we should have, raise a point of order when you were on your feet, Mr President, making a ruling and Senator Bishop was then interjecting on you, which was most disorderly. We did not do that, to try to progress Question Time. Senator Baume asked a serious question; I acknowledge that. From the nature of the question that Senator Baume asked, I thought that he wanted a long and detailed response.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that disgraceful response, which deliberately set out to corrupt Question Time and took over 10 minutes. I thank him particularly for that element of his response—
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Question Time is for asking questions; what we have from Senator Baume is a speech. That is out of order.
—You are a fool; you are a fraud.

—For senators opposite to complain about the Government making speeches or debating the question and then doing the same ill behoves them and is hypocritical. Mr President, I ask you to make Senator Baume ask a question or to sit him down.
—Before we get to that point, I ask Senator Baume to withdraw his interjection against Senator Cook.
—I genuinely ask: is it the fool or the fraud bit you want me to withdraw?
—Order! Senator Baume, withdraw.
—I withdraw. Now if I may proceed with my supplementary question—
—I suggest you ask the supplementary.

—I thank the Minister for his assertion that policies are in place for continuing job growth, presumably at the rate of minus 90,000 a month, which we have seen in the latest statistics. What hope do these policies provide to the almost 200,000 young Australian school leavers now facing a market where there is a worst ever 31 per cent of under-20s who cannot find full time work?

—I have described the grounds for optimism which presently exist in the economy. If Senator Baume wants me to repeat those in the length and detail that I did during my answer, I will be very happy to oblige him, but I do not think that would be very satisfactory in the terms of your ruling, Mr President.

PARA.TAB: The signs are there and the predictions were there in the Budget. They were debated. All of this has been put on the record. It is nothing new. It is an unhappy situation, as I frankly acknowledge, but it is not one that the Opposition or its policy package will do anything remotely to improve. That is the bottom line of the Government's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security explain to the Senate why the Government decided to impose a liquid assets test on Jobsearch allowance? Is the Minister aware of proposals to make the test tougher? Has the Government considered such an action?
—It is now 14 minutes to three.

—I thank Senator Macdonald for pointing out the time to me; I am conscious of it. I am asked about the liquid assets test. Honourable senators might recall that in last year's February statement the Government announced that it was to impose a liquid assets test for Jobsearch allowance. It is $10,000 for those with dependants and $5,000 for single people. Obviously, in setting that amount, the Government took its time and considered quite a number of levels. Obviously, we can make a level as harsh or as lenient as we like. Once we chose that level we decided that people would have to wait for four weeks if they had sums in excess of those amounts. That is a reasonable thing, given that there ought to be a responsibility on the part of people in so far as it is possible to look after themselves.

PARA.TAB: Immediately after that announcement, and since the onset of the recession, we had continual representations from the welfare sector to suggest that that was too hard and too tough. The Government has, however, maintained the figure and has no intention of changing it. I am aware that there have been suggestions in recent times—in particular from the coalition in the consumption tax package—that that four-week waiting period ought to be vastly extended, that in some way that was far too weak, not tough enough, and that it needed to be tightened very considerably.

The reason the Government will not consider tightening the waiting period further is best done by example. If a 54-year-old production worker—married, with three children —lost his job, after 20 years service he might get as much as $50,000. It might be said that that is a fair bit of money. Under the proposal that the Government will not adopt, one would not get any help from the Government for 101 weeks. For just on two years, one would be expected to exhaust every single cent that that $50,000 represented. That $50,000 represents hope and some kind of future.

Under a proposal such as this, every single cent is wiped out for just on two years. That is not a matter of being tough or targeting beyond this, because I have to concede that it does target something. It targets any Australian put out of work during the recession for another mean and vicious test. It makes certain that people are not having to wait just four weeks but years. Even if we use the Opposition's example of someone who gets $15,000 upon termination, one has to wait six months—25 weeks. That is not targeting.

If people ask questions about the increases in unemployment that have been announced today, I hope they understand in asking those questions that the only prescription they give for those people who are unemployed is further misery—the kind of misery and straight-out destitution that that kind of liquid assets test demands and imposes. We will not be doing that. The Government will not be adopting the kind of nonsense that is entailed in making someone who is in his or her fifties wait two full years to get unemployment benefit. That is the kind of misery that this Government will never impose and to which it will never agree.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given the continuing recession, plus today's increase in the unemployment figures—which will be swelled further by 190,000 school-leavers who are not going on to tertiary education—is not the Minister concerned by the paralysis of the Government and its lack of effective policy to deal with unemployment? Is it not time for the Labor Party to settle the leadership crisis so that the Government can get back to the job of governing the country; the Prime Minister can be put out of his misery; and, far more importantly, the misery of Australians can be addressed properly by the Government? Does the Minister believe that the Australian electorate will have difficulty in accepting that the man who created the unemployment crisis—Paul Keating—can now effectively fix it?

—On this question, or any other questions that might be asked upon this subject, I say just this: in the near decade that Prime Minister Bob Hawke has been in office he has made a very proud contribution to the life, character and prosperity of this nation. He has made a very profound contribution to the reputation of this nation. That is not a contribution that is going to be diminished in any way by the kind of criticism that is presently being mounted against him. I express my full confidence in the Prime Minister and beyond that I have no comment whatsoever to make.

—I ask the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia whether the claims made in Question Time yesterday by Senators Baume and Macdonald that he did not take the removal of fuel excise into account in his calculation of Northern Territory electricity charges are correct? I also ask whether the claims that air-conditioners, refrigerators and whitegoods will be cheaper in northern Australia under coalition policy are correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Baume said that I had not taken the removal of excise on fuel into account when I had calculated the horrendous additional burden that northern Australians are going to have to pay for electricity. I pointed out yesterday—and I have to say that Senator Tambling, on a radio debate with me this morning in the Northern Territory, had to concede it—that territorians will be paying somewhere between $70 and $100 a year more in Federal taxation on their domestic electricity accounts.
—Senator Tambling said this?

—Senator Tambling conceded this morning on ABC Radio that territorians will have to pay between $70 and $100 a year more in Federal taxes on the same amount of electricity that is used by consumers in New South Wales. An accountant in the Northern Territory has a good slogan for his business, which is: `If you need advice ask a local'.

PARA.TAB: We stopped using diesel fuel to generate electricity in the Northern Territory about five years ago. Now, 95 per cent of our power is generated, thank goodness, from our own indigenous gas supplies. I would like to give credit to the former conservative Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Ian Tuxworth, for his far-sighted decision in building that pipeline from Alice Springs to Darwin.

I can tell Senator Baume: we do not pay excise on our fuel. The Power and Water Authority in the Northern Territory pays a total of $5m a year in excise on diesel fuel. If it was fully passed on to consumers it would cut their electricity costs by—wait for it—$13 a year. However, that will not be passed on because the Power and Water Authority in the Northern Territory has never made a profit; it loses $90m a year, and—Darwin is unique in this respect—it is subsidised by Federal Government subsidies for that loss. So it will not be passed on.

In answer to the second part of the question, Senator Macdonald was making the point that these items, which consume an enormous amount of electricity in northern Australia, will be cheaper under the coalition's GST tax. Yesterday, in noting my answer, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: One pays 30 per cent wholesale sales tax on refrigerators, air conditioners and other whitegoods. What will happen under the coalition's policy? That will be wiped out completely and replaced with a 15 per cent GST. So again, air conditioners will be much cheaper. Refrigerators, which are used extensively in north Queensland and northern Australia, will be that much cheaper.

I would like to refer Senator Macdonald and all honourable senators to the Australian Sales Tax Guide. Schedule 3, which deals with a 10 per cent sales tax, lists domestic air-conditioners, washing machines, refrigerators and other whitegoods. It is about time Opposition members started getting on top of their own package. The fact is that, under the GST policy, not only will they whack a huge increase on power costs, but all the items Senator Macdonald mentioned yesterday as being much cheaper will all increase the taxation by 5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate to an answer which he gave yesterday to Senator Bjelke-Petersen on the drought affecting large parts of eastern Australia. Is it not a fact that the Minister does not have to sit on the right hand of the Almighty to have known that an El Nino would cause a drought in Australia this year? Is it not a fact that the Government's policy of cuts to CSIRO have resulted directly in its inability to use information on El Nino, which became available to it in January 1991, to warn farmers that they would suffer drought and that it would be wise for them to at least save the expense of ploughing, fertilising and seeding?
—I am not up to speed on El Nino; I am not too good on sunspots, either. I will seek further information and advise the honourable senator accordingly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not expect the Minister to be able to provide answers to these questions either, but perhaps he will take them on notice. What is the estimate of the cost of the drought? What is the estimate of how much would have been saved if farmers had been given adequate warning that an El Nino would cause a severe drought in 1991? What proportion of time is now spent by project and program leaders in CSIRO departments hunting for funds and accounting for those funds which could more profitably be spent actually doing research? Will the answers to these questions not prove the absolute stupidity of the Government's policy and direction with respect to research funding in this country?
—I do not believe for a moment that the answers will demonstrate the stupidity of anyone, except conceivably the questioner, but that is probably unreasonable. I will take the questions on notice.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to UN resolution 3379, one of the darker episodes in the history of that body. Will the Australian Government support efforts at the United Nations General Assembly this year to rescind resolution 3379 which equates Zionism with racism? What position will be argued by Australia?

—Australia will support those efforts. I am sure I do not have to remind honourable senators of the consistent opposition of Australia towards resolution 3379, the so-called `Zionism is racism resolution', which was passed by the General Assembly back in 1975. Australia, of course, voted against that resolution at that time. In 1986, this Parliament was the first in the world to pass through both Houses a resolution calling for the overturning of resolution 3379. The Government has also lent a great deal of assistance to elected leaders of the Australian Jewish community in their efforts to secure support in the Asia-Pacific region to overturn the resolution.

PARA.TAB: As Foreign Minister, I have, on numerous occasions, including in addresses to the General Assembly in 1990 and again this year, pointed out that the resolution is not only wrong in itself, but also a hindrance to the peace process and should be rescinded. Therefore, I am very pleased to be able to advise the Senate that Australia has agreed to co-sponsor a resolution in this year's General Assembly to rescind resolution 3379. That initiative was announced by the United States on 3 December. A vote should be held before the end of this year's Assembly on 17 December.

As a well-known opponent of 3379, Australia has been closely consulted by the US on this initiative and we have offered to actively assist American efforts, in particular, by urging nations within our own region to support the rescinding resolution. I am sure that these efforts at least would enjoy the bipartisan support of this Parliament and, indeed, of the whole Australian community.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows his answer to my colleague Senator Olsen. I remind the Minister of his assurance to the Senate yesterday that he fully expected Mr Hawke would lead the Government to the next election. Is he still of that opinion?
—I have already answered a question on this subject. I indicated I would have no further comment of any kind on this particular issue. I restate that now.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is a matter that goes to the heart of Cabinet. I would have thought the Minister would have been prepared to answer. But I will be more specific in my supplementary: has Mr Hawke, in fact, agreed to resign?
—I said I had no further comment on any aspect of this particular subject, but certainly that is not the case.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a distinguished former President of the Senate, Sir Harold Young. I wish him well on his visit to Canberra. I assure him that the seat in the gallery at the moment is much more comfortable than the one down here.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Government have any intention of discriminating against women by restricting pension eligibility to wives of disability support pensioners?
—As recommended by Finance.

—Senator Alston, I explained yesterday that the Government often knocks back recommendations from the Department of Finance. I think that tends to prove what a fearless and independent Department it is and how unchallengeable its figures are, which have highlighted just how crook the figures of those opposite are. But in terms of the question which Senator Crowley has asked—I apologise for answering interjections; I realise they are taking up too much time—the Opposition has suggested this, but the Government will not be discriminating against women by removing the eligibility for the wives pension if they are married to disability support pensioners. I think the Senate ought to know the reasons why the Government cannot accept that kind of policy.

PARA.TAB: The personal situation of the spouses in question here, the spouses of those on disability support pensions, is really worthy of some examination. The vast majority of women who are receiving these pensions accept without complaint the burdens that are often entailed in being married to someone who cannot work.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?
—Because of the fact that they have a disability serious enough to have qualified them for the old invalid pension or for the new disability support pension.
—You know it can be token, like a 15 per cent disability.
—Senator Alston, I am asking you to cease interjecting. You are doing it persistently.

—Those spouses who are on this pension already accept a considerably reduced standard of living because of the incapacities of their husbands. Their lives are often circumscribed by the physical and other psychological conditions of their husbands. When their husbands went on to this pension, those women accepted that they would have to fetch and carry for them, transport them and often lift them. They realised that their level of selflessness had to go up and up just to maintain normal family life. That is what this suggestion seeks to break up.

PARA.TAB: It goes a bit further than that, though. I understand the Opposition certainly sometimes has the view that people on invalid pensions are habitual malingerers—that is certainly the view of Senator Alston. But it is not the view of the Government, and we cannot adopt this policy. I wonder whether those opposite or anyone else in the community has actually stopped to consider what it must be like for many of these women, and what it must be like to be married to someone who has been legitimately awarded this kind of pension—whether that incapacity or that impairment is related to physical disability or perhaps to a combination of medical and mental conditions, or whether the essential diagnosis is about paralysis or schizophrenia. One wonders what has to happen to these wives. They are expected—indeed, obliged—to be watchful, attentive, alert, and always at the ready to help.

Some have the great physical burden of lifting the incapacitated. What about those women who have to look after those with occasional or frequent incontinence? In such circumstances even simple things such as laundering become huge tasks in ordinary families. Yet for women suffering all those burdens the only offer that is being made by those who propose this new course of action is more misery. The only offer is: `We will take you off that pension because we think it is best for you'.

If I were one of the hundreds, indeed the thousands, of women who are in this situation, I would wonder just who had in mind what was best for me. I would wonder about a policy that ripped the pension off me when I had to accept a lower standard of living for years and a much heavier burden of care. I would really have to wonder at the motives of those who pushed it. I think I would come to the conclusion that their motives were as base as are the figures for savings. Their motives are wrong. Their figures are wrong. It is a wrong policy. What is more, it puts a financial burden on thousands of Australian women who are already struggling. It is unworthy.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you expect them to look for work.
—Even of Senator Alston, it is unworthy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a further question of Senator Evans in his capacity as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why will he not tell the Senate whether the Prime Minister has resigned?
—What?

—Does the Senate not have the right to know whether the Prime Minister is in office or not? Is the Government not going to be responsible to the Parliament in some way? Why is the Acting Leader of the Government refusing to answer questions on whether Mr Hawke is still Prime Minister or not?

—I do not want to contribute any further to the orgy of speculation that is going on in this place. That is why I said I did not want to enter into any comment. But at the end of my answer, just before I sat down, I said, `Of course he has not agreed to resign' and I repeat that statement now: of course he has not agreed to resign.
—So he has refused to resign.

—Why in the hell should he agree to resign in an environment where in four successive election victories he has produced in this country a reputation that stands Australia high in the world—a reputation for economic efficiency, a reputation for effective international relations, a reputation for delivering equity to the Australian community and a reputation for delivering fairness and decency to the Australian community? Why should he contemplate resignation?

PARA.TAB: If he ever chooses to do so, it will be his own decision in his own time. There is no question of any input from the Opposition that would make any difference whatsoever to the way in which we respond to this situation. I have already expressed my full confidence in the Prime Minister; I could not have made that clearer. I sit down on that basis and will not contribute further to this discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the Minister's answer, Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If that is so, why did the Minister tap the Prime Minister on the shoulder this morning?
—Mr President, that is a totally false premise. The question does not begin to get close to the truth of what is happening at the moment. I have no further comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Should the Constitution guarantee the eternal and inalienable right to organise and to act collectively, that is, a right to strike? Does the Minister agree that the exercising of this right should take precedence over other legal considerations, and that unions and their members should be exempt from civil or criminal liability for strikes or justifiable acts of dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the week I was interjected on by Senator Parer asking me to tell him about the Japanese situation. What we have just heard is a set of words that I am sure that Senator Parer does not agree with, but they are quotes from, in the first place, the Japanese Constitution and, in the second place, Japanese jurisprudence. They are, of course, constitutional provisions in Japan and the legal framework within which the practice of industrial relations in that country is worked out. To explain it further, let me go to the International Encyclopaedia for Labour Law and Industrial Relations, supplement No. 47, January 1985, and read the brief based on that description. It says:

PARA.TAB: The Japanese Constitution guarantees the right to organise and to act collectively. These provisions have been interpreted by the Japanese courts as extending beyond the right to organise, to encompass the right to bargain collectively and the right to strike.

ANSWER.PARA: The unions' exercising of this constitutional right takes precedence over other legal considerations and unions and their members are exempt from civil or criminal liability for strikes or justifiable acts of dispute. I could go on, but one of the reasons why I think this is a question that is relevant to the Australian industrial relations system is that the Opposition touts the Japanese model of industrial relations as its model. It does so because of the enterprise union structure in Japan. There are over tens of thousands of trade unions in Japan and the Opposition wishes to translate that structure into Australia. The same brief tells us what the union structure in Japan really is:
Although Japanese unions are fundamentally enterprise based—
the very point I have just made—
they do not operate independently, but co-operate on a national level under industry-based umbrella organisations and the Japan Trade Union Confederation.
It goes on to make this important point:
The industry wide union organisations or federations are key players in wages and conditions negotiations, and the policies of these organisations are reflected in individual enterprise agreements.

So what we have in Japan is industry unions with branches based on the enterprise but with their wage negotiations coordinated by the industry federation, which in turn is affiliated to the central confederation. The feature of the Opposition's package is that it simply cites the number of unions and does not explore the issue any further, as if the number of unions indicates the whole framework. It does not.

PARA.TAB: We cannot select an industrial relations framework from the Japanese experience because, obviously, culturally, traditionally and in terms of the paternalistic nature of its society, it is different from Australia. The legal structure is this: there is an inalienable right to strike as well as organise, and that right is predominant over the practice of the civil law; and Japanese unions, while numerous, are affiliated to central confederations which negotiate wages and working conditions.

I do not want to hear from the Opposition any more about the Japanese example. Our legal structure is slightly different, but what this Government is seeking to achieve is industry based unions with enterprise based branches in order to generate at the enterprise level agreements which lead to higher productivity and profitability. I think if we cease hearing examples of how many unions there are and look exactly at the whole of the structure, we will advance this debate most beneficially for us all.

My final point is that the Japanese Constitution guarantees rights. It does not deny the rights of organisations; it recognises that if a framework is created in which organisations and individuals have guaranteed rights, they will act responsibly. What we have from the Opposition is a denial of rights and the creation of a framework in which organisations and individuals will have to take action to protect themselves, which is a highly disputatious scenario. That is the scenario of the Opposition. Not only is it a policy of low wages in Australia; it is a policy of high disputation as well.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Leadership of the Australian Labor Party

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate of Senator Jim McKiernan's press release of today, which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: There are now 900,700 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia. The man who gave us the recession we had to have should not now be rewarded for his accomplishment.
In the light of Senator Evans's endorsement today of Mr Hawke, does that mean he also agrees with Senator McKiernan?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McKiernan has expressed his view; he is entitled to it. I have expressed mine.

—Under standing order 72(1), my question is directed to Senator Vallentine. Are the provisions of her Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Bill 1988 still valid? If so, does she believe that it would be to the advantage of the children of Australia if this Bill were taken up by another senator after she leaves the Senate next year?

—I thank Senator Bourne for her question. As a matter of fact, only yesterday the Australian Council for Children's Film and Television lost a case regarding television advertising in children's television programming. In July 1990, the Australian Council for Children's Film and Television asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to conduct an inquiry into whether Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles constituted advertising. The ABT's finding was that the program did not constitute advertising, revealing the ongoing relevance of this Bill.

PARA.TAB: In light of the draft broadcasting Bill of the former communications Minister, Mr Beazley, which would allow for a new broadcasting authority with greater provisions for self-regulation of the industry, and considering the ABT's current six-month review of the industry, the findings of which are due to be publicised any day now, it seems to me that this piece of legislation, attempting to deal with one aspect of television violence, is highly relevant.

There is a great deal of community concern about the level of violence, especially as far as our children are concerned. It is generally recognised that Australian children watch far too much television, and that it is a major socialising influence on their lives.

So I would welcome the reintroduction of this Bill to the Notice Paper by my replacement, Christabel Chamarette, or any other senator after my departure. The same could be said for the Peace Trust Fund Bill, which I introduced in 1989; the Defence (Conscientious Objection) Bill 1990; and the Whistleblowers Protection Bill 1991, which was introduced today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it acceptable for Ministers who no longer support their leader to stay in the ministry, or should they resign?

—Mr President, I have no idea what Senator Durack is talking about in this respect. It is news to me. Perhaps he has some intelligence about the nature of the political process that has been denied to me. Maybe he is saying something different about the way in which the Liberal Party has traditionally operated in government. I do not think so, from my recollection of that environment. I have nothing to add to my previous answers.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports that management and unions at Aerospace Technologies of Australia Aircraft Services have agreed on arrangements which will greatly enhance the productivity of this company?
—Have you swapped sides, Terry?
—Senator Walters is interrupting the question. I mention the word `productivity' and she tries to interject.
—Order! Ask the question.

—I will, and without interruption. Have they agreed on arrangements which will greatly enhance the productivity of this company? If these reports are correct, do they indicate that the Government's policy of decentralising industrial relations in a managed way is working well in important areas of industry?

—The wages system over which we have presided as a government is a wages system that is supported by the industrial parties. The Confederation of Australian Industry and the ACTU both applauded the last national wage case, which was a case that responded directly to the Government's national wage case submission.

PARA.TAB: Our wages policy enables moderate aggregate wage outcomes to be factored into the Budget and to be delivered. Therefore, it is a positive macro-economic tool. It also enables us to manage the decentralising of the centralised wage fixing system in a cooperative way. It does this in a way which features world best practice to increase productivity and efficiency of Australian industry and which ensures that there is an equitable outcome for wages across the board, including for workers who are poorly protected or who have no bargaining power. They can achieve an equitable wage outcome in our system. I might say that throughout Australia as a consequence of these settings, workers and employers are now sitting down together and sorting out the joint goals of the company, working out how to increase production, how to share the rewards between themselves fairly in profits and wages; they are coming to win/win outcomes.

Let me cite the names of some of those companies that have done that. They are household names in this country: ICI, Rheem, Daimaru, Kelloggs, Bridgestone, SPC, Hoover, ACI and Pacific Dunlop. We can add to that list of luminaries the ASTA Aircraft Services Corporation, which just this last week registered in the Industrial Relations Commission a new workplace agreement which picks up the metal trades profitability and productivity provisions and which is an agreement that sets that corporation on a path in which it will be about delivering quality and customer service at world competitive prices. It is a path that will make sure it is efficient, effective and internationally oriented.

The whole organisational focus of this company will now be changed: workers will be working in cellular working groups which will organise production into semi-autonomous teams which will perform job tasks cutting across traditional demarcations. A total quality management scheme has been introduced. Ten-hour shifts and new shift rostering arrangements have been introduced to maximise productive working hours and facilitate faster turnaround times. Wage increases of 4.5 per cent will be phased in in two stages.

Since its establishment in 1988, the number of employees has increased from 100 to 660 and the company expects to employ 1,000 by the end of next year. That is an increase in employment by virtue of the industrial relations changes in wage fixation in that company. This is one of a number of very positive stories to be told as our wage policy begins to take effect in the broader community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that the Prime Minister has been our national leader since 1983 and given all he has done for the Labor Party, why can the Minister and his dwindling supporters not find the courage to do the decent thing and save him and us from the humiliation of a dead duck leader going through the sad charade of pretending to be in charge during President Bush's visit, when all the world knows that Bob Hawke's time is finished?

—It is not a matter of the Prime Minister doing things for the Labor Party since 1983; Bob Hawke has been a great leader for this Australian nation. He will remain a great leader of this Australian nation just as long as he chooses to be in that position. He will have the support of his Government and his Ministry and he will add lustre to this nation and not diminish it in any way.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: New Zealand: Visits by Nuclear Vessels

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether it is true that the Australian Government is encouraging, or putting pressure on, the New Zealand Government to change its widely acclaimed policy banning nuclear warships from its ports, with a view to bringing New Zealand out of the freeze in terms of its status as a member of the ANZUS alliance. Have there been any meetings or consultations of any kind between the Australian and New Zealand governments on this issue since the National Party Government was elected? If so, what advice, if any, has the Australian Government given to the New Zealand Government?

—It seems to be news to Senator Vallentine, but it is no news to anyone else, that the Australian Government has had a different policy view about the appropriateness of that ship visits legislation ever since it was first enacted. We have expressed that policy view on a number of occasions, most recently in the course of my visit to New Zealand a few days ago for bilateral discussions with Mr McKinnon. I do not think there would be any surprise in anyone's mind to know that that continues to be our position.

—I direct my question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to today's unemployment figures, which show a record level of unemployment of 900,700 people—a rate of 10 1/2 per cent—which is the highest level since the Great Depression. Can the Minister assure the Australian public that when Mr Paul Keating replaces Mr Bob Hawke and becomes Prime Minister he will act to reduce this disgraceful level of unemployment, despite its having been the product of his own policies?
—I do not answer hypothetical questions.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the difference between basic cover and top table cover health insurance? Does $800 buy top cover? Can the Minister say whether basic cover allows people to have private medical treatment in private hospitals or only in public hospitals?

—I think the question that Senator Crowley is posing depends on an understanding of all the tables offered in the various insurance funds around Australia. Of course, it is these insurance funds that will be particularly manipulated and used by the Opposition in its policy to transfer hundreds of millions of dollars from the pockets of the patients who either present themselves for primary health care by their general practitioners, or find themselves, by medical necessity, required to enter a hospital.

—Senator Herron knows that the Opposition's Fightback policy says, for example, that GP consulting fees should be set after consultation between the AMA and the health insurance funds. That is just a very cosy formula to permit the doctors to enrich themselves at the expense of patients through the mechanism of insurance premiums. That is precisely what the Opposition's policy is designed to do.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, one can have no confidence in the so-called tax credits that might be offered by the Opposition in a way which it says will cover basic health insurance costs. Dr Bob Woods shows a complete lack of understanding of the real impact of the sorts of premiums required by the health insurance funds even now.

On 4 December, Dr Woods was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying that HCF provides top cover for $842 and NIB provides top cover for $860, with a small excess. What he has failed to indicate is that under those particular cover arrangements, the small excess he refers to means that in the case of NIB a person has to pay $300 up-front and in the case of HCF a person has to pay $500 up-front. For persons who require care, that is a considerable payment that Dr Woods tries to imply they will receive by way of insurance covered by tax credits. That will not be the case. The tax credits will not cover the cost of the insurance that people need to take out.
