Dr Woods has certainly not explained how one will deal with an excess payment of $300, $500 or whatever it might be, by way of an initial payment for the care that is provided.

It is quite clear that Mr Reith believes that State grants to public hospitals should be reduced by $350 per bed day. We are confronted with a situation where, as far as hospital care is concerned—particularly for private patients in public hospitals—under the Opposition policy, if the $180 ceiling on the amount that insurers can pay by way of a contribution to hospital care is maintained, the hospitals will miss out on $170 per bed day. That is a formula for the destruction of public hospitals in this country.

If the insurance companies are allowed to pay $350 per bed day, the cost of premiums will absolutely skyrocket. We will be caught in a situation where we will be asking Australians to pay a tremendous amount more by way of premiums not covered by tax credits, or the public hospital system will be destroyed. One suspects that that is the aim of the policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to elaborate in the light of that answer whether, under the Government's policy of private and public insurance, there is choice; whether the option for choice means just that; and how different it will be from the Opposition's package?

—The matter of choice is very important in this situation. Of course, those opposite do not understand that at all. They are denying to a general practitioner, for example, the opportunity to choose to offer bulkbilling to those who are not pensioners or card holders. They do so simply because they do not want any GP's practice to offer bulkbilling and compete with and undermine the AMA schedule fee of $31 per consultation. They want that to become the benchmark. They want all Australians who present themselves for primary health care from their GP to pay the full AMA schedule fee in this cosy deal, sanctioned by the Opposition, between the Australian Medical Association—the doctors' union—and the private insurers. Of course, without bulkbilling, that will be the situation confronting every person presenting at a GP's surgery, and that is an intolerable situation which this Government will certainly not emulate.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In the interests of stable government, in light of the Minister's press conference on Tuesday and, further, in light of Senator Evans's answer a few moments ago that Mr Hawke should remain in office, does Mr Hawke enjoy his continuing and unqualified support as Prime Minister?
—The leader of my Party enjoys my support.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I entitled to draw the conclusion from that answer that his usual brand of disloyalty is being applied to Mr Hawke as he applies it to other leaders ahead of him?
—The kind of conclusions that Senator MacGibbon's twisted mind might draw is a matter for him and not for me.

—I direct my question, relating to unemployment, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to page 1 of the statistics released today by the ABS on the labour force which says that full time employment fell by 90,400. Does this mean that thousands of males and females are now underemployed in the community; that therefore the amount of money families are receiving is insufficient to make ends meet; that the figures for females looking for part time work have substantially increased; and that this means that those who were forced into the paid work force because their husband's salary or wage was insufficient to make ends meet are now forced out of the paid work force? What is the Government doing to compensate them for that situation?

—It is the case that the substantial fall in full time employment is one of the unhappiest features of this month's figures. There can be some ricochet consequences of the kind that have been described by Senator Harradine. I am not sure it is appropriate to put quite such a bleak face upon those figures and that environment as Senator Harradine does, but that is a matter for his judgment.

PARA.TAB: The Government is particularly concerned, of course, to ensure that, through the social welfare safety net and the very substantial labour programs we have put in place and supplemented with additional funding in the recent Prime Minister's statement, we are doing everything possible to minimise the personal and national harm that follows from these unacceptably high levels of unemployment. If there is anything further I can add in answer to Senator Harradine's question going to some of the specific matters about part time and casual employment and the implications of these figures for that, I will be happy to do so and put down a supplementary answer.
Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I claim to have been misrepresented. During Question Time Senator Collins indicated that I had wrongly, by way of interjection, claimed that the removal of a fuel tax had no impact on the price of electricity in the Northern Territory. That was not in fact the thrust of my interjection. I refer the Minister to page 4611.
—You sound like a clapped out air-conditioner.
—If Senator Sherry would like to engage the mind before opening his mouth, he will see on page 4611 of Hansard that Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: Businesses would get a rebate every two months—
that is under the GST—
but, in terms of the imposition of a consumption tax on the cash flows of a business, they would have to think carefully.
The next remark made by Senator Collins was:
The removal of a wholesale sales tax and a payroll tax would not impact on this—
that is, the question of cash flows of businesses—
in the slightest.

At that time I challenged the Minister to include the words `the removal of excise on fuel' and I criticised him for not doing so. However, if by some curious chance the Minister believes that I was referring to the cost of generating electricity, I put it to him that I was also correct and that he was quite wrong today to dismiss my comments as false. All remote rural farmers who generate their power from excise free diesel have to face an enormous transport cost on that diesel, which emerges out of the freight paid to take it to them. The huge freight cost depends heavily on the excise price of fuel. So even if the Minister misunderstood me, he is wrong on both cases. I should not have been treated with that nonsensical aside today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I ask Senator McMullan whether he will now report to the Senate on when the House of Representatives is coming back.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Yesterday, because I had to leave the Senate before the conclusion of the very lengthy debate on defence, I gave advice to Senator Hill, as I had indicated, about the situation as I understood it. Nothing has changed since I gave that advice to Senator Hill yesterday; that is, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) advises me that the House of Representatives will definitely sit on Thursday, 19 December.
—What about Wednesday?
—Wait a minute. Would Senator Walters like me to say something about Sunday as well?
—You previously told us Wednesday.

—I actually did not, but Senator Walters can have a little hallucination about what she thinks I said, take a Bex, lie down, and I will tell her the rest. The situation is as I told Senator Hill yesterday, and as he should have told everyone else. I will tell him again. The Leader of the House told me that the House of Representatives will sit on Thursday, 19 December; if it is his view that the amount of business requires more than one day, the second day will be Wednesday, 18 December. The Leader of the House will make a final decision on Friday. As the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives require, he will advise the Speaker who will communicate with all of the members. The Leader of the House has given me the undertaking, which I gave to Senator Hill yesterday, that when he makes that decision he will convey it to Mr Fife at the same time as he conveys it to the Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) during Question Time this day, relating to unemployment benefit and disability support pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: I move this motion because the Australian public might misunderstand some of the partial statements made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). For example, he referred to the coalition's policy in relation to extension and typing of a liquid assets test and leave deferment waiting periods as somehow harsh and unconscionable and—I suppose, in his terms—inflicting more misery on people.

PARA.TAB: I refer to what has happened in Western Australia in recent times. The State Government granted a $50m voluntary redundancy package payment to public servants. Dr Lawrence, when asked whether these people would be eligible for unemployment, or JSA, said that people accepting the redundancy package would not be able to claim the dole for two years. In other words, she said it without comment because she thought it was reasonable and that is what she understood the position to be.

Dr Lawrence subsequently said that she had been confused. She said that given the complexion of those selected for redundancy she would be surprised if they went on the dole. Again, she was saying that they might technically be entitled to the dole but she could not imagine that they would be so greedy as to want to receive the dole.

In the very same article in the West Australian it is reported that a spokesman for the Department of Social Security said that the Department's benefits—meaning the State Government's—and entitlement criteria were generous. He said that the Department's financial information service had been flooded with calls from many of the 1,700 public servants wanting to know whether their redundancy pay-outs would put them outside the entitlements net.

In other words, Senator Richardson is saying that he and this Government condone public servants getting pay-outs on average of $35,000 each and immediately putting their hands out. I would have thought that was a disgrace and something that the Minister ought to be disapproving of. But no, again we have a bland statement saying, `Because you can identify someone who might have received a $20,000 pay-out at age 54, that somehow implies that they have an entitlement'. People in that situation getting a $20,000 pay-out will have an implicit income of $455 per week under our approach. We therefore say that they should be required to defer their application for a period of 33 weeks. If that is not reasonable, I do not know what is.

I challenge Senator Richardson to explain the concept of redundancy. It is a payment made to tide one over between jobs—in other words, to meet the very cost that one is expected to cope with on one's own once one ceases receiving a regular income. That is what it is about. It is not a free handout to pay off the flat, the mortgage or whatever else; it is meant to be an income support arrangement to which people have quite often contributed during their working life.
For the Minister to misrepresent our policy in this way is nothing more or less than simply trying to ignore the obvious. The editorial in the West Australian of 13 November said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is something wrong with a system which allows people who accept voluntary redundancy payouts to sign up for dole payments only a few weeks later.

It is compounded in Victoria by public servants who are getting payments under a $300m voluntary redundancy package immediately getting the dole. The average pay-out is $44,000 each. If that is the sort of system that Senator Richardson wants to preside over, we are delighted to hear it. I am sure the Australian public will reject that as totally outrageous, as bringing welfare into disrepute and simply giving the lie once again to the oft repeated statement that he makes that there is not one more cent to be squeezed out of welfare.

PARA.TAB: The other question that I wanted to deal with related to wives of disability support pensioners. I want to make it clear that our policy says that only wives under the age of 50 and whose husbands do not need a carer ought to be required to look for work. The Minister's erstwhile leader—we do not condescend to names because Senator Richardson only supports the leader of the moment—the leader he used to support, Mr Hawke, used to run around the countryside pretending that our policy involved people having dole payments stopped once they had been on the dole for nine months. Everyone else in the community understands by now that that has never been our policy. Our policy has simply been that people would go on to special benefits after that time if they qualified. It is utterly wrong and mischievous of Senator Richardson to pretend that we are somehow taking these women off income support, because we are not. All we are saying is that they ought to be required to look for work. By definition, they are able bodied.

If Senator Richardson wanted to chalk up a lower back injury, to get himself onto a disability support pension, which is absurdly easy to do, all he would need to do would be to get a couple of medical certificates to say that he has a 20 per cent impairment level, which I would have thought is ludicrous. If we compare it with equivalent standards around the world, honourable senators would immediately come to the conclusion that it is ludicrous too. Let us say that Senator Richardson managed to get himself a lower back injury.

TALK.START.PARA: —A jellyback injury.

—Yes, that is a very serious impediment and it is probably fatal for some people. Let us say that Senator Richardson is able to show that he is not likely to be able to get income for the next two years. He would get himself a disability support pension.

PARA.TAB: By definition, Senator Richardson's wife would be entitled to a pension. Is that fair? His wife could resign from work, where she has been able-bodied and gainfully employed for a period of years, but simply because she is married to a disability support pensioner she gets a pension. I do not understand the logic of that and I would like the Minister to explain it. I would have thought that is unfair, that is un-Australian, that brings the system into disrepute, and that is an advantage given to one-half of the population simply because, by definition, they happen to be spouses of disability support pensioners. It is not even a spouse pension; it is a wife's pension. I do not understand the logic of it and I do not think the Australian public does either.

All I can say is that if Senator Richardson wants to go around pretending that somehow we should have a welfare system that subsidises able-bodied citizens who are capable of earning a living, who do not have responsibilities to care for disability support pensioners—because they would be eligible for a carer's pension under our policy—I would have thought that is a classic example of why the welfare state is in the trouble that it is today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to say in relation to the redundancy payments for people in Perth is that the mere fact that a number of them inquire of the Department of Social Security as to whether they can—
—It was flooded.
—Let us say every single one of them inquires. It does not mean that every single one of them goes on unemployment benefits.
—They are pretty keen on it.

—They may be very keen to get unemployment benefits, but that does not mean that they get them. Because of the way in which the Government has tightened the eligibility for unemployment benefits, and for a whole range of other benefits, it is very difficult for them to do so. For those receiving the very big pay-out figures it will become wellnigh impossible.
—They just pay off the mortgage.

—For those who are jumping out, using the honourable senator's own example—he does not have to look at our example—very few of the people getting laid off in Australia at the moment are going out on big packages, as the honourable senator well knows. It is all right to say that one group of public servants in one place had an average pay-out of something. If one looks right across the board at private industry, at where people have been losing their jobs in manufacturing in the course of the past 12 to 18 months, one will not see them with the big payments. The honourable senator's own example is about someone on $15,000 who stays out of reach of unemployment benefits for 25 weeks. His own example is about someone with $15,000 being forced to spend every single cent of it before they are entitled to unemployment benefit. That is just wrong. That is an awful policy, that is an absolutely appalling policy, and it is one that we cannot support.
—Rubbish!

—I did not interject once on Senator Alston, and he can never shut up. That is half his problem; but only half. If we then turn to the second issue, we get this statement about disability support. This issue has been going on now for a long time. We always get the scoffing by Senator Alston of lower back injuries. Apparently everyone who has a lower back injury, irrespective of what pain and what discomfort it causes, is a malingerer. All of those people who have lower back injuries and receive invalid pensions have the support of members of the medical profession. Senator Herron is not going to disown doctors; he is not going to tell us that all of these doctors have got it wrong; he is not going to tell us that none of these people with lower back injuries—at which Senator Alston scoffs—are not suffering pain, are not suffering discomfort and are not finding it impossible to work.

PARA.TAB: I find it so disappointing that not only Senator Alston but his colleagues cannot understand that those people are suffering and do need income support. But he is taking this much further. He is saying that the wives of disability support pensioners, if they are under 50, on low impairment levels, or what he would call low impairment levels—he is saying the lot—are not entitled to any form of income support. So do not take some extreme example of a woman who may have resigned from employment. For many women, the sort of reduction in living standards involved in doing that would be impossible to contemplate.

There are thousands upon thousands of women at home, caring for their husbands who are on invalid pensions and cannot work because of health problems. An extra load must be placed on women in those households. We are not talking about a few women; we are talking about thousands upon thousands of women. All Senator Alston does is scoff at lower back injuries and tell us that a woman somewhere might resign from employment. The fact is that he has never come to grips with, and does not even understand, the plight of these women. That really worries me. Forget about the political argument. I wish he would go out and experience the conditions in which these women are living. If he did, even he would have to back away from this policy. There is an awfully long way to go in this argument. These policies are untenable. Senator Alston will not stick with them and neither will his Party.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: - I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 12 December, from Senator Michael Baume:

PARA.TAB: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:

INTERJECT.PARA: `That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The Government's failure to respond to the human tragedy of the worst level of unemployment in Australia since the Great Depression, in Mr Keating's deliberately engineered "recession we had to have".'

PARA.TAB: (MICHAEL BAUME)
Senator for the State of New South Wales

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Baume, I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit speaking times as follows: Senator Baume, 10 minutes; Senator Cook, 15 minutes; Senator Lees, 10 minutes; Senator Kemp, 6 minutes; Senator Schacht, 7 minutes; Senator Olsen, 6 minutes; and Senator Harradine, 6 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The Government's failure to respond to the human tragedy of the worst level of unemployment in Australia since the Great Depression, in Mr Keating's deliberately engineered `recession we had to have'.

The unemployment figures released today are not simply the last political nail in Mr Hawke's coffin; they are a tragedy for all Australians, particularly young Australians leaving school—there will be just under 200,000 in the coming weeks—who will be thrown onto the job market. This means that, at present, 31 per cent of young people under the age of 20 cannot find a full time job. That is the most horrendous figure on the records of the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

PARA.TAB: On top of that we have an overall unemployment figure of 900,700. That is almost double the number of people who were unemployed during the Great Depression. It represents an unemployment rate of 10.5 per cent. That is despite the fact that the participation rate in Australia—in other words, the number of people trying to get jobs—has gone down by almost one per cent over the last 12 months. If the same participation rate had existed this month as existed at the same time last year, the unemployment figure would be well over one million. It is not over one million only because people have given up the hunt for a job.

This disaster is not simply a problem that is happening to other people, it is happening to everyone in Australia. Everyone in Australia has a friend who is suffering from this Government's deliberate recession we `had to have'. It is extraordinary that the man who deliberately engineered this recession is now being promoted as the man who should take over from the Fall Guy, Mr Hawke, who happily allowed Mr Keating to engineer the `recession we had to have'.

But look at the number of jobs that have been simply wiped out as a result of these policies. A quarter of a million full time Australian jobs have been wiped out over the last 12 months as a result of policies that the Government says are fine. We heard here at Question Time the Government consistently saying not to worry, `We have everything in hand, we are on track'. That is exactly the same phrase Mr Keating used to use before we actually had the recession we had to have: everything was on track. We were not told in what direction this track is leading us. But everything was on track—on track to disaster.

The appalling thing is that of those 250,000 full time jobs that were wiped out, almost 40 per cent of them were for young Australians —Australians under the age of 20. So this Government has generated a situation of very little hope for even the most skilled young Australians, and no hope for unskilled young Australians. A 31 per cent unemployment rate for young people seeking full time work is certainly the highest ever. When the school leavers eventually break over the dam wall that this Government has created by paying Austudy to secondary school students to hide the real level of youth unemployment, the level of unemployment will be appalling. As the Australian Chamber of Manufactures warns today, the nation's unemployment rate may reach 11 per cent early next year when these school leavers hit the market.

Not only do we have this disastrous reduction in the number of jobs available to people but also there is no prospect of anything happening in the near future to resolve the situation. There was nothing in the answers at Question Time that indicated any plan or any coherent action being taken by this Government. Only three weeks ago the Government brought out an employment statement. It did not create one job. All it did was seek to take further measures to hide, in various training schemes, particularly in TAFE, the genuine level of unemployment. Despite all of these schemes, we still have this horrendous unemployment.

At the moment there are only 269,000 young Australians actually at work. I compare that with the 450,000 young Australians who were in full time work in the depths of the 1982-83 recession that we keep hearing so much about in this chamber. Mr Hawke said no government should ever be forgiven for creating that kind of unemployment. But there were more people at work—a huge difference —under the Fraser Government than there are now under this disastrous Government.

So we have to ask, how did all this happen? How did we end up in this terrible disaster if everything was on track, if the Government knew what it was doing, if in fact it is looking forward with confidence to a pick up? All the experts are saying that they expect unemployment to be over 10 per cent or around 11 per cent for two or three years to come. We have not seen any effective denial of that. I look forward to Senator Cook denying that later, if he can, and giving us solid forecasts about how there are going to be reductions in unemployment within that timeframe. All the experts say that the prospects are gloomy for employment unless there is some circuit breaker, unless something is done to restore incentive, to restore job opportunities.
We have seen today's press release in which Senator McKiernan, the former Labor Whip, asks: why do we have this huge level of unemployment, why did it happen and how did it happen? He says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are now 900 700 reasons why Paul Keating should not be elected Prime Minister of Australia. The man who gave us the recession we had to have should not now be rewarded for his accomplishment.

Nothing can be more accurate than that. Yet we heard at Question Time Senator Evans say, `Oh well, the Budget had indicated that unemployment would be around 10 3/4 per cent and what is happening now is simply in line with the Budget forecast'. If the Government expected these sorts of unemployment levels, the Government and Mr Keating's supporters must also recognise that it is generally accepted that the Budget parameters were set by guess who? They were set by Mr Keating before he left in May.

PARA.TAB: The Budget parameters were clearly set by the man who created the crisis and who now seeks to oust the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, whose sin in this area was to allow Mr Keating to do what Mr Keating wanted to do. That is Mr Hawke's sin and now he is paying for that sin.

There is no doubt that Mr Keating quit in May of this year to avoid being seen as related in any way to this Budget which has deliberately created this unemployment. As Senator Evans said, this unemployment was forecast totally in this Budget. Mr Keating got out of the role of Treasurer to avoid being the signatory to this document which is now spelling the doom of the Prime Minister. Now he has the hide to seek to distance himself from what is his own direct responsibility.

He has no answer, just as Mr Hawke has no answer. The only hope that Australians, particularly young Australians, can have is to get rid of this tired, awful Government and restore a government that has a policy, the Fightback policy, to solve these problems. It is an urgent task for this Government to be got rid of and for the Opposition to be able to introduce its Fightback policy.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, takes no comfort or joy at all from the unemployment figures that have been released today. We regret that there has been an increase in unemployment. We believe, as I will set out shortly, that the fundamentals of the economy are set in such a way that employment will grow in the future.

PARA.TAB: We do not flinch in the face of this urgency motion. If this were a genuine debate in this chamber about unemployment in this country, it would be a welcome debate for most Australians. They would be delighted to hear the policies of the contending parties for electoral office in this country and be able to judge who can deal with the issue best.

We have not heard in this debate any policy input whatsoever from the Opposition. All we have heard is a lurid and somewhat overemotional description of what in fact is the case, and I will set that in context in a minute. We have heard some personal allegations about Mr Keating and inferences about Mr Hawke but no policy prescriptions whatsoever.

The fundamentals that we have set in the economy mean that we do have a policy which will put people in jobs. They will not be false or make-work jobs; they will be jobs with careers. In a moment, I propose to outline those policies in broad detail. I also propose to reply briefly to the Opposition and to set the record straight on the significance of these figures.

Let me take the middle of those three objectives in this speech first, that is, to reply to the Opposition. Governments must be judged on their capacity to deal with the economic realities of the day. The judgment therefore is: are we better equipped than the Opposition to deal with it? It is interesting, therefore, to see, in terms of the Opposition's position, the analysis that has recently occurred in the media over its consumption tax package released by Dr Hewson, which will be the basis of all economic reform in this country should the Opposition come to power.

The most interesting article I have read is one that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 10 December. This was written by the former chief of staff to John Howard, when he was Leader of the Opposition for four years, and a senior adviser to the Fraser Government. It is therefore a column not written by a Labor sympathiser but a think-tank expert from the Liberal Party. In his column, Mr Gerard Henderson said:

In other words, the firm warranty that some 2 million jobs `will' be created and unemployment halved by the end of the century is just a guess. Well meaning, no doubt. Yet a hypothesis just the same.What is more, the AEM model on which this overtly optimistic promise is based does not take into account the inflationary impact of the Coalition's across-the-board goods and services tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that these are the words of Mr Henderson, John Howard's adviser and an adviser to the Fraser Government. Mr Henderson concludes by saying:
It is all pie in the sky.
What Mr Henderson is talking about is the Opposition's policy of creating employment. He says that it is pie in the sky, that there is no basis for the Opposition's estimates of job creation.

PARA.TAB: I will not simply rely on the words of someone who is now out of the Opposition organisationally. Let me rely on what Dr John Hewson said on 23 November when he appeared at the Eastern Suburbs Leagues Club and talked about the goods and services tax package that he had released. What did he say on employment? He dodged the question; he evaded giving an answer of any significance. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not making any promises about the level of unemployment. There will be transition effects.

He said something similar on 22 November. I do not want to spend any more time on the Opposition's pretensions to power in this country. It is clear that one of the people best placed to judge and who has been part of the Opposition's economic thinking for so long, has condemned the Opposition's package. He has said that the job increases are illusory and pie in the sky. Dr Hewson himself has evaded the question.

PARA.TAB: I note that the package has a $2.6 billion hole in it; that it imposes $2 billion extra costs on medical expenses for Australians; that, according to Syntec, an independent economic forecasting unit, it is inflationary to a level of 9.5, not 4.4 per cent; that it will create a permanent underclass of working poor; and that it provides a revolving door under an alleged training program for unemployed which has no training requirement at all. I think that is testimony to the credentials of the Opposition.

Let me put into context the current figures on unemployment. It is true that liars can figure and figures can lie. The Government is not at all fazed by the fact that the situation is as presented. We do not like the situation that way and we regret the level of unemployment but, as I have said, the economic settings are properly attuned to dealing with this matter.

Even after the loss of employment due to the recession, almost 1.4 million, or 22.3 per cent, more Australians are employed than when we came to office. At the peak of employment in July 1990, 7.928 million Australians were employed, compared with a mere 6 1/4 million when the Government came to office—almost 1.7 million more people employed than when the coalition was thrown out of office by the people of Australia last time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The participation rate is the weakest excuse.

—I hear by way of interjection, `What about the participation rate?'. The participation rate is an economic measure that measures how many people are in the work force applying for jobs. In November of this year the participation rate stood at 63 per cent. The participation rate during 1982 and 1983, the last years of the Fraser Government, stood at 60.3 per cent. The number of people offering for employment is much greater now that it was then. If we applied the Fraser level of participation rate to the current level of unemployment in this country, the figure would be 6.5—not 10.5, as it is now. The fact is that these figures show the extent to which the size of the Australian work force has grown.

PARA.TAB: The other contextual point is that in the seven years of the Fraser Government, employment grew by 5.6 per cent. In other words, in the seven years and five months that Australia lost to the Fraser Government, a Government in which the current Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was the economic adviser, the coalition could generate only about 330,000 jobs, a growth rate of a mere 0.7 per cent per annum. I contrast that pathetic performance with the record of this Government. In the first seven years and five months of this Government—that is, from April 1983 to August 1990—this Government produced over 1.6 million jobs. I wish to make the point that we are looking at a mere 330,000 compared with 1.6 million.

Let us consider the numbers further. Under this Government, employment grew between April 1983 and July 1990 by a total of 27 per cent at an average rate of 3.3 per cent, not by a total of 5.6 per cent at an average of 0.7, which was the Fraser comparison. Ours, 27 per cent; theirs, 5.6. Our average rate of growth was 3.3; theirs, 0.7. That is what the figures say.

What is more, even after the employment loss over the last year, employment today is still some 22 per cent above the level of April 1983 and has grown by an average of 2.3 per cent per annum. We are 22 per cent above the level of April 1983. Even taking into account the recession, this Government has still created jobs at a rate over three times faster than the Opposition managed the last time it was in government.

I make those remarks for the reason of setting into context a them-and-us comparison. Those opposite are the pretenders to power. That is their record and that is our record. Let the record speak so that an assessment can be made about who can handle these matters more effectively. On the record and when it speaks, it can be seen with the figures set out quite clearly that the record is very much one that sits with us and not with the Opposition.

The Australian economy is undergoing a massive transformation. Through the policies of this Government, we are going from a country that in the past has ridden on the sheep's back to a more diversified, competitive exporter striving for world best practice. As I have said, the present level of unemployment is unacceptable, but I believe that we have the basic policy elements that will restore sustainable growth, and thereby sustainable and secure job growth. There is evidence that the first stages of the recovery in the economy are under way. Unfortunately, employment is the lagging indicator. It picks up only after production and sales in the housing, retail and manufacturing sectors pick up. There is substantial evidence that our policies are working and that these leading sectors—the housing, manufacturing and retail sectors—are picking up.

Just today we have had the good news in statistics released on the retail, building and manufacturing sectors. Retail trade increased by 2.1 per cent in October. Dwelling unit commencements increased by 6.2 per cent in the September quarter. Industrial production in manufacturing increased by 0.9 per cent in the September quarter. Manufacturers' sales also picked up in the September quarter, by 2.8 per cent.

Furthermore, the leading indicators of employment prospects of the Department of Employment, Education and Training have been rising for the past four months. This augurs well for the better employment picture in the first half of next year. Already DEET's skilled vacancy survey for November has shown a 2.4 per cent increase in the vacancy index for trade related skills. It must be remembered that this Government has undertaken major reform measures that have placed Australia in a favourable position to take full advantage of the recovery to get back to the sustainable path for secure employment.

We are now a low inflation country. Make no mistake: the maintenance of low inflation is critical to achieving sustainable employment growth. Inflation distorts investment decisions, significantly reducing the incentives for productive job creating investment. Our inflation rate is 3.3 per cent. It now stands below the 4.3 per cent of our major trading partners in the OECD. We are lower than the OECD average. For the first time in a generation, we have an opportunity to make this a permanent situation. The commitment we have received from our accord partners to work with us in keeping Australian inflation at levels comparable with those of our major trading partners is a key element in our strategy for sustainable growth.

This Government has made Australia a more competitive economy than the one we inherited in 1983. Restructuring and micro-economic reform are not just being talked about; they are being achieved. The performance of our manufacturing sector competing on world markets attests to that fact. Over the eight-year period to 1990-1991, the value of exports of machinery, transport equipment and other elaborately transformed manufacturers increased by 220 per cent, involving growth in volumes of 149 per cent. Over the last two financial years, the volume of these exports has grown an astonishing 57 per cent. We are now exporting more manufactured goods than we are exporting agricultural commodities for the first time in our history. The industrial base of Australia is transforming and it is because of that transformation that more jobs will be created which offer longer and better careers. The result has been a dramatically improved balance of payments. The balance on goods and services is forecast to be in surplus in 1991-92 for the first time in over 10 years.

The latest trade statistics show that the value of merchandise exports rose by 5.5 per cent in the September quarter, reaching $12,000m. They rose a credible 4.4 per cent in the June quarter, but the September quarter is the highest level ever recorded for merchandise exports. These figures are a remarkable testimony to the effectiveness of our restructuring.

The fact is that in the past 8 1/2 years this Government has instituted a program of economic reform unprecedented in the history of this country. Never has the pace been faster than in this year where, through the March economic statement, the November employment statement, and the Budget, we can see the evidence of the fundamental changes we are bringing about. Nowhere has this been more apparent than in the remarkable success of Senator Collins in reforming the waterfront and in going about the other micro-economic reforms that this Government has achieved. For example, nationally there has been a 50 per cent reduction in the cost of grain handling through our ports. The Australian Wheat Board has heralded the change. It has said that Australian ports are now among the most efficient grain loading ports in the world.

These are questions of fundamental shifts in the economy. These are changes that take time to put into position; it will take time to reap results. We are going through a low spot now; that is true. It is towards the middle of our term and it is not surprising that it would be a low spot. But these fundamentals will now be working in the economy to see that there is a productivity surge in the Australian community, to see that job prospects lift, and that jobs will not be illusory—they will be real. The training programs we have put in place in the meanwhile will ensure that the degree of training which the work force is undergoing at an enhanced level during this period of downturn will be able to be picked up in real jobs when those training programs mature and the economy recovers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has virtually replied to the first part of the motion, as to why the Government will not respond. Basically, it is because it believes its policies are on the right track. I will come back to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with two words which appear in the first line of Senator Baume's motion: `human tragedy'. This is something that other speakers have tended to skip over. We are not just talking about figures here; we are talking about people. I would like to quote from two different sources. The first is a statement by the Catholic Bishops of Australia which was made at the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment is not just an abstract problem: it involves people: the young who have never had a job: the middle aged who are stunned to find their careers suddenly cut short: those who have been without work for so long that they are no longer regarded as "employable". And it does not stop there: their families are affected, we are all affected.

Unemployment means that a person's work is not wanted, or not valued. It can mean real losses: of participation in the life of the community; of esteem and self-esteem; financial security. The losses can multiply into loss of emotional and physical health and disturbance in personal relations.

I now quote from an article which appeared in the Bulletin not too long ago, entitled `Clock off—for the rest of your life'. It refers to a study conducted by two economists, Raja Junankar and Cezary Kapuscinski, of the ANU Centre for Economic Policy Research. The article states:

"The long-term unemployed are not only a wasted resource but also a wasting resource," the study says. "They lose their skills, motivation, fall ill more often. In crude economic terms, human capital is being depreciated. There is a mass of misery and suffering: often they live in poverty, they have lost their self-respect and dignity and they accept the verdict of the labour market with a mixture of resentment and resignation. The social implications of this are very serious: some people argue that it leads to increased illness, suicide and homicide as well as to civil strife and a breakdown of marriages.

I come back to what we are looking at now: the Government's response to this problem. Today we have before us the worst unemployment figures that we have seen in Australia since the Great Depression. I say again that, basically, the reason the Government has not responded—and apparently does not intend to respond in any significant way—is that it would mean a change in policy and a new direction. It would mean taking another look at what it has been doing and admitting that it has not been going in the right direction.

PARA.TAB: Today I have time to look at only a few of these policies. I will start with this mythical level playing field. The rest of the world seems to believe that the pursuit of this strange place is a nonsense. The rest of the industrialised countries support their industries and, in particular, encourage research. I draw attention to Senator Coulter's question today regarding the low level of support for the CSIRO. These countries often fund new sunrise technology and encourage the people in their countries with talent to keep new technologies in their own nation and to put them to best effect for the benefit of all.

Add to this the pursuit of the level playing field in agricultural policies. Australia and New Zealand are the world's agricultural odd couple. The latest figures indicate that 11 per cent of Australian farmers' incomes are attributable to government subsidies and other support mechanisms. In New Zealand it is 5 per cent. For our main partners and competitors, the figures are: 48 per cent in Europe, 30 per cent in the United States and 68 per cent in Japan. It is an incredible testimony to the efficiency and productivity of our farmers that they are still in the race at all and that they still remain world competitive with comparatively so little government or community support. In 1990, just as the Uruguay GATT talks were meant to be reducing world agricultural protection, the world cost of subsidies soared by 12 per cent to a total of $383 billion.

I move on to deregulation, something Senator Kernot touched on earlier. Speculation and greed replaced regulated banking practices. One example is the television industry. Two of the three commercial networks are in receivership. The production staff have been slashed and the quality of programs has deteriorated significantly—all because of the availability of easy money to a few greedy entrepreneurs who were only after the quick dollar basically because of bad banking decisions.

Let us look at our tight monetary policy and the decision to hold interest rates high for far too long. Farmers and business people, already disadvantaged by what I have spoken of previously with regard to the tariff structure in this country, have had to face this additional burden. Interest rates rose to the point where not even the interest payments could be met and this forced many into bankruptcy. There have been record levels of bankruptcies. Many of those people will never recover. They will not be able to trade their way out of debt and will not recover economically or personally.

I will move on to the refusal to put more funds into areas where expenditure would not only boost employment but achieve important community goals, such as in the public housing sector. I acknowledge that the better cities program is a step in the right direction, but it is nowhere near enough. In the area of public transport it is the same story again. Nothing is happening in the area of local government expenditure or in respect of the enormous need in the environmental area.

To add insult to injury, those who have been hit the hardest have been hit again by the tightening of the social security system, and those who are already suffering under the Government's policies—the people who are mentioned in the two articles I referred to previously—are being hurt even more. Record numbers of people are now queuing at our welfare agencies. The Salvation Army in South Australia has just revealed that it spent its five-month government grant in six weeks. That represented 195,000 separate requests for food and money—a 300 per cent increase compared with the 65,000 requests received in the corresponding period last year. The number last year was up significantly compared with the year before.

In my last couple of minutes, I would like to look at what the Opposition would propose in each of these areas. Unfortunately—I find this really depressing—the hands off policy would worsen to a `no hands at all' policy. Its plan is to reduce tariffs even further to—I quote from its document—`negligible levels'. Our vehicle, textile, clothing and footwear industries would be being threatened. There is no way we can get our wages down to this level playing field nonsense. To do that we would have to get down to the sweatshop conditions, the sweatshop levels of many of our Asian neighbours.

In a recent article it was said that children as young as eight and nine are forced to work in backyard factories for however many hours it takes to make the required number of articles. The Opposition would have even less tariff support for our rural industries. I did read the figures earlier. A number of policymakers, particularly from the Liberal Party, are flocking across the Tasman to study the New Zealand 5 per cent model—a model on which they want to base Australia's future. Liberal leader, Dr Hewson, flagged his views in March when commenting on the problems being faced by wheat growers and the probable devastation of country towns based around the wheat industry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't think you solve problems by throwing money at them and breeding inefficiency. . .

The Australian Democrats believe that Australian agriculturalists simply cannot afford to lead the world in further tariff and other support reductions. It is suicide. The ideological path advocated by Dr Hewson may be economically efficient according to some textbooks he reads, as long as the rest of the world decides to play on a level playing field. But the Democrats believe that in Australia in the latter part of the 1991 it is unachievable; indeed, it is totally unrealistic for the foreseeable future and politically irresponsible.

PARA.TAB: Under a Liberal Party government we would not only see further deregulation; we would also see a wholesale sell off of the rest of the family silver—the little that is left after the Labor Party has had a go. That would even include the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and Telecom Australia, et cetera. If inflation is to be kept in check, a tight monetary policy is the only alternative.

In conclusion, we will be supporting this urgency motion with some hesitation. However, we find that there is absolutely nothing in the Opposition's package that will improve the situation. It is relying even more on the trickle down effect which has been proven throughout the world to be an absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the urgency motion, which states:

PARA.TAB: The Government's failure to respond to the human tragedy of the worst level of unemployment in Australia since the Great Depression, in Mr Keating's deliberately engineered "recession we had to have".

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious debate. In this chamber today are Senator Cook and Senator Schacht, two men who are the strongest backers of Mr Keating to replace Mr Hawke as the leader of this country. I say to those two honourable senators, `There are a million reasons out there, numbered in the people who cannot find jobs, why your man for Prime Minister, Mr Keating, should not become the head of this country'. Neither should Mr Hawke, but that is a matter which I will be pursuing.

PARA.TAB: In her speech, Senator Lees drew our attention in a somewhat moving and correct way to the tragedy embodied in these figures—the tragedy of individuals who now cannot find jobs as a result of the policies of this Hawke Labor Government. I say to Senator Cook, who seemed to read his speech without enthusiasm: the unemployment rate in Victoria is not 10.5 per cent or 10.6 per cent; it is over 11 per cent. Unemployment amongst young people is rising to close to 32 per cent. Senator Cook should come down to Victoria and visit St Albans, Footscray or the western suburbs. He will see what has happened to the people who have ceaselessly put him and his colleagues back into government and the damage that this Government has brought on those people. I believe that he would then ask himself how he could continue to support policies which are inflicting such damage.

Senator Cook stands up in this chamber day after day pretending that the Government's policies are a success. How he can say that, on this of all days, is beyond belief. Senator Cook, in his speech, said that he was not fazed by the problems that the Government is currently facing. He dismissed them by saying that the Government is mid-term. As if `mid-term' is an excuse for one million people being without jobs. That is an absolutely disgraceful comment. Senator Cook then pointed to some aspects of the Government's policy and suggested that they were a remarkable testimony to the success of the Hawke Government—when there are one million people without jobs and we have a foreign debt above $140 billion. When this Government came to office, foreign debt was $30 billion.

Senator Cook is an absolute disgrace not only for any government but for a Labor government. He has cut living standards of ordinary Australian workers. I have put this charge to him time and time again and he has failed to come into the chamber and counter that charge. Not only has Senator Cook cut the living standards of workers under his precious accord, but he is now throwing them out of a job. Senator Cook speaks about his accord partners.

How about having a partnership with the Australian people, with the ordinary workers in this country? Senator Cook's partnership is one with the union bosses. We will not have a bar of that. This Government has said that the union movement was part and parcel of this Government. My oath it is; it is absolutely part and parcel. How Government supporters can go out and talk to their union members, the very people they are putting out of work, is beyond belief.

This is a serious debate; it is a vital debate for this country. We hoped that when Senator Cook got up he could have made a contribution. The question that people out there in the community will have to ask themselves, and those people who are listening today, from Senator Cook's speech—and we shall be listening closely to Senator Schacht's speech—is: what are the Government's plans to deal with this human tragedy? It has now created the worst unemployment for 60 years; of that now there can at least be no dispute. I suggest that when Senator Schacht stands up he outline in detail the Government's plans to deal with this tragedy, because those opposite say that their policies are on track.

Let me just point to a newspaper today where it says that the mining industry this year, which the Government has killed with its green and red tape, is expected to cut investment expenditure by nearly $1 billion because of a loss of confidence. Of course, how can the mining industry possibly have any confidence in this Government when half of the Ministers show no support and no loyalty to their Prime Minister; these Ministers who plot and connive against him and who undermine him ceaselessly? I have no truck for the Hawke Government; nor do I have any truck for Mr Hawke. But I believe that Mr Hawke is at least entitled to the loyalty of Ministers in his Cabinet. If they are not prepared to give that loyalty they should leave that Cabinet. But no, these Ministers want the best of all possible worlds; they want to undermine their Prime Minister; they want to retain their jobs; but they do not care less about the one million people who have lost their jobs.

What we need from the Government is its strategy to restore Australian employment; its strategy to ensure that most Australians—our children and grandchildren—have the prospect of achieving some jobs. Let me point out why Dr Hewson has captured the imagination of this country: he has had the courage to outline his policies and to outline his vision. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this urgency motion, which is another one of the stunt urgency motions that the Opposition has been persistently putting up for as long as I have been in the Senate; that is, since 1987. Year in, year out, this sort of urgency motion comes up so that senators like Senator Kemp can speak froth and bubble but with no substance. I am astonished that Senator Kemp would stand up in this Senate and proclaim his interest in the unemployed, such as the ordinary people of St Albans, when he is a self-professed member of the New Right of the Liberal Party which before the last election made sure that it destroyed any of the more moderate elements of the Liberal Party of Victoria. For instance, Mr Macphee, the former member for Goldstein, paid the penalty and Senator Kemp himself arranged the political assassination of Senator David Hamer, the former Deputy President of this chamber and a long respected senator. These people all had to be shoved out because they actually believed in a few democratic ideals, unlike Senator Kemp who is a member of the New Right.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp talks about his concern for unemployment; he who is an avowed supporter of Dr Hewson with his so-called Fightback package and the GST proposals. But the Opposition does not tell too many people that the package also contains $10 billion worth of cuts to government expenditure. The Opposition does not tell us how many more tens of thousands of people will be put out of work by imposing $10 billion worth of cuts. Those opposite say, `Oh yes, but after a period of time we will create some confidence and there will be 200,000 jobs created elsewhere'. That is an absolute fantasy which is not based on any substance in the document. It is an attitude of trusting Dr Hewson who says, `This is the culture I want to create'. The culture is basically to sack tens of thousands of people and to destroy the public sector by reducing its expenditure by $10 billion in a whole range of areas.

This morning I represented the Government at the graduation ceremony at the Australian Defence Force Academy where 250 young Australians graduated with pride from that academy to go into our defence forces. There is not much talk by those opposite saying, `We are going to cut back the defence expenditure by at least $200m'. Some of those graduates will be put out of their jobs in the defence forces. The Opposition in its obsessive, ideological desire to reduce government expenditure is setting about wrecking the competence and efficiency of the Australian Defence Force. It is an absurd notion.

We do not see Senator MacGibbon, who is always proclaiming his interest in defence matters, standing up in this chamber saying, `Hang on, Dr Hewson, we've been complaining that there is not enough money being spent by the Hawke Government on defence and you want to cut it by another $200m'. Senator David MacGibbon is absolutely silent, and he is supposed to be a defence expert. Senator Newman is always whingeing and whining in this chamber about the conditions and the role of the defence forces. She is always asking for more money but there has not been a word out of her, as shadow Minister for defence personnel and science, about the impact of $200m worth of cuts in the defence budget; not a word out of anyone in the Opposition.

I agree that the figure today of 10.5 per cent unemployment is tragic. No-one on this side of the Parliament has any joy in talking about this figure; we accept that. But I want to make a couple of points about the unemployment figures. One reason the unemployment rate is at 10.5 per cent is that there are a lot more people seeking employment. If we had the same participation rate as the Opposition had when it was last in office in 1982-83, the unemployment rate would be 6.5 per cent, not 10.5 per cent. There are a lot more people still in jobs because when the Opposition was last in office the participation rate was just on 3 per cent less than it is now. That is an equivalent in the unemployment rate of 4 per cent. There is no mention of that from the Opposition or that, despite the loss of jobs in the last year, this Government has still provided well over one million extra jobs since we came to office. We still have the highest percentage increase in job creation, which is more than any percentage level achieved when the Opposition was last in office. There was no mention from the Opposition that we now have the lowest interest rates for over 20 years. There was no mention that, despite the decline in the rural economy because of the decline in world prices for our primary products, we are now exporting much more than we ever did in manufacturing, which is a splendid achievement.
Senator Olsen interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Olsen screams and shouts. Senator Olsen used to be a dealer for machinery and so on. He will be interested to note that, over the eight-year period ending 1991, the value of exports of machinery, transport equipment and other transport items increased by 220 per cent, involving growth in volumes of 149 per cent. When Senator Olsen and his Party were in office, manufacturing was going absolutely in the other direction.

PARA.TAB: I believe that these sorts of stunt urgency motions are aimed at doing only one thing by the Opposition; that is, to do everything possible to destroy confidence in this community in every way because those opposite believe that they can ride into government by reducing confidence and therefore increasing unemployment; they believe they can get elected on misery. It is typical of the Opposition and always has been. To have people opposite, like Senator Kemp, representing the New Right concerned about ordinary people is an absolute joke. This motion should be thrown out of the Senate forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Government speakers who have participated in this debate have attempted to defend the indefensible. They have failed miserably on one count alone: in November 1983, during the last recession, there were 680,000 people out of work; in November 1991 there are 900,000 people out of work—another quarter of a million people. Senator Schacht and Senator Cook should give their speeches to the additional quarter of a million people out of work and tell them how good the Government's policies are.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that honourable senators opposite, in their collective wisdom, have delivered Australia's longest, deepest recession since the 1930s. It has reached the stage, as we continue to bump along the bottom rather than show any sustainable signs of recovery, where Government members opposite ought to be asked one simple question, namely, how do they sleep at night in this present crisis when they are so obviously far more concerned about changing leaders and protecting their factional backs than changing economic policy and protecting Australians?

At 3.30 this afternoon, six Ministers went back to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to get his reply to the meeting that took place this morning. The Prime Minister has said that he will not go unless he is blasted out. The fact is that there will be a second ballot—that is the only way those opposite will get him out. The Prime Minister does not want a second ballot until January. What do we have? We have further hiatus of government, no decision-making of government and no consideration by government of its policy direction. We have more of the same for Australians, particularly the unemployed.

I specifically ask those opposite how they can sleep at night and I look forward to the reply. It is just two weeks until Christmas, a time we grow up anticipating as a season of tidings of great joy. But the tidings for Australia and Australians this Christmas are not of joy but of sadness, worry, fear and anxiety about their future. One million Australians are unemployed and the number keeps growing.

Today's unemployment figure of 10.5 per cent is the worst since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Some 41,000 more Australians are unemployed this week than were unemployed last month. We know that that number will increase yet again over the Christmas break as many companies, especially in the small business sector, which have limped to the end of the year, are forced to give up the fight in the face of an ongoing recession.

More than 190,000 school leavers who are not going on to tertiary education will swell the job market, only to have their hopes slashed when they find that newspapers are now publishing job advertisements at the rate of just one for every 70 people out of work. This week we have also heard that the recession has nearly doubled the number of university graduates unable to find full time work. Worst affected are graduates in engineering and building related disciplines who rely for employment on investment generated by the private sector.

Life in the so-called lucky country is getting worse, not better and, incredibly, those to blame appear those most unconcerned—the Labor members. Do they not realise, or are they unwilling to see, that a million unemployed at Christmas translates to hundreds of thousands of children who will be deprived of Christmas presents; that it translates to hundreds of thousands of parents who will feel that they have let their children down because they cannot provide appropriately and that their only prospect is another year without work or hope to look forward to?

Does the Government not understand, in human terms, that no job equals a collapse in self-esteem? Guilt follows that collapse in self-esteem and there can be no greater damage done to any individual than to destroy self-pride. This Government has effectively destroyed the self-esteem and self-pride of hundreds of thousands of Australians. That has brought human tragedy to many Australians who have not been able to cope.

Senator Lees referred to bankruptcies. She made the point that people have resorted to suicide because their self-esteem has evaporated and their self-pride has been absolutely destroyed by the economic policy direction of Labor. The economic indicators, at this point, are certainly not indicating that Christmas 1992 will bring tidings of joy either. That is the human cost of this Government's mismanagement this Christmas.

We have seen a Prime Minister with hollow words. But what of the perceived leadership challenger, Paul Keating? The Keating camp's crocodile tears over unemployment are an even greater act of hypocrisy than Prime Minister Hawke's. At Christmas 1991 we have a Labor Party which, while showing absolutely no remorse for the suffering that it has created, is fighting amongst itself to decide who gets the top job. There are one million unemployed while the Labor Caucus squabbles over one job—a job which pays well over $150,000 a year, comes with two houses, an army of staff, and a plane at beck and call.

The choice is between the man who single-handedly created the recession through a procession of wrong and ill-timed economic decisions, and then had the gall to tell us that we had to have it, Paul Keating, and the man who let him get away with such gross acts of economic vandalism, while even accepting the glory for them, the present Prime Minister, Bob Hawke. The tableau which we have before us does not have a nativity scene this Christmas because of the actions and economic policy directions of this Government. Although we have a Government surrounded by copious evidence that its economic strategy is all wrong, the worst is yet to come. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The job figures which have been announced today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are a matter of shame for us all. We can point score against each other but the time has come where we should work together to ensure that the rights of those people who are seeking paid work and are unable to find it are upheld.

PARA.TAB: It is important to express feelings of concern. My blood boils, my heart bleeds, for those who are unemployed. The figures are stark and very revealing. In my State of Tasmania, compared with this time last year, 11,000 full time jobs have been slashed; they have been lost. In other words, this time last year there were 151,200 people working full time in Tasmania; today, there are only 140,600 people working full time. The loss of full time jobs is a significant problem. What does it mean? It means that we are entering a period of under-employment; we are entering a period where people, the large percentage of whom are the sole income earner for the family, are now going on to part time work. That means a substantial loss in their wages, with attendant difficulties for the family, with commitments unfilled, with the mortgage rates going unpaid, with loan repayments being unpaid and a future of economic despair.

TALK.START.PARA: —And 33.3 per cent youth unemployment.

—I acknowledge the point that has been made by Senator Baume. Over the last three or four years I have been concerned about the growing number of unemployed youth. As Senator Baume said, in my State over 33 per cent of youth are unemployed.
—It is 41 per cent in Launceston.

—In some areas, as Senator Calvert has indicated, it is up to 41 per cent. It is a disgrace. It is a grave matter of concern.Today I want to focus on the loss of full time jobs and the ramifications of this. I have stood up in this place and pointed out that it is no good the Government saying that it has created all these jobs. Most of the jobs that have been created have been part time jobs. We are becoming a Third World country.
—It is a worldwide phenomenon. It is not unusual.
—As Senator Sherry says, it is a worldwide phenomenon. Go and tell that—
—It is no excuse that it's a worldwide phenomenon.

—I accept what Senator Sherry says, that it is no excuse. I agree that it is a worldwide phenomenon, but surely it is a matter of concern that we should be looking at jointly. I have asked Senator Button on a number of occasions to look at the participation rate and see whether there are people in the paid work force who have better reasons to be out of it, but cannot come out of it because of the severe effect that that would have on the family income, or on the incomes of individuals who wish to retire. That is what we ought to be looking at.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that there are more people in or seeking paid work at the same time that technological change is slashing new job opportunities, and at the same time that this tremendous depression that we have is affecting investor confidence. We should look at those things. We should look at them factually and make a joint effort to overcome them. I wanted to go on to the area of workers with disabilities, but my time has obviously expired. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
