DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Active Citizenship Revisited. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
TO
THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING: ACTIVE CITIZENSHIP REVISITED

PARA.TAB: For the information of honourable Members, I present a statement containing the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Active Citizenship Revisited.

SPEECH.PARA: In March 1989 the Standing Committee tabled a Report entitled Education for Active Citizenship. In that Report the Standing Committee surveyed the widespread evidence of ignorance, apathy and feelings of powerlessness among Australians, and particularly young Australians, towards democratic institutions and processes. The Report went on to review the provision of courses, programs and services which attempted to give students and youth the capacities and motivation to actively participate at a number of levels in the Australian democratic process.

In Active Citizenship Revisited the Standing Committee has monitored the progress which has been made since the earlier Report, and makes a series of recommendations directed towards ensuring that citizenship education continues to be a priority for schools, higher education institutions and other relevant agencies.

The Standing Committee received 146 submissions, including submissions from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Australian Electoral Commission. The Standing Committee tabled its Report on 14 March 1991. The Government has closely examined the report and its recommendations and I am pleased to present this statement in response.

In Active Citizenship Revisited the Committee has surveyed progress in citizenship education at a number of levels and in a variety of forums. It found that there has been considerable progress by States and Territories in incorporating the goal of citizenship education in formal policy and curriculum statements. School systems are also acknowledging the need to go beyond a strictly institutional approach to this subject ("civics") and are emphasising the participative aspects of active citizenship. The Committee found, however, that there is a significant discrepancy between curriculum theory and practice, and that some systems have yet to provide teachers with the curriculum materials and professional training to make citizenship education more than a collection of political facts.

However, the Committee also found a number of innovative projects at school level which are successfully exploring the possibilities of citizenship education. These initiatives indicate that, when teachers are convinced of the value of citizenship education, and are supported by their school, students can be prepared to actively participate in democratic processes. In summary, significant progress is being made in promoting active citizenship, but much remains to be done.

It should be noted that perhaps the most important pre-condition for citizenship education, and one of the most easily overlooked, is the presence of young people in educational institutions. Between 1983 and 1990 overall participation in education and training by the teenage cohort rose from 56.9% to 66.7%. The most significant element is this change has been the increase in Year 12 retention rates which reached 64% in 1990 compared to 33% for most of the 1970s. This dramatic increase in the number of students in educational institutions will work to promote active citizenship both by developing the literacy skills and general knowledge which are essential to effective political participation and by exposing much larger numbers of students to specific citizenship education programs which are developed by schools.

In its Report the Standing Committee has recognised the positive advances the Government has made in promoting citizenship education at a number of levels. Since the publication of the 1989 Report the Australian Education Council (AEC), which comprises Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers of Education, has agreed to act jointly to improve Australian schooling within a framework of national collaboration. The AEC has also announced ten common and agreed national goals for schooling, the seventh of which seeks to `develop knowledge, skills, attitudes and values which will enable students to participate as active and informed citizens in our democratic Australian society within an international context.'

In order to give effect to these common and agreed national goals, the AEC has embarked on a mapping of a number of key curriculum areas in primary and secondary schooling and has also begun the task of developing common and agreed curriculum frameworks or national statements in eight approved areas of learning for all Australian schools.

One of the eight learning areas for mapping and development of a national statement is Studies of Society and Environment. The mapping of Studies of Society and the Environment has been completed and is expected to provide broad information about the definition, status and location of active citizenship in the curricula of Australian government schools.

It is already apparent that States and Territories have different ways of defining and integrating such studies in school curricula. One of the outcomes of mapping the area will be to reveal different approaches but more importantly, to identify areas of commonality across education systems. Such information will be of value in developing the next stage—a common curricula framework for Studies of Society and the Environment, acceptable to all Australian school education systems.

Work on the development of the frameworks paper for Studies of Society and Environment will commence in October 1991 and is expected to be completed by March 1993. The Commonwealth is a member of the Steering Committee for this project, along with other State and Territory governments. It is expected that wide ranging consultation will occur during both the planning and development of the Studies of Society and Environment frameworks paper. It is in this context that the Commonwealth, and its collaborative partners in the process the State Governments, will have an opportunity to consider in what ways the Report and its findings has implications for school curricula and the development of a common curricula framework for this area.

While teaching and learning about active citizenship may be seen as integral to Studies of Society and Environment, it has relevance in other areas of the curriculum where learning has a social dimension and impact, including the curriculum areas of English, science, technology and mathematics. The skills of language, communication and negotiation, for example, which are also important aspects of learning for active citizenship, are also important aspects of learning in the curriculum area of English; such skills may also be considered for inclusion in a national statement on health education, which incorporates the area of personal development.

I am pleased to report that the Committee has commended the Government for initiating and providing ongoing support for the Citizenship Visits Program (CVP). This Program, initiated in response to Education for Active Citizenship, has been very successful, with the numbers of students visiting the Parliament from the distant States of Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory growing from a few hundred in 1988 to over 6,300 in 1990. The Government has agreed to funding for the CVP in 1991-92 of $650,000. More than 100 schools have booked places to participate in the Program this year, involving more than 4,000 students.

In addition to this Program, the Commonwealth Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Australian Electoral Commission fund the drafting, production, distribution and evaluation of a comic for disadvantaged youth called Streetwize. The comic covers such issues as the political process and its relevance to youth, the individuals potential for political action, where to enrol to vote and information on how to vote. Evaluation of the comic is carried out by sampling its readers. For example, in 1991 a sample of 130 young people from three States (metropolitan and rural) completed a questionnaire after reading comic number 18. The results have been used to better understand the problems encountered by youth in dealing with the political process and their part in this process, and to provide valuable feedback on these issues. Streetwize Comics have a national distribution system whereby sample comics and order forms are sent out to most youth services around Australia, including some distribution through Youth Access Centres. The Streetwize production and distribution process is documented in Reaching young People: The Streetwize Option. There have been seven evaluations of different aspects of the comics over the last five years.

The recommendations of the Committee are wide-ranging, and the majority of them are directed to agencies other than the Commonwealth Government, including schools, school systems and universities. The Commonwealth does not have the administrative responsibility for the operation of schools or higher education institutions and on many of the issues raised in the Active Citizenship Revisited report the Commonwealth's primary contributions to the advancement of the recommendations is to refer them to the relevant agency for consideration or co-operation with the States through the Australian Education Council (AEC).

The Commonwealth tabled the report at the recent 66th meeting of the AEC in October 1991. At this meeting, the AEC agreed to ask State and Territory Ministers to consider Recommendations 1.1, 1.2, 1.3 and 1.4 in relation to their school systems and provide a progress report to the first AEC meeting in 1992. The AEC also agreed to refer recommendations 2.1, 2.2, 2.3 and 2.5 to the AEC Curriculum and Assessment Committee for advice and report back to the first AEC meeting in 1992. The AEC has also asked the Curriculum and Assessment Committee to refer the report, as a source document, for the use of steering committees responsible for developing curriculum statements in Studies of Society and the Environment and other collaborative curriculum areas. Such referral will assist these processes take into account definitions, ideas, and issues concerning active citizenship and their role and integration in the curriculum. The AEC further agreed to refer recommendation 5.1 regarding production and distribution of the Australian Constitution to the Curriculum Corporation.

The recommendations of the Report which are directed to the curriculum, organisation and research of Higher Education institutions can only be acted upon by those institutions. The Commonwealth will refer the Report to the Australian Council of Deans of Education (ACDE), a newly formed body comprising representatives of State and Territory organisations representing education faculties and with special interests in teacher education and educational research. The ACDE is an appropriate national forum for the issues raised in the Reports recommendations for Higher Education. In addition, where appropriate recommendations will be referred to the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) and the State higher education authorities.
I attach the list of recommendations of the Standing Committee's Report and provide a response to each recommendation.
RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING ON
1. TO SCHOOLS AND EDUCATION SYSTEMS
Recommendation 1.1
The Committee recommends that school systems identify, publicise and support existing citizenship education initiatives and encourage their extension to other schools.
Response
The Government supports the recommendation, and has referred it to State and Territory Ministers of Education through the AEC.
Recommendation 1.2
The Committee recommends the establishment of human resource registers in schools as an aid to the development of active citizenship education.
Response
The Government supports the recommendation, and has referred it to State and Territory Ministers of Education through the AEC.
Recommendation 1.3

The Committee recommends that schools provide training and other assistance to student representatives on school councils to enable them to maximise the opportunities offered them to contribute to school governance. It further recommends that such training be extended to all school students to assist them to become active citizens in the wider community.
Response

The Government supports the recommendation, and has referred it to State and Territory Ministers of Education through the AEC. This recommendation has implications for school governance, school practices and organisation, teaching skills and strategies, participative learning and the transfer of learning from the school to the wider community environment.

As well, it has implications for the teaching and learning of skills of language, communication, decision making and negotiation. To this extent the Report's findings may be considered relevant to curriculum areas beyond Studies of Society, such as those of English and Health, which incorporates the area of personal development.
Recommendation 1.4
The Committee recommends that libraries, schools and other public information providers ensure the ready accessibility of a range of newspapers, and promote the reading and discussion of them.
Response

The Government supports the recommendation, and has referred it to State and Territory Ministers of Education through the AEC. Newspapers are already an important source of information and comment for many classroom activities but their wider promotion would need to be integrated with teaching and learning skills which focus on language, analysis and interpretation. In this context the curriculum frameworks paper in Studies of Society being developed by the AEC will not only seek to define the curriculum area encompassing active citizenship and identify it as a single discipline, cross-curricular and/or multi-disciplinary area of Studies of Society, but describe a number of strategies such as use of newspapers which could support the teaching and learning of active citizenship.
2. TO THE AUSTRALIAN EDUCATION COUNCIL
Recommendation 2.1

The Committee recommends that the AEC preface its national curriculum framework on Studies of Society and the Environment with an affirmation of the importance of values learning and with policy directions for teachers on appropriate strategies for implementing it.
Recommendation 2.2

The Committee recommends that the AEC develop a clear statement of the concept of active citizenship as a prerequisite for the formulation of the national curriculum framework for Studies of Society and the Environment.
Response to 2.1 and 2.2
The Government has referred these recommendations to the AEC for consideration.
Recommendation 2.3
The Committee recommends that:

(a)The Commonwealth and State Ministers of Education jointly commission regular national surveys of the political knowledge, attitudes and orientations of young people. This should be undertaken either as a separate initiative of the AEC, or as part of the existing national survey operations by, for example, the ANU, Research School of Social Sciences or the ACER, or the ABS.

(b)Controlled studies be undertaken to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed national social education curriculum specifically in relation to citizenship education in schools. Such studies might best be performed by the Curriculum Corporation.
Response

The Government supports the recommendation, and has referred it to State and Territory Ministers of Education through the AEC. In addition the AEC has already endorsed a process whereby in conjunction with the development of frameworks documents in each curriculum area subject profiles (or descriptions of learnings) and related assessment strategies are also being developed. Such processes will have considerable potential for schools and teachers as a mechanism for monitoring learning outcomes for students in areas such as Studies of Society. It is understood that the National Social Science Survey (NSSS) at the Research School of Social Sciences (RSSS), ANU surveys Australians attitudes to the political situation and opinions concerning the Commonwealth, State and Local Governments. The samples used are drawn from the Australian Electoral Roll, which by definition represents members of the population 18 years of age and over. The ABS would collect this type of attitudinal information concerning Australian youth on an ad hoc basis only.
Recommendation 2.4

The Committee recommends that active citizenship education at both preservice and inservice level be promoted in the context of the National Project on Quality Teaching and Learning being carried out under the auspices of the AEC.
Response

The National Project on the Quality of Teaching and Learning is a tripartite body with a mission to provide a forum for co-operative development work on key policy and procedural issues designed to improve the quality of teaching and learning across the nation. Since its inception the Project has established its priorities to enable attention to be given to the resolution of important structural issues. The major focus of the Project is therefore on award restructuring in the teaching profession covering such issues as: competencies, skills and techniques which make up the pedagogical component of teaching; structure and organisation of teachers' work and the relationship this has to management structures at school and regional levels; existing support structures for teachers; training and career structures; national framework for teachers' qualifications, conditions, and entitlements. `Active Citizenship' education, along with other teaching content and values issues fall outside the scope of the project. The Government will however refer this recommendation to the Australian Council of Deans of education in relation to pre-service education and to State/Territory education authorities in relation to in-service education activities.
Recommendation 2.5

The Committee recommends that a co-ordinated approach be adopted to the production of resource materials for the national curriculum on Studies of Society and the Environment. Production should be the responsibility of a variety of organisations including the Curriculum Corporation, the Parliamentary Education Office, the Australian Electoral Commission, State Education Departments and Legislatures and individual organisations with an interest in this subject. Materials should be designed to broaden the approach to active citizenship in schools and to complement existing materials.
Response

One of the aspects of national collaboration in curriculum and the development of national curriculum frameworks for the eight main curriculum areas is the identification of particular areas for curriculum materials development. The Corporation is currently considering the area of political education/active citizenship for curriculum materials development. A proposal to develop materials, subject to consultation with member systems and following development of a national statement in the curriculum area of Studies of Society and the Environment, is being considered. The Commonwealth will ensure that curriculum materials development work in this area involving Commonwealth agencies will be undertaken by, or in reference to, the Curriculum Corporation.
3. TO GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND DEPARTMENTS
Recommendation 3.1

The Committee recommends that seeding grants be offered by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (DILGEA), and other relevant agencies, to schools with a high proportion of non-English speaking background (NESB) students for innovative programs which are already operating successfully or have been developed to implementation stage.
Response

DILGEA offers a range of funding programs to facilitate settlement of migrants of NESB. One of the programs, the Migrant Access Projects Scheme (MAPS), provides funding towards the cost of projects likely to improve services to migrants settling in Australia.
Applications from organisations such as schools can already be considered under the Scheme for projects of a developmental nature.

However, under the Scheme preference is given to applications for projects which address current settlement priorities. In particular, the Scheme aims to improve the design, planning and coordination of services with migrants' needs in mind.

While recognising the value of such programs, it is not DILGEA's role to fund curriculum related initiatives. Should applications for such programs be received, usual practice is to refer them to other appropriate agencies.
Recommendation 3.2

The Committee recommends that local government associations coordinate and encourage individual local councils in implementing and following up educational programs on local government for adults and students within their communities. This should be done in cooperation with education systems.
Response

The Office of Local Government (OLG) supports this recommendation. The OLG is conscious of the need for greater awareness of the activities of Local Government and the relationship between local councils and the local community. The OLG prepared an article written to appeal to school age children outlining the role of Local Government within the three spheres of Government. This was included in a publication entitled `Project Help for Students of All Ages' which is sold through newsagents. Run-on copies of the articles have been sent to all local governing bodies throughout Australia plus Local Government Associations.

Under the Local Government Development Program, the Queensland Branch of the Municipal Officers' Association was funded to produce a booklet `Career Opportunities in Local Government' intended to provide school leavers and graduates with information on positions and careers available to them in Local Government. The book was released as part of a Local Government Awareness week in 1989 and the book and promotional ideas would be readily transferable to other States.

Entries in the 1990/91 National Awards for Innovation in Local Government indicate that individual Councils are promoting Local Government in their communities. For example, Flinders Shire Council produced a curriculum kit for school children to educate them about Local Government; Knox City Council produced a Local Government Projects Book designed for upper level primary school children and St Kilda City Council produced an information video on the services and facilities provided by Local Government.
Recommendation 3.3

The Committee recommends that education for active citizenship in the broad sense referred to in this Report be promoted as a National Priority Area in its own right under the National Priorities (Reserve) Fund.
Response

Australian studies is one of the national priority areas identified for the National Priority (Reserve) Fund. Under this category, institutions have been invited to submit curriculum development proposals which promote an appreciation and understanding of Australian issues, including "projects concerned with instruction in the parliamentary system of government, legislative processes and administration in Australia". In 1991 $80,000 was allocated under this heading to a project assessing the undergraduate and postgraduate needs of local government staff.

For the 1992 Fund there has been a change of emphasis away from funding individual projects to the funding of institutions under broad headings. Australian Studies will remain as a general priority area on which institutions may focus in applying for funding. The new arrangements which have been introduced for funding under the 1992 Reserve Fund are designed to place much greater emphasis on funding within a framework of institutional planning and decision making in relation to national priority areas. In this context funding will be directed to larger projects which reflect institutions' priorities in terms of their strategic plan instead of the former practice of funding many smaller projects.
Recommendation 3.4

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth specifically promote Goal 7 of the Hobart Declaration as an objective to be pursued in inservice training for teachers. This might best be pursued through Commonwealth Education Centres which should be encouraged to play a part in developing and coordinating inservice training for teachers of active citizenship in collaboration with state systems.
Response

Commonwealth Education Centres are Commonwealth funded independent organisations. They were established with the principal objective of improving the professional competence of teachers by providing inservice teacher training and the opportunity to test and implement curriculum changes. Commonwealth Education Centres provide resources and training to teachers from all school systems and have admirable relationships with most State and Territory education systems. These Centres would welcome the opportunity to promote Goal 7 of the Hobart Declaration, particularly through dissemination of materials on participative citizenship. The Commonwealth will undertake to involve the Centres in the dissemination of curriculum materials developed in this area through national collaborative processes.
4. TO HIGHER EDUCATION SYSTEMS
Recommendation 4.1

The Committee recommends that teacher training institutions place due emphasis on active learning, critical reflection and community involvement in their courses for teachers at both primary and secondary level.
Recommendation 4.2

The Committee recommends that teacher training institutions look closely at introducing participation as a way of stirring interest and enthusiasm among student teachers, too many of whom still lack the knowledge, skills and enthusiasm to excite their pupils with regard to active citizenship.
Response to 4.1 and 4.2

It would be possible for institutions to include elements of active citizenship and related themes within their pre-service programs for primary and secondary teachers, but the extent to which they would be prepared to do so, given the constraints applying to their existing programs in terms of time, resources and structure, would be an issue for consideration by the institutions, possibly in consultation with employing authorities. Both of these recommendations will be drawn to the attention of the Australian Council of Deans of Education (ACDE).
Recommendation 4.3

The Committee recommends that relevant Departments in Australian universities consider undertaking research into the way young people obtain information from newspapers, and the influence of print media on their political attitudes and awareness.
Response

The Government notes this recommendation and will refer it to the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) as an effective channel through which to pursue particular issues with relevant university departments.
5. TO LEGISLATURES AND THEIR AGENCIES
Recommendation 5.1

The Committee recommends the production and distribution of copies of the Australian Constitution, at minimum cost, to schools and to the general public through libraries, AGPS bookshops where they exist. This could be undertaken by the Curriculum Corporation, the Parliamentary Education Office or State Legislatures.
Response

The Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) prints and sells the Constitution through its bookshops and other outlets, and through its mail order service. Rates for bulk orders are available and, depending on quantity and quality, can be as low as 60 cents per copy. The size of the print and quality of paper of the A6 version enable it to be offered for sale at the inexpensive price of $2.50 which is the minimum necessary to cover production and distribution costs. A higher quality version, in a larger print size, is available for $8.50, while a Department of the Senate publication (including an outline of the content and structure of the Constitution) is available for $9.95.
In addition, this recommendation will be referred to the Curriculum Corporation by the AEC.
Recommendation 5.2

The Committee recommends that State Legislatures and universities consider the establishment of tertiary educational programs similar to that which operates between the University of Melbourne and the Victorian Parliament.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation and refers it to State higher education authorities to take up the matter with their local institutions.
Recommendation 5.3

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Education Office convene a meeting of education officers (or equivalent) of all Parliaments to discuss cooperative approaches to Parliamentary education in general, and to the production of learning resources in particular.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation.
Recommendation 5.4

The Committee recommends that favourable consideration be given by the National Parliament to the enhanced funding of the Parliamentary Education Office for the purpose of extending its community education programs and its educational leadership role amongst Australian legislatures.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation.
Recommendation 5.5

The Committee recommends that all Parliamentary and electoral education services re-examine their programs with a view to an increased emphasis on programs for adult clients, and to deliver those programs in a manner which encourages the content knowledge, contextual understanding and personal involvement necessary to promote genuine participation as an active citizen.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation.
6. TO THE PRESS
Recommendation 6.1

The Committee recommends that the journalists of Parliamentary press galleries, and the editors for whom they work, re-assess the public interest implications of their work in terms of the apparent emphasis on conflict and a limited range of key figures at the expense of issues-based political debate.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation.
7. TO COMMUNITY ORGANISATIONS
Recommendation 7.1

The Committee recommends that community and sporting groups consider the establishment of schemes similar to the Footscray Football Clubs BULLDOG CARE FOR KIDS program as a practical way to enhance the opportunities for young people to develop skills and attitudes conducive to successful citizenship.
Response
The Government notes the recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the very lively debate showing the ills of our economy at the moment and our large unemployment rate, it is interesting to see that there is a glimmer of hope in the 1990-91 annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission.

PARA.TAB: In a letter to the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) the Chairman, John Haddad, points out that despite the Gulf war and the effect it had on tourism into Australia, tourism grew by 4 per cent over the last 12 months when international travel overall is estimated to have dropped by 10 to 15 per cent. It speaks volumes for John Haddad, whom I know personally. He was responsible for the first casino in Australia—the Wrest Point Casino. He is a man of vision. I am pleased to see that at least the Government appointed someone who will achieve something.

I note that the Commission is aiming to achieve $10 billion in foreign exchange earnings by 1995-96. I just hope that that happens. According to this report, the major increase in tourism into Australia is from Japan. The actual increase is 20.3 per cent over the last 12 months. Senator Sherry would have to agree with my own experience in Tasmania and the large number of people out of work there. It was sad to see that, when the Sheraton Hotel advertised about 15 part time jobs recently, there were in excess of 200 people queuing all day to try to get interviews. It shows how bad the unemployment situation is in Tasmania at the moment.

I was very disturbed during Question Time to hear Senator Evans commenting on the proud record of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) over the last eight years. For the record, as far as Tasmania is concerned, the record of the Prime Minister and this Government over the last eight years has been a 50 per cent increase in unemployment in Tasmania and I have the figures to back that up.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Gray's contribution? He took all the credit when State unemployment went down in Tasmania. When it goes up you blame us.

—Mr Gray is not the Premier of Tasmania. We have a Labor government there at the moment. I do not think it can be very proud of the fact that Tasmania has the highest unemployment figure in Australia—11.7 per cent. We have 33.3 per cent young unemployed, as Senator Harradine pointed out, and 12.2 per cent of our males in Tasmania are unemployed.

PARA.TAB: This report is a report of hope. The Commission is looking to bring many more tourists into Australia. There has been a big increase in Japanese tourists; hundreds and thousands of them are flooding into Australia at the moment. Unfortunately, they use a lot of our services but they leave very little money to pay for them. They arrive in Japanese planes, they stay in Japanese owned hotels, they travel in Japanese owned buses and they buy their goods in Japanese owned duty free shops. Recently, I had the pleasure of looking at the new Japanese department store in Melbourne—the Daimaru.

That is all very well—they are investing in the future in Australia and they are creating jobs in Australia; there is no question about that. But under our proposed Fightback program, with a goods and services tax they will at least be making a contribution to the services in this country that they use. At present they do not make any contribution at all to the services they use, whether they be sewerage, water or whatever else. They are using those services which are paid for by the taxpayers of Australia.

Under our proposals they will be contributing, as they should be, as we do when we go overseas to other countries. We contribute to the services we use in those countries by paying a goods and services tax in most of them. That is exactly what we are planning. I believe that every Australian would agree with me, except perhaps Senator Sherry, who was a leading figure in the Liquor and Allied Trades Union in Tasmania. That is another story. Senator Sherry would have to agree that tourism is one way in which we can improve the unemployment situation in Tasmania. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the 1990-91 annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission. This document is one of the great success stories of the Hawke Labor Government. The Commission outlines, and underlines in black and white, the sheer increase in the volume of tourism into Australia in the period of the Hawke Labor Government during the 1980s. Australia has gone from having only about 200,000 international visitors per annum in the early 1980s to 2 1/4 million overseas visitors in 1988 in the bicentennial year.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that, despite the impact of the Gulf war, in the financial year 1990-91 we almost achieved that record figure of 2 1/4 million overseas visitors. We were within a few thousand of attaining that peak level of international visitors to Australia. It is a tremendous achievement compared with the backwater Australia was under the conservative Government in the early 1980s, when very few international visitors came to Australia. They could be numbered in the hundreds of thousands; now they can be numbered in the millions. The key growth area this year was Japan. About 480,000 Japanese visitors came to Australia, and there was a 20 per cent growth in the Australian inbound tourism market.

Senator Calvert very studiously ignored the important point in this report that not only are visitors staying longer in Australia, but also they are spending more in this country. Very important comments are made by the Australian Tourist Commission itself in underlining just what a contribution international tourists are now making to the Australian economy. They are spending more in the Australian economy; they are staying longer.

The new focus in tourism will be on Korea and Taiwan. There are now Qantas flights to Korea and a Qantas subsidiary—Australia-Asia Airlines—is now operating on the Taiwan route. Those areas have been targeted by the Australian Tourist Commission as potential major growth areas for inbound tourists to Australia. Of course, there has been the recent campaign by Mr Greg Norman to generate interest in Australian tourism in North America. I understand that the bookings from that new campaign of advertising Australia as a destination have gone up dramatically and are very optimistic for the future.

Tourism now at an international level is a major contributor to the Australian economy. It generates jobs, it generates investment and it is also a major contributor to our balance of payments. It is now effectively a major export earner for Australia in the form of a generator of foreign currency process. There has been a tremendous turnaround in the period of the Labor Government in international tourism. Australia was once a backwater under the Liberals; now we have a very large international tourism sector in our community.

It is a very labour-intensive sector of the economy. It creates many jobs. The Australian Tourist Commission quite rightly gives credit to the Federal Government for the success of recent campaigns. I refer to page 8 of the report, which states:

Much of ATC's success can be attributed to the level of support we now get from the Federal Government and our industry colleagues. Our marketing budget almost doubled during the review period following a Government decision in December 1990 to increase our allocation.

SPEECH.PARA: There it is. The Commission is sheeting home the success of this recent campaign for increased assistance from the Federal Government.

PARA.TAB: The last thing that this Government will do to the tourism industry is introduce a goods and services tax. We are not going to make Australia a more expensive international destination than it is at the present time. Those opposite are crazy in what they want to do to the tourism industry with a goods and services tax. People sitting in California will look at brochures, look at the opportunity and say, `Do I go to Hawaii? Do I go to Australia?', and they will see that with a goods and services tax the cost of travel to Australia will be increased. Australia will become a much more expensive international destination with a goods and services tax.

The reverse mechanism will also apply. Australians considering where they are going for a holiday will choose between local destinations within Australia and international destinations. They will find, when they see the effect of a goods and services tax, that Australia has become a more expensive destination compared with international places and will go offshore.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1990-91 annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission is important because in the present economic crisis around the world it is vital that Australia does what it can to develop one of the few industries that are still alive under this Government, and that is tourism.

PARA.TAB: Senator Maguire's comments illustrate the sort of muddled thinking that seems to be going on in the Government about the impact of a GST on the tourism industry. I am glad that Senator Maguire has said on behalf of the Government, and no doubt with deep authority—the sort of authority that he no doubt deserves from his position in the Government —that the Government is not going to introduce a GST on the tourism industry. In other words, the Government is going to leave Australia as one of the few nations in the world out of step with what happens throughout the developed nations.

Senator Maguire's claim that it would massively disadvantage tourists if a GST were to be introduced is just clear, self-evident bunkum. He knows that this Government has a very substantial sales tax on the inputs into the tourism industry. Maybe the good senator has not become aware of that—has not come in contact with it—but he must surely know that there is a 20 per cent sales tax on every sheet of toilet paper that is used in every tourist hotel in Australia. Apparently this Government regards that as a luxury; so it puts a 20 per cent sales tax on it.

Here is the Government hypocritically saying that it is somehow offensive to put a 15 per cent GST on accommodation, when at the same time the Opposition would totally remove the sales tax on all the inputs into the tourism industry. We would remove the payroll tax, which is one of the crippling elements of costs—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a State Government tax.

—Yes, it is a State Government tax, and we will withdraw it, and Senator Maguire knows that. We have a clear situation where we would be significantly reducing the costs of the tourism industry. For example, we would reduce the cost of freight by widening the excise on fuel. Think of the stimulus to internal tourism that that would generate.

PARA.TAB: We keep hearing absolute nonsense from people like Senator Maguire. The Senate will note that he said that because of the GST which will come in—and I am glad to notice the way that everyone, especially on the Government side, takes it for granted that the GST will come in because we will be elected—Australians will choose overseas destinations because it will be relatively cheaper to go there. The fact is that whenever Australians go to a European destination they end up paying VAT on their hotel rooms and so on.

I can assure the Government, soon to be the Opposition, that it has no position on this and is in total disarray. As has just been announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), he will stay on and fight the next election, and his decision has been endorsed by the six senior Ministers here. It means that we are going to have policy paralysis until heaven knows when, as this Government fails to do anything.

If there is any threat to the tourism industry, it is the threat of a government which is going nowhere, doing nothing and has no policies, and no capacity to reduce our massive unemployment. I stress to those opposite that it will be a disaster for local tourism if these 10 per cent unemployment rates persist, because Australians will not be able to afford internal tourism, let alone overseas tourism. That is the basic threat to the hospitality industry in Australia, whereas when the Opposition becomes the Government the coalition's Fightback package will be a massive stimulus to the Australian tourism industry, particularly local tourism. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the speech just delivered by Senator Michael Baume is an example of knowledge of the tourism industry, then heaven help the tourism industry under the Opposition if it ever gets into government. At least Senator Calvert displayed a little more knowledge of the tourism industry than Senator Baume. Those opposite have been demanding evidence of what we have been doing positively to improve the labour market in this country. I will give them some figures from the tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: When we took office in 1983, 402,000 were employed in the tourism industry. Today there are 605,000 people employed in the tourism industry. That is an increase of 50 per cent, an increase of 200,000 jobs in the tourism industry, in the last eight years under this Labor Government. What has happened in the past year? Job growth has continued. This time last year there were 561,000 jobs in the tourism industry and now there are 605,000. That is an example of dramatic job growth. In the past year under a Labor Government, 45,000 jobs have been created in the tourism industry. What do we get from those opposite? We do not get a word of thanks; all we get is negative criticism. The job figures for the hospitality industry speak for themselves.

A number of important factors emerge from the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission. There was a 3.7 per cent total growth rate in tourist arrivals to this country in the past year. Again, there has been no thanks from those opposite for what this Government has been doing through the ATC and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to encourage job growth in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —A million people on the dole.

—If Senator Crane wants some examples of what we have done, this is a good example of what we have done. Why do those opposite not acknowledge it? They will flatten the tourism industry with their 15 per cent consumption tax. We will see what sort of job growth there is when a 15 per cent consumption tax is put on the tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: The Japanese tourist market has continued to grow with the number of visitor arrivals increasing from 405,000 to 488,000 in the past year. New Zealand is an interesting example because tourism arrivals there have declined by 2,000 in the past year. Why? The economy has collapsed because of a goods and services tax and the implementation of policies that those opposite want to implement. Those policies have flattened the New Zealand economy and that is startling evidence of what those opposite would do to this economy if they ever got into office.

We increased funding to the Australian Tourist Commission in the past year from $56m to $62m. The Tourist Commission is a good example of what a positive increase in government funding can do. The industry should be congratulated. The industry itself has increased its contribution from $11m per annum to $13m per annum. Even in the area of other income, the Tourist Commission has done an excellent job. Its revenue rose from $3.8m to $5.5m because it had the foresight to ensure that the money that it brought in from overseas increased in value due to changes in the fluctuation of the dollar. So the ATC should be congratulated for what it has done.

The Government has shown vision for the future. The television campaign by Greg Norman was actively pursued and promoted by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, David Simmons. That is another great example of what this Government has done in tourism. I am pleased to see in the report that the Tourist Commission is looking at eco-tourism. That is one of the greatest areas of improved visitation in the world. One of the few things I will agree on with Senator Calvert is that it is good to see that John Haddad has been reappointed to the position of Director of the Tourist Commission. He did a great job for tourism in Tasmania and under this Government he will continue to do a great job for Australia.

There has not been a word of thanks for our Minister, David Simmons, from those opposite. They are full of negative comments and criticism. He is one of the quiet, great achievers of this Government. The Minister has done an excellent job in continuing to promote tourism.

The 15 per cent goods and services tax that those opposite wish to introduce will flatten the hospitality industry in this country. If we look at the Fightback! document, the `Doomsday book' as I refer to it, the Opposition is to abolish the Department of Tourism. The Opposition claims that that will save $23m. If it takes into account the cost of redundancy and shifting staff—the ATC's headquarters are in Sydney where it is very expensive to rent accommodation—it cannot possibly save $23m. That is another example of a negative approach, of removing the positive props of government, the positive initiatives that are necessary to encourage industrial development in this country.

The tourism industry stands as one of the great successes of this Government. All those opposite want to do is tax it to death with a 15 per cent goods and services tax. They want to tax to death our greatest single export earner. They want to dismantle the government structures around it as well. That is no way to go.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel for Senator Sherry. Obviously it is a very stressful day for the Labor senators. They are not sure who their leader is going to be tomorrow, tonight, or in half an hour's time. They are not sure which backbenchers will get onto the front bench. Poor old Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations, is not sure whether he made a mistake a couple of months ago which will mean that he will end up on the back bench.
—You will have to put up with me for a long, long time, I'll tell you that.
—Senator Cook—
—What has that got to do with tourism?
—That is a good question from Senator Sherry. I think it is fair enough that Senator Sherry should ask the Opposition to recognise—
—Are the job figures right in tourism? Come on, are they right?

—I listened to Senator Sherry in absolute silence. Like Senator Sherry, I have had some experience in the tourism industry. I think that the Australian tourism industry should be congratulated for what it has achieved, in spite of the recession that this Government has created. If the figures that Senator Sherry referred to in his contribution to the debate on the annual report of the Australian Tourist Commission are correct—I have no reason to doubt them—then, indeed, the industry should be congratulated.

PARA.TAB: However, if the Government wants to take the credit for what has been achieved in tourism in Australia, it should also take the credit for what has been achieved in the rest of the economy. It is not fair for Senator Sherry to say that the Government has created an environment which is conducive to growth in this very important industry, because there are a number of things the Government could do to make the industry blossom even more.

We have an incredible potential in the tourism area. We could probably double or triple the number of tourists who come to Australia and thereby create the sort of job growth that the Hewson Fightback package looks at. An important point that should be made is that there are a number of disincentives to growth in this industry, and the area of industrial relations is one of them. Senator Sherry very well knows some of the problems that exist in the tourism industry due to the current state of industrial relations, both in State and Federal jurisdictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, the workers aren't paid enough. There's a severe skill shortage. They should be paid more.

—Senator Sherry is probably quite right, but in the short time I have to speak I would like to be given at least the same courtesy that I gave Senator Sherry during his address. It is clearly stupid for someone working at the Mirage in Port Douglas to be told by someone in Collins Street in Melbourne how much they should be paid per hour, as it is for someone working in Caves House in Margaret River—a place that I am sure the Minister for Industrial Relations is familiar with. We need a decentralised wage system and the tourism industry is a particular example where that can apply. The work structures of those who are employed in the industry need to be more flexible. We need more multiskilling, to use the Minister's term, but more flexibility, to use my term.

PARA.TAB: The industry is to be congratulated and the Australian Tourist Commission should also be congratulated. We should be going a lot further. It is wrong to criticise the effects of the GST on the industry. The tourism industry supports our package. There is a lot more in the package than Senator Sherry would have others believe. When people living in the United States of America make a choice as to whether to travel to European destinations, to Australia or to Japan, they will note that in just about every OECD country to which they may choose to travel there is a similar form of value added or goods and services tax. So, of course, Australia is putting itself in the same league.

As to the removal of fuel excise, I heard Senator Sowada interjecting earlier about the tax on jet fuel. Of course, there is no such tax. The fact is that domestic tourism is a very important part of our market. One hell of a lot of mums and dads, middle Australians and lower income Australians are big users of fuel. Under the Opposition's policies, the cost of their travel and their holidays will be reduced. The other point that Senator Sherry should realise is that the cost for someone travelling from the mainland to Tasmania on either the Sea Cat or the Abel Tasman will be reduced by between $10 and $20 per head, which will help his own State. So before he criticises our policies, he should look at them very closely. I will give his side of the chamber credit where it is due. He should perhaps give more credit to our policy when it is due.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas has been through a very difficult year and faces another period of difficulty. However, I think with a very dedicated board and with enthusiasm there is a prospect that its long term problems may well be overcome; but it will take a great deal of effort.

PARA.TAB: The problems can clearly be seen from the table at the beginning of the report which shows that although Qantas flew an extra 10 per cent of kilometres, increasing from 118.7 million to 130.7 million, the number of passengers carried fell by 2.1 per cent; so it worked harder to receive less. Its revenue seat factor fell from 69.1 per cent to 66 per cent, and the revenue load factor fell from 66.7 per cent to 65.2 per cent. This clearly was a year that was interrupted by problems in the Middle East and, as the Australian Tourism Commission report shows, passenger traffic from Europe was seriously interrupted.

How this can be resolved is a matter of great concern. One would hope that the industrial problems that have at times made it difficult for Qantas to keep its punctuality, and which have disrupted it in the past, will continue to diminish. As I notice on a chart on page 9, the trend is in the right direction. But there is no doubt that, in this very competitive environment, the fewer disruptions that there are to the service that Qantas provides the better. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Landcare is a non-profit company which was established in 1989 as one of the spin-offs of the decade of land care and the billion trees program. The company was established with a number of objectives. Amongst those was included the following: to develop a land care ethic amongst all Australians; to encourage and stimulate public awareness of the importance of land care and the adoption of land care principles; to encourage and stimulate public participation in land care activities; and to encourage and facilitate education on land care principles in schools and the community generally.

PARA.TAB: I believe that a lot of that is happening because it is established in every State and varies in its operations from State to State. It is being funded through an overdraft arrangement with the Federal Government through the national soil conservation program. It is envisaged—and I hope it will be successful—that corporate sponsorship continues to ensure the ongoing works of Landcare. A target of $2m has been set for 1991-92 which, given the recessionary times, will not be easy to reach. However, the investment we put into soil and land conservation works today will be repaid tenfold in the next decade.

I spoke to people in the country areas a little while ago; we all know they are going from drought into flood in some areas. Mr Deputy President, in the south of your State, for example, river rises are now being reported because some eight inches of rain or more has fallen in the last day or two. It is very welcome because it breaks the drought, but now it has gone from drought to flood. If land care measures are in place and people are looking after their land in a proper, sustainable way, and given the incentive and the education to do it by the outreach from Landcare, obviously the land will be looked after in a much better way.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the annual report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report describes the operations of the Committee during the 1990-91 year. During this year the Committee was particularly active, scrutinising some 1,645 pieces of delegated legislation, which is a greater number than in any previous year. I think I can say that the Committee is carrying out its charter from the Senate to ensure that delegated legislation, made by the Executive under the authority of Acts, is of the highest quality. In this context the Acting Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Norman Reaburn, mentioned the work of the Committee when he opened a public seminar on delegated legislation earlier this year. He said that the Committee `was vital to maintaining the integrity of the law of this country'. Although we on the Committee take ourselves very seriously, and our tasks also, we would be too modest to make this claim on our own behalf. Nevertheless, it is very pleasing when the Committee receives such recognition.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that during the year Ministers and other law makers gave undertakings to amend or review no fewer than 54 different instruments or parent Acts to meet the concerns of the Committee. These undertakings are separate from the many other less significant but still important undertakings to improve explanatory statements, provide numbering and citation for instruments, or take administrative action. This represents a high level of commitment by Ministers to the non-partisan parliamentary ideals of personal liberties and parliamentary proprieties.

To take just one example, the most important umbrella Act dealing with delegated legislation is the Acts Interpretation Act. The Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, undertook to amend that Act to meet our concerns immediately after the Committee raised a particular matter. That is the kind of cooperation the Committee receives from Ministers. This amendment will have an important effect upon regulations made under all Acts.

The report also gives details of the Committee's submission to the inquiry by the Administrative Review Council on rule making by Commonwealth Agencies. The ARC is the statutory body responsible for providing advice to the Government on review of administrative decisions. There has already been an interim report on the project and we understand that the final report will go to the Minister this month. That interim report accepted the major recommendations put by the Committee. If these recommendations of the Committee are accepted and implemented it will be the most important reform affecting delegated legislation since the Acts Interpretation Act itself was passed in the first year of Federation. The Committee will report in detail to the Senate after we receive the final thoughts of the Administrative Review Council. I commend the Committee's report to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

.Stage 3 Development of RAAF Base Tindal, NT
.CSIRO Redevelopment, Parkville, VIC.
.Relocation of Naval Support Command Headquarters, Pyrmont, NSW
.Special Broadcasting Service Relocation of Radio & Television, Artarmon, NSW

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President
(Tindal Speech)
The first report which I have presented relates to the third stage of the development of RAAF Base Tindal, Northern Territory.
Stages 1 and 2 of the development were the subject of previous reports by the Committee in 1984 and 1987.

The development of RAAF Base Tindal over the past seven years represents one of the largest and most expensive defence infrastructure developments in Australia's history. What in 1984 was a bare base, located in a remote area with a harsh climate, has been transformed into a modern air force base. It was obvious to the Committee during the inspection of the base that RAAF personnel are proud of what has been achieved.

Stage 3 will involve the provision of air defence facilities, living-in accommodation, deployed squadron operational and technical facilities, aircraft pavements, aircraft shelters and associated engineering services.
The estimated cost of the proposed work is 53.5 million dollars at April 1991 prices.
The Committee has recommended that the works comprising Stage 3 should proceed.

Facilities for use by aircraft deployed to Tindal are required because existing operational and support facilities, which were essentially provided for No. 75 Squadron, are inadequate. The Committee therefore concluded that if it is intended to continue the deployment of fighter and strike aircraft to Tindal, adequate facilities must be provided for them.
Similarly, additional aircraft pavements are required to realise the full potential of the master-planned `coathanger' runway and taxiway configuration.

The Committee also concluded that now is a good time for the relocation of No 2 Control and Reporting Unit from Darwin to Tindal. Facilities in Darwin are inadequate to house replacement equipment which it is proposed to acquire. There would be strategic and operational advantages as well as financial benefits if the unit were located at Tindal and for the relocation to coincide with the delivery of replacement equipment.

In conclusion, I would like to mention two matters which generated some local interest at the Committee's public hearing into the proposal. A number of witnesses suggested the scope of Stage 3 development should be extended by the inclusion of a bicycle track from Katherine to Tindal. Some RAAF personnel cycle along the Stuart Highway, a practice which is potentially dangerous because of the heavy traffic.
The Committee concluded that a bike track could be constructed linking East Katherine with Tindal, with the Northern Territory Government and Katherine Town Council meeting the cost.

The second matter concerns the need for an independent analysis of the drainage pattern of the Tindal-Katherine area. The Katherine Town Council submitted to the Committee that unusually heavy flooding of the eastern side of Katherine had occurred during the 1990/91 wet season. The Council believes this flooding may be the result of the development of Tindal. The Committee has recommended that an independent analysis of the drainage pattern of the Tindal-Katherine area should be undertaken to identify factors contributing to flooding and to recommend realistic measures to minimise it. The analysis should be funded by Territory Government and Katherine Town Council.
(Parkville Speech)

The second report I have tabled relates to the redevelopment of CSIRO facilities at Parkville, Victoria. CSIRO is proposing to redevelop its Parkville site as a major research complex and to provide the headquarters for the Division of Biomolecular Engineering. The redevelopment will provide facilities for 140 staff and work will be undertaken in three stages so that the site remains operational at all times. The Committee has recommended that the work proceed at a cost of 12.25 million dollars.
In February 1990, the mission of the Division of Biomolecular Engineering was changed to concentrate on assisting the development of the Australian pharmaceutical and health care industries.
The change in direction away from wool technology and agricultural protein research will have a major impact on the nature of laboratory accommodation required by the Division.
CSIRO advised the Committee that the existing laboratories require urgent upgrading to provide facilities suitable for sophisticated computer-based instrumentation and micro-analytical techniques.

The continued occupation by the CSIRO of the site at 343 Royal Parade, Parkville was strongly opposed by the Parkville Association. The Association fundamentally believes that the location in North Parkville of such a facility is inappropriate, because North Parkville is an area which the Association regards as being predominantly residential and having high environmental sensitivity. The view of the Parkville Association was supported by the Melbourne City Council.

While the Committee appreciates the wish of the Parkville Association and the Melbourne City Council to retain the predominantly residential nature of Parkville, the fact is that CSIRO has been established on the Parkville site in accordance with local planning regulations since 1952.
The Committee accepts the view of CSIRO, which was supported by other research institutions, that the Parkville location of the Division of Biomolecular Engineering is vital to its research program.

In recommending that the works proceed the Committee has recommended that CSIRO should provide it with a comprehensive report detailing the energy management systems and energy conservation measures to be incorporated in the Parkville development.

Concern was expressed at the public hearing by the Commonwealth Fire Board and the Melbourne Metropolitan Fire Brigade regarding the effects of the `immunity of the Crown' from state building regulations particularly in relation to fire safety. The Committee is still considering the wider implication of this issue and will report to the Parliament shortly. However at this stage the Committee has recommended that consultation with local fire authorities should be undertaken prior to the referral of all projects to the Committee.
(REVY Speech)

The third report relates to the relocation of the Naval Support Command Headquarters from the Remington Centre in the Sydney CBD to two former Naval warehouses at the Royal Edward Victualling Yard at Pyrmont. The proposal is to refurbish the historic warehouses to provide office accommodation.
The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed at an estimated cost of 13.4 million dollars at April 1991 prices.
The Committee concluded that accommodation occupied by the Support Command in the City is inadequate and very costly at an annual rental of 4.7 million dollars.

The proposed relocation and refurbishment appeared to the Committee to be the best option examined in terms of capital cost and recurrent expenditure. Indeed, the Committee concluded that the refurbishment offers the Commonwealth the opportunity to capitalise on an existing asset and at the same time provide the Support Command with accommodation in an area with a maritime flavour.

The two buildings to be refurbished are listed on the Register of the National Estate. The Committee concluded that provided the recommendations of the conservation and management plan and of the Australian Heritage Commission are adhered to, the refurbished buildings will maintain an important part of Sydney's maritime heritage as well as providing modern office accommodation for the personnel of the Support Command Headquarters.

The Committee also concluded that the proposal represents an ideal opportunity for the inclusion of a state of the art building services system designed to exceed current energy targets, and for the provision of a building services monitoring system, capable of sensing and rectifying air quality as well as temperatures.

The proposal is the first occasion in which the Department of Defence has not used Australian Construction Services as its design and construction authority. Instead, Defence will call tenders for a number of contractors to design, execute and supervise construction. Given this change, the Committee has recommended that it be provided with six-monthly reports on the achievement of major milestones in the design and construction of the proposal and the level of expenditure.
(SBS Speech)

The last of the four reports that I am tabling today relates to the relocation of SBS Radio and Television to premises in Artarmon, New South Wales. The SBS plans to relocate radio station 2EA at Bondi Junction and SBS television at Milsons Point to an existing building in Artarmon. The proposal that the SBS put to the Public Works Committee was for the renovation of an office/warehouse complex for the SBS's use, at a cost of 14.5 million dollars.

The Committee has concluded that there is a need for the SBS to have new premises. Its present premises are too small for its requirements and its television service is constrained by the grossly inadequate studio space available to it.

The SBS carried out an extensive search for new premises before choosing the Artarmon site. It found that a new, purpose-built building was beyond its means and opted to adapt an existing building to its requirements. The building in Artarmon will provide the SBS with the space that it needs and, most importantly, with the scope to adapt part of the warehouse in the complex as studios to industry standards. This will allow the SBS, for the first time since it was established in 1978, to extend its television current affairs coverage to panel discussions with more than three participants and with the possibility of having an audience. It will also provide the SBS with the means of making its own productions. With these facilities, the SBS will be better placed than it is at present to serve Australia's multicultural community.

Some concern was expressed to the Committee about the choice of Artarmon as the location for the SBS's new premises. On balance, however, the Committee believes that the location is a suitable one. It is a cheaper location than the CBD, it is near other television stations and associated services, public transport makes it readily accessible for staff and contributors, and it will prove to be an asset. Furthermore, the building is larger than the SBS needs. The SBS plans to lease out the excess space and use the revenue gained to help finance local productions.

The Public Works Committee is recommending that Commonwealth funds be spent on the refurbishment of the office/warehouse complex at 14 Herbert Street, Artarmon to provide accommodation for the SBS's radio, television and corporate services. In making this recommendation, the Committee was concerned about the very tight time frame for the refurbishment and the use of fast track methods of construction. We know that fast track construction tends to be more expensive than normal methods and, if the tight time frame for the project slips, the SBS will encounter additional costs. Because of these concerns, the Committee has recommended that the SBS report to it every three months on how well the project is keeping to its program and its budget.

Finally I will mention that the Committee also made recommendations about energy conservation, parking and transport for shift workers and the provision of child care. In addition, the Committee urges the SBS to undertake more comprehensive consultation with the unions than it has hitherto.
I commend these reports to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
