DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies

TALK.START.PARA: —I present an interim report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies on telephone services.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has decided to bring down an interim report at this time because of its concern about the continued availability of unsuitable material on Telecom's 0055 telephone message services. Telecom has requested that the Committee give it some indication of its attitude to the issue of content regulation before the end of 1991, because of the need to regularise its contractual relationship with the information service providers. Therefore, the Committee has indicated to Telecom that it will comply with this request, and is now bringing down an interim report specifically in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The Committee was established on 21 June 1991 as a result of concerns expressed by a number of honourable senators about the absence from the Telecommunications Bill 1991, agreed to by the Senate on 17 June 1991, of any provision to regulate the content of telecommunications services. Furthermore, there was considerable disquiet in the community about the content of material carried by Telecom using its 0055 and Discovery services, particularly as to the suitability of the material being transmitted to the family home where it could be accessed by minors.

The Committee has received 2,242 submissions, many of them signed by or representing more than a single individual. In addition, around 700 form letters, and 40 petitions—signed by a total of 7,085 petitioners—have been received. The Committee has conducted three full days of public hearings in Melbourne, Sydney and Canberra and held a final hearing of Telecom management in Canberra on 7 November 1991.

The Committee has sought to identify the nature of `adult' material being carried by Telecom on its 0055 commercial recorded message service and the measures undertaken by Telecom to ensure the acceptability of that content having regard to community standards for equivalent material available through other media.

The Committee recognises Telecom's genuine efforts to respond to community concerns by establishing the Telephone Information Services Standards Committee—TISSC—incorporating the TISSC codes of practice into its agreements with the service providers, and appointing a telephone information services arbitrator to adjudicate on telephone messages in the light of the codes of practice.

However, the Committee is not satisfied with Telecom's response to Federal Government concerns, and, indeed, to the concerns of the Committee. The Committee notes that the then Minister for Transport and Communications, the Hon. Kim Beazley, wrote to Telecom's Chairman in September this year to express his concern to ensure that all `adult' services be removed immediately from 0055.

The Committee is also critical of Telecom for its failure to fully respond to the Committee's operations and for having proceeded with certain areas of policy measures which clearly fall within the Committee's terms of reference, while the Committee's inquiry has been still in progress. It is acknowledged that some of these related to long term contractual arrangements, but the Committee was not informed of these in its initial hearing.

The interim report makes clear the Committee's concern about the adequacy of Telecom's current approach to content regulation and, in fact, commends the approach that Telecom management had originally adopted when the 0055 information service commenced operations in July 1988. The Committee notes that, if Telecom had shown greater concern for the public interest rather than the industry's commercial interest in the early days of the 0055 service, this aspect of the Committee's inquiry would have been unnecessary.

The recommendations contained in the Committee's interim report call on Telecom to adopt a code of conduct which would completely eliminate the carriage of unacceptable sexual material on 0055 where it is accessible by minors. This is in line with former Minister Beazley's request and is the unanimous view of this bipartisan Committee. The industry would then be allowed to cater for this market only through its 0051 closed user access service, restricted to adults who must opt in to the system, but only for material of an equivalence to the M film-video rating. The Committee has recommended that Telecom ensure compliance with this code of conduct by utilising the services of the Office of Film and Literature Classification as the expert and independent arbiter of community standards.

The Committee has rejected Telecom's approach to the problem, essentially because it is clearly not working. While a new code of practice, introduced on 22 October 1991, was designed to address the problem of `adult' material being accessible to minors on 0055, advertisements continue to appear in the daily press for such 0055 services. In the Canberra Times as recently as 7 December, some of these services are still being advertised; for example, `Gay Affairs', `My First Time', `What Gays Do' and `Inch By Inch'.

The Committee's recommendations will work to resolve this issue where Telecom's measures have failed. The principal recommendation of the Committee as to message standard reflects the fact that the submissions and evidence were almost exclusively concerned with sex content of messages on open access 0055 services.

The Committee's response includes a direct restatement in its recommendation 1(a) of standard 1.1(a) of Telecom's own operational requirements—issue No. 3 of 31 January 1990 —contained in an attachment to the 0055 service provider agreement. The operational requirements referred to above contain other standards or codes of conduct relating to content and advertising which deserve to be retained in any new contract or agreement between Telecom and service providers. The Committee did not find it necessary to canvass these.

In its continuing inquiries next year, the Committee will monitor Telecom's implementation of these recommendations. It will also examine in detail the carriage of adult material on the Discovery service by Genesis Telecommunications Pty Ltd. The Government's announcement of its approval of pay TV on 9 October 1991 and the release of the exposure draft of the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 on 7 November 1991, by which pay TV services will be regulated, will also be the subject of close attention by the Committee in its continuing inquiries.

I would like to thank the secretariat for its energy and commitment in handling large volumes of correspondence and in giving consistent support to the Committee. I would especially thank all members of the Committee for their cooperation in assisting to make unanimous recommendations on this important and sensitive issue which has concerned so many parents. I look forward to further developing this harmonious approach to the remaining issues before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds, as the chairperson of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies, has adequately dealt with this matter. But as I have no doubt that at some stage members of the Committee and other senators will wish to have a discussion on the report, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOHN CURTIN SCHOOL OF MEDICAL RESEARCH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes the growing concern in the community about the Federal Government's handling of the management of the John Curtin School of Medical Research (JCSMR) of the Australian National University (ANU); and
(b)calls on:

TAB.TAB: (i)the parliamentary representatives on the Council of the ANU to support the rescinding motion relevant to the JCSMR before the ANU Council on 13 December 1991, and

(ii)the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to take no further action on the administrative arrangements for the JCSMR until the findings of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training are brought down on 1 April 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I gave notice of this motion that calls upon the Senate to note the growing concern in the community over the Federal Government's handling of the management of the John Curtin School of Medical Research. The motion also calls on the parliamentary representatives on the ANU Council to support the recision motion before tomorrow's meeting of that Council. Further, it calls on the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to take no further action with respect to the administrative arrangements of the JCSMR until the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has handed down its report on the matter on 1 April 1992. It is this motion which the Government opposes and I am compelled to speak today in order to try to head off this blatant abuse of power by the Minister and to stop his hidden agenda of intervention in the affairs of universities.

PARA.TAB: The Australian National University has effectively been blackmailed into abdicating its responsibilities for the John Curtin School of Medical Research to the National Health and Medical Research Council. This action was taken by the ANU Council under duress. In holding the purse strings, Mr Baldwin has attempted to circumvent the will of the Parliament, breach the autonomy of the university and emasculate the authority of the ANU Council.

The ANU is established by an Act of Parliament which specifies that there will be a research school in the field of medical science and that it is to be known as the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It also states that the ANU Council should have the entire control and management of the university. It would seem, therefore, pretty much cut and dried that it would be impossible to separate the two bodies. To do so would certainly be against the spirit of the law.

The Council is, however, able to delegate powers. It will, under the Baldwin plan, hand over responsibility for the John Curtin School to a committee that will be controlled by the NHMRC, with token university representation. Under this arrangement the ANU gives away as much control as it can under the law. The effectiveness of these arrangements will be a factor in the disbursement of funds. This means that, if the National Health and Medical Research Council does not get what it wants, it can ask the Minister to cut funding to the school. This only underscores the fact that the ANU will lose control of the school.

The great majority of the Council members were strongly opposed to the loss of this control. Although the NHMRC has a record of good management, they questioned the wisdom of centralising the funding of all Australian medical research. This goes to show that this Government continues to be deaf to the argument that a plurality of views must be cultivated if the country's scientific enterprises are to remain healthy.

At the moment the questions of how funds are to be administered, representation of academic staff and the relationship with the Institute of Advanced Studies have not been addressed. This is a sign of the haphazard and careless approach that the Government has taken in its rush to dominate and centralise the centres of higher learning in this country.

Government interference with and intervention in higher education institutions have been both disruptive and destructive. We now have a bureaucratically administered system dominated by ministerial discretion. Independence of the education system has had to make way for bureaucratic favours while the Government enforces policy with the threat of withholding funds. Now this ruinous policy has gone as far as threatening the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

The JCSMR is first and foremost an academic unit within a university structure. It has never been a freestanding research institute with a top-down management structure driven by a mission oriented research agenda. Its greatest strength is that it nurtures and tolerates long term research on a wide range of problems. Yet from this wellspring emerge trendsetting research areas, of which the John Curtin School of Medical Research can be justly proud.

The JCSMR is a world-class biomedical research institute. Its greatest strength is that it nurtures and tolerates long term research on a diverse range of problems. In fact, the John Curtin School is one of the few institutions left, thanks to the Dawkins-Baldwin assault on the higher education system, that still continues this essential research—research which is not politically or economically motivated but which ultimately yields the most beneficial results.

History has shown that the results of this research, without the Government breathing down the necks of the researchers for instant results, have been the essential building blocks for so many of the advances made in science but which may not come to fruition commercially until after many years. It is these commercial results that are so often used in comparing the JCSMR with other research institutions such as the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, which is funded by the NHMRC. These comparisons, however, have very limited validity as the research objectives are very different in nature.

The Hall has a much narrower function than the John Curtin School, which must also cater for the broad education of graduate students. On a per dollar basis, the John Curtin School is as productive as the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research but it is fundamentally different from this institution in that it tackles basic scientific problems that often have a very long lead time.

This unique quality of the JCSMR is something that should be treasured and nurtured. It is through institutions such as the John Curtin School that Australia can stay at the cutting edge of scientific advancement. The work being undertaken at the school will stand us in good stead in the future. It is not something that should be thrown away. Yet this is what Mr Baldwin and the Hawke Government are asking us to do in order to meet short term political goals.

The John Curtin School, which is an integral part of the ANU, was not established to be just another arm of government policy. This was clearly not the wish of its founders, who include such eminent Australians as Sir Howard Florey, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs. Likewise, that is certainly not the wish of the Opposition. Mr Baldwin has tried to gain control by circumventing the authority of the Parliament through manipulating the ANU into delegating its powers. This cannot be allowed to occur.

In this place last week, I moved that the issue of the JCSMR's funding and control be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. The motion was passed and the Committee is to report on 1 April 1992. In this way, Mr Baldwin cannot get around the will of the Parliament. The Committee can fully investigate the actions of the Minister and call him to account.

The Minister's actions have put all Australian universities on notice that the Federal Government will not hesitate to intervene at any level in their internal affairs. We cannot allow the Government to continue this interference in our higher education institutions. Research is already being manipulated to fit a national agenda through the Australian Research Council and its funding criteria and the discredited education profiling process.

It is difficult for nations to establish a truly first-class research and scholarly institution. Australia has done this with the ANU and the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It does not make sense that we should undermine the really good thing that we have established. We must embrace change but at the same time be very conscious of the excellent and potentially durable institutions that we have established—institutions such as the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

In a deplorable action, the Government has inflicted its policy on the ANU and the school against the wishes of almost all concerned. The Senate must reject these actions. That is why this motion is before the Senate. With support from this place, the ANU Council should rescind its reluctant decision to relinquish control of the John Curtin School of Medical Research and Mr Baldwin should halt his destructive plans until the Senate Committee reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support the motion moved by the Opposition in relation to the Government's handling of the John Curtin School of Medical Research. It is quite clear that the Federal Government hoped that this issue would simply die a death and go away, but to its shock it has grown bigger than Ben Hur. It is an outworking of the greater malaise in the higher education system—that is, the disillusion, the dissatisfaction and the disenchantment felt by many students and academics with the direction of higher education and research funding in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have seen the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, directly intervening in the affairs of the ANU and in the life of a vibrant and international element of the university's diverse research program and shunting it off elsewhere. The university's administrative and financial control of the John Curtin School of Medical Research is being transferred to the National Health and Medical Research Council, a move which will have serious implications for the autonomy of the research programs conducted by the John Curtin School.

Indeed, it has already been reported in the Australian on 4 December that the funding of investigations into the immune system of large animals by noted immunologist Dr Peter McCullagh has been deemed unfashionable by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Indeed, the same report goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . while acknowledging his work is of a high calibre, the NHMRC has nevertheless recommended it be discontinued.

So much for supporting quality research of vital interest to our rural community. One must ask what other controls, changes and interference will occur with the change in administration and funding of the John Curtin School. Serious questions must be asked of the wisdom of this move when respected senior Australian academics such as Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs are prepared to so publicly and bitterly criticise the Government's interference in relation to the ANU and the John Curtin School. Indeed, I understand that Sir Mark Oliphant has offered to hand back his honorary doctorate.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats supported the reference of this issue to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on 2 December 1991. We believe that these are issues which should be investigated by the Committee, particularly in relation to the actions of the Minister. In light of this reference, I believe that it is imperative that the Committee be allowed to investigate and table its findings before any further action is taken in relation to the transfer of the school. In supporting this motion, the Australian Democrats have been advised that support for it, especially of part (b), which calls on the parliamentary representatives on the university council to support the recision motion on Friday the 13th, will not result in those members of this Parliament who are on the board being held in contempt of the Senate if they do not support the recision motion.

As the ANU is governed by an Act of this Parliament, we have a right and responsibility to scrutinise executive activity which may affect the operation and academic health of the Australian National University. This motion expresses that concern, along with emphasising that the Minister must abide by the due processes which have now been set in place by the Standing Committee inquiry. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put the Government's view on this issue. I want to indicate that because of time considerations we will not call for a division. But we must oppose this motion, not because of any substantive differences of opinion we may have about it but because of the inappropriateness of the Senate taking a position on this issue, especially on the particular concerns expressed in the motion, at a time when the Senate has given the Committee which I chair—the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—a reference asking us as a matter of inquiry to look at the issues and problems that surround the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PARA.TAB: It would be entirely inappropriate if I, or anyone else for that matter, were to be involved in a debate in this Senate prior to our Committee bringing down its report. It would be very silly if, as Chairman of the Committee, I were to get up and express viewpoints on behalf of the Government, myself or the Committee when we have an inquiry under way. As I said, because of that, I do not propose to debate any of the substantive issues that are raised in the motion except to say that it is inappropriate in terms of the way in which the Senate examines things simply to say, `Here are our views as a Senate. We will then go and have an inquiry. The inquiry will come back and presumably find that what we have said today is true or not true'. It just seems to me that, if we are going to have an inquiry and if, as a Committee, the Senate gives us a reference, it behoves the Senate in particular to stand aside from the issue and allow us to look at things objectively.

I mention this point because there are many people at the ANU, both in that faculty and other faculties in Sydney and elsewhere, who I know hold very strong views one way or the other about this issue on what the Government has done, what needs to be done at the ANU, what effect this may have on other universities, what effect it has on medical research in this country, et cetera—all those areas that are covered by our terms of reference. As Committee Chairman, I would feel it totally unsatisfactory if I were to say, `Okay, we will give a view today' when we are about to go into this inquiry.

Our Committee has a long history of working objectively through problems. In fact, I can remember only one occasion when we have divided on particular issues, and that concerned the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990. That division occurred in only two places. The majority of the issues were agreed on a consensual basis. It would seem to me that to ruin what the Committee has achieved over the years by getting it to take a stand on this issue prior to the release of its report would be an inappropriate use of the Senate's resources and, in many ways, would undermine the processes that we have managed to achieve between the parties. I put that on the record.

As I indicated, the Government does not wish to debate this issue for the very reasons I have outlined here today. I will indicate once again for the record that we do not intend to divide, but that is simply to save time. We have a great deal of legislation before us. Therefore, on behalf of the Government, I oppose the motion before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the view taken by Senator Aulich, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, to which this matter will be referred. I think it is the proper attitude to adopt—that is to say, I did not hear anything in his contribution that would be at odds with his position as Chairman of that Committee. He took the proper approach. But I do not think it flows from what he said that we should vote against this motion.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, this motion is noting the concerns that have developed. It is really asking our representatives on the Council of the Australian National University to rescind a motion which they passed under duress on a previous occasion. It requests the Government not to take any further action in respect of this matter pending the outcome of the inquiry that has been referred to Senator Aulich's Committee.

I think Senator Tierney has moved a perfectly reasonable motion and I agree with what he said. I also agree with the informed remarks made by Senator Sowada. They are of such a nature as would influence persons who are listening to this debate to the effect that the motion should be supported.

I would like to add two other points. It concerns me that this matter has gone so far via Executive Government decisions when the John Curtin School of Medical Research is mentioned as an integral part of the legislation. The Government is attempting to change the whole character of the school and to place it, in effect, under the control of an outside organisation—namely, the National Health and Medical Research Council.

The 1951 report of the interim Council of the ANU says that, as far back as 1913, Mr Andrew Fisher expressed the hope that Canberra would become the centre of Australia's learning as well as its politics. Fisher made it clear that Canberra must be something more than the seat of government and that a national university ought to be established here. The university itself owes its birth to discussions which took place in 1943 about the possibility of creating in Canberra a national institute of medical research. Mr John Curtin met Sir Howard Florey, the director of the Sir William Dunn Institute of Pathology at Oxford, whilst Sir Howard was visiting Australia in connection with wartime medical services. Mr Curtin sought Sir Howard's advice, and the initial considerations and difficulties were outlined in the interim council's early report. Sir Howard Florey's proposals became a blueprint for the John Curtin School of Medical Research and that then became part and parcel of the Australian National University Act.

When I first heard about what was taking place, I did not take much notice because, as a member of parliament, I thought the Government would have to come to this place if it was going to alter substantially the workings of the John Curtin School and its relationship with the Australian National University Council. In effect, that is what it has done.

I understand that there has been some disagreement between the ANU Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council over who would undertake certain tasks which the Government wanted undertaken following the release of the Stephen report. Two or three persons were put up. One person, nominated by the Australian National University Council, was rejected by the National Health and Medical Research Council. So the debate went back and forth. Eventually, it was decided that the person put forward by the National Health and Medical Research Council would be the one to undertake this task.

But, ultimately, it should be known—and ultimately it will be stated—that that person has some explanations to make. I believe people deserve some explanations from that particular appointee, who was the nominee of the National Health and Medical Research Council. One of the most controversial grants from the National Health and Medical Research Council was a very substantial grant of something like $450,000 for what, in effect, was a project which was not in the nature of a medical project—it was in the nature of a philosophical project. It ended up in the hands of a particular professor and then went to a Monash group. It related to the development of a utilitarian philosophical approach to experimentations on early human beings.

Once all of the information comes out, I think it will support the view that institutions separate from the National Medical and Health Research Council should be supported in their scholarly medical research which is competitive, both nationally and internationally.

I see Senator Short is in the chamber; possibly he knows Nugget Coombs. I knew him many years ago. We did not always see eye to eye, but when Nugget Coombs speaks I think he deserves to be listened to. Nobody can say that he is naive and nobody will say that he does not know what is going on or that he is not able to find out what is going on.

What he has now said publicly should convince a lot of people that there is more in this than meets the eye. I believe that the opportunity that has be given by the Senate Standing Committee to persons to come forward and give information and public submissions to that Committee is a very important exercise of the power of this chamber. I would hate to see anything being undertaken, either by the Australian National University Council or by the Government, which would pre-empt that inquiry. That is why I support the motion moved by Senator Tierney.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I rise to respond to some of the remarks made by Senator Aulich which I cannot let go. As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I am fully aware of the nature of the inquiry and what the inquiry could achieve.

PARA.TAB: The basic point is that there is a real danger that our reporting date of 1 April will be too late to reverse the process, because of the current situation where the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has moved so far down the track towards taking control of this element of the Australian National University. Hence, I have moved this motion to give strength to the very strong views of the Australian National University that this action by the Minister must be stopped.

Yesterday I had the honour of addressing 500 members of the staff of the ANU, along with Dr H. C. Coombs and Sir Mark Oliphant. I would like to convey to the Senate the strength of feeling there. It was quite obvious that the 500 academic staff were outraged, and unanimous in the view that the Minister must reverse this decision. The main speaker, Sir Mark Oliphant, made the point very clearly that this Minister does not know what he is doing. He does not have any idea of the history of what has happened at the ANU and the fact that the John Curtin School of Medical Research was a foundation school, that it has contributed greatly to research in medicine in this country and that the very integrity of its work will be greatly threatened by this action.

We also pointed out very clearly to the staff that this action has enormous implications for Australian universities generally. It is quite possible that the Minister can now interfere at any level in any university by the very simple device that he has adopted in this case, and that is, moving funding from one body in a university out to a government department. That is why this must be stopped.

The main way it will be stopped is by the Council gaining a bit of backbone tomorrow and reversing its previous decision. If it does this, it should then put the Minister on notice that he should hold off any administrative changes for the John Curtin School until the Senate Committee brings down its report. I would have thought that Senator Aulich would have welcomed this move. The inquiry has a chance to achieve the freezing of the arrangements to leave the John Curtin School under the control of the ANU until our Senate Standing Committee brings down its reports. We could then proceed in a considered way from that point and leave the control of this very valuable school where it belongs—under the auspices of the Australian National University.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That General Business be not further proceeded with this day.
Motion (by Senator Collins)—by leave—agreed to:
That consideration of committee reports and government responses be not proceeded with this day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 190, I seek the leave of the Senate to make a short statement about a matter on which I may have given wrong information to the Senate yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My statement relates to my speech yesterday on a motion to take note of an answer that Senator Collins had given about sales tax on air-conditioners. Senator Collins has referred to that in answer to a question on the matter from one of his team today. I wish to acknowledge that the information I gave yesterday, in all good faith, was incorrect. The sales tax on personal air-conditioners is not 30 per cent. I do apologise if I misled the Senate. As I say, it was quite unintentional, if it happened.

PARA.TAB: The fact was wrong; the principle was correct. Briefly, I would like to indicate that the Government's wholesale sales tax rates are so confused that they are difficult to understand. For example, commercial air-conditioning in Senator Collins's Darwin office would be subject to a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax. Commercial refrigeration in any shop in Darwin would be subject to 20 per cent. Sales tax on air-conditioning in Senator Collins's home would be 10 per cent, as he says. If the air-conditioning happens to be ducted, there is a 20 per cent sales tax on the ducting. That is 10 per cent on the unit, and 20 per cent on the ducting. People who happen to have air-conditioners in their motor vehicles—which in northern Queensland is fairly common because it is very hot at times —pay sales tax at 20 per cent, and if they own a luxury vehicle they pay 30 per cent.

My principle is that under the Hewson package those taxes will be completely waived. The cost of goods in north Queensland will be cheaper in any case because the costs of manufacturing those air-conditioners and refrigerators will be so much cheaper. All inputs into business will be waived under Dr Hewson's GST. The freight cost of getting goods to northern Australia will be so much cheaper because there will be no 26 cents per litre excise on fuel. There will be none of the wholesale sales taxes on the vehicles that go there. Generally speaking, most of those items will be considerably cheaper.

I thank the Senate for allowing me to correct those things and acknowledge that the information I gave yesterday was not correct. The sales tax on commercial refrigeration, commercial air-conditioning and home ducting for air- conditioning is 20 per cent. All that will be removed completely and will be replaced by a 15 per cent levy. I just wanted to make that clear. I thank the Senate for giving me leave to do so.
Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 is yet another example of the Government not being able to get its legislation right. For example, this is the second package of amendments in as many months to the Pipeline Authority Act which is included in this strange grab bag of Bills. In handling this Bill for the Opposition, let me make it plain that the Liberal and National parties, therefore, oppose the Bill as put forward today. In a second reading amendment, jointly with the Australian Democrats, we will require the Bill to be withdrawn and redrafted according to the guidelines laid down in our amendment.

PARA.TAB: We are concerned that, once again, sloppy work by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and his Department has imposed an additional workload on the legislative process of this Senate at a time when we are sorely overloaded and under time constraints to finish all the business before the Senate. We should not be having to sit here and waste our time in tidying up the Government's loose ends.

However, what concerns us most is the section of the Bill dealing with the amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, and it is to this section which the Opposition and Democrats amendments primarily refer. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said that the amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act are based on the recent review of the Comcare program which had been envisaged when the program was first set up. What the Minister does not say is that he refused to table the report which came out of that review and that he has refused to implement most of the recommendations made in the report. In fact, the Minister does not say very much at all in his speech, which is really quite inexcusable, considering the scope and depth of the review and its recommendations.

It is quite clear that the Government has taken its usual path of commissioning a review of a government enterprise and then trying to ignore most of the recommendations which came out of that review. What reason does the Minister have for not tabling this report? Does he think that by not doing so he can blithely ignore its recommendations? Does he think he can avoid responsibility for the interests of the clients of Comcare? Why did the Minister not give an explanation as to why he has not accepted the recommendations?

He has admitted that the review targeted additional areas where effectiveness could be enhanced. I would put it more strongly than that. I would say that the review has identified some very serious deficiencies in the operation of Comcare. More importantly, the report made it quite clear that the recommendations are meant to be taken as a whole. On page 35 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The workers compensation environment is complex and sophisticated and the internal balances are sometimes very delicate and not obvious. To take part of this package and not others could in some cases have consequences that would not be in the best long term interests of the Government or the workers who have compensation coverage under Comcare.

Why has the Minister chosen to ignore this directive? The consultants who conducted the review of Comcare are clearly concerned about its operation. They recommended some fairly extensive changes to the structure of the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees itself, to its staffing arrangements and to its operations. These recommendations were not made lightly. The review panel was headed by Mr Ron Brown, a former secretary to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who was unceremoniously dumped from that position by this Government and who is now a management consultant. The review panel comprised representatives from three very reputable consulting firms: Pappas Carter Evans and Koop, Clayton Utz and Coopers and Lybrand. The panel therefore had a great deal of expertise and extensive resources at its command.

PARA.TAB: Yet out of the 15 important recommendations made in the report, all but one have been rejected by the Minister. The one recommendation that he has deigned to implement he has changed to such a degree that it greatly weakens its original intention. I will briefly go through the major recommendations of the report because, clearly, the Minister is not going to. It is important that all of us realise to what extent the Minister is neglecting his duty to the Parliament, the Government and the semi-government clientele of Comcare.

The first recommendation, and the only one which the Government has even attempted to implement, is that the Commission should be split into two parts. One is to be a regulatory commission which will oversee the management and regulatory functions under the new Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. The responsibility for the other part, to be known as Comcare, will be as a service arm managing claims and commercial activities. However, that is as far as the Government is prepared to go along with the recommendations.

The review panel recommended that the regulatory and service arms be clearly separated and that the new structure needed an expanded board with wider areas of expertise. It also recommended that Comcare should have its own board as a subset of the Commission with its own chief executive officer. The Minister claimed in his speech that the Bill provides for:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the separation of the powers and functions of the current Commission between the new Commission and the new body to be known as Comcare.

Yet the amendments do nothing of the sort. They ignore the recommendations for a part time chairman, preferably with a financial or insurance background, and for a separate chief executive officer of Comcare, preferably with a marketing background. Instead, the full time chief executive officer of Comcare will continue to chair the Commission as well, thereby negating the report's recommendation that Comcare be accountable to the Commission.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, the amendments ignore the recommendation to have greater commercial employer representation on the board and instead it leaves the Commonwealth representative as the sole employer representative, while adding another representative of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to the board. Where the report explicitly recommended that the board consists of nine members, the Government has allowed for only eight.

Another vitally important area that the Minister has chosen to neglect is the matter of some 3,000 people on long term benefits who are suffering very real financial and physical hardship as a result of deficiencies in the transitional arrangements made when the current system took over from the previous Commonwealth employees compensation scheme in July 1989. The review recommended that a fixed sum, a suggested $50m annually, be made available for each of three years on compassionate grounds on a first come first served basis for those people suffering financial hardship because of those flawed transitional arrangements.

This recommendation was, in fact, a second best suggestion because the panel knew that its preferred proposals would not be accepted by the Government. The original suggestion would have allowed people the option to have their benefit paid out in a lump sum. Although the immediate costs were large, the long term savings were quite substantial. However, the panel considered that the estimated cost of $718m for a total buy out, or $60m for a limited buy out of 700 entitlements, would be unacceptable. As it turns out, the Government apparently does not like any of the options, because it has not done anything at all to alleviate the problems of those 3,000 people who have now been living with inconvenience and uncertainty for more than three years.

The report also expressed concerns about the length of time being taken to process some claims, particularly the more complex ones, which is causing undue hardship to many claimants. It therefore recommended that statutory time limits of 28 days for handling primary decisions and 35 days for review decisions should be put in place. As an added incentive to process reviews quickly and fairly there should also be provision for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal immediately a claim is disputed. This would prevent abuse of the system whereby the length of time taken in the review process can effectively block access to the Appeals Tribunal by claimants. Under the present system, claimants must wait until either Comcare or one of the self-administrators, Telecom or Australia Post, review their claim before they can appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Other recommendations, which the Minister has ignored altogether, were that the Commission become self-funding, which was one of the principal aims of the original scheme; that the Commission be able to offer more flexible packages to its clients, particularly its semi-corporatised clients who now account for 46 per cent of its clientele and 50 per cent of its premium income—many of whom indicated they would desert Comcare given the chance; that Comcare should be able to seek business in the private sector; that the continuing uncertainty about who is responsible for compensation for defence military personnel be resolved; that, in order to enable greater flexibility and service delivery, the staff employed by Comcare should not be employed under the Public Service Act; and that service standards in the Australian Capital Territory office of Comcare be addressed immediately.

The thrust of this legislation is that Comcare should stand on its own feet; that it should be self-funding; and that it should operate on a fully competitive and commercial basis. The coalition supports that thrust because it is compatible with our policies for self-determination and individual effort which form the whole basis of our Fightback reform package. In line with those policies, it is the coalition's belief that both the Commission and Comcare, along with many other government enterprises, should be privatised at the earliest opportunity.

Looking at the amendments that this Labor Government has put forward, one has to ask just whose interests the Minister is safeguarding—the Government's, the Commission's, the ACTU's or all three? Sadly, the interests of the clients, especially those on long term benefits, have been ignored. They have been seriously disadvantaged by the transitional arrangements from the previous scheme and are losing out on their entitlements.
I turn now to the amendments to the Navigation Act 1912 in Part 5 of the Bill which, according to the Minister, arise:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . out of the Government's initiative to increase the number of Conventions of the International Labour Organisation ratified by Australia.
Yet, the Minister also says:
As a general rule Australia does not ratify a Convention until law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions complies with the requirements of the Convention.
The amendments proposed here are intended to enable compliance with three maritime conventions of the ILO which will allow Australia to ratify them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I had concluded addressing my remarks on behalf of the Liberal and National parties to the Comcare aspects of the legislation, and had pointed out the unsatisfactory nature of the legislation from our point of view, particularly the fact that the Bill does not implement the recommendations of the Brown report into Comcare—a report resulting from an inquiry set up by the Government itself. Not only does it not implement those recommendations but also there has been no explanation from the Government as to why they have not been implemented. Indeed, the Brown report has not even been tabled in this Parliament. I concluded that one really had to ask whose interest the Minister is safeguarding—the Government's, the Commission's, the ACTU's, or the interests of all three.

PARA.TAB: I had also commenced some remarks on the amendments contained in part 5 of the Bill to the Navigation Act 1912. According to the Minister, they arise `out of the Government's initiative to increase the number of conventions of the International Labour Organisation ratified by Australia'. Yet, the Minister also said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a general rule Australia does not ratify a Convention until law and practice in all relevant jurisdictions complies with the requirements of the Convention.

The amendments proposed here are intended to enable compliance with three maritime conventions of the ILO, which will allow Australia to ratify them. However, in this case not all State and Territory jurisdictions comply with the conventions because although they apply to seagoing ships in Australian waters which engage in interstate trade, which comes under the Federal Navigation Act, they do not apply to ships which only come within State or Territory jurisdiction because they do not trade interstate. The Minister confirmed in his speech that the regulations and orders that would be able to be made under the Navigation Act to give effect to the conventions in respect of all seagoing ships in Australian waters nevertheless will not apply, and again I quote the Minister:

. . . where any existing or future law of a State, or of the Northern Territory, gives effect to the Conventions. This will ensure that the Conventions are applied to all sea-going ships in Australian waters, while preserving the jurisdiction of the States and the Northern Territory in respect of the matters covered by the Conventions.

It appears to me that there is a note of inconsistency here. On the one hand the Government has insisted in the past that Australia will not ratify conventions unless, as the Minister said, law and practice at all levels of government comply with them. On the other hand, here we have the Government trying to push through prematurely compliance with three maritime conventions to enable their ratification, even though not all State and Territory jurisdictions comply with those conventions. This has more to do with the Labor Party and its union mates trying to shore up its power and influence in the International Labour Organisation in order to use its backing for instigating resistance to the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties than it has to do with any altruistic feelings towards the machinations of the ILO.

PARA.TAB: While the coalition does not oppose the principle of this Bill, nevertheless it condemns the Minister for the arrogant way in which he has either changed or ignored expert opinion—opinion which he sought but which he has refused to table in the Parliament, particularly with regard to Comcare. We therefore oppose the Bill as presently drafted, and I move as an amendment to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after "That" substitute:

(a)"because of the unacceptable attitude of the Minister for Industrial Relations in refusing to table the Brown Report on COMCARE and failing to explain why the Government rejected its major recommendations, particularly the recommendation for early redemptions:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Senate expresses its concern at the proposed changes to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act;
(ii)the Brown Report on COMCARE be tabled without delay; and
(iii)the Senate declares its support for the general thrust of that Report;

SPEECH.PARA: (b)the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to include the recommendations of the Brown Report, especially those concerning:

TAB.TAB: (i)provision for compassionate early redemptions;
(ii)setting reasonable time limits for determinations, reconsiderations and reviews;

(iii)provision to the Minister by the new Commission, within a reasonable time, of a detailed strategy for addressing the most important service problems identified in the Brown Review and an implementation report to overcome them;
(iv)licensing arrangements for self-administrators; and
(v)the appointment of a part-time Chairman of the Commission who is not the Chief Executive Officer of COMCARE; and to include:
(vi)allowing disputed claims to be referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal before they are reviewed; and
(vii)having self-administrators' disputed claims reviewed by COMCARE; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c)the Senate rejects the proposal of the Government to amend the Navigation Act to allow compliance with ILO convention 73, the Medical Examination (Seafarers) Convention 1946, in spite of unresolved concerns on the part of the Government of the Northern Territory, until the Commonwealth Government has undertaken full consultation with the Government of the Northern Territory".

This amendment is moved on behalf of the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats. I foreshadow an amendment to this amendment which will be moved on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, which is to add at the end of the motion just moved, `and the Senate declares its belief that both the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees and Comcare should be privatised'. Because of the procedural requirements precluding me from moving two amendments, this foreshadowed amendment will be formally moved later in the debate by one of my coalition colleagues. I commend both the amendment and the foreshadowed amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 seeks to amend six Acts: the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989, the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, the Navigation Act 1912, the Pipeline Authority Act 1973 and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I wish to question the sense of lumping together what are essentially so many disparate items. Part 2 of the Bill deals with amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act, which arise out of a review of the operation of the Acts. I will return to that review shortly.

The amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act, in part 3 of the Bill, relate to chemicals. The amendments to the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act, in part 4 or the Bill, relate to long service leave payments. Part 5 contains amendments to the Navigation Act to regulations concerning medical examinations and accommodation for ships crews and part 6 deals with amendments to the Pipeline Authority Act.

The Australian Democrats have no quarrel with the last four parts of the Bill, although some of us might wonder at the Senate's collective competence as a House of review when the amendments in part 6 of the Bill are necessary to correct mistakes in a Bill which we passed earlier this year. That is a matter which has been raised before. If the Senate is to be a House of review, why is it that, six months later, we seem to be reviewing what we have already reviewed?

The Democrats do not oppose the amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act. However, we have discovered that, although the amendment is seen as a sensible move, there really is a hornet's nest of unsatisfactory practices in the area of industrial chemicals. I give notice that the Democrats will be looking at the current arrangements concerning registration and data collection. The Democrats see no reason to oppose the proposed amendments which represent the Government's reorganisation of that situation at the moment.

Part 2 of the Bill is another matter; and it ought to be the subject of a separate Bill. In 1988 the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill was introduced to replace the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 and to bring in a new scheme of compensation and rehabilitation for Commonwealth employees who were injured at work. The new scheme was to provide more generous benefits for injured employees with a much heavier emphasis on rehabilitation. It was the Government's view that costs of compensation claims had increased too much under the previous Act and that they had to be contained. The way to do this was to adopt a new system which focused on preventing injury, encouraging rehabilitation and providing compensation. This led to the establishment of the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth employees—the Comcare Commission.

The Government, to its credit, made provision for a review of the Commission's operation after two years. The findings of that review, which has been conducted, are contained in the Brown report. Some of the recommendations of that review have been picked up by the Government—notably, the proposal to separate the regulatory and service functions currently performed by Comcare.

The Bill provides for the establishment of a new commission to undertake the regulatory functions and a new body named Comcare to carry the commercial and service functions. By and large, the Democrats will be happy to support that proposal, particularly if the regulatory functions of the commission were considerably enhanced. However, we are by no means convinced that this will be the case.

The 1988 legislation made another important change to the provision of compensation arrangements. Section 101 of the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act enables the Minister to declare a Commonwealth authority to be an administering authority. That enabled selected statutory authorities to administer the scheme themselves—in other words, in parallel with Comcare. This is precisely where the Democrats have parted company with the Government's present intentions. We are parting company not just in terms of the way this system has worked or has been made to work, or because of the refusal of the Government to enable correction of the abuses which have been and are occurring but, more importantly, because of the future provision of adequate and just compensation for Commonwealth employees. It is our belief that under the misguided deregulatory and market driven imperatives that now so dominate this Government—making it only a very pale shadow of its past—continued compensation that is just and equitable will inevitably be regarded as a luxury of the past.
The inquiry headed by Mr Brown reports considerable disquiet about the system of self-administrators. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: There have been significant problems with the management of claims by the two self-administrators. . .

Current self-administration arrangements should be ended and replaced with two classes of licences—for self-insurance and inhouse claims administration—both subject to an annual fee. Both should be subject to strict entry thresholds and reporting requirements, and should be required to be renewed after 5 and 2 years respectively.
The submission to the Brown inquiry from the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union and the ATEA/ATPOA is equally blunt. I quote from that submission:

Since the introduction of the CERC Act, the performance of both the Self-Administrators had not been good. Therefore. . . unless fundamental changes are made to the provision of compensation and rehabilitation in Telecom and Australia Post. . . then self-administration then should be denied to both employers.
It continues:
If self-administration is taken from Telecom and Australia Post, it is our view that the administration of compensation and rehabilitation should be performed by Comcare.

In Western Australia an action group within what is known as the Injured Persons Action and Support Association of Western Australia has taken shape. It is comprised of people actively opposed to the way that Australia Post and Telecom have administered or have been allowed to administer the CERC Act in respect of their employees. In the very short time that we have been dealing with this Bill in my office we have been deluged with a truckload of material basically suggesting that, while the intentions of the Act may be commendable, those two self-administering authorities have, in effect, misused and in some cases abused the Act to embark on massive cost cutting exercises at the expense of dozens of injured persons who were employees of those organisations.

PARA.TAB: Part of the material we have received, I have been told, says that the rehabilitation and claims management sections of Australia Post in Western Australia received an award for achieving what was called `considerable financial savings' in compensation expenditure. Inquiries that I have made do not enable me to tell you here tonight, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether those savings were from excellent results in rehabilitating people or from a successful strategy of reducing the number of claimants. We will be pursuing that matter because I think it is important to make that distinction.

A moment ago I made reference to the way in which the Act has been allowed to be administered. I invite the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) to take up that point when he addresses this Bill because, despite the Act requiring the Commission to keep a watchful eye over self-administrators to ensure that they are not inconsistent with the requirements of the Commission in the performance of their functions, there seems to be very little evidence of this watchful eye being exercised. Indeed, despite the promise of Mr Howe when introducing the 1988 Bill—and his promise was that the Commission will be required to report on the operations of self-administrators—I cannot find evidence that even this superficial requirement has been implemented. Indeed, Mr Brown in his review was moved to point out that `no adequate provision was made for overseeing their performance'. That is not the only complaint. There is a myriad of complaints; so many it is difficult to know where to start.

An overwhelming number of case studies have invaded my office over the past couple of days. The Brown report itself highlighted some of the problems. We are told that there are significant time delays in handling claims. That is a recurring complaint which concerns the time taken in making decisions at all levels—at the primary level as well as the review decisions. My colleague Senator Kernot asked a question on this very problem a week or so ago. She asked about the length of time taken for Telecom to reconsider a decision concerning a claim by Mr Edwards. Senator Collins, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, said:

SPEECH.PARA: A request for reconsideration of the above decision was submitted by Mr Edwards on 13 February 1991.
The determination . . . was affirmed by Telecom on 28 June 1991.
I observe, as everybody would realise, that that is a period of nearly five months. The Minister went on to report:
Mr Edwards has unfortunately since died.

Here we have one less complainant. I wonder whether that is why the award for efficiency was given to the Department. Some of those who are now contacting my office are saying that such a tragic story is by no means isolated. I am not suggesting that the decision making process is deliberately being strung out in the hope that claimants will, by one means or another, go away, but I wonder at the reason for such a long process. It does not seem to be justifiable.

PARA.TAB: Mr Brown reported on what he euphemistically called `overly enthusiastic use of surveillance' as a tool of management. In this chamber, former Senator Jean Jenkins reported to the Senate over a year ago on several methods of surveillance and harassment used to generate evidence or material that could be used to damage a claimant's credibility, including the planting of eavesdropping devices in claimants' homes.

I have a copy of a report of a medical board—I will come back to the problems of these boards later—from which I will quote as it brings to light some of the surveillance practices. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Board commenced by viewing surveillance film taken of Mr X over a fourteen day period. Mr X was not made aware of the film, but the Board used the information to frame the questions to be posed to him.

It seems that this sort of operation is commonplace. It is a device used to discredit the claims of people seeking compensation. It is pretty obvious that we need guidelines on the type of conduct that is acceptable in these cases. When these boards are allowed to sail off without guidelines, that is the sort of caper they get up to. We need guidelines to be established and monitored.

PARA.TAB: A recurring source of complaint concerns the status of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to appeals against decisions made by self-administering authorities. Conflicting advice is coming from the Government concerning this question. In a letter to the honourable member for Canning, Mr Gear, the former Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Telecom has advised, that although recommendations made by the AAT are not binding, it normally follows the recommendations, provided it is assured that the AAT is fully aware of all available facts and information prior to making a declaration.

What an extraordinary proposition that is. The decisions are not binding. Telecom normally treats them as binding, except that where it thinks the AAT was not aware of all the facts, Telecom makes the decision not to follow the recommendations. Nevertheless, Comcare or perhaps the Minister is saying that the decisions of the AAT do not apply to self-administering authorities. Where do we go? Just what is the status? What is the basis? What is the legality of all this?

PARA.TAB: Another area of concern is costs. The intention of the Act was to establish a system that would be affordable, not just to administering authorities. However, the practice of departments and authorities employing expensive, high powered legal representation to defend claims brought before the AAT has obviously imposed a further handicap. Without the availability of some form of legal aid, injured employees are often simply not able to afford matching representation, and they do not bother. That is a pretty old trick, but it seems to work in this case.

Another vexed area concerns the use of medical review panels or medical review boards. Section 57 of the Act gives power to require examinations by `a legally qualified medical practitioner nominated by the relevant authority'. I notice that that reads exactly: it is `a legally qualified medical practitioner'—not 50, not even three; just one. This section is being used to set up boards of review. It is not so much the use of boards that is the source of complaint but the way they are apparently being used. They should be either prohibited entirely or set up properly and monitored. Something similar to the boards under the 1971 Act would be suggested so long as the authority is not able to appoint a majority of members having sympathy to one side of the question.

I am told that these boards have been devices by which Australia Post has selected an expert to put its case, to appoint a chairman as well, and then to invite the claimant to also appoint a member. In effect, that means that the claimant's representative, of course, would always be in the minority, with the number of board members. But all these experts sitting around providing expert advice is put across as being fair and reasonable.

What nobody seems to be able to explain is why Australia Post has gone down this road when Comcare has not used such a system. It has not been seen as necessary for Comcare to administer the system for itself, but there seems to be an advantage to Australia Post in doing that. It is not to save money. Or is it? Is it not a case where the operation of the Act by the administering authority is at variance with the way Comcare administers the Act and, therefore, not in accordance with the Act? I do not know, but it is a nagging question. At the very least, there needs to be established a set of guidelines that I referred to before. We need to know how these boards should be set up and what the recommendations for the methods would be. We need to know whether the claimant might have the right of veto over the chairperson, at least, and whether such guidelines could be monitored by the new commission.

If the purpose of this Act is to set up the framework for a new commission and for the subsequent Acts to operate, then I have a great deal of suspicion at the outset. I am certainly not prepared to endorse the framework that has been described here.

Another serious problem that occurs with the existing situation is when longstanding determinations are reviewed. In many instances determinations are made to cease compensation payments without the knowledge of the claimant. I do not know how that is defined when the claimant or the person affected is not notified, but the word `equity' comes into it, in my view. I cannot see the equity in that sort of practice, but it appears to be standard practice. It is standard practice to use a variety of techniques to institute reviews without notifying claimants. One of the many examples I have is a letter to a Mrs Clark from Australia Post. In the text of that letter, Australia Post writes:

Since 21 April 1989 you have received no additional treatment. Therefore I have determined that Australia Post is no longer liable to pay compensation in respect of incapacity or medical treatment for your claim on and from 22 April 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Clark subsequently appealed. The appeal was disallowed. It is this kind of big brother bureaucratic type of operation that surely the Act was intended to prevent. Instead, we appear to have created a mechanism for despotism, to enable an attitude of cost containment at all costs to develop at the expense of the rights of injured employees.

PARA.TAB: As far as we are concerned, this Bill is simply no way near good enough. It does not properly address the concerns that were raised in the report by Mr Brown, nor the concerns that have been brought to us by a significant number—and I believe we were looking at only the tip of the iceberg—of employees and previous employees. If a Bill is to be prepared and brought before this Parliament, then it should at least properly address the priorities that were identified by Mr Brown. This Bill does not. It should be withdrawn and redrafted so as to properly implement the changes identified in the Brown review.

I was told a few minutes ago by the Minister's office that we are all off key, that we do not understand it, that it is all going to be wonderful, and that in the autumn session everything is going to be solved. I am afraid that that advice comes far too late. It comes in the light of the huge amount of information that has been provided to us by the people who have suffered under the present arrangements and who do not see their problems being solved by this Bill.

Whatever the Minister and his office choose to think at this moment, the information that has been provided to us over the last several days, when we have been dealing with it, is not in accord with that and does not show to us that people will be satisfied by what is proposed here. As far as I am concerned, the amendments would go a long way towards achieving that; that is why the Australian Democrats believe very strongly that the only way to deal with the legislation is to take it away, get it right and bring it back when it is right. For that reason, we support the amendment that we are moving jointly with the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. It contains amendments to several Bills, but I refer to the amendments to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. That Bill came into force in December 1988, having been through the Parliament the year before. It was a Bill that we passed with some reservations, and at the time many honourable senators indicated that they would be keeping a close watch on how it operated. The Government itself indicated that after a couple of years a review would be carried out as to how the Bill was functioning and whether or not any changes were required. The second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments implement changes based on a recent review of the Comcare program. The Review was conducted by Mr Ron Brown, a management consultant. He was commissioned in December 1990 to carry out a comprehensive review of the Comcare program, including the self administrators.

You may remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it became general knowledge that this review was being carried out last year, but nothing was heard about it. In April of this year I asked a question of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) as to whether he had initiated a review; what were the terms of reference; who was conducting the review and what were their qualifications; whether the review was advertised so that interested parties could take part and make submissions; whether the Minister would supply a list of the groups and organisations, et cetera, who had been consulted; and what was the reporting date.

PARA.TAB: On the same day that I asked that question, the Minister made a response and then replied more substantially the following day. In the Minister's initial response he indicated that he had initiated a review of Comcare. In part, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Those terms of reference would spring from a desire by any government to ensure that the scheme operated efficiently, delivered its benefits to the best level to its members and ensured that rehabilitation was given primacy in the concerns of Commonwealth employees who have suffered accidents. . . The terms of reference reflect an inquiry to see whether they can be improved upon.
The next day, in a more detailed answer, the Minister tabled the terms of reference and referred to the background and the consultation. He said:

A number of client agencies of Comcare Unions, individual compensation claimants, service providers, special interest groups and others with an interest in the scheme's operation have made written submissions to the Review.

In addition, consultation with people or organisations with an interest in the program was undertaken by way of a stakeholder survey conducted by Pappas, Carter, Evans and Koop, a management consulting firm. This consisted of interviews with selected clients and a wider survey of client attitude.

There were meetings with Comcare's employer consultative group (attended by about 50 employer representatives), and with union representatives (unions representing more than 75 per cent of workers covered by Comcare attended this meeting). There was also a seminar for senior government decision makers involved with Comcare.
He concluded by saying:
I expect to receive the final report of the Review by the end of next week.

PARA.TAB: I am not entirely sure when the Minister received the review, but nothing more was heard of it. I inquired about it at the Estimates committee in the Budget session this year. Subsequently, I obtained a copy of the report, which was dated April 1991, consistent with the answer the Minister gave, but it was some time before other people saw it.

As a result of all that and as a result of the Minister indicating the depth of inquiry which had been undertaken, the report was anticipated with considerable interest, especially by those who have been involved. Madam Acting Deputy President, I remind you particularly of the members of that group who were severely disadvantaged by the changeover from the old scheme to the new scheme, many of whom I still see and know about.

The review's recommendations—and I shall not read them all—covered 15 particular points in some detail. Those of us interested in Comcare were pleased to see the recommendations. Many of them reflected the sorts of things that we believe should be included and which appeared obvious from the way the scheme had been operating over the last couple of years. When we heard that the Minister was bringing in a Bill to make amendments, it was with some anticipation that we looked for those amendments to see what was happening to the recommendations of the Brown report. I have quoted the relevant part of the second reading speech which refers to making changes. Only one of the 15 recommendations that have been dealt with in this legislation has been brought before us, and it has not been dealt with properly either.

As I said, I will not read through all 15 recommendations, but it is worth referring to some of the things that have not been implemented in this legislation. I ask the Minister: why has he not implemented the report? How much did it cost to go to the trouble of employing Mr Brown and that competent committee to review the operation of the Act and how it was affecting people, get 15 recommendations from it, and then come in here with an amendment to the Bill that picks up only one recommendation? The Senate is entitled to an explanation as to why the rest of the recommendations have been ignored.

The Government has ignored the recommendation regarding qualifications of the commissioners. It has added another ACTU nominee to the board while continuing to allow the Commonwealth representative to represent employers generally. It has ignored the recommendation to implement a limited redemption scheme for the estimated 3,000 long term compensation cases that have been adversely affected, some severely by the transitional arrangements between the new and the old compensation schemes. I could give examples of that.

The Government has ignored the recommendation to impose a statutory time period on the processing of claims and reviews and has ignored the recommendation to expand and restructure the Commission to strengthen its expertise in financing and marketing. It has also ignored the recommendation that the Commission should present the Minister within three months with a detailed strategy for addressing the most important service problems identified in submissions to the review and, within six months, with an implementation report. It has ignored the recommendation to rationalise the position of defence military personnel under the Comcare scheme. It has ignored all but one of the recommendations of the Brown review.

What is the point of asking an independent body to review an organisation and then treat it with such contempt and not even come here and tell us why it has ignored all the other recommendations or even tell us when they will be implemented? Tonight we are spending time on this legislation which is clearly flawed in that the one thing the Government has tried to do has not been done in accordance with the recommendation.

Nobody would suggest that any report must be fully followed as to every recommendation. We are fully aware that that is not always possible and would not always happen. Most of these are fairly straightforward recommendations that would improve the operation of Comcare, but they have been not been taken up by the Minister. The Minister has not tabled the report in the Parliament. Why has he not done that? He has not bothered to explain why because, if he did, he would have to answer these questions.
The Opposition has moved an amendment. I shall not read it all out, but it is before the Senate. It states that the Bill be redrafted to include, amongst others, the following recommendations:
(i)provision for compassionate early redemptions;
(ii)setting reasonable time limits for determinations, reconsiderations and reviews;

(iii)provision to the Minister by the new Commission, within a reasonable time, of a detailed strategy for addressing the most important service problems identified in the Brown Review and an implementation report to overcome them;

I go back to the Minister's answer.
