When one looks through the list of the people whom he says the Brown review went to the trouble to consult, why does he then ignore the review when everyone possible has had the opportunity to contribute, and has contributed? As a result of that, the Brown review came up with its recommendation and the Minister now says, `Blow you; not interested. I had the review I said I'd have after two years. I don't care what's in it. Put it in the bin; get rid of it', and to heck with Comcare clients who rely on this legislation for the consequences of accidents which they have had at work. There seems to be no concern whatever for their welfare.
There is another aspect of the legislation which we would like to see implemented. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the words to be added, add the following: "; and
(d)the Senate declares its belief that both the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees and COMCARE should be privatised".

It would be easy to speak about Comcare matters for the rest of the time I have available to me, but I believe I have made the point that there is a report before the Government which does set out some of the things which need to be done. The Minister comes in here with a second reading speech in which he claims to be implementing the recommendations of the Brown report, which he clearly has not even attempted to do. I urge the Senate to pass the amendment moved by Senator Chapman relating to that implementation, and I urge the Government to set about bringing in a Bill which will enable that to happen—and to do it as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say something about the Brown report, the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 and the amendments. The argument from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats seems to be that, because everything that the Brown report has recommended has not been instituted, none of it should be. Indeed, the first two recommendations have been kept by the Government. The first recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The general levels of benefit provision under the Comcare scheme should be maintained.
That is what is happening. Recommendation No. 2 states:
The regulatory and service functions of Comcare should be clearly separated.

That is being done in this Bill. The argument seems to be that, because at this stage the Government has gone a certain distance with the reforms suggested in the Brown report but has not embraced all of them, the very good reform that has been introduced should be rejected. That is a matter for the Opposition and the Democrats, but it seems to me to be a very interesting approach to legislation—that even though good legislation has been introduced, it should be thrown out if it does not go as far as the Opposition and the Democrats think it should.

PARA.TAB: There is no criticism of what this legislation does, that is, separate the regulatory and service functions of Comcare. Everybody agrees with that. But those opposite say, `Because you didn't do other things, we're going to throw out that very good reform'. As I have said, that is a matter for the Opposition and the Democrats.

It is interesting that the Brown report has been spoken about tonight as though it were a condemnation of what the Government has done. If one looks at the executive summary which appears on the first page of the report, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The review team—
that is, under Mr Brown—
concluded that Comcare:
.provides a generous, but sustainable package of benefits to workers;
.has a relatively low incidence of claims;
.is competitive both in its premium rates and its administrative costs; and
.has substantially improved claims processing times compared to the former system, and continues to improve its performance in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —And then they go on with recommendations which would improve it.

—It does. Senator Reid is absolutely correct. The report goes on to make recommendations for improvements which she says, and properly so, ought to be considered. I just want to put those recommendations in context. On page 28 the report says of those recommendations:

SPEECH.PARA: It must be emphasised that these recommendations should be seen in the context of earlier observations in this report, that overall the scheme has been well designed and has been very successful in achieving the stated objectives of the Government in adopting it; and that there have been significant management achievements in bringing about the changes from the old environment to the current one.

When we talk about change we have to talk about it in the context in which the author of the report puts it. It does not do anybody any good to read the recommendations of a report on the basis that they have been ignored by the Government, on the basis that the report is somehow greatly critical of the Government, when in fact it is not. In fact, the report is saying that the Government has acted very well in this area but that there are some improvements that could be made to the scheme.

PARA.TAB: That is hardly consistent with an amendment that is put forward which says that Comcare and any new body that is set up under this legislation should be privatised. Why privatise it when it is running very well as it is? That sort of suggestion in the amendment raises the question as to whether this report from Mr Brown has been read properly by those on the Opposition benches and by the Democrats.

It is quite clear that the report is critical of self-administrators; that is, principally, Australia Post and Telecom. Certainly that has to be looked at. It seems to me to be taking surgery to the dramatic stage to throw out this Bill on the basis that it does not deal with self-administration. I am sure the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Kerin) will say that he has concern about the way in which Telecom and Australia Post are self-administering this Act. It is another illustration perhaps of where it is very much horses for courses. People who may provide good telecommunications services and good services for Australia Post are not so apt at providing good service in the rehabilitation and in the compensation of people injured in their employ. I have received a lot of criticism of the way in which Telecom and Australia Post have dealt with this Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act. That does not seem to me to justify the throwing out of this very good reform that has been introduced this day.

It is also said that there should be provision for compassionate early redemption. I do not think that we should embrace that suggestion from Mr Brown without looking at it very carefully. One of the problems with some of the rehabilitation schemes, with some of the workers compensation schemes, that have been adopted in the past is that lump sum payments are counterproductive to rehabilitation. It seems to me that to go back to the old way of allowing redemptions is quite dangerous. To simply throw out the Act because it does not accept redemption provisions or does not introduce redemption provisions seems to me again to be missing the point and to be taking, may I say, an almost dangerous approach to workers compensation. That should not be the situation.
I read something else to indicate just how well this organisation is running. This is from the Brown report which both the Democrats and the Opposition accept. The report, on page 8, states:

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of benefits,—
that is, the amount of money going to injured workers—

Comcare's are more generous than in any other State except South Australia. This is particularly evident in relation to long term benefits which fall away dramatically after 26 weeks in the New South Wales system.

I hope that the Opposition, in rejecting this legislation, is not aiming to introduce the scheme that was introduced in New South Wales by the Liberal Government which makes it a very bad scheme for people particularly those who have to stay away from work for more than 26 weeks. The report goes on:
In terms of costs (premiums), Comcare is well below the levels for comparable categories in Victoria, but slightly higher over the same categories than NSW.
New South Wales, of course, does not provide the same level of benefits. Page 15 of the report, under management performance, states:
The review—
that is, the review by Mr Brown which is the review that is relied on by the Opposition and the Democrats to put forward the proposition that the present amendment should be thrown out—

concluded that the performance of the scheme's management in achieving the financial results set out in the appendix and in streamlining administrative systems to give a better service both to agencies and injured workers has been commendable.
Then over the page:

Although the current performance is much better than under the old arrangements, Comcare is not yet meeting all the performance targets it has set for itself; nor, as we shall see in a later section, is it succeeding in meeting all the service expectations of its customers.

I take it that what it means by `customers' is the departments which Comcare services. The thrust of this report without any shadow of a doubt is that it commends the Comcare scheme and says that it is a good scheme and that there ought to be improvements but does not, in any way, condemn Comcare in round terms. What it does in round terms is to condemn the self-regulators, at least by inference. Because the report has done that it is somewhat ungenerous of those on the other side to throw out an amendment, which is a good amendment in line with the general thrust of the Brown report, simply on the basis that they do not like it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell, for whom I have great respect, says that there are all sorts of difficulties with investigations under this scheme. There have always been great difficulties investigating workers who have been injured. Workers have been photographed, followed and harassed, as Senator Sherry will no doubt agree, for decades after decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any system.

—In any system; and one would have hoped that Senator Bell and the Opposition would have realised that well before now because it has been around for a long time. He has spoken of medical boards. I do not favour medical boards. I think that these people who have a claim under any workers compensation scheme should have the matter dealt with rapidly. There is no doubt about that. In so far as those suggestions are made then they should be taken up, but that sort of improvement can be made in a later Act. Why not get this part of the recommendations into operation and then talk about what further appropriate reform can take place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —At this point I do not want to reply to all of the debate . What I want to do, and which I now foreshadow, is in a moment seek leave of this chamber to continue my remarks. I am advised that so doing will have the effect of adjourning consideration of this Bill. I would want to do so on the basis that, having listened to the speeches on the second reading, there are some misunderstandings about the Comcare part of this Bill and, dare I say as well, about the part of the Bill that deals with the application of ILO conventions to the Navigation Act and the position of the Northern Territory. That is a secondary consideration, although I do not wish to diminish its importance.

PARA.TAB: But I do think that there are some misunderstandings. The reason why I would seek leave to continue my remarks, and therefore adjourn this Bill, is to have some discussions with the leaders in this debate from both the coalition and the Australian Democrats in the belief that I can assuage some of the concerns that have been expressed. Therefore, this Bill might proceed next Wednesday, when we meet again, in a speedier fashion. I am advised by the worthy office of the Clerk that I should confine my remarks directly to the amendment that is the subject of, at this stage, a paper majority in this chamber, given that it is an amendment sponsored by both the coalition and the Democrats which as a combined group outgun us in numbers. It is to that amendment, and not the amendment related to the privatisation of Comcare which is an amendment sponsored only by the coalition, that I will direct my remarks. If leave is denied, of course, I will reply to the fuller debate in the greater degree of detail that I normally would want to do.

With those notes of explanation, I turn to what I consider to be some of the elements that are misunderstood in what the Government has done, and the significance of some of the provisions in this Bill which are misunderstood by virtue of the attitudes set down in the amendment to the second reading proposed by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Section (a) of that amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . because of the unacceptable attitude of the Minister for Industrial Relations in refusing to table the Brown report on COMCARE and failing to explain why the Government rejected its major recommendations . . .

It then goes on to a series of points. I just say to the point about refusing to table the Brown report: I regard the Brown report into Comcare as quite a significant report. It is a report that I am on the public record as saying that we wish to implement. I said that by way of a press release on 18 September this year which was headed `Comcare restructure to further improve efficiency'. On page 2 of that press release I said:
Legislation will be introduced in the budget sittings of Parliament to give effect to these changes.

The changes, of course, that I was referring to are the ones set out in the Brown report. I see, as I said in my press release, a number of things that need to occur for those changes to be properly implemented and realised. It is in this Bill that I am trying to move forward some of those things that need to occur for those changes to be properly implemented and realised. But if those positional changes cannot occur in this Bill we are not then in a position to move forward on the timetable that I originally envisaged. That does put back considerably, and perhaps for at least six months, the application of those changes.

PARA.TAB: Given that in the speeches which have been made in this chamber, and, indeed, in the amendments circulated, a number of complimentary remarks have been made about the Brown review and its findings, the implication is that the parties here would like to see the Brown review implemented. I draw the conclusion that they would not like to see it delayed but in a non-obstructive and helpful way, I should say, the impact of carrying this amendment would be to delay it.

In respect of the first part of the amendment, which says that I have refused to table the Brown report, I say that I have expressed in press release form my commitment to the findings of the report and my commitment to ensuring legislative passage of those findings. One of the reasons the Brown review has not been tabled, and one of the reasons I think this chamber would respect the Government for not doing so, is that the report contained submissions and information given to the inquirer, Ron Brown, by various of the State authorities.

This compensation and rehabilitation authority obtained commercial-in-confidence information from various State authorities in order that the review could be properly conducted. Those State authorities wanted the information they made available kept in confidence. It is for the eyes of the Government but it is not for the eyes of commercial competitors, and it was on that basis that the information was given. I, therefore, do not think it appropriate to breach the commercial-in-confidence undertakings by making public the report.

What I have done, though, is, along with my press release on 18 September, released for public information an edited version of the report that excludes the commercial-in-confidence material and sets down the recommendations. So on the first charge that I am refusing to table, as if I am holding back from public scrutiny the findings of this report, the defence is clearly that, first, there are commercial-in-confidence matters; secondly, I have announced my position with respect to the report; thirdly, I have released an edited version of it; and, fourthly, the recommendations are available. I think that is, frankly, a perfectly reasonable and responsible course of action for a government to follow in all the circumstances.
Part (b) of the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to include the recommendations of the Brown Report—
which is something that I have just said I am publicly committed to—
especially those concerning:

The amendment lists seven things that the parties opposite and on the interchange bench would want to occur. The first point that I want to make about that—and, again, this is in my press release—is that I have said I want to implement these things.

PARA.TAB: I want to now go to some of the matters that have been raised. Paragraph (b) of the amendment continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)provision for compassionate early redemptions;

That is not a recommendation of the report that I have rejected. It requires, though, in the Budget context, some consideration of the cost and value of those redemptions. They are not small in money terms and they are not something that I as a Minister can commit myself to without involving the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and other Ministers who are responsible for Government outlays. So on that ground, I am caught within what are the normal strictures of government, whichever party is in government.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b) continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (ii)setting reasonable time limits for determinations, reconsiderations and reviews;

I think this is a very important point. I am glad it has been raised and I acknowledge its significance. I should point out that 80 per cent of all of the claims that have been lodged with Comcare are turned around, replied to and settled within 10 days; and 90 per cent of that 80 per cent are settled within two days. Item (ii) of the amendment was not a recommendation of the Brown report. Nonetheless, it is a matter of concern to Comcare. Comcare is now involved in drafting some performance criteria to ensure that it is even more efficient. I think I can demonstrate that quite clearly to the parties.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b)(iii) of the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: provision to the Minister by the new Commission, within a reasonable time, of a detailed strategy for addressing the most important service problems identified in the Brown Review and an implementation report to overcome them;

That, too, is an important matter but until this Bill is carried we will not be in a position to implement that provision because we need to set up the new Commission, which is the first step towards the necessary overseeing of the implementation of the other recommendations. I say that for this reason: I, as a Minister, could proceed by ministerial fiat but it is much sounder in terms of Government consideration to appoint the Commission that will be dealing with these matters and, with that body, draw up the detailed strategy for addressing the service problems because it will have the responsibility of directing the administration of Comcare, and it is important that it own part of the responsibility for the standards implemented.

PARA.TAB: So while it is true that perhaps I could impose by ministerial fiat, it is my more sober judgment that I should appoint that Commission as a first step and work with it to draw up the implementation of those proposals. That is not a matter that will be greatly delayed, either, because Comcare now is developing a service plan which could go to the new Commission when it is set up. It has already had discussions about the service plan with the inquirer, in this case Mr Brown, and with 30-odd of the major client agencies who are concerned about the strategy for addressing those service problems. So we are not talking about a delay here; matters of administrative detail are being attended to promptly. But as a first step we do need the Commission in place for this to work effectively.

Paragraph (b)(iv), concerning licensing arrangements for self-administrators, has attracted a fair bit of debate in this chamber. We agree to this recommendation but again I want the new Commission to be in place to advise me on it. On the basis of its advice, and after working to settle the terms of the licensing arrangements—that is also related to subparagraph (vii), having self-administrators' disputed claims reviewed by Comcare—that is something that we would wish to pick up in the licensing arrangements, but I think it will be picked up in association with the Commission.
Paragraph (b)(v) states:

SPEECH.PARA: the appointment of a part-time Chairman of the Commission who is not the Chief Executive Officer of COMCARE;

Proposed sections 89E and 89G indicate that we are proposing to appoint the Commission and we are proposing to appoint the Chairman. I think Senator Chapman suggested there would be eight members; there would be nine.

PARA.TAB: Paragraph (b)(vi) of the amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: allowing disputed claims to be referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal before they are reviewed. . .

This is an important matter as well, and it does deserve some consideration. Comcare itself has found that it is cheaper and more effective to conduct the review first, before going to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Clients who have gone through that process get a speedier turnaround and are happier about the outcome. The outcomes are often better. If, then, the matter still is contestable, if it has not been settled, the right to go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is preserved. As a first step, it seems a reasonable thing to do in all the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: In view of those explanations I would shortly propose to seek leave, as I indicated at the beginning of my remarks, to adjourn the debate. I say in a non-contentious way, simply to inform the chamber, that there are some reasonable and weighty considerations as to why, in a more raucous debate or a more argumentative setting, some of the arguments intrinsic to the amendments could be attacked. I do not wish to engage in that sort of politics here on this Bill now, but it is reasonable that there be some acknowledgment that prima facie the case I have made is worthy of some consideration and when I do seek leave that leave be granted. We can conduct further discussion and next Wednesday, if the Opposition parties are still of a mind to, they can proceed with their amendment or, if their attitude has changed, we can speedily deal with the legislation. On that basis I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On the basis of what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has said with respect to bringing the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 back into the Senate next Wednesday for further consideration, the Liberal and National parties—and, indeed, the Australian Democrats, as they have indicated to me—will accept the Minister's request to continue his remarks. However, we do so on the basis that, following the discussions that we will have with the Minister with regard to the legislation, both Senator Bell, on behalf of the Democrats, and I may wish to seek leave to speak again in the second reading debate. Our agreement to the Minister's request is on the basis that he would reciprocate a request from us to seek leave to speak further on the second reading of the Bill. As long as we have that assurance, we are prepared to accept his request.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

As I comprehend it, Senator Chapman is taking me at face value about what I have said, but in case, upon closer scrutiny, something is not to his taste or desire, he wishes to preserve his right to address it.
