DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major purpose of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 is to implement decisions in the area of aged care announced by the Government in the 1991-92 Budget. The other purpose of this Bill is to make amends for errors and oversights in earlier legislation.

PARA.TAB: It seems that too often we spend time in this chamber, especially towards the end of a session, patching up mistakes which have been made in legislation from a previous session or earlier in the session which really has not been thought through sufficiently at the time and which, with hindsight, could have been done much better. I suppose that happens because we have rushes, as we did this morning. Instead of introducing the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill into the House of Representatives, as it should have been, to circumvent the time constraints on that House it was introduced here in the Senate. Of course, that means that we have less time to concentrate on the legislation and it is more likely that unintended consequences will occur.

One of the provisions in this Bill, amending an oversight which occurred earlier, will allow a physiotherapist to refer for certain R-type X-rays. When the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment (No. 2) Bill 1990 was passed, it allowed for chiropractors to refer for certain X-rays but the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services had forgotten that physiotherapists, in their normal course of diagnosis, refer for X-rays.

It seems that the Department often forgets about the allied health professions. So does the Department of Social Security. For example, when we were doing the review table for disabilities, I asked which experts had been consulted. Senator Richardson told me that many throughout Australia had been. I discovered that two rehabilitation doctors had been consulted and no-one had thought to consult physiotherapists or occupational therapists, many of whom have expertise in the area of functional assessment. They had been omitted.

I think it is time that the Department and the people in Canberra began to look a bit further than the medical model and look towards the allied health professions. In the dining room tonight Senator Zakharov told me that when the new senator for Western Australia arrives—Mr Deputy President, you will be interested in this, being one of them—there will be five psychologists in the Parliament. Hopefully, we can draw the attention of the bureaucrats not only to the work that our profession does but also to the work of other allied health professionals and the contribution they can make.

As I said, physiotherapists were forgotten in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. Since 1 May, physiotherapists have been restricted in their ability to order X-rays. A GP's referral is needed for R-type X-rays for which a Medicare benefit is payable. Having taught a couple of thousand physiotherapists in the 13 years I was at the Lincoln Institute, they realised that they had someone who knew something about physiotherapy and, as I have said previously in this chamber, they beat a pathway to my door. I have had more letters from physiotherapists than almost any other profession on an issue.

In the past, physiotherapists have been responsible for ordering such X-rays for their patients. Statistics gathered by the Australian Physiotherapy Association showed that a majority of physiotherapists in private practice use X-rays as an integral part of diagnosis and patient care. It might be of interest to the chamber to know that one of my former students and a couple of other physiotherapists undertook a survey of young female students in one of the outer eastern suburbs of Melbourne. As a community service, they were not paid for this, they surveyed every sixth grade child—I stand to be corrected; it might have been first-year females—and detected, by way of X-rays, that a large number of girls had the beginning of scoliosis and referred them for treatment.

These physiotherapists were able to involve themselves in a fairly extensive public health exercise as a service to their local community, free of charge, at their own expense. One of them came to me as he was concerned that he would not be able to carry out such an exercise if he was not permitted to undertake these X-rays. That is another example. It is not just in their day-to-day profession; it is in exercising a community service and a public health service that they were concerned about the omission.

The following points indicate why the legislation should be amended. I have outlined one of them. Physiotherapists are primary contact health practitioners who have undertaken a high degree of educational training which has provided them with specialised skills in diagnosis and assessment. As I have mentioned, X-rays are an integral part of diagnosis and patient care. Under the current arrangements, patients who require X-rays will be forced to make additional visits to a medical practitioner for referral and obtain a radiologist's report. This would ultimately lead to increased Medicare costs. Physiotherapy patients have been required to make additional visits to medical practitioners, which may have resulted in delayed treatment.

Following extensive lobbying by the Opposition, the Government has agreed to amend the legislation to allow for physiotherapists to refer for R-type X-rays of the spine and pelvic regions. The Minister said that these amendments would take place as soon as legislation was introduced to do this. That option was not taken up by the Minister. The Opposition decided that the only way to force the Government's hand was to introduce the amendment ourselves.

The Government has agreed to support an Opposition amendment to allow podiatrists as well to refer for R-type X-rays of the foot and lower leg. Having taught a large number of podiatrists in Victoria over the 13 years I taught at Lincoln, I saw enormous changes in the education of podiatrists. They moved from being simply chiropodists, as we once knew them—treating maybe elderly patients for corns, et cetera—to very professional people looking at patterns of gait and the effects on knees of pronation of the foot. Mr Deputy President, I am sure you will be interested in that as well, as we both have knee problems.

They are also very involved in the treatment of preventative disease in young children and the effects of disorders of the foot. So they have really developed a much more professional approach to problems of the foot and of the lower leg. In fact they do some minor surgery as well. In the course of their profession, which has become much more in-depth and much more professional, they need the ability to also refer for R-type X-rays. That is another reason why we have moved that amendment.

One other area that is covered in this Bill relates to the National Food Authority. The National Food Authority Act was passed by the Parliament in June 1991 and was proclaimed to come into effect on 19 August 1991. The NFA has the responsibility for developing and amending food standards. The Bill permits the National Food Authority to treat applications for the development or variation of food standards of the NHMRC as

SPEECH.PARA: having been made under the principal Act and to omit any of the steps normally required in respect of the development or variation of standards. The amendment overcomes an oversight in the operation of section 71 of the principal Act—again another oversight. The Opposition will be supporting the amendments that correct the anomalies in the Act.

PARA.TAB: The next issue relates to day care surgery. In 1989 the Government introduced Medicare benefits to encourage day only surgery in hospitals. However, in order to prevent procedures which could normally be done in doctors' surgeries being transferred to hospitals, the Government compiled a list of procedures which could not attract such a benefit unless a certificate was signed by the treating doctor stating that in that particular case the patient required day care admission. Only doctors from private or public hospitals were able to issue these certificates. This amendment fixes this oversight which meant that the certification system was not available to doctors at freestanding day surgery facilities. I believe there are 64 such centres around Australia. One of my former student's husbands actually runs one of these day care centres and when the legislation came through he pointed this out as a matter of concern to him and as an issue that he felt needed addressing. The Opposition supports this amendment to remedy yet another oversight.

One would have to say that the plethora of oversights that surrounded the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority had to be seen to be believed. I congratulate the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which undertook what I believed would be a very short investigation or inquiry but which turned out to be a very long one, because we have seen the unintended consequences of legislation which has been brought in here and which was not thought through. During that Committee hearing we became aware that the Health Insurance Commission and the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority—and I do not know where the responsibility lies—did not set out guidelines for the interim period for the pharmacy restructuring process. I have been to many of the sittings of the Committee and I have seen people whose livelihoods have been either taken away from them or severely affected because nobody really thought through the ramifications of what was happening.

One of the unintended consequences of that legislation was that there was no process of review. So the amendment that is now before us gives aggrieved applicants the right to seek a review of a recommendation from the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. Applicants will be permitted to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of a decision made by the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. Appeals may be made in relation to approval to dispense PBS prescriptions, the payment of essential pharmacy allowances, and the payment of amalgamation or closure packages.

This amendment arises from an omission in the legislation under which the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority was established. As I said, applicants aggrieved with the decision with PRA found themselves with no appeal mechanism to the AAT. However, there was an appeal mechanism open to the Federal Court of Australia. It seems unbelievable to me that the response was, `Well, you can go to the Federal Court'. We had failed to see—and I include all of us in this but I basically blame the Government—the need for an appeal mechanism and for those people the only recourse was to go to the Federal Court.

We should all realise the great responsibility we have here to ensure that legislation that goes through this place does not have unintended consequences which affect the livelihood and the well-being, particularly the emotional well-being—and we have seen people who have been severely affected—of innocent people who are the victims of the fact that the legislation was not properly thought through. In its annual report the AAT spent considerable time talking about the problem that had arisen because of this omission.

Having dealt with the amendments that have corrected the anomalies, I now address the provisions of the Bill that implement the Budget proposals relating to aged care. Firstly, the Bill enables community care packages to be provided to frail older people who continue to reside in their own home. The Minister has said that surveys of older people show they would prefer to live in their own homes than to move into residential care. I would actually like to see those surveys. I do not think it means that all older people would like to live in their own homes but means that people would prefer to have the opportunity to make a choice. Maybe the Minister means that basically older people would prefer to live in their own homes. But I do not think we could say that all older people would chose to live that way.

The basic element—and what we ought to be about—is choice. People who would prefer to live in the security of residential care should have that choice and those who prefer to remain in their own homes for as long as possible should also have that choice.

Two pioneering efforts that I have seen in my own home State are the Hawthorn program, which comes under the linkages part of HACC, and the Brotherhood of St Laurence program in Geelong, which provides assistance to people with dementia. Both of those programs involve caring for people at home.

I actually spent some time with people from the Hawthorn Council program. We started off at 7.30 in the morning. The first client we visited was severely restricted in her movement because of arthritis. She was very concerned that the linkages program would not continue and that she would not be able to stay in her own home. That Hawthorn Council program demonstrated, through an evaluation, that 19 people were able to be maintained in their own homes at a cost less than the average cost of maintaining that number of people in nursing homes and hostels. Some of them were assessed by GAT teams as requiring residential care in nursing homes, some in hostels. When that cost was averaged out it was found that Hawthorn program was cheaper.

The Brotherhood of St Laurence program is innovative. People with dementia are cared for in their own homes. Training programs even include taxi drivers who run some of the clients from their homes to various doctors, et cetera. The taxi drivers are encouraged not to leave their clients at the front door of their homes. They are advised to take them inside and to put the front door key exactly where the person will find it. As we know, some of these people have short term memory failure. So that program is even at the level of training taxi drivers who work with these people. Everyone who is associated with those clients is taught and made aware of the special needs of people with dementia. Hopefully, this program will have long term viability as a result of this announcement.

As part of the Budget announcement the number of hostel places per thousand people over the age of 70 will be reduced from 60 to 55. As a substitution for the reduction in hostel places, funding will be provided for community aged care service packages. Under the program, financial assistance will be paid to organisations providing community aged care service packages designed to meet individual needs, and I hope this will include organisations such as the Hawthorn Council and the Brotherhood of St Lawrence.

The number of packages which will be approved are based on the number of hostel places forgone. As we know, the Government had planned to have 60 hostel places and 40 nursing home places per thousand people over 75. Those 60 places have now been reduced to 55 places. Those five beds are to be over time—it seems over quite a considerable time—devoted to these community care places. Approvals are to concentrate on those areas in Australia in which it is particularly difficult to provide hostels due to factors such as cost, lack of population, demand or suitable land. Remote and rural areas are particularly singled out.

An important point to note is that older people to whom these community care packages are targeted will also require other services such as those provided under HACC. Unless HACC is able to meet the increased demand, the success of the community aged packages may be at risk. The Bill also gives effect to restructuring of personal care subsidy. The subsidy is divided into three levels according to the level of dependency. As we know, the Government brought in changes to funding for nursing home residents, bringing in a resident classification index which had five levels. One of the differences between the way in which that was implemented and the way in which this is implemented was that, prior to the bringing in of legislation to this House, the Government had surveyed, from memory, 17,000 residents to develop the RCI and to test it. We were able to read and examine the final report.

The reason I am particularly interested is that Victoria has a distribution of residential care different from any other State. We have fewer nursing homes and more hostel residents. We have twice as many nursing home residents in State-funded nursing homes as any other State. We have a totally different profile, with more small rural nursing homes, to that of any other State. So I have concentrated particularly on that. There were some very grave concerns raised when the RCI was developed. I would have liked to have seen the three-tier system for hostels developed more before the legislation came into this House. It would have been more appropriate to have done the survey and to have presented us with the report, as was done with the nursing home RCI classification index, so that we could examine it and the industry could bring its concerns or its congratulations—I do not want to be biased in predicting what might happen—about that distribution: the percentage and the factors that are included to classify people in levels 1, 2 or 3. I have a concern that we should have had that information beforehand.

I will be moving some amendments, although I am not sure the Democrats will support them since the Minister has given an undertaking to them. We have a copy of that letter as to how that process will be undertaken—it is currently under way—but I believe it would have been more appropriate for the same procedure to have been used for the introduction of the hostel classification as was used for the nursing home classification.

The Bill also enables the Government to control the quality of persons operating hostels approved under the Act. In 1989, the National Health Act was amended to be able to control the quality of persons operating approved nursing homes. The Bill seeks to exert the same control over the quality of hostel proprietors as exists over nursing home proprietors. The amendments will make it a condition of a hostel's approval that the person operating or proposing to operate a hostel will be approved as an approved operator. Where a hostel breaches this condition, the Commonwealth will be under no obligation to sustain financial assistance in the form of a recurrent subsidy.

The decision to approve, refuse or revoke an approval will be based on consideration of a person's ability to satisfy certain criteria. These criteria will include relevant experience, honesty, efficiency and history in the aged care industry. Also contained in the Bill are some changes in the arrangements for CAM funding for non-government nursing homes. Nursing homes will be able to delay applying for a new classification for a patient whose previous classification expired during or shortly after return from hospital leave. An application will not need to be made until the resident's care needs have been carefully assessed after their return from hospital.

A number of concerns have been expressed to me as I have moved around Australia, particularly in Victoria, that there have been problems with the classification for CAM funding with regard to people leaving hospitals, and changes in their status. I am pleased to see that the Government has at least responded in this area.

The amendments in the Bill regarding infrastructure funding follow the recently completed SAM review. Remote homes, whose infrastructure costs are substantially higher because of their location, will receive additional funding of approximately $3 per resident per day. Additional funding will also be provided for residents needing nasogastric feeding or continuous oxygen so that they do not have to pay these costs. That has been a very long time coming as well. It has been apparent that some residents have had to stay in hospitals rather than be moved back to their nursing homes, because hospitals provide a service at no cost. This Bill will allow people to move into a more appropriate type of care rather than being in an acute hospital.

The industry is more than disappointed that there has been no general increase in infrastructure funding. The situation in Victoria is critical at the moment, and it would be remiss of me not to mention this in my speech. The industry has calculated that there is a deficiency as high as $10 a day in infrastructure funding. Since the inception of SAM, the industry has pointed out that there is a major deficiency in the construction of the return on the investment element of the funding package.

I have been to some places in the country where the directors of nursing—who have been in the facilities for a considerable amount of time, and have a great commitment to them—have been doing loads of washing because they believe there is not sufficient SAM money to employ people to do it. This situation will be critical until it is remedied. In Victoria, 21 per cent of the private sector homes are in or near receivership. If one believed in the conspiracy theory, one would believe that the Government's policy has set out to ensure the demise of the private sector in the nursing home industry.

The Opposition believes that the government of the day should ensure that there is an appropriate and adequate level of infrastructure funding for nursing homes. It seems very odd to us that an ingoing is required for a hostel and not necessarily for a nursing home and, in the same complex, that if a person moves from the hostel to the nursing home the ingoing has to be passed back. Surely the Government can develop flexible arrangements to ensure that the care of, and delivery of service to, our older people is not affected by lack of funds.

Charitable and benevolent organisations have for many years received capital grants to assist them to build new nursing homes or rebuild existing homes. Proprietors who do not receive capital grants will now receive supplementary recurrent funding for 10 years for new homes. The legislation allows the Minister to take into account proprietors' records when determining this additional funding. The Minister said that he did not consider it would be appropriate to encourage proprietors with unsatisfactory records to remain in the industry by providing them with additional recurrent funding for new buildings. The Opposition would have to agree, as I am sure the Democrats would, that anything we can do to ensure that the standard of care is as high as possible for older Australians is important.

I will not go into great detail about nursing homes and hostels for disabled people because the Standing Committee on Community Affairs examined them. The coalition was not convinced by the arguments that were put forward by the Department that the interests of the 17 nursing homes and three hostels that have not transferred under the DSA would be served by the current clauses in the Bill. We are moving a number of amendments which we believe meet the needs of those nursing homes and hostels and which would ensure that until their continued funding is guaranteed, and until the transfer is satisfactory to them, the legislation will not be passed as it is.

In summary, we suggest that there should be a deferral of the passage of the Bill until, firstly, appropriate legislation is in place to ensure continuity of the level of funding to the nursing homes and hostels to be transferred and, secondly, proper guidelines are drawn up for the proposed transfer of accommodation services to the States which ensure continuity of funding or complete clarification of the intending relationship between the State and Federal governments as to the funding of accommodation services. Given that the Government is unwilling to do this, I foreshadow that the Opposition, as I said before, will be opposing the relevant clauses in the committee stage of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 implements a number of Budget decisions, mainly about aged care, most of which are welcomed by the Australian Democrats. Firstly, the Bill allows for organisations providing help to aged or disabled persons living at home to receive financial assistance. This assistance is to be called community aged care service packages and they are a further step towards enabling aged people to stay at home if they so wish rather than be forced into institutional care. I do not think anyone would question that this is a laudable aim.

PARA.TAB: We do not need surveys to tell us that most older people would much rather stay at home in their own localities with friends and neighbours, often in homes that they have lived in for many years, rather than be forced into a nursing home or hostel. Of course, it is not always possible for people to stay at home as they get older and their physical or mental health deteriorates. However, it should be our goal to assist older people to stay at home where it is what they want and where it is possible for them to do so.

The community aged care service packages will enable people to receive hostel level personal care services in their own homes. They will be directed towards those persons who have a relatively high dependency—in other words, the ones most at risk of having to move into residential care. Both residential care providers and community based care providers would be eligible to receive funding under this program. I am hopeful, as is the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), that this will lead to increased contact and improved understanding between the two. It certainly has the potential to lead to a more efficient and effective use of resources and services.

The packages offer a way of giving maximum possible effect to the wishes of an older person and to tailor support programs to an individual's needs instead of just packing the person off to a hostel or nursing home when he or she starts to deteriorate or becomes a nuisance or problem for his or her neighbours or relatives. These packages will undoubtedly prove to be of major benefit to many older people and will be especially valuable to people living in remote or rural areas.

However, their introduction is also likely to raise a whole new set of problems. I trust that the Government will be closely monitoring the operation of the packages—and the consequent reduction in the number of hostel places per 1,000 people over 70—to make sure that they do serve the needs of aged persons in the community. In particular, I urge the Minister to get serious about properly funding the home and community care program in recognition of the potentially very valuable role HACC is likely to play in ensuring the success of these packages.

The Bill also covers the restructuring of hostel personal care funding, which is an attempt to target funding towards residents who are very physically frail or who have dementia. Again, this is a worthwhile objective. Inadequate support for people with dementia has been a cause of concern for some time. While there are still problems with the level of support available, I believe that the new three-tier subsidy structure is very definitely a step in the right direction. Certainly it will mean that more services will receive more assistance for dementia sufferers. However, the phasing out of the dementia grants program is likely to cause problems for the specialised dementia hostels. I ask the Minister whether he can inform the Senate how the Government is planning to address the ongoing needs of these hostels.

I appreciate Senator Patterson's concerns about not being able to see the detail relating to the three tiers. As I have said before, this Government is most adept at leaving major issues to delegated legislation rather than including them in the principal Act. This practice is highly unsatisfactory and it is tempting to see it as a way of dodging the processes of Parliament. But, as I have also said before in this chamber, I do not see it as a reason for holding up legislation. I am pretty sure that when Opposition senators find themselves in government they will not be particularly keen on having their legislation delayed because they do not have the relevant delegated legislation completed.

It is obviously not always possible to present regulations or instruments at the time the principal legislation comes up. In this case, under clause 2, section 10 and section 11 will commence on 29 April. I asked for and received an assurance from the Minister, Mr Staples, that relevant guidelines will be tabled by the end of March next year. I seek leave to have his letter dated 12 December 1991 incorporated as it sets out in quite some detail the fact that the instrument is currently being trialled in some 347 hostels and gives details as to the date when the general conditions will be tabled.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Lees
I refer to your expressed concern at the Government's intentions in respect of the conditions under which the proposed new hostel personal care subsidies will be determined and how they will operate.

As you are aware the proposed amendment makes provision for three rates of personal care subsidy instead of one. Further, it allows that the `General Conditions' will be amended to enable the determination of the classification of hostel residents for the purpose of payment of the subsidy according to the classification of the person.

To this end, substantial work has been undertaken to develop a new instrument to effect the classification of residents. This has been done in consultation with peak service providers, consumer and union groups as well as recognised experts in the field of dementia. All of these have co-operated in this process and the peak service groups, Aged Care Australia and the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association have supported the trial of the instrument.

The instrument is currently being trialled in some 347 hostels, involving some 6,500 residents. The sample has been so structured as to ensure a balanced representation of all hostels by State, metropolitan and non-metropolitan areas, size range and focus on special needs groups—including double sampling of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander hostels and hostels for specific ethnic groups to ensure statistical reliability in the returns. Also, the sample has been balanced to ensure representation of hostels in receipt of dementia grants, i.e., approximately 37 per cent.

The `General Conditions' will detail the criteria for assessment and the method of classification of people and identify the points scale and cut-offs at which the different rates are applicable. The trial will provide the data to enable the statistical analysis which will determine the weightings to apply to the various questions. This in turn will allow the determination of those factors which will permit the classification of the individual to the relevant group for subsidy purposes. This analysis will be publicly available and the basis of consultation with the industry. I would be happy to ensure you received a copy if you so wished.

The `General Conditions' relating to the classification of persons will be tabled prior to the implementation date of 29 April 1992 to take effect from that date. They will, of course, be developed and finalised when the results of the trial data analysis and consultations are completed which will be during March 1992. I give an undertaking that the `General Conditions' will be tabled by the end of March 1992. You will appreciate that the General Conditions are a disallowable instrument and as such both Houses should have an adequate opportunity to consider them by April 29, 1992.

I trust that I have alleviated your concerns as to the process and timing of the implementation of these new funding arrangements which are designed to give recognition to the valuable role hostels play in caring for the frail aged, including those with cognitive and behavioural problems, and in ensuring that funding is targeted to those with the greatest need. You will appreciate that extra funding is proposed to facilitate this change and that more people requiring personal care support will now be eligible to receive additional funding to assist in the provision of that support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill also sets up control mechanisms over the operators of hostels similar to those already in place for nursing home proprietors under the National Health Act. I know that there are a lot of mutterings in the aged care industry about too much government intervention and regulation, but the Australian Democrats do not accept these arguments. When someone is operating for profit a service that provides direct care to a group of people who, by and large, are not in a position to push their own interests, then the community, through the Government, has an obligation to ensure these people receive proper protection and are not exploited. This is not an area where we can afford the so-called free market to operate uncontrolled and unobserved.

PARA.TAB: I think it is quite clear that the Government's efforts in this field have been instrumental in the industry cleaning up its act. That is not to say that the industry has not done quite a bit to get its own house in order; nor am I saying that there are vast numbers of shoddy operators out there. But it has to be acknowledged that there are some unscrupulous and uncaring hostel and nursing home operators and there are some who simply do not have the experience, knowledge or capabilities to provide a good standard of care to their residents.

It does not help to pretend that these people do not exist—although we also need to appreciate that physical, emotional and financial abuse can, and indeed unfortunately does, occur in the older person's own home. In short, I do not consider that introducing the concept of approved operators into the hostel area represents any great infringement on the rights of hostel owners.

There are other changes to nursing home funding arrangements contained in the Bill, including additional SAM funding for nursing homes catering for residents who require nasogastric feeding or continuous oxygen and those homes situated in isolated areas. We support these measures, which are generally welcomed by the industry.

However, the general point needs to be made to the Government that, as long as we are going to have private-for-profit hostels and nursing homes, there must be a recognition of the costs involved in providing an adequate standard of care. I think the industry makes a number of very valid points when it talks about the inadequacy of the present levels of subsidy available to it. I have to say that this issue has been raised with me many times throughout the entire country by various proprietors and service providers, and I am sympathetic to their arguments.

Estimates vary as to exactly what increases are needed to fix the situation, but both private and religious or charitable service providers have told me that they are struggling to maintain a high standard of care under present SAM levels. I think a convincing case can be, and has been, made for increasing SAM levels. This issue of adequacy of SAM funding really has not been addressed properly by the Government.

In this Bill, the Government has also moved to rectify an omission relating to the payment of Medicare benefits to physiotherapists for certain types of X-rays, and I understand the Government has accepted similar Opposition amendments covering podiatrists. Like many other honourable senators, I have received numerous letters from physiotherapists and podiatrists concerned about the impact of their omission from the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1990. We were advised by the Minister early in this session—I think it was as early as August—that amendments covering physiotherapists would be introduced before the end of the year. We indicated to all those who contacted us that such amendments would have our support.

We are also supportive of the move to cover podiatrists and we recognise the sensible approach being taken by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) in giving effect to these changes. The credit really belongs to the many physiotherapists and podiatrists who picked up the omission and who lobbied so hard to have it recognised.

This Bill also provides for the revoking of approvals for 17 nursing homes and three hostels for disabled people to coincide with the Commonwealth-State disability agreements coming into force in each State. These provisions allow the remaining nursing homes and hostels for people with disabilities to be included in the transfer of responsibility for Commonwealth-funded accommodation services to the States. These revocations will take place only when the CSDA comes into operation in each State. I must say that I have considerable difficulty with the premise behind these provisions, but not so much with the provisions themselves.

The Australian Democrats are not big fans of the so-called new federalism. We do not consider that the States have good records in the delivery of human services and we are concerned that the interests of people with disabilities must be protected under any transfer of services to the States. We have put our concerns about handing over services to the States on record on many occasions. However, despite what the Democrats—and, I might add, many community organisations and service providers—may feel about the whole new federalism debacle, the Government will be proceeding with the hand-over to the States of accommodation facilities for people with disabilities.

I was tempted to put a spanner in the new federalism works by delaying the revocation of these approvals. However, I must say that we have now had two very comprehensive briefings from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services—and I thank the officers concerned, particularly for the very late ones they attended. I really cannot see much point in holding up the process just in relation to these 20 services, especially—and this I wish to stress—as it may very well be to the detriment of the residents concerned.

Firstly, under the terms of the CSDA, no service will be transferred, including those services mentioned in this Bill, until each individual State enacts legislation complementary to the Disability Services Act. I accept the argument that the residents in these facilities are more likely to receive services that meet their needs under this sort of complementary legislation than under the existing legislation, which is basically directed towards aged care. Furthermore, there will not be any funding gap as a consequence of these amendments.

Secondly, the CSDA provides that each State is required to maintain funding for the transferred services at current levels for the first year after transfer. There are certainly problems with three of the services, all in New South Wales, because they basically fall outside the parameters of the CSDA, being primarily for drug and alcohol rehabilitation. However, negotiations are continuing about their transfer. I cannot see that delaying this process does anything much one way or the other for these particular services.

Under the CSDA, the Commonwealth will provide initial funding under a special purpose payment for the first year and is offering the States and Territories $245m over the next five years, with $100m earmarked for growth in the transferred services and $145m for improving existing services. While the Commonwealth is obviously unable to give cast-iron guarantees about funding, it does seem likely that the particular services mentioned in this Bill will get an opportunity to increase their funding levels.

Further—and I think this is a very convincing point—the CSDA obliges all governments and services to enter into service agreements which will specify the outcomes to be achieved and the standards to be attained. At present, the services we are talking about are not obliged to meet particular service standards. At the moment there is still very little control over the services concerned. Further delays could mean that residents in these places may be denied access to the provisions and protections of the Disability Services Act.

In these circumstances I cannot see that it makes much sense to hold these particular services back from the CSDA transfer process. It would not be consistent or fair to proceed with the arrangements for every other service and, effectively, leave these high and dry, occupying a little corner all on their own. Then one really would wonder what their future would be. Accordingly, we will not be supporting the deletion of clauses 13, 38 and 53.

Finally, the Bill provides for a Commonwealth benefit to be paid in respect of newly built nursing homes. The Opposition had proposed some amendments relating to an appeal process for ministerial decisions, and I welcome its decision not to proceed with these amendments. We had major problems with these because, effectively, they would have allowed proprietors to appeal against a refusal to grant them a benefit. This could have led to considerable delays and great problems as normally appeals are about eligibility rather than whether the Minister decides, once an application has been accepted, to go ahead and fund the applicant. I will close by simply saying that we are pleased to note that the Opposition has withdrawn those amendments. (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate; I thought there was a longer speakers list. I do wish to respond on behalf of the Government on this very important Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, because it covers a range of matters which are of great importance and certainly require the attention of the Senate to enable these important reforms to proceed.

PARA.TAB: For example, the Bill proposes a significant amendment to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act to enable community care packages to be provided to frail older people continuing to reside in their own homes. I think all honourable senators would agree that it must be a fundamental objective of any aged care policy to try to extend the independence of older people in the community through the provision of home care services. Certainly, it has been my experience, and no doubt that of other honourable senators, that older people do prefer to stay at home and receive care rather than move to a residential facility. The introduction of community aged care services packages is an important step in that process. In so far as this Bill facilitates that, it is certainly to be welcomed.

There is also, as was foreshadowed in the Budget, following the review of hostel recurrent funding, a decision by the Government to restructure hostel personal care funding. This was seen as necessary to target funding to those residents with high levels of physical frailty and to those suffering from dementia. The restructured personal care subsidy will provide clear incentives for hostels to provide care for more highly dependent and confused people consistent with the objectives of the aged care strategy. I understand that may be the subject of further discussion during the committee stage. I think some amendments will be moved by the Opposition.

A further purpose of this Bill is to make amendments to the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to revoke approvals to the 17 remaining nursing homes for disabled people and three remaining hostels for disabled people at the time the existing Commonwealth-State disability agreements come into full operation in each State. I recall that that was the subject of some discussion by the legislation committee.

The amendments proposed in the Bill relating to the payment of Medicare benefits for R-type or referred diagnostic imaging services are designed to enable the payment of benefits of certain imaging requested by physiotherapists. I think it is to do with the spine and pelvic area, and it gives physiotherapists the same recognition as was accorded to chiropractors. Quite clearly, when one is considering spinal manipulation, the importance of spinal X-rays to ensure safe manipulation is particularly important.
This Bill, as I say, covers a wide range of matters of interest so far as the provision of health care in the Australian community is concerned, and I commend it to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 2, page 1, subclause (2), omit the subclause, substitute the following subclauses:

PARA.TAB: "(2) Section 10 commences on 29 April 1992.
(2A) Section 11 commences on the day on which General Conditions for the purposes of paragraph (ba) formulated in accordance with subsection 10F(1) take effect.

(2B) Despite section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the General Conditions referred to in subsection (2A) take effect on the first day on which they are no longer liable to be disallowed or to be taken to have been disallowed, under section 48 of that Act.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will ensure that clause 11 does not take effect until the general conditions under which the personal care subsidy assessment instruments are formulated. Clause 11 brings in the principle but the details will be in delegated legislation. The coalition believes that those details should be tabled before the clause takes effect.

PARA.TAB: Many organisations have been concerned about the personal care assessment instrument and, as I said, they were concerned about the RCI during its development. Apparently the Government consulted with the industry and consumer groups in October but, despite satisfying none of those groups, proceeded to conduct a pilot study involving five hostels in New South Wales and Victoria. Following the pilot study there is to be a major trial of the new instrument involving 340 hostels across Australia. Mr Staples sent a letter to Senator Lees, which she has incorporated, which outlines that process.

The latest version of the personal care assessment instrument is perceived to have a number of deficiencies, including placing undue demands on hostel management because of documentation requirements to validate assessments and the categorisation of residents, and the resultant funding is not likely to reflect the real costs of personal care for residents who have dementia or some other behavioural disorder. Specialised dementia hostels are not accommodated by the general personal care assessment instrument. A separate instrument is proposed for those facilities but details have not been forthcoming for consideration. Short term illness is not recognised in the new instrument and the personal care assessment will be effective for three months.

There are a number of concerns, and for these reasons the coalition would be happier if clause 11 did not take effect until we have had time, and the industry and the consumers have had time, to consider the delegated legislation in detail.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share a number of Senator Patterson's concerns. The Australian Democrats have looked very carefully at this issue. However, we are prepared to accept the Minister's assurance that we will have time to look at this instrument; indeed, it is disallowable. I note that the Democrats will be very carefully examining it to make sure that a number of points raised by Senator Patterson are covered. At this time, however, the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been foreshadowed in the second reading debate and announced in the committee stage of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill, and as would be well known to those following the debate, whereas the three-tier personal care subsidiary has the full support, as I have been advised, of the hostel industry, there are further provisions and details to be worked out.

PARA.TAB: To that end, a trial is presently being conducted, as has been noted. I believe that consultation is taking place in a very deliberate and real way with consumer service providers, industrial organisations and other professionals. This trial has their support. The trial is being undertaken in 347 hostels across Australia, involving some 6,000 residents, randomly selected, to provide for a complete coverage of hostel types and care needs of hostel residents.

It has been noted by Senator Lees that the report is targeted to be available by the end of February 1992. The report ought to be available to any interested senators—I do not see any reason why it cannot be made available—and it can form the basis of further representations, if thought suitable or required by honourable senators, along with the various service providers, industrial organisations, consumer lobby groups and so on who might wish to comment on it.

As I expect, the report will be the basis for the drafting of the general conditions and setting out the detail of the operation of the new scheme, including how the assessments will be made and the cut-off points for each category on the assessment scale. If, as is intended, those general conditions are tabled in the Parliament by the end of March 1992, then that certainly gives the full opportunity to debate those general conditions if it is thought necessary.

I believe that there is no need to defer the substantive legislation which determines the general structure of the new system. The Senate will be able to exercise its full powers in relation to the disallowable instrument, which will contain the general conditions. For that reason, the Government will not be supporting this particular amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 12, by leave, taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 13, 38 and 53, by leave, taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 13, page 6, lines 6 to 24, clause to be opposed.
6.Clause 38, page 21, lines 6 to 24, clause to be opposed.
7.Clause 53, page 27, lines 11 to 31, clause to be opposed.

As part of the rationalisation of the provision of services between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, the Premiers and the Chief Ministers signed the Commonwealth-State disability agreement. A major feature of this agreement was the transfer of responsibility for disability services to the States and Territories, with a related increase in funding from the Commonwealth to compensate for this additional expenditure required. The aims of the agreement include a reduction in administrative duplication and less confusion for people with disabilities.

PARA.TAB: The Bill proposes amendments to the National Health Act 1953, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974 and the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act 1954 to revoke approvals to the 17 remaining nursing homes for people with disabilities and the three remaining hostels for people with disabilities at the time the existing Commonwealth-State disabilities agreement came into full operation in each State. The amendments allow for these nursing homes and hostels to be included in the transfer of administrative responsibility for all Commonwealth funded disability accommodation services to the States when the Commonwealth-State disability agreements, which were signed on 30 July 1991, come into operation.

The Bill includes a sunset clause which will remove the guaranteed funding that is available under the Health Act. The Opposition is not prepared to accept this clause at this stage with the present uncertainties about future funding. The Opposition has a number of concerns. Firstly, many of the nursing homes and hostels have already transferred to the DSA. Despite the fact that there was a promise of a guaranteed level of funding, there have been circumstances where funding has been reduced. There is also some concern that the number of beds may be reduced in a hostel, thereby threatening the viability of the entire hostel.

The Bill includes a sunset clause for 30 June 1991. Accommodation under the DSA will be transferred to the States and employment services will be retained by the Commonwealth. There is some uncertainty as to whether the States are ready to accept responsibility for accommodation services, given that the matter of transferring services to the States has not been addressed at the Premiers Conference. Secondly, on what basis will the States have the accommodation in hostels and nursing homes transferred to them? If it is on the basis of the present DSA, the Opposition has proposed amendments to the DSA. These include bringing the guidelines before Parliament for debate.

The reason the 17 nursing homes and three hostels have not transferred under the DSA is that they are concerned about their future funding. This concern was expressed to the Department of Community Affairs. It is for this reason that we move these amendments to ensure that, firstly, the continuity of the level of funding to the nursing homes and hostels will be transferred and, secondly, proper guidelines are drawn up for the proposed transfer of accommodation services to the States.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We were attracted to these amendments basically because of our objection to the whole new federalism process. It took a committee hearing plus several briefings to convince us otherwise, basically for two reasons. Firstly, we believe the amendments may well prove to be detrimental to the interests of the residents concerned, leaving them out in the cold altogether. Residents are more likely to receive services that meet their needs if the services are transferred. If the transfer does not proceed, an option is being shut down for them and doors are being closed. Secondly, at the moment there is very little control over the services concerned. Moving makes sure that these residents will get access to the provisions and protections of the Disability Services Act. Therefore, we will not be supporting these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government also will not be adopting the amendments moved by the Opposition. We believe the arrangements that are envisaged will receive a cooperative response from the States. We expect the legislation which the States are requested to make complementary to the Commonwealth's DSA to be in place. With sufficient safeguards, with the Minister himself taking a very real interest in the matter and with the possibility of the Senate having a look at the way in which it works out in detail, I believe that there is sufficient certainty in the process envisaged by the simple passage of these amendments of the Bill to allow the Senate to support the Bill as it stands.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 14 to 22—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 23 to 25—by leave—taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.
