DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SELF-GOVERNMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. Let me say from the outset that it serves little purpose to go over all the old ground in detail as to the history of the electoral system in the ACT. It is sufficient to remind honourable senators that after considerable debate, which went on for months, the Parliament agreed to a proportional representation electoral system based on the European d'Hondt system and colloquially known as `modified d'Hondt'. At the first election members of a disenchanted electorate, which for various reasons did not want self-government, set out to protest in the way they voted. Some weird and wonderful parties were registered, such as the Party! Party! Party!, the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party, the Abolish Self-Government Party, the No-Self Government Party and so on. In fact, some candidates were elected from parties with those weird names. When the many independents were added, the ballot paper ended up being a metre long.

PARA.TAB: In view of the hostility to self-government, irrespective of the electoral system in place, whether it had been a Senate type or a modified d'Hondt, the bizarre outcome would have almost certainly been the same. It was inevitable. It is patently obvious that the silly and expensive amendment passed by the Labor Party and the Democrats as part of the recent electoral Bill to send a brochure to every candidate in the next Federal election and to every household in this country has the potential to produce the same result.

The amendment as passed when guillotined through this place last week had two major flaws: the candidates would not be known until nominations closed; and the Electoral Commission would then have a maximum of 20 days to receive photographs, CVs and policy statements, incorporate them in a leaflet and distribute them throughout Australia. It is inevitable that in many electorates there will be a plethora of candidates for a variety of reasons. For instance, local business may see merit in nominating. For the cost of the nomination fee they may have their brochure distributed, courtesy of the taxpayer, to every household. Political parties will almost certainly run multiple independents with bizarre policy statements simply to pick up a few preferences which could be vital in a marginal seat.

What concerns me about this is that it has the potential to throw the whole electoral system in Australia into disarray. I fear that what we saw in the ACT election could be extended Australia-wide. This will not do anything to enhance the already low opinion that the electorate has of the Parliament of this country. Perhaps that was an intended consequence of a Labor Government. It seems to me, however, to be yet another example of the actions of an incompetent, tired and stupid government.

Some of the recommendations of a report on the ACT by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters were implemented by the Parliament some months ago. The original legislation was amended to remove some of the distortions based on the experience of the last election. For example, the coalition insisted that cross preference voting be permitted rather than straight party list voting. It was also agreed that at the time of the next election a referendum would be held so that the people of the ACT could determine whether they wanted the Hare-Clarke system of proportional representation or single member electorates.

As a general rule, the coalition supports single member electorates. However, we recognise that the ACT is unique in that it is of pocket handkerchief size, it is the national capital and it is subject to the Burley Griffin plan. For that reason, elected members are required to take a global view of the ACT. The Labor Party, however, is not prepared to take a reasoned view but is driven by the political desire for a one-party government which would almost certainly be the outcome of having single member electorates in the ACT.

For example, I note the number of occasions on which Senator McMullan has spoken on this matter. So far, I have not seen one cogent reason in favour of the single member electorates. The Minister stated, and we agreed, that further legislation would be introduced to give control of the electoral system to the ACT Assembly after the election. This legislation honours that commitment.

I understand that in the committee stage of the Bill the Democrats will move to yet again amend the electoral system to the Senate type system. The Opposition will not agree to that amendment. We ask the question: why, at this stage, impose another system on the ACT which will be there just for one election? Frankly, the ACT has been mucked about too much already and the referendum will, hopefully, determine the future system in the ACT. Even though I have some sympathy with Senator Sowada's amendments, we just cannot see the justification for this less than two months before an election.

My own calculations indicate that the outcome of an election with modified d'Hondt with cross preferences would produce a result which should be almost identical to that achieved under the Senate system. The problem of wasted votes, which is often thrown at the modified d'Hondt, occurs under all systems of proportional representation. There is no perfect system. If there were, I guess we would all have it.

The major parties under a Senate system always distribute their preferences down the line in a way which would not benefit the other party. This can produce some strange results, such as the election of ex-Senator Robert Wood who, in New South Wales, received about 2 per cent of the primary vote and was elected. To argue that the voters of parties whose preferences helped him be elected intended to do so is nothing short of ludicrous. They would have been the most surprised.

The Opposition will be moving an amendment at the committee stage, which I hope has been circulated by now, which will enable the Electoral Commissioner to refuse the registration of the name of a political party which he considers is mischievous or is meant to deceive electors.

There is a loophole in the Act which prevents the Commissioner from being able to do so at present. There is no doubt that this has already occurred within the Australian Capital Territory. With the inevitable copycat flow-on, it can be expected to occur in other parts of Australia once the precedent has been set in the Australian Capital Territory. Regrettably, it is not possible in this Bill to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to cover this loophole. We suggest that the Government should seek to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to prevent that from occurring. If not, we ourselves will take advantage of a future opportunity to do so. I point out that the amendment which we will be proposing in the committee stage will not be retrospective.

Should the Electoral Commissioner rule in the future that an application for registration is mischievous or meant to deceive, the applicant under the existing provisions of the principal Act will have the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. When this amendment was moved in the House of Representatives, it was argued that there were problems in legally defining the meaning of the terms `frivolous' and `vexatious' and that it would be difficult to define what the criteria of `vexatious' and `frivolous' would be.

I have obtained an opinion on this matter. It has been pointed out to me that the terms `frivolous' and `vexatious' are longstanding terms at law. They are clearly understood by the courts and are used extensively in the Australian statutes. For example, the term `frivolous' occurs at least 62 times in Commonwealth statutes, and the term `vexatious' occurs at least 77 times. The terms are used in the Federal Court rules, the High Court rules and in a broad spectrum of legislation ranging from the Lands Acquisition Act, the Bankruptcy Act, companies and securities legislation, Defence Force discipline legislation, family law legislation, the Public Service Act, and the Merit Protection Review Agency.

The terms are therefore widely used and clearly understood. As to the concept of `mischief', this term is used at least three times in the Commonwealth statutes, more particularly in the Federal Court of Australia Act, the rules of the High Court, and the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court. I point that out because it makes nonsense of the arguments put in the House of Representatives that there were problems with legal definition.

The Opposition will not be opposing the second reading of the Bill as it fulfils a commitment by the Government and the Parliament to hand over control of the ACT electoral system to the Assembly. We will, however, as outlined earlier, be moving an amendment in the committee stage. I think everyone in this chamber will be pleased at long last to hand over the ACT electoral system to the ACT Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, a Bill with great ramifications for the future of fair elections in the Australian Capital Territory. We have been given this opportunity to legislate for justice and fairness for the electors of Canberra and surrounds and for an equitable system of elections. The question is: are we going to waste this opportunity? Legislating for the ACT raises issues of constitutional delicacy and fine judgment. Canberra is the national capital, but it is also the centre of a region which transcends the borders of the ACT, and it is a local community. Developing and applying legislation which acknowledges the threefold character of the ACT and strikes a proper balance between these elements is a complex and important task.

PARA.TAB: Amongst other things, the basic guts of this Bill seek to give the ACT Legislative Assembly the power to make its own electoral laws; that is, the power to determine which electoral system will be used to elect its government. Hopefully, as Senator Parer suggested, this Bill marks the last sorry chapter in what has been a litany of missed opportunities in the quest for a perfect electoral system in the Territory. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill and, in so doing, we will be moving our own amendments to help rectify a major problem in relation to the coming election, which the Government has not chosen to address in this legislation.

It was my intention to move an amendment to this Bill providing for a stricter disclosure regime within the ACT, but I am pleased to say that the passage of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill last week has made that unnecessary. The Australian Democrats have always supported full, open, fair and transparent disclosure of political contributions.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SELF-GOVERNMENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this legislation the Government has made one other move in the right direction: it is modifying the present nitpicking and inappropriate arrangements for Federal control of the number of Ministers the Territory has. This is not to say that the number of territorial Ministers should increase. Whether it is fair to say that the increase is the business of the Federal Parliament is not for us to determine, and this legislation in clause 5 vests that power and responsibility where it rightfully lies—with the ACT Government. Let it account to its own voters for the number of Ministers it chooses to have.

PARA.TAB: Canberra is, amongst other things, the national capital. Basic processes of democracy in that national capital, such as electoral fairness, are of concern to all Australia—ministerial headcounts are not. The Government should go on to make changes in relation to other matters called to attention over the years by the Australian Democrats, such as the ability of the Federal Executive to intervene to disallow laws passed by the territorial parliament. We must, as soon as possible, proceed to a situation in which, if laws made by the ACT legislature are to be disallowed, the disallowance is by this Parliament and not by the Federal Executive.

In passing, I give notice that I will be addressing the relationship between the two parliaments in a private members' Bill that I will be introducing early next year. However, it is right and proper, after several years of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, that finally devolving responsibility for the electoral system to the ACT Assembly is actually happening. The matter will be determined by the people of the ACT in a referendum on 15 February to determine which electoral system those voters would like to have. This Bill will ensure, one would hope, that the results of that referendum will be upheld in new electoral laws.

The matter which most urgently needs to be addressed is the voting system to be used in the ACT elections due to be held on 15 February next year. The d'Hondt electoral system is a scandal and has brought great discredit on this Parliament. As one of my predecessors, former Senator Jean Jenkins, said at the time it was first adopted, the Government hunted high and low—mainly low—to find the only truly objectionable form of proportional representation ever invented.

We have a chance to make amends. We have a chance to tell the long-suffering people of the ACT that the d'Hondt abomination looming ahead and threatening them on 15 February next will be lifted, and that while they choose the voting system to be used in the longer term, a three-quarters good system, the Senate system, with which they are all familiar, will be used on that day instead of d'Hondt. To that extent, I will be moving amendments to this Bill to down load the Senate system to replace the modified d'Hondt for the purposes of the coming election only.

It would be irresponsible not to make this change. Honourable senators should consider just a little of the enormous weight of opinion against d'Hondt. It is not just that d'Hondt is despised by the people of the ACT and laughed at by the media throughout Australia, it is also that the Australian Electoral Commission itself has consistently over more than three years advised against d'Hondt and has even on occasions been led to shed its normal Public Service-like indirectness and to speak about the system in blunt everyday Australian terms.
Way back in October or November 1988, the Electoral Commission was warning the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that if there is any suggestion made publicly that consolidated d'Hondt has the Commission's approval, we will be obliged to repudiate it.

In the years since then the Commission, as the nation's finest specialist in these complex matters, has honourably stuck to its guns. In May this year in a letter to Senator Bell, included in Hansard of 4 June, the Commission said:

It is a matter of concern to us that as things stand . . . (a) further election will be held under the `modified d'Hondt' system. The Commission has consistently taken the view that the modified d'Hondt system has been demonstrated both by theoretical analysis and practical experience to be fatally flawed, and that it should not be used again. . . . The defects of the system, which were documented in detail in our Submission to the Joint Standing Committee, include the following:
. It accepts certain votes as formal even when the markings placed on the ballot paper by the voter are ambiguous and contradictory.
. It distorts preferences expressed by the voters, attributes to voters preferences which they did not in fact express, and enhances the relative influence of some electors' votes for no good reason.

. It arbitrarily excludes from the count candidates who and parties which received less than 5.55% of the vote. The rationale for this exclusion process has never been clear. At the 1989 election, it caused the exclusion at the outset of the scrutiny of the candidate who polled the second highest number of first preference votes given for individual candidates rather than parties, and had a major influence on the current composition of the Assembly.
. It offers electors an inducement to vote "strategically", indicating preferences other than those they truly hold.
. It is literally impossible to find out from the public record what purpose is meant to be served by the last 3 stages of the scrutiny.
. The system is complex, is not based on any well-defined principles of electoral justice, and consequently is understood by hardly anyone at all.
. Because of the inordinate complexity of the system, the scrutiny takes an unacceptably long time to complete.
. The legitimacy of the Assembly has been diminished by the general recognition that its members were chosen using a defective voting system.

Taking all these factors into account, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters agreed with the Commission's view that the modified d'Hondt system was fundamentally defective and should be replaced. The Commission went on to say:
It should be emphasised that the defects of the modified d'Hondt system as set out above (would) not be corrected by the minor changes to the system contained in the Bill (then) before the Senate.
Analysis and criticism of d'Hondt has not just come from officials and specialists; it has also come from within the Government's own ranks. I will give one of my favourite examples.

PARA.TAB: In a Senate occasional lecture on 23 September this year, the Leader of the Government in the Senate made his view plain to a packed lunchtime audience. Senator Button was asked by emeritus Professor Arthur Burns whether he would, as a sort of farewell present to ACT electors on his retirement, introduce for the ACT's 1992 election the very same electoral system by which he, Senator Button, had been elected. Senator Button's reply offered some hope to the ACT community—alas, a false hope, it has turned out. The honourable senator said:

SPEECH.PARA: Disgraceful though the situation in the ACT may be—

I will repeat that: `disgraceful though the situation in the ACT may be', he was not going to give an answer on the spot but would certainly have a look at the issues raised. Senator Button has now managed to escape this Bill and has gone off to Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: How much more starkly thrown into relief is the need for change when we recall that the ACT Legislative Assembly, without dissent, resolved to request us to make the very change we are now debating. What could be clearer than the Assembly's message on behalf of the people of the ACT as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This Assembly calls on the Federal Parliament to discard the discredited d'Hondt and to provide the Senate electoral system for the 1992 ACT Legislative Assembly election as recommended by the Australian Electoral Commission to the Electoral Matters Committee of the Federal Parliament.

A copy of that resolution was sent to the President of the Senate on 2 December and was tabled in this place. If we have any commitment at all to open government and public processes, and to respecting the will of the elected representatives of the ACT Assembly, it would be unconscionable for us to disregard the Assembly's request. It is simply not a course which would in all honour be open to us.

PARA.TAB: Further, we need to remember that it was the slowness of action at the Federal level, and only at the Federal level, which made it necessary for this matter to be brought before us tonight. Clearly, in its proposals the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters envisaged that a referendum of the ACT people to select a replacement voting system would be completed in time for the outcome to be reflected in the voting system put in place for the 1992 ACT election. It would be nobody's fault but the Government's if this did not happen in good time. The Government should hang its head in shame.

The scandal is that, underlying all this, the Government is probably attempting to deceive the ACT electorate by pretending that d'Hondt has anything to do with the Hare-Clarke option in the referendum. I call on the Opposition to consider seriously its position in relation to my amendments, to consider the need to rid the ACT electorate of a totally discredited electoral system once and for all—a system that has been widely discredited from many corners, including the Australian Electoral Commission—and to consider its responsibility to uphold the will of its own party members in the ACT Assembly and support this move. Like the Government, the Opposition has also had the opportunity to respond to the request of the ACT Assembly and to remove the hated d'Hondt system.

Having regard to the positions announced previously by the Government with regard to this amendment and the nervousness displayed by the Opposition on this issue, I am not confident that this amendment will pass. Nevertheless, on behalf of the people of the ACT, I must ask them to support it. I commend the Bill and our amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 to support strongly the words of my colleague Senator Sowada. I do so, not in any sense to elaborate on them, but rather to reinforce them because the sentiments she has expressed have been before this place previously and they have been expressed by the community of the Australian Capital Territory and by the legislature of the Australian Capital Territory. For the life of me, I cannot understand why we are closing our ears to these sentiments.

PARA.TAB: The plain fact is that d'Hondt will never be used again; if it is used this time in the ACT it will never be used again. It seems that we are facing yet another missed opportunity. We have an opportunity to follow Senator Sowada's suggestions and amendments and to institute in the ACT something which is at least practical and desirable and will be effective in electing a proportional representation of the electors.

The arguments have been canvassed to some extent that it is all a bit late and a bit hard; that it might be too hard to understand or that it might not work. But all of those arguments have been addressed by the fact that Senator Sowada has done it. The preparations have been made; it is possible. In this amendment we have the vehicle to actually achieve our goal. To close our eyes and ears to that is to deny the people of the ACT the remedy for the despicable d'Hondt system which does not deliver what the ACT people desire to be delivered.

I say again: d'Hondt will not be used again. It has been discredited. Another dose of d'Hondt will not satisfy anybody in this Territory; the system will be discarded by whichever legislature is elected. It will be discarded for two reasons. One of those is that the options that are available under the referendum, which will run concurrently with that election, do not provide the opportunity to use d'Hondt.

The referendum does not provide that opportunity. In my questioning of the Minister at the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters which was dealing with this matter on a couple of occasions, I was quite pointed as to whether it was possible for a newly elected legislature of the ACT to ignore the outcome of the referendum. While it is unlikely, it remains possible. So there is the possibility that even though at the referendum one of the options of either single member electorates or a Hare-Clark electorate system would be endorsed by the people—that is only one of the options they have—it is possible, but as I said unlikely, that the newly elected legislature could ignore that and retain the d'Hondt system. Of course, it will not. We know this.

Of course, the newly elected legislature could ignore the referendum processes and, given the discredited nature of the d'Hondt system which would now have delivered two doses of elected members to the people of the ACT, there could well be a suggestion that because of the uselessness, the ineffectiveness and the unrepresentativeness of such an electoral system, the people who were elected were not truly representative and, therefore, the decisions they make could be challenged. That is the sort of question that could be avoided by recognising the reality, the wisdom, of what is proposed in the amendments that have been prepared by Senator Sowada.

I appeal to other senators to listen to the people of the electorate, to realise the distinct possibilities of even greater confusion during and after this next election, and to realise that this legislation offers the chance to deliver to the ACT people a system with which they are familiar, a system which is workable and a system which does not require the people to go through that most unpleasant experience of another election using this most unsatisfactory system. I commend the amendments which have been foreshadowed by Senator Sowada.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we are here tonight discussing the Australian Capital Territory and its electoral system is that the Government has brought forward a Bill entitled the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, a Bill in which the Government is putting into effect its commitment to hand over to the ACT legislature responsibility for its electoral system in the future and, in addition, to remove the requirement for the ACT to obtain the Federal Treasurer's approval before making certain guarantees. That does not seem to have attracted much attention at all, but the electoral system continues to excite interest all around the place.

PARA.TAB: We were discussing similar matters in June of this year when we put into effect the fact that the Government has agreed to fund a referendum to take place on the same day as the election next year, namely 15 February. At that time the electoral system itself was capable of being discussed and the Senate left the system as it was, with the d'Hondt system somewhat modified. People have been incredibly rude about the d'Hondt system. It seems to work in other places and I agree that it would be hard to make out a good case for it in this Territory because it has been significantly discredited by a number of people.

However, we at least had a system where we could vote—no electoral system is perfect—and it did provide a result, one that some were not entirely happy with. I fail to see what a Senate type system would do that would be markedly different. If there are to be 117 candidates in an electorate the size of the ACT, a Senate type vote would take just about as long to count.

There was a lot of criticism of the count, the length of time that it took, the nature of the system and the number of parties that stood. Certainly, some of the names of the parties were absolutely ludicrous. Surely, in a democracy, it is better to have a number of people wanting to take part and to be a part of the election than to have none. I find it remarkable that people will be critical of the system because a lot of people wanted to participate. It ought to be the essence of democracy that people wish to participate and feel that they have something to offer.

I have to concede that a ballot-paper a metre wide was somewhat daunting, but it was fairly clear. I believe that most citizens in the ACT voted in the way they intended to vote on that day the year before last. As I said, a Senate vote also takes quite a long time to count.

Returning to the question of the referendum, Senator Bell referred to the fact that there is nothing in this legislation which requires the implementation of the referendum. That did surprise me. I find it quite extraordinary. The Commonwealth has gone to the trouble to hold a referendum and to pay for it, but it then seems to say that it does not matter much what happens after that. I would have thought the obvious thing to do was for the Commonwealth to hold the referendum, to enact the consequences of it and then hand the system over to the ACT. But that is not what is to happen. The Commonwealth does not even seem to be concerned about saying that the result of the referendum shall be implemented by the ACT Government. It could well be that we have the result of the referendum and a different group elected who are not disposed to implement it. If that happens, I think it would be extremely unfortunate. It would add nothing to the regard in which politicians are held in this country. I certainly hope that it will not be the case.

This incredible suggestion tonight, 12 December—when the election is just two months away on 15 February—that we should put into effect yet another voting system from that which has operated in the ACT is quite extraordinary. We have had the d'Hondt system once and we are going to have it again. We are having a referendum on the same day to choose between the Hare-Clark system and single member electorates, yet just two months before that election another idea comes up for a different voting system—one that is not going to be on the ballot-paper for the referendum on 15 February.

If somebody were trying to urge a change to ensure that one of those two systems was used on 15 February, one could at least understand that there might be some logic to it. But to suggest now that we embark upon yet a fourth system, a one-off, to be used only once—in February—would make the Commonwealth Government look absurd. I cannot believe that is a rational solution to what seems to be a difficult problem for some people.

The d'Hondt system has its defects; the Senate system has its defects; the Hare-Clark system has its defects; and single member electorates certainly can be challenged as well. There is no perfect electoral system. Given that it is set that the election in February will be based on the d'Hondt system, which I recognise will probably not happen again, I expect the referendum result to be put into effect. If the suggestion had come up even in June that we should have a different system, it could have been debated and looked at. But if a referendum is to be held for either Hare-Clark or single member electorates, then things should at least be left the way they are for the present if this system is not to be put onto the referendum ballot as well. The Senate system is not one of the options for the referendum and it should not be introduced at this time.

It would be possible to go on and talk at some length about this and the history of it. It is all well documented. I do not believe there is much more that needs to be said at this stage. I support the amendment moved by the Opposition which Senator Parer referred to in his speech earlier this evening. I certainly will not be supporting the amendments that have been put forward by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points that I wish to put on the record about the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill. This piece of legislation, as is possible in this place now, was referred to the appropriate Senate Standing Committee which, in this case, was the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts covering, as it does, the Territories. At very short notice, the Committee was asked to deal with the Bill as proposed. It was at such short notice that the Committee agreed to proceed to examine the legislation even though we were unable to organise for a Minister to be present—and I might say that we made considerable efforts to do that. There was a tight time constraint on the Committee to report back to this place.

PARA.TAB: I will take advice or correction from you, Mr Deputy President, but my understanding is that, if a Bill is referred to a committee, that committee's report to the Senate effectively replaces the deliberations in this place on the Bill. That is the purpose of the examination of the Bill by a committee and the committee's report to this place.

I know it is perfectly possible for the Senate or senators to change their minds, but I would like to put on the record what an absolute mockery of the system it is that at very short notice a committee is required to examine a Bill. Having done so and reported to this place, I do not know what arrangements were made earlier—I was unable to catch that—to overturn the report from the Committee by way of deliberations. The Bill was referred to our Committee prior to the completion of the second reading stage and that may be, in fact, the exception to the usual procedure in this place, and why a slightly different process has been proceeded with in this case.

The hearings on that morning allowed for a curious contribution—that might be the kindest way to describe it—from a Mr Mackerras, but it was certainly not something that gave the Committee much pause or contributed to the deliberations on the Bill.

The only other point I wish to make is that, when Senator Sowada requested that the Committee examine the Bill, as I recollect—and I will stand corrected—I do not believe that proposals for a Senate-type election were even mooted at that time. In some ways it is very difficult for the Senate—which has referred a Bill to a committee to canvass those sorts of options—to find that this was done under such time constraints. In trying to meet those needs, we did the best we could. I think we did all that was required of us. We did that thoughtfully. We certainly took the time of officers from the Department and officers from the Australian Electoral Commission. We proceeded properly, despite the difficulties of not having a Minister present. By agreement within the Committee to proceed, we examined the legislation. We heard evidence, principally from one witness. No hard case was made to amend, or recommend any amendment to, the Bill and a proposal for a Senate-type election was not floated at that time.

As the Chair of that Committee, I certainly made it my business to check that Opposition senators who had had an interest in this piece of legislation when it was previously very extensively canvassed were given the opportunity to come to that Committee if they wanted to. I was advised that both the timing and the extensive canvassing of the issue previously meant that there was no significant desire on the part of Opposition senators to do that.

I appreciate that Senator Sowada is new to this place and I do not mean any criticism of her or any individual senator. I do think, though, that the process needs to be examined. In particular, if we are to have amendments following a committee's deliberation of a Bill, that ought to be taken into consideration by those people whose responsibility it is to see that the processes of referral of legislation to committees are properly managed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution just made by Senator Crowley is not the only reason I rise to speak on this measure, but it is an additional reason. Frankly, I take exception to what she has said. I will retain my right as a member of the Senate to move amendments to legislation whether or not those amendments have been submitted to a committee. It is not possible, and Senator Crowley knows it, for each of us always to be in attendance at each committee hearing. The committee she was talking about spent maybe a couple of hours on the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill. I was on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which spent months on this matter. It was our deliberate intention that never again would the modified d'Hondt system be used in the ACT. That intention has been frustrated.

PARA.TAB: We came up with a recommendation that there should be a referendum in the ACT and that two propositions should be put—the Hare-Clark system, and single member constituencies. I personally supported the introduction of the Hare-Clark system. But to suggest that just because this particular measure has to go to a committee, we should not examine and vote upon Senator Sowada's amendments on their merits is not proper and nor does it in my view have regard to the history of this matter. The most recent history of the matter is that the ACT Legislative Assembly wrote to the President and suggested that we exercise our power as a Federal Parliament to ensure that a system other than the d'Hondt system be used. The Assembly called upon us to discard the d'Hondt system and introduce the Senate electoral system. That was a decision of the Legislative Assembly of the Australian Capital Territory, made by the elected representatives of the people of the Territory.

I believe that we have to look at it this way: we might say that members of the Assembly have been elected on the modified d'Hondt system, it is a lousy system and therefore they are lousy representatives. I do not think that follows. I think we ought to have regard to the views of the people who are likely to be candidates at the next election. If this proposal were adopted by the ACT Legislative Assembly, we should have regard to it. I do not suggest we should adopt everything that the Assembly recommends, quite the contrary, but I do suggest it is quite proper for us to consider the amendments to the Bill proposed by Senator Sowada which give effect to that express view of the Assembly. As well, it was the very deliberate intention of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters that the modified d'Hondt system should go. I will not canvass all of the matters that came before us, because most honourable senators would be aware of them, but one thing is for sure: we do not want to see the modified d'Hondt system used again in the ACT.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was unanimous.

—Yes, that was the unanimous view of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Tonight we have the opportunity to ensure that that unanimous view of the Committee is adopted for at least the ACT election. Why do we not accept Senator Sowada's proposal for the 1992 election in the ACT? There is nothing to prevent the proposal being put forward by referendum, as was proposed by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, at that election. That referendum can go ahead—what happens to it afterwards is anybody's guess. Let us at least give this proposal a chance on this occasion; if we do not, we will have the foul-ups which resulted in the use of the modified d'Hondt system at the last Legislative Assembly election in the ACT. We will have egg on our faces. The only people who will not have egg on their faces will be the ones who vote for the proposal which is being put forward by Senator Sowada.

PARA.TAB: I reject the suggestion that accepting this proposal will frustrate what has been proposed by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. It will not. That referendum can clearly go ahead; there is nothing to stop it. This proposal also accepts the unanimous view of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters that the modified d'Hondt system should never be used again in the ACT, with its accompanying uncertainty and in-built electoral injustices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment briefly on the remarks made by Senator Crowley earlier. I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, chaired by Senator Crowley. I must say that the reference of Bills process that took place a couple of weeks ago in relation to the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 was of great concern to me.

PARA.TAB: We received notice of the meeting to reconsider the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill some 12 hours—correct me if I am wrong—prior to the meeting. We were advised at 9.30 p.m. on a Thursday of a meeting on the Friday morning. Of course, most honourable senators find out during the week whether they will be required to take part in committee proceedings on a Friday; if they are not, and if they come from a State such as Tasmania, Western Australia or Queensland, they more often than not make appointments in their electorate, be they with their constituents, with their wife and children or with their garden.

I make the point that the way the Bill was referred to members of the Committee was a matter of concern. I had certainly made previous arrangements for that day. It is not satisfactory to have 12-hours notice of a committee meeting to consider a matter. I was contacted by Malcolm Mackerras, who I recognise in the gallery tonight. I know that this is a matter about which Malcolm and many other Territorians are very concerned. However, if one is to consider these sorts of matters properly, one should be given significant notice.

I want to make a point about the Democrats' interesting principles and interesting conflicts of principles in relation to the reference of Bills to committees. Last Thursday Democrat senators were given the opportunity—and I exclude Senator Sowada—to allow the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill to be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. All of those senators who were involved in the long and vigorous debate on that matter last week knew that there were very many complex matters relating to that legislation that could have benefited from due consideration by the Senate Standing Committee. But because of the so-called urgency surrounding that Bill, the Democrats decided that it would not be appropriate to refer it.

I remind the Senate that the Bill we are currently debating relates to an election which will be held in February 1992. So, of course this Bill is urgent and of course it should be given proper consideration. The legislation we were dealing with last week refers to every State, Federal and local government election which will be held around Australia for the foreseeable future until the Hewson government is elected and rescinds this political advertising ban farce. So of course this legislation is urgent. The reference of that Bill to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was a matter that did not need to be dealt with urgently. The only urgency was that the Labor Party—with the assistance of the Democrats—wanted to make sure that it banned political advertising as quickly as it could for its own political benefit.

I will conclude my remarks on the Bill now before us by referring to the Democrats' hypocrisy in supporting at short notice the reference of this Bill to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts but then not allowing the Committee enough time to consider the issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a deadline for reporting to the Parliament.

—The matter which we dealt with last week at great length was not urgent and could have easily been referred to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. We could have given it the consideration that such a piece of broad-reaching legislation, which will affect every local, State and Federal election across this nation for the foreseeable political future, deserves.

PARA.TAB: I reinforce and support the comments made by Senator Crowley regarding the reference of Bills process that was used in relation to this legislation. The Democrats would have had more success in pushing forward their amendments and their point of view—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sowada voted against that.
—I know she did; I made that exclusion.
—She has been entirely consistent.

—Senator Sowada has been entirely consistent. The remainder of the Democrats—the Democrats I referred to earlier in the week as the `fellows of the repressive Australian undemocratic', that is, FRAUD `party'—are the ones who are being inconsistent. I further condemn them for that action. I suggest to them that if they wanted to be consistent they would refer the political advertising bans legislation to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. If they were to be consistent in the application of their principles and their use of the processes of this Senate, they would end up with a lot more support from honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. I conclude my remarks on that note.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks that we have just heard are, of course, absolutely ridiculous and wide of the mark. The principles which underlay the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, which was passed last week, and the principles which underlay the extensive amendments moved by my colleague Senator Sowada are precisely the same. They are to democratise the processes of election. One is not surprised that the Opposition is smarting under the inability to get its rich mates to donate large amounts of money so that they can buy its deceptive advertising.

PARA.TAB: The appropriate mechanisms have been put in place by which the amount of time available for that very powerful medium will be precisely determined on democratic lines. It is appropriate that the people who will represent the ACT or anywhere else should be determined on precisely the same democratic lines.

The processes which underlie the d'Hondt system necessarily disenfranchise quite a significant number of voters. The proposals which my colleague Senator Sowada has put forward by way of amendment—as with the election of senators in this chamber—are done on precisely democratic lines in which every vote counts and every person is elected according to the proportion of the vote which he receives in the election. So for Senator Campbell to try to claim that there was any discontinuity between the attitudes which we adopted the other evening and the attitudes which underlie the amendments being put by Senator Sowada tonight is, of course, to totally misread the situation, but we are not surprised because the Opposition is not really driven by democracy at all; the Opposition is simply driven by its desire for power at any cost, irrespective of what it means in terms of protecting the democratic institutions of this country.

I was pleased to hear Senator Harradine tonight defending the amendment moved by Senator Sowada. Of course, the honourable senator comes from the State in which this election process was first put in place, and with even more democracy, I might say, than obtains even in the Senate. I totally dissociate the Democrats from the sorts of quite stupid, ill-informed and self-interested remarks which we have heard from the Opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very significant day for the Australian Capital Territory in so far as its democracy is concerned. I understand that earlier today—I rely only on radio reports—the High Court, the highest tribunal in this nation so far as constitutional issues are concerned, determined that the transfer of self-governing power to the ACT House of Assembly was indeed well based in our constitutional arrangements in this Commonwealth of Australia. I think it is very important that that assurance to the democratic processes in the Australian Capital Territory has been given by, as I say, the repository of the highest judicial power of the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The Senate this evening is discussing the further refinement of the transfer of self-governing powers to the Australian Capital Territory, in that the Bill itself is designed to implement our decision to pass to the Australian Capital Territory the power to control its electoral system. That would seem to be a very sound extension and deepening of the bestowal on the Australian Capital Territory and its citizens of all the proper attributes of self-government, which of course is a matter of world-wide significance as peoples right around the world take control of their electoral systems and the democratic processes and the ability to participate and exercise power as far as those in government are concerned.

This particular description by various contributors to the debate of the modified d'Hondt system probably has some validity when they say that it has defects, defects which have led to ridicule, in some instances, of the present composition of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. Nevertheless, there is very clear intent to enable the people of the Australian Capital Territory, the citizens of this jurisdiction, to determine for themselves which of two systems they would wish to see as the basis for future elections in the Territory, whether it be a single-member electorate system based on the House of Representatives model or the Hare-Clark system, with which Senator Harradine and I are of course extremely familiar. If I may express a personal preference, I would encourage ACT voters to look to the Hare-Clark system as a very effective model for them to advance their system of democracy here in the Territory, though I understand that some members of the Labor Party in the Territory take a different view.

I believe it is important that the people of the Australian Capital Territory make that determination by referendum on 15 February. Certainly at this very late stage, only eight weeks from the election, the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia should refrain from yet again imposing another electoral system on the people of the ACT.

Senator Sowada has foreshadowed that she will put an alternative proposition by way of moving an amendment to provide for the election on 15 February to be conducted in accordance with the Senate process of election. I did not quite understand everything that Senator Sowada was saying. She retreated into quite technical language. At one stage she said that she praised the use of blunt, everyday language, but then went on to say something about down-loading the Senate system onto the ACT. I am afraid that she lost me there. I do not regard that as blunt, everyday language, at least not for somebody of my technological ignorance.

The fundamental principle to be observed is that on 15 February the people of the ACT will have the opportunity to make a choice between two systems, and that choice has been recommended by the unanimous decision of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I believe that is the way things should go on 15 February. It would be quite ridiculous to suggest that in this chamber on 12 December we should bring about a situation where on 15 February a completely different electoral system would be imposed on the ACT.

One criticism of the modified d'Hondt system, which in my observation as a resident, though not a citizen of the Territory, has some weight, is that the results of the last election engendered a lack of stability. I think that we need stability and predicability in the lead-up to the 15 February election. People are expecting the modified d'Hondt system to be employed. I believe that the political system here sorely requires stability in the several weeks that lie ahead as candidates conduct campaigns and the people move to elect their representatives. There are other features of the Bill which enable me to commend it wholeheartedly to the chamber, and I do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister a question. Clause 2(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (2), this Act commences on the day on which it receives the Royal Assent'.
Clause 2(2) states:
Sections 4, 7, 8, 9 and 11 commence immediately after polling day for the second general election of members of the Legislative Assembly for the Australian Capital Territory.
I ask: what is the reason for that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that proposed new sections 4, 7, 8, 9 and 11 are those sections which, when operational, will effectively transfer the power in relation to the devising of the electoral system to the House of Assembly in the ACT; in other words, it is meant to confer that power on the House of Assembly as constituted after the election to be held on 15 February.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Giles)—Senator Parer, do you wish to move the Opposition amendment? The intention is that all the Democrats' amendments will be moved together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 11, page 4, insert the following clause:
"11A. Section 13 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following subsection:

`(3) The Electoral Commission shall refuse an application for the registration of a political party if, in its opinion, the name of the party or the abbreviation of its name that it wishes to be able to use for the purposes of this Act:
(a)is frivolous or vexatious; or
(b)is mischievous or is likely to deceive, mislead or confuse.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: I have already canvassed the background to the amendment in my speech in the second reading debate, so I will not go over it in great detail again. It follows on from some of the remarks made by Senator Crowley about why, when a Bill is referred to a committee, subsequently there may be some amendments. In this instance, the reason for this amendment came after the Bill had been referred to the Committee, when an individual in the ACT, running for election, decided to name his political party in a way that I believe would be seen to deceive, mislead or confuse electors.

PARA.TAB: This became quite a dilemma for us. We felt that it should be corrected, there was a loophole in the Act and yet we could not be seen to be doing something that was retrospective. My great concern is that, this having happened in the ACT, because of the copycat effects we find in any society, it is almost inevitable that we will see it happen in other parts of Australia. I would like to see the Government at some stage change the Commonwealth Electoral Act to close this loophole. I believe a record number of objections were placed with the Electoral Commissioner over the name of this political party, yet the Commissioner could not under the Act prevent the party being registered.

In the House of Representatives, quite fallaciously, the argument was put that words such as `frivolous', `vexatious' and `mischievous' could not be legally defined. I think I showed in my speech in the second reading debate that that was quite untrue. Where the Government got that information from I do not know, because I gave it all the examples in the world where those words had been used in various statutes within the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this amendment moved by the Opposition. Like the Opposition and like the ACT community, I am most disturbed by the wilful and opportunistic actions of Mr Craig Duby in seeking to register the so-called Hare-Clark Independence Party, which is clearly an attempt to confuse voters. In supporting the Opposition's amendment, I would have preferred it to go further to have expressly defined the limits which ought to exist on the rights of a party if it registers its name and it is intended to be confused with an option being put in a referendum held concurrently with an election. That is perhaps a matter which should be taken up by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to be investigated in calmer times.

PARA.TAB: Vexatious party names are not alien to the ACT system. Under the Commonwealth Electoral Act a number of party names have been registered which have caused a great deal of concern to a number of parties in this place. I refer honourable senators to the Australian Ethnic Democrats, a party name that was registered via the Commission about two years ago; and the Rex Connor (Snr) Labor Party, a party name registered in my own State of New South Wales, which caused a great deal of heartburn to the Labor Party in Sussex Street.

In fact, I think the Labor Party attempted to have that issue determined by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and was unsuccessful in having that party name overturned. With respect to the Australian Ethnic Democrats, we were also unsuccessful in our appeal to the Commission to have that party name overturned.

The issue of vexatious party names does need to be addressed and the Democrats would certainly support any amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which cleared up this issue in respect of Federal elections. I think the Australian Electoral Commission could exercise a little more discretion in its acceptance of party names, and a little more judgment as to what is acceptable under the Act and not simply refer to it as a political issue. This amendment has the full support of the Australian Democrats. We would not support any retrospective notion of deregistering the vexatious party that has caused so much concern in this election, given our general opposition to the principle of retrospectivity, but we are happy to support the amendment moved by the Opposition to ensure that this does not happen again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects this amendment. There are great dangers associated with it. It would vest in the Electoral Commission a very wide discretion which would require it to exercise very subjective judgment as to whether a particular name or label to be attached to a political group was, in the terms of the amendment, mischievous, vexatious or likely to deceive, mislead or confuse. It seems to me that the amendment would vest in a non-elected, admittedly independent, group of officials of high integrity, no doubt, a terrible burden in the run-up to an election in the democratic system, to determine where the borderline lay between these criteria that are being put forward as frivolous, vexatious or mischievous, or likely to deceive, mislead or confuse.

PARA.TAB: I am told that there was consideration of this years ago by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. It considered a Bill which proposed to prohibit, amongst other things, party names which were offensive, obscene or frivolous. I understand that that Committee rejected all those grounds except obscenity. Obscenity was adopted by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Obscene' is in the Electoral Act.

—That is exactly what I have said. `Obscene' was accepted but `offensive' or `frivolous' did not find favour in the deliberations of that Committee. Senator Harradine would probably remember who was on it. I think it included Ralph Hunt, Peter Rae and Sir John Carrick. It was a very distinguished committee. I implore the Democrats to think again about what sort of power they are vesting in the Electoral Commission in a way which would enable it to circumscribe the rights of citizens to band together under a particular name.
—There is a right of appeal.

—Senator Parer has come to my next point by interjecting, `There is a right of appeal'. That would create a situation in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would find itself dealing with many appeals against a disqualifying power being exercised by the Electoral Commission.
—I hope there are not too many.

—Senator Parer does not know how many there will be, but he will certainly find any group of citizens who are offended or find that they cannot operate under the name that they would wish to in the electorate appealing to the AAT for a review of the decision of the Commission on whether to register them. It is such a very basic matter.
—It is going to flow on.
—It is so subjective. What one person finds vexatious, likely to vex or upset—I do not quite know the definition—
—We would never challenge the Australian Labor Party for being labour.

—That has been tried. There were attempts to ask the Electoral Commission not to permit the name `Democratic Labor Party' to be used, possibly on the grounds that it was not really democratic or possibly on the grounds it was not really labour, in the same way that the National Party might not be regarded as truly national or the Australian Democrats might not be regarded as really deserving that title. As for the Liberals, masquerading under a title which has so much honour attached to it in the English sense, I find that something that I would immediately take to the Electoral Commission if this provision were available to allow me to challenge that.

PARA.TAB: The Committee should think very seriously as to whether it will put in the hands of the Commission the task of deciding whether a particular label or name attached to a political group is likely to vex. Would it vex citizens, other citizens, some citizens, members of the Commission or the reasonable voter? How does one judge this? There is the question of the term `mischievous'. According to the Oxford dictionary, `mischievous' means having harmful effects. How does one judge whether a particular name has a harmful effect? It is almost incapable of application in this area.

As I say, I believe that the disqualification of names which are likely to deceive, mislead or confuse would also be highly uncertain. The Electoral Commission advises that at the moment the provisions relating to confusion have a very precise focus. Confusion must be with the name of a parliamentary party or registered political party.

On the other hand, the proposed provisions would have no position in their operation. Any name which gave rise to a likelihood of any form of confusion would be prohibited. As I say, just in interjection and in somewhat light-hearted banter, it nevertheless could be claimed, as it was claimed concerning the Democratic Labor Party, that the name is likely to deceive, mislead or confuse. I believe that, as I say, we already have some political history of an attempt to use such a claim to disqualify a major political group which was then formed within the Australian political scene.

Quite apart from the inherent difficulty of finding precision enough in such an important matter as refusing registration to a group of Australians who wish to put themselves forward to the electors, I also ask honourable senators to think about the way in which appeals to the AAT would operate. They are really casting an impossible burden on the Commission and the AAT in a way which will not in the end serve our democratic processes and which will allow somebody, either the Commission or AAT members, to determine the form of posture in name by which certain groups of Australian citizens present themselves to electors for their consideration during an election campaign. That is a very dangerous power to put into the hands of unelected officials. I certainly urge the Committee to reject this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to respond to Senator Tate. I am no legal man but Senator Tate is. At the risk of being repetitive, I indicated in my speech at the second reading stage that I had sought some views on these two words, `frivolous' and `vexation', because exactly the same sort of argument was used in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is—and I am sure Senator Tate, being of distinguished legal background, would know—that those two words are longstanding terms in the law. They are clearly understood by the courts and they are used extensively in Australian statutes. During my speech on the second reading I gave the example that the term `frivolous' occurs at least 62 times in Commonwealth statutes and the term `vexatious' occurs at least 77 times. So how the Government can take the point of view it has taken is beyond me. I have some great difficulties with it.

It is a decision that has to be made by the reasonable people in the Australian Electoral Commission, who are independent. What concerns me is that the reason this came about is patently obvious. I think Senator Sowada mentioned that perhaps the language could be broadened a bit; but I thought it was broad enough to cover those sorts of problems, whether they related to a referendum or even just to election campaigns. I did not hook it in directly to referendums because I believed it would have limited it.

I thought it was warranted to respond to Senator Tate in relation to this matter. This is the sort of thing—I know there have been examples in the past—which could spread into the Federal scene. It is something we have seen to a limited degree. Senator Tate talked about the Democratic Labor Party. I am sure it would have argued at the time that it was the true Labor Party and that those opposite were the renegades. It argued that very strongly. In fact, in some States I understand that it kept the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The electorate should decide that, not some Commission.

—That is right, but that was a family dispute which turned into a divorce, as I understand it. I believe this is an important matter and, as I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate, I think it is something the Government should think about very seriously for the Commonwealth Electoral Act before it happens again.

—I would like to reinforce what Senator Parer has said. I remind Senator Tate that nearly every statute in every State talks about not accepting pleadings which are frivolous and vexatious and not accepting statements of claim which are frivolous and vexatious. Senator Tate will know that they have been adjudicated upon by courts in every State for as long as the British justice system has been here. It has been determined, and what Senator Parer says is exactly correct.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that we are very familiar with such terms as `the vexatious litigant'. The terms `frivolous' and `vexatious' do occur in many statutes. Of course, these terms are used in the practice of the courts, but I cannot think of an instance where they are not related to behaviour. They are designed to describe a form of behaviour which vexes the court or other persons, or a form of behaviour which is trivial or frivolous. They are not used in relation to names. The honourable senator is saying that a name can somehow be characterised as `vexatious' or `frivolous' and, therefore, ought to lead to a group of Australians who are citizens and who have a perfect right to band together in order to present themselves to the electorate being unable to do so under that name. That is where there is no line of precedent or assistance which would help either the Commission or the AAT to exercise this very great burden which the Opposition wants to put upon them.

PARA.TAB: It is for that reason I believe the Committee should reject those particular words. This was the case with a joint select committee which examined this matter and thought that, yes, obscenity had a meaning which could be attached to a name or a title, and that was OK. A joint select committee of this Parliament has already looked at this matter. I plead with the Democrats not to accept this amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
