SPEECH.PARA: I have already said quite a deal about these amendments in my speech in the second reading debate and I do not propose to repeat that. However, at this point I would like to pay tribute to those who drafted what turned out to be a most complicated series of amendments to this Australian Capital Territory Self-Government Legislation Amendment Bill. I would just like to respond to Senator Reid's comment that we are proposing a new system. We are not proposing a new system; we are proposing a system that is well-known not only to voters of the ACT but to voters all around Australia and which has been around for a very great deal of time. Everyone understands how it works; it is not a new suggestion.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of placing this system into the ACT for this election, my colleague Senator Robert Bell has informed me that he attempted to do this in June this year. It was rejected on that occasion when the Senate had plenty of time before the election to move amendments and to clear up what to everybody is quite plainly a most iniquitous and unfair electoral system.

In relation to some of the remarks made at the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on this Bill, I was the one who referred the Bill to the Standing Committee, chaired by Senator Crowley. The timeframe given to us under the Standing Orders of the Senate was very tight and there was only one day on which a hearing could be held before the date to report to the Senate. This was something that was discussed at the Committee hearing that I attended. I do agree with Senator Campbell that it was a very tight time schedule. A number of honourable senators could not attend. It was suggested at the Committee hearing that perhaps the procedures need to be adjusted to ensure that adequate time is provided for notification of Bills to committees so that sufficient time can be set aside for hearings and reporting. I put it to the Committee that that is something that needs to happen arising out of this particular event.

In relation to Senator Crowley's remarks that we did not raise the issue of downloading the Senate style system into this Bill at that hearing, that is true, we did not. The Bill itself dealt with the so-called patriation of the system to the ACT and not with this issue specifically. But I make the point that my amendments were drafted upon receipt of notification of the motion moved by the ACT Legislative Assembly on 21 November this year which, as I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate stage, called on the Federal Parliament to enact the Senate electoral system for the 1992 election.

When we discussed this Bill at the Committee hearing we did not have any idea that this motion had been passed by the Assembly and, as I said, written notification of this was provided to me some several days after the Committee hearing. It was most unfortunate that we did not have an opportunity at the Committee hearing to discuss the wider issues that had been raised by the ACT Assembly. I make the point again that my amendments to this Bill tonight are a direct response to the letter and the resolution of the Assembly and seeks to enact the will of the people as expressed by the Assembly.

I make a couple of remarks in relation to the amendments. Amendment No. 2 in relation to proposed new section 20 on page 1 of the circulated amendments essentially seeks to provide that the integrity of the Senate proportional representation system will be maintained and cannot be changed by regulation. The amendment on page 3 of the circulated amendments relating to paragraph 239(1)(b) provides for optional preferential voting to ensure that the minimum number of squares numbered is one less than the number of members to be elected at the election. Given that there were so many candidates at the last election—some 117 candidates, I understand—it would of course be very difficult for us to be suggesting to the voters of the ACT that they number all squares below the line, as is currently the case with Senate elections.

With those remarks, I simply commend these amendments to the Committee. As I said, I have already made extensive reference to them in my speech at the second reading stage. I remind the Committee once again that, in moving these amendments, I am simply acting on behalf of the ACT Legislative Assembly which has requested this Parliament, by way of letter to the President, that this be done. I leave it with the members of the Government and the Opposition to go back to their members, their Party members and their own parliamentary representatives in the ACT, to explain why they will not support my amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech on the second reading I gave the reasons why we would not be supporting the Democrats in their amendments. As I indicated, I did have some sympathy with them, but the Opposition will not support them. I would like to make a quick observation, which is somewhat quaint from the Democrats' point of view. I think the Democrats were the first cab off the rank to say that the ACT Assembly cannot be trusted and that a referendum is needed to determine the electoral system. Having done all that, they come in here and say, `Guess what, the ACT Assembly has passed a resolution of which you should take note'. I just thought I would draw the Senate's attention to that little anomaly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if the remark just passed were true, Senator Parer is saying that the d'Hondt system is fully democratic, that the ACT Assembly elected under that system is truly representative and that that body has made that request. The reverse argument has just as much weight.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the ultimate argument ought to be that if we truly believe in democracy the question of the form of election to the Legislative Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory should be determined by the citizens of this Territory. Senator Sowada, even in her short time here, is showing those authoritarian tendencies that sometimes break through in the Australian Democrats where they want to impose their view as to what would be a good voting system on the people of the Territory. As has been said, there are Cleopatric tendencies coming through, which no doubt come from her study of ancient Egypt.

PARA.TAB: We believe that on 15 February the people of the Territory ought to make a determination as to the electoral system they wish to see operating. It is not for this Parliament to impose yet again another system on them for the election on 15 February. I believe that the series of amendments put forward by Senator Sowada should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I hearing the Minister correctly in that the Government has two major reasons for opposing this amendment? The Minister mentioned the Australian Democrats, but if this were carried in this chamber and in the other place as well it would be the Australian Parliament. Is the first reason for opposing this amendment that the Commonwealth Parliament should not impose an electoral system upon the people in the Australian Capital Territory? Is the second reason that the people of the Australian Capital Territory should have the opportunity to vote in a referendum on the type of electoral system they desire? Are those the two major reasons for the Government opposing this amendment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to put the reasons for opposing the amendment in very short form, having dealt with the arguments at somewhat greater length in my response to the second reading debate. I believe that my remarks as to why this Parliament should not impose another electoral system on the ACT have to be seen in the context of the next eight weeks. In other words, in my more extended remarks in the second reading response, I was relating it to the fact that it is now 12 December and the election is to be held on 15 February. It would be quite inimical to the stability of the political system in the Australian Capital Territory for this Parliament to now impose a different system for the elections to be held on 15 February.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the people making a choice, I do not know that I was putting it as an argument; I was simply remarking that I think it is good democratic practice that the people of the Territory should have a choice on February 15 as to the future conduct of elections. I believe that the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters unanimously agreed that the people of the ACT should decide this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow that through to its logical conclusion. I am a member of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters and I know what happened there. I also know what occurred leading up to that recommendation. The Committee was principally concerned that the people of the Australian Capital Territory should never again have imposed on them the task of going through another modified d'Hondt election. The Minister would agree with me that Senator Sowada's amendment, if carried, would not prevent a referendum taking place.
—No, it wouldn't.
—The Minister says, `No, it would not'. So that possible reason for opposition to the amendment disappears. We come to the question of whether we are imposing another electoral system on the ACT.
—We are doing that anyway.

—As has been said, we are doing that. It is unanimously agreed that the system contained in Senator Sowada's amendment is far more preferable and is likely to represent the wishes of the electorate in a far more accurate fashion than the modified d'Hondt system which we have already imposed upon the ACT.
—You had the chance four months ago to do it under that Bill.
—It is important that we have a meeting of minds around the chamber. Surely the way to approach the problem is for us not to impose anything on the people of the ACT. We could provide in

SPEECH.PARA: clause 2—the commencement clause—that the ACT Legislative Assembly decide immediately on the electoral system for its elections. The Assembly would then be able to decide whether or not it wants to go ahead with the d'Hondt system for this next election.

PARA.TAB: The Assembly has unanimously said that it does not. It has unanimously said that it wants, presumably in the interim, the Senate system. Senator Sowada is trying to accommodate its wishes. Why should we be, as it were, continuing our imposition of the modified d'Hondt system on the electorate here? If the Minister is opposed to Senator Sowada's amendment, would he or the Government consider allowing the commencement of this Act to be from the day on which it receives the royal assent?

That proposal is reasonable. It is not going to prevent the referendum from taking place at the time of the next election. As the Minister said, today is a great day for the ACT. The High Court has upheld that the transfer of powers to the ACT Legislative Assembly is constitutional. Why not, on this very auspicious day, allow the people of the ACT, if they so choose, between now and the next election to adopt for that election the Senate voting system?

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Sowada was canvassing her amendments and speaking on the second reading debate the muttered excuses coming from those who were not prepared to consider the amendments seriously went along the lines of `it is too late', `there is not enough time', `it was not introduced early enough', `it should have been mentioned before' and `why haven't we seen this?'. None of those excuses hold up because the simple fact is that this matter has been canvassed over a period of many months, if not years. But whether such a suggestion about time is an excuse or not, it is not a reason for passing up this chance and ignoring the ACT legislature.

PARA.TAB: There are several reasons why we should refuse to deliver another dose of d'Hondt to the ACT. They have been well canvassed by Senator Harradine. I refer to the unanimous resolution of the ACT Assembly, and also to the unanimity that was reached in the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which again Senator Harradine explained very well to us. Matched to that unanimity, I defy anybody to stand in this place and identify for me an enthusiast, or even an apologist, for d'Hondt. Even Minister Simmons was not enthusiastic.

Senator Harradine remembers, I say with admiration, the historical perspective of this matter. I remember the recent past perspective, but enough of it. Getting on for a year and a half ago I remember waiting anxiously for Minister Simmons to deliver the format of the referendum and the style of the election which is to take place in February next year. The procrastination attached to the deliberations of the Minister frustrated me, and I know it frustrated those who wanted to see delivered to the ACT something other than d'Hondt.

The Minister himself was not enthusiastic about d'Hondt: he wanted to modify it, he wanted to de-modify it and he wanted to modify it in another way. There were several different versions. The on-again off-again proposals for the legislation went on throughout 1990 and now throughout 1991 we have had a litany of missed opportunities to accept something like the Senate system—opportunities which were distinctly canvassed and distinctly described in the letter from the Australian Electoral Commission which Senator Sowada referred to earlier.

Let us have no more nonsense about there not being enough time. Senator Harradine's proposal illustrates that the time remaining between now and the ACT election cannot be used as an excuse to ignore the propositions contained in Senator Sowada's amendments. I think people are scared away from the Senate system because it might actually work. The Senate system has worked to deliver senators such as Senator McMullan and Senator Reid to this place. The people of the ACT are familiar with the system; the people of the ACT obviously make good decisions when they are using it. If there is any criticism of the Senate system, it certainly has not reached the Democrats in the way that the criticisms of the d'Hondt system have.

I fail to see any reasons why the Senate system should not be implemented. The issue of time is a petty excuse; it does not hold up, because there has been sufficient time not only to see the merits of the Senate system, as it could be applied to the ACT, but to actually prepare the amendments. Senator Sowada has caused that to happen. The amendments are here in front of us this morning; they are ready to roll. Senator Harradine has suggested a way of cutting the Gordian knot, which seems to scare off many of those who have spoken.

Having watched the unsubstantiated procrastination of Minister Simmons, I cannot see how time can be given as an excuse. I cannot see that complexity can be given as an excuse, because Senator Sowada has delivered the means of undoing the complexities. It is here in front of us. I do not see any excuse for not accepting the Senate system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer briefly to the issue of lack of time in terms that it is too late in the day. It seems to me that governments, from both sides, have a habit of enacting electoral legislation, or amendments to electoral legislation, very late in the piece. I recall that in 1988 the Labor Party in New South Wales, under Premier Unsworth, enacted some very major changes to the State electoral laws. The State Electoral Office was in a flap about it because it had no idea that the changes were forthcoming. The Unsworth Government made it very difficult for the Electoral Office.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have given plenty of notice of these amendments. We believe that the Australian Electoral Commission is in a position to very simply and very easily change the voting system to be in place for the next ACT election. In fact, we have given notice at past hearings of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, in correspondence and so forth that the AEC is ready and prepared to accept this move if it is passed by the Parliament. It is certainly not the case that it is too late: the mechanism is there; it is ready and waiting. It requires only the political will of senators in this place to do what has been requested of us by the ACT Legislative Assembly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear that the Government will not be supporting the amendments moved by Senator Sowada. The chamber made its decision, I take it, by the amendments made to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act in the autumn session earlier this year. The chamber determined that a referendum ought to be held on the same day as the polling day for the next ACT election. That has already been determined by the Parliament; I think we ought to adhere to that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Sowada's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not understand the Minister's response concerning the commencement date of the legislation and why it was not possible to have the commencement date for the whole of the Act the day on which it receives royal assent. If that were the case, then we would not be imposing anything on the ACT. We would not continue to be imposing the modified d'Hondt system onto the ACT, we would throw all of this responsibility onto the ACT Assembly as of now. It could decide for itself whether or not it chooses to have the Senate system for the election in 1992. That would not prevent the referendum from taking place on that particular day, but it would prevent the shemozzle that took place on the last occasion when the modified d'Hondt system was introduced. I seek leave to move two amendments together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 2, page 1, subclause (1), line 7, omit "Subject to subsection (2),".
Clause 2, page 1, subclause (2), lines 9 to 11, omit the subclause.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of that passing this chamber would be to have the Act commence on the day it receives the royal assent.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pointing out that a political arrangement had been arrived at in late autumn whereby this Parliament determined that on the day of the poll to be held for the second election of the Legislative Assembly a referendum would also be held. The arrangement which Senator Harradine is putting forward would have the effect of vesting power in the ACT Assembly to determine an electoral method without the benefit of the referendum results. Clearly, it was envisaged that the referendum precede a vote by the Assembly on the electoral system which should apply in the Australian Capital Territory.

PARA.TAB: I am further advised, as a matter of the consequential effects of the proposal that Senator Harradine is putting forward, that as soon as the ACT Assembly enacts an electoral law the Australian Electoral Commission loses the power to run ACT elections. Therefore, if the proposal were adopted, the ACT would have to set up an electoral law and an electoral administration in eight weeks. That is why I was trying to relate my perhaps general remarks about democracy and so on to the actual timetable we are facing.

What might have been possible in autumn is not feasible on 12 December when we are discussing in this chamber matters which were put in train with a view to holding the election on 15 February. So it is a matter of various principles and the timetable and chronology which led me to say that the Government would not be supporting this proposal. That is quite apart from the chaos that would occur in the ACT if the Legislative Assembly at this stage, the eve of Christmas, were asked to sit and devise an electoral system that ought to apply to the election on 15 February. It is a burden that should not be placed on that Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —There really is a heck of a lot of nonsense attached to the excuses given for not seriously considering what Senator Harradine has proposed. The ACT legislature does not have to sit again. A unanimous resolution has been presented to the Government. There is no need for the ACT legislature to go through a confusing spectacle so close to Christmas, as the Minister suggested. It has been done; it is plain; it is unanimous.

PARA.TAB: The suggestion that the ACT would have to set up an electoral system, an electoral law, without the benefit of the referendum is also nonsense, because that is precisely what we are imposing upon the ACT electorate now. The people have said resoundingly that they do not want it. We are imposing upon the ACT electorate a system which has been discredited, dishonoured, dismissed and is not required by the ACT electorate. Here we are shying away from the opportunity to deliver to that electorate this system which is admired, respected and with which they are familiar.

As has been observed already and confirmed by the answers I have been given, the people of the ACT are being required to go through the processes of a referendum without a requirement that their elected government implement the results of that referendum. So if we are going to talk about useless exercises, let us look at that and recognise what it is. What is being proposed by Senator Harradine is something with which the ACT elector can identify, something that has been requested, something with which they are familiar, and something which does not have the resounding objection that d'Hondt has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I voice my support for Senator Harradine's amendment and I endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Bell. As I understand Senator Harradine's amendment, it suggests that the ACT Assembly be granted the power to make its own electoral laws before the election takes place so that it can make up its own mind what kind of electoral system it would like to have for that election and so that it can enact the resolution that it has placed before us in its letter of 2 December.

PARA.TAB: To that extent, if that is what the ACT Assembly wants, we should have the guts to give it that power to do what it sees is in the best interests of its own electorate. As Senator Bell suggested, we are imposing a discredited system on the ACT electorate. It is a system that is not wanted by the ACT electorate and it delivers a very distorted election result. We should at least give it the opportunity, as it has requested in its letter, to determine the method by which members of the Assembly are chosen. The amendments are here. It can simply take the amendments which have been drafted for us tonight and have them inserted into its own electoral legislation for the purposes of the next election.

The Australian Electoral Commission knows how to run a Senate election. This is not something new to it. It can simply take the system that it uses at every Federal election and use it for this election. It is not something that would take a great deal of time to implement.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague has said, it is not a new system that would have to be explained or one that requires complex amendment. With those words, I simply add our voice of support to Senator Harradine's amendment and urge the Committee to do likewise.

—Very briefly, we will not support this amendment. The reason why we will not support it was spelt out very clearly during the second reading debate. I will just touch on one matter. A couple of months ago we passed a Bill in this place which amended the ACT electoral system. It followed many of the recommendations of the Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which was chaired by my colleague Dr Michael Wooldridge. Many of the recommendations were taken up and included in that Bill. That was the opportunity for the Australian Democrats to propose that an entirely separate system be introduced—a system that will last one election. That has been repeated over and over again by honourable senators in this place.

PARA.TAB: Let me say—and I exclude Senator Sowada from this criticism—that the Democrats are taking the moral high ground. Just a week ago they sank themselves in the eyes of their own constituency by sacrificing democracy. They come into this place and talk about democracy tonight, but they would sacrifice democracy and freedom of expression on the altar of self-interest. They sold themselves out. They put their hands in the pockets of the taxpayer and in the pockets of the television stations. Everyone in Australia knows that they did it. They come in here and take the moral high ground. They should be ashamed of themselves. They are a bunch of hypocrites and we will not have a bar of it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to make a few points. Firstly, we have to make very clear the background to this so-called Legislative Assembly resolution and how it was arrived at. I am advised that when the motion was moved in the Legislative Assembly, the Deputy Chief Minister, Mr Berry, of the Australian Labor Party, immediately moved for the replacement of the words `Senate system' by the words `single member electorate system'. That motion—
—It didn't get up.

—Senator Bell did not tell us that. He has given the impression that this was a unanimous resolution and he has tried to mislead the Committee in that regard, which is typical of the way he has operated tonight. I refer to you, Mr Chairman, rather than be distracted by Senator Bell and his misleading of the Committee. That motion was defeated and the original motion was carried on the voices. That is the background. It is not as though the Democrats are able to present to this chamber a unanimous resolution of the Legislative Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory, and that is the impression they have tried to give to this Committee.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Sowada obviously was not listening to me when I said that, under this legislation, if the Legislative Assembly of the ACT passes an electoral law, then under other provisions, the Australian Electoral Commission loses all power and cannot be vested with the power to conduct the election.

Senator Sowada went on about the way in which the Australian Electoral Commission, being conversant with the Senate system, would be able to conduct the election in the ACT by 15 February. It cannot be given that power. The ACT Legislative Assembly would have to constitute its own electoral commission. Senator Sowada does not know what she is talking about in this respect. It would create absolute chaos if Senator Harradine's amendment were carried. For that reason, I believe the Committee should reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment does not rest on Senator Tate's perception of what may or may not have been said in the debate about the—
—I wasn't referring to you; I was referring to them.

—My amendment does not rely on Senator Tate's perception of what may or may not have been said relating to the House of Assembly resolution. This backs up what the Minister was saying before, and that is that yesterday was an historic day—the High Court upheld the legitimacy of the transfer of powers to the ACT Assembly. All I am saying is that, if that is the case, let us celebrate the day and provide the ACT Assembly with its full rights as from now. Those rights would include the determination of the type of system that is best suited to the Territory for the 1992 election. It does not prevent the referendum proceeding. In fact, that referendum has to proceed.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, as to the Australian Electoral Commission not being able to conduct this election if this amendment were adopted, I would like to hear from the Minister why he makes that statement. I would like to hear from the Minister why the Legislative Assembly of the ACT could not construct a Bill and enact legislation which would request the Australian Electoral Commission to be the electoral authority for the purposes of the ACT legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have advice from officials that what I have suggested to be the case is, indeed, the case. Apparently it comes from clause 14 of the Bill, which has the effect that an enactment of the Australian Capital Territory cannot confer functions and powers on the Australian Electoral Commission. If that is linked to clause 8, new section 67A, I am told it has the effect that once the House of Assembly enacts an electoral law, the Australian Electoral Commission cannot be vested with the power to conduct subsequent elections.
—That could be overcome by an amendment to the Electoral Act. The answer is yes, is it?
—One can do anything in this Parliament. Senator Harradine knows that.

—I thank the Minister. Otherwise we are wasting our time on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters because at present we have a reference as to cooperation between the State and Federal electoral authorities. I am proceeding with this proposal because that would simply be a consequential amendment to the Electoral Act.

—I thank the Minister for his response to Senator Harradine's question. I accept that there are possibly some legislative difficulties that have to be overcome in order to enact Senator Harradine's amendment. I respond to Senator Tate's assertion that I misled the House. I did not mislead the House. I simply refer him to the text of my speech at the second reading stage wherein I said that the ACT Legislative Assembly, without dissent, resolved to request us to make the very change we are now debating.

PARA.TAB: I was aware that the Labor members had moved to have the motion amended to replace the words `Senate electoral system' with the words `single member electorates' and that that motion failed. If the Labor members of the ACT Assembly were so unhappy with this motion, they should have called a division and a vote should have been taken. That did not happen and the motion was carried without dissent. I take great exception to the assertion by Senator Tate that I misled the House. I did not mislead the House. I simply suggest to him that he should go back to his Labor colleagues in the ACT Assembly and ask them, if they objected to this motion so strongly, why they did not call a division and thereby show this Parliament that the motion did not have the full support of the ACT Assembly.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal very briefly with some matters that, unfortunately, I did not get the opportunity to deal with last night. They relate to the collapse of the Estate Mortgage property trusts and, in particular, to the practices of the trust managers and the oversight of those trust arrangements by the National Companies and Securities Commission.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to intervene on Senator O'Chee.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Senator O'Chee is proposing to talk about the summary interim report of the Australian Securities Commission on certain matters to do with Estate Mortgage. The reason why it is called a summary interim report is that it was vetted by the DPP to ensure that there be no prejudice to any forthcoming legal proceedings—presumably criminal in this case, but there will be civil proceedings also, no doubt. I just ask Senator O'Chee to be exceedingly careful that he does not speculate beyond what is contained in that report and presented to the Parliament. If he does, he may unwittingly prejudice either a criminal trial or perhaps a civil proceeding—I do not see quite how one could prejudice a civil proceeding, although I suppose it might affect the mind of a judge.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator O'Chee ought to be somewhat careful because, quite clearly, not only will the question of the trustees but also of the regulatory authorities at the time be the subject of the further full report which is foreshadowed. The interim report is called an interim report because it was thought that those who were meeting today as unit holders to determine the restructuring of the six trusts ought to have as much information as was prudently able to be put before them. I just put in that cautioning note to Senator O'Chee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Minister Tate for that. I assure him that that will not occur, but there are a couple of matters of detail that relate to these matters that need to be discussed.

PARA.TAB: One of the areas that are indicated in the summary interim report is the possibility that the trustees committed a breach of trust in executing supplemental trust deeds in relation to the six trusts, subsequently disposing of mortgage securities previously held by the trust and providing to assignees priority ahead of the interests of the trust. The question has been raised during this day as to how this had the effect of diluting the asset backing of the trust. I shall take only two examples to show how this was done.

The first relates to a company called Janmont Pty Ltd. Janmont Pty Ltd. owns the old Myer building on Queen Street Mall in Brisbane. I understand that, after the execution of the supplemental trust deeds amending the original trust deeds, Mercantile Mutual Insurance received a priority over the trust in respect of $25m loaned against the property. As at 30 June 1991 the trusts were owed $54.5m in principal and interest and MMI was owed $32.5m in principal and interest. I make these comments because they are derived from material provided by the fund managers or trustees and, therefore, are based on documents that are already on the public record.

Another example is a company called Ozton Pty Ltd, which holds a number of properties in Sydney. These include 20-22 O'Connell Street and corner Bligh and Hunter Streets, over which the trusts have mortgages. After the amendment of the trust deeds it is believed that Hongkong Bank received the benefit of first ranking charges, securing $40m owed to it. This pushed the trusts into second place. The current trustees expect to write off the total amount owing to them on these properties.
In relation to the overall position of the trusts, the effect was that, in total, as much as $209m of assets may have been given away

SPEECH.PARA: through these deals. This figure is disclosed in material prepared by the new trustees which shows the trusts will receive only $349.9m from the sale of assets, whereas the trust could look forward to recovering $558.4m if the priority interests had not been granted to the banks and other institutions.

PARA.TAB: As far as I can see, the effect of these transactions was to diddle, wittingly or otherwise, the trusts by giving certain banks and financial institutions first go at the trusts' assets. There was no way the trusts could stay afloat by diluting the value of the assets they held, and it was foolish to think otherwise. Obviously, it is a reflection not just upon the trustee company but also upon the oversight of the National Companies and Securities Commission in approving the supplemental trust deeds that made this possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have all the 39 recommendations made by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report on Visits to Australia by Nuclear Powered or Armed Vessels, tabled in 1989, been implemented; if not, which ones have not been implemented, and why not.
(2) Has the document recommended in paragraph 9.21 (p.283), been published and made available to the general public; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) All significant actions foreshadowed in the Government's response to the Senate report tabled in the Senate on 13 December 1989 (Senate Hansard p.4397) have been completed, allowing visits by nuclear powered warships to continue.

Other minor matters, some of which involve actions in conjunction with State and Territory Governments, and which do not effect planned visits, are being progressed by the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) (VSP(N)).

The VSP(N) is a Commonwealth Government Interdepartmental Standing Committee with responsibilities for developing and maintaining procedures related to nuclear powered warship visits and overseeing safety arrangements for visits by nuclear powered or weapon capable warships.

In all recommendations requiring actions by or in conjunction with State and Territory Governments, the VSP(N) has established the necessary working level contacts. I am informed that all outstanding actions are scheduled for completion in the first half of 1992.

The Royal Australian Navy now has commissioned two Auxiliary Minesweeper (Tugs), AT(M) WALLAROO and BANDICOOT. These vessels act as nuclear safety vessels during visits to East Coast ports by nuclear powered submarines. Both vessels were recently in Brisbane for the visit of USS PASADENA 4-9 December.

The Nuclear Safety Bureau of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology organisation, a member of the VSP(N), is continuing its examination of the options, feasibility and necessity for early warning radiation monitoring of nuclear powered warships (Recommendation 8). Until this examination is completed existing arrangements requiring the Royal Australian Navy to provide a vessel to monitor continuously nuclear powered warships at anchor will be retained.

I have recently written to the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, informing him that all actions in relation to recommendations 37 (Drydocking) and 38 (Nuclear Weapon Accidents) have now been completed. This letter was tabled in the Senate on 28 November 1991 (Senate Hansard p.3647).

OPSMAN 1, the Operational Manual for nuclear powered warship visits is in the process of revision to include all changes resulting from the Senate enquiry. Edition 3 is to be published in the New Year and will be forwarded to all public libraries who hold copies of Edition 2 already provided in accordance with recommendation 7.

(2) Recommendation 10 does not require the Government to, in Senator Vallentine's words, "...publish and made available to the general public" a document. However such a document '..suitable for incorporation in, or attachment to, individual port safety plans' (para 9.21) has been produced and distributed to all State and Territory Nuclear Powered Warship Visits Committees.

The Tasmanian Government's port safety plan for Hobart (released 1 September 1991) includes this document in full on pages 46-61, while the Queensland Government's new port safety plan for Brisbane uses a large section on pages 25-31.
